PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 420 citizens), Senator Kemp (from 180 citizens), Senator Ian Macdonald (from 705 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 199 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from three citizens) and Senator Knowles (from 130 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PARA.TAB: The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase wholesale sales tax on wine by more than 50%, from 20% to 31%,

PETITION.PARA: discriminates against the wine industry compared with other beverages;
discriminates against South Australia, which produces 70% of Australia's wine;
threatens the continuing existence of 150 smaller wineries and 500 related jobs;
destroys the capacity for a further $500 million, job-creating investment in the wine industry;
will result in lower grape prices for grapegrowers already burdened by the rural recession;
will severely damage the domestic market base for Australian wine which is so essential to its continuing export growth;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the increase in wholesale sales tax on wine.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Chapman (from 7,704 citizens) and Senator Vanstone (from 22 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: 1.At least $500 million in investment in the wine industry is threatened by this proposal.
2.The implementation of this proposal could force more than 500 grape growers from the industry and threaten the jobs of hundreds of employees in wineries and other associated industries.
3.The proposed tax increases will accentuate the current decline in domestic wine sales.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the scheduled fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bolkus (from 65 citizens) and Senator Harradine (from 91 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Agricultural Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned petitioners, respectfully request that the Australian Government place a levy on the sale, in proportion to the toxicity of the chemicals, on the basis of polluter pays, in accordance with *E.S.D. Principles. Such levy to be used for the purpose of encouraging the implementation of education, training and development of low toxic/chemical-free agricultural production.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Army Band
PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that the Regular Army Band based in Adelaide is

PARA.TAB: 1.an integral part of South Australian community life
2.a valuable contributor to nearly 250 charitable, civic and military functions per year
3.important to the morale and identity of Defence Force personnel
4.not adequately replaceable by a Reserve Force band

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

PARA.TAB: 1.condemn the Keating Labor Government's decision to abolish the band
2.call on the Minister for Defence to retain the Regular Army Band in Adelaide

PETITION.PARA: and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution—"Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God. . .
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
(1)The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem—"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2)The adoption of a Christian National Motto—"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3)The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
(4)The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
(5)The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
(6)The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
(7)Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that

(1) One of the most critical issues to the Vietnamese people today is the persecution of their freedom of religion and expression, which has been carried out by the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) since 1945. World media reports have shown consistently that this persecution has increased greatly since 1992, when Buddhists, despite violent repression by the GOSRV's armed forces, started asking for `real' freedom of religion.

(2) The continuation of the GOSRV's centralised and corrupt structure, as well it's failed and disorderly `economic renovation' and it's declared loyalty to the atheistic socialism, has seriously degraded the moral, cultural, family, economic and spiritual life of most Vietnamese people.

(3) The GOSRV's policy of oppressing religions has, since 1945, applied equally to Catholics, Protestants, Caodaists, Hoa Hao Buddhist members and, most seriously to the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist Church (UBCV) which represents the faith and spiritual life of 80% of 72 million Vietnamese.

(4) As the rightful heir of the 2000-year old Buddhist tradition in Vietnam, the UBCV was formally formed in 1951 by all Buddhist sects, lineages and regional congregations. It is the sole legitimate umbrella Buddhist body in Vietnam despite the GOSRV's unsuccessful attempt, in 1981, to disband and forcibly replace it with the State-run Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), and instrument for the GOSRV's propaganda purposes.

(5) Despite being held under strict house arrest since February 1982 simply because of his opposition to the GOSRV's attempted disbandment to the UBCV and its formation of the State-controlled VBC, the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang, a nominee for 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, has been repeatedly and patiently appealing to leaders of the Communist Party and the GOSRV to ask for:

TAB.TAB: a)the urgent restoration and legal recognition of the UBCV's independent status,
b)the separation of Church and State and the withdrawal of the GOSRV's control over, and politicisation of, the Buddhist church.
c)the release of all arrested clergy, including the Patriarch, along with thousands of other prisoners of conscience,
d)the return of, and compensation for, all confiscated and misused Church properties.
e)open negotiations, free of pre-conditions, between the leaders of the UBCV and the GOSRV to establish mutually agreed solutions to the current conflicts.

PARA.TAB: (6) In replying to these reasonable requests, the GOSRV has, in the last few months, ordered stricter surveillance of the Patriarch's place of confinement and placed bans on all of his external communications. Whoever tries to contact, visit, help or offer gifts to him are stopped, threatened, interrogated, bodily searched (and in some cases strip searched), etc. The Patriarch's straightforward appeals have not only been ignored by the Hanoi leaders, but have also been vilified as `anti-state', `reactionary', `creating division amongst Buddhist community', etc. by the GOSRV's mass media and it's nation-wide agencies, including it's own VBC.

(7) All of the UBCV's brave clergy and lay members who openly declare their support for the UBCV's appeals and who have worked sincerely for the reconciliation between the State and the UBCV, also between the VBC and the UBCV, have been inhumanely and violently attacked by the GOSRV. In the last 12 months, hundred of monks, nuns and lay persons have been arrested and/or tortured, harshly interrogated, searched, investigated and threatened. Amongst them are the Venerables Thich Nhat Lien, Thich Tri Luc and Thich Khong Tanh (Oct—Nov 1992), Thich Thien An (Oct. 1992, tortured to death few days after arrested), Thich Hai Tang, Thich Tri Tuu, Thich Hai Thinh and about 50 lay members (5/6/93), Thich Hanh Duc, 17 other monks and about one hundred of lay followers (9/7/93) etc.

(8) The GOSRV's violent attack and mass media campaign against Buddhists' appeal for Church independent have caused suffering to many thousands of people, resulting in increased instability for the whole country. Despite the GOSRV's current campaign to illogically calumniate them and to deceive the world, these monks and lay Buddhists are arrested, solely because of their aspiration to be involved and support their chosen church, the UBCV.
(9) To politicise the traditional Buddhist community in Vietnam, the GOSRV has publicly been, and is:

TAB.TAB: a) recruiting members for the VBC by forcibly converting the UBCV's moderate clergy to join it, and arresting or exiling other leaders who refuse to do so. (The GOSRV's view of `religious freedom' is not in accord with natural human dignity and heritage, but a rare favour given reluctantly on the terms of the State),
b) forcing the VBC to include, in it's Charter, `Socialism' as it's third aim of service—the other two, which originated from UBCV Charter, are People and Buddhism,

c) creating mutual distrust and conflicts between the lay Buddhist community and their clergy or amongst the clergy themselves by appointing VBC senior leaders to artificial political positions, and by closely controlling and intervening in the limited activities it is permitted to perform training programs such as ordination procedures, seniority promotions, etc.
d) requiring the VBC to make frequent political statements supporting the GOSRV's inconsistent policies, with the consequence of eroding the VBC's religious identity.

e) directing the VBC to start a nation-wide campaign accusing the UBCV of having political ambitions, and forcing it to declare the VBC as the `only legitimate Buddhist authority' and its `everlasting loyalty' to the GOSRV. This is whilst the GOSRV is facing huge pressure and condemnation from the international community about it's oppressive attitude to the Buddhists and it's systematic violation to all human rights of all non-party-cadre citizens in the country.

PARA.TAB: (10). The GOSRV's exclusively economic renovation has not, and can not, lead to democratisation or potentials which will allow long-overdue human rights to it's citizens, such as freedom to select their own political aspirations, ways of expressions, religions, education, employment, place of resident, etc. The greater it's economic strength, the more determined and confident the GOSRV is in it's opposition to such a democratisation process and the worse it's treatment of it's citizens becomes. This causes ever greater social instability and a sense of total hopelessness for Vietnam's future, and more broadly, prevents the development of stability in the SE Asia region as a whole.

(11). As it's history has proved, if the UBCV is completely free and independent of political intervention, it would be a most beneficial part of, and the best spiritual force to contribute to, a humanitarian and ethically orientated redevelopment process for Vietnam.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate requests the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: 1. make conditional the release of currently approved financial assistance, and any future aid, to the GOSRV, on it's granting of all internationally accepted human and civil rights to it's people, without discrimination. This must be demonstrated by the GOSRV through it's complete cessation of persecution, in any form, of all religious organisations, particularly the UBCV.
2. urge the GOSRV to cease all ill-treatment of the UBCV, and to achieve a mutually acceptable resolution, by means of fair negotiation, of all appeals made by the UBCV's Patriarch;
3. make clear statements requesting the GOSRV:

TAB.TAB: (a) not to conduct in any further suppression of those who non-violently demonstrate their beliefs and involvement with their chosen religious organisations;

(b) immediately release all who are under arrest, with or without trials, because of their religious beliefs, including the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang and other clergy; the GOSRV should also cease their unreasonable political accusations directed towards the UBCV leaders concerning their appeals and commitment to religious freedom and the Church's independent status;

(c) completely withdraw it's politicisation of religion obstinate and it's gross intervention in the internal affairs of religious bodies such as supporting the VBC whilst inhumanely oppressing the UBCV or by using the official mass media to create staged scenes dishonouring and defaming holders of religious authorities.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our opposition to specific changes proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and associated subordinate legislation in the 1993-94 Federal Budget introduced by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on Tuesday 17 August 1993.
Specifically, we the undersigned oppose:
(i)proposed measures whereby students taking more than an extra semester to complete their first undergraduate degree accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 1.5%;
(ii)proposed measures whereby students enrolling in second undergraduate degrees accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 2; and
(iii)proposed measures whereby the rates of prepayment increase from 2, 3 and 4 per cent of taxable income up to 3, 4 and 5 per cent for the three thresholds respectively.
We strongly urge the Senate to reject these measures.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 335 citizens), Senator Coulter (from 220 citizens) and Senator Woodley (from 176 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin the repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: Rejection of Increase in Leaded Petrol Tax

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announced by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 10 cents per litre.

PETITION.PARA: is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against poorer people and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;
is therefore counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject this increase in fuel excise and that the Senate will urge the Government to take initiatives to reduce the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia, thereby making new cars cheaper to buy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Chapman (from 16,302 citizens) and Senator Hill (from 946 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that tobacco taxes have been raised 12 times by the various Australian Governments in the past 12 months, and that further projected increases in Federal excise will severely affect the jobs and the standard of living of Australian Tobacco Workers.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Restore the amount of excise on tobacco to the levels announced in the Budget on August 17, 1993.

I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances with these regulations related to review of decisions made by administrators, about which the committee wrote twice to the minister. I am pleased to report that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, the Hon. Ross Free, has now advised that the Abstudy scheme will be brought under an act and regulations. PARA.TAB: As usual, I seek leave to incorporate the committee's correspondence in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 7 April 1993
The Hon Kim Beazley, MP
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement Regulations, Statutory Rules 1992 No.454, considered by the Committee at is meeting of 6 April 1993.

The regulations provide for the payment of AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY Supplement allowances. Regulation 14 provides that where an application has been lodged late and the student has taken `all reasonable steps' and has been `prevented from lodging the application. . . because of circumstances beyond his or her control' the lateness, in effect, will be overlooked. There is no indication of who will make these decisions or whether there is independent review of the merits of an unfavourable decision.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Stephen Loosley
Chairman
22 June 1993
Mr David Creed
Secretary
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Creed

On 7 April 1993 the Hon Stephen Loosley wrote to my colleague the Hon Kim Beazley MP about the AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY Supplement Regulations. Senator Loosley's letter has been referred to me as Minister responsible for AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY.
Senator Loosley expressed concern about decision and review procedures under Regulation 14 of the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement Regulations.

As you may be aware, under Sections 20-24 of the Student Assistance Act 1973, if a student considers that application of the AUSTUDY rules may have been incorrect he or she can ask that a more senior officer consider the Department's decision. If the student still disagrees he or she may ask for a review of the matter by the Student Assistance Review Tribunal. Although the Tribunal is an independent body there is a requirement, as there is for the Minister and the Department, that it reach decisions within the framework of the student assistance legislation.

Under ABSTUDY policy if a student is unhappy with a decision made in respect of his or her application for assistance then he or she may ask for a review of that decision by a more senior officer. If unhappy with the senior officer's decision the student may appeal to the Minister.
The same provisions have been extended to students who are unhappy with a decision made under the regulations relating to the AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY Supplement.
Yours sincerely
Ross Free
19 August 1993
The Hon Ross Free, MP
Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to your letter of 22 June 1993 on aspects raised by the Committee of the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement Regulations, Statutory Rules 1992 No.454. The letter was considered by the Committee at its meeting of 19 August 1993.

Your letter contained useful advice. However, the Committee would be grateful for further information about broader aspects of both the Austudy and Abstudy schemes, including the supplements. The Committee wishes to know the details of discretions, if any, which may be exercised by the Minister under both schemes. In this context we note from the second last paragraph of your letter that there is discretion exercisable by the Minister under the Abstudy scheme.
Yours sincerely
Stephen Loosley
Chairman
8 September 1993
Mr David Creed
Secretary
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Creed

I refer to Senator Stephen Loosley's letter of 19 August 193 to the Hon Kim Beazley MP regarding the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement Regulations. Senator Loosley's letter has been referred to me as Minister responsible for the AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY schemes.

Senator Loosley asked for further information about broader aspects of both the AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY schemes, including the Supplement. General comments about the schemes, with particular reference to review mechanisms, are given below. Reference is also made to explanatory material that may be of assistance (copies are enclosed).
AUSTUDY schemes

The AUSTUDY scheme is set up under the Student Assistance Act 1973. More detailed provisions relating to who can get AUSTUDY and how much AUSTUDY is payable are contained in the AUSTUDY Regulations. General information about AUSTUDY is contained in:
the Report on the Operation of the Student Assistance Act 1992;
and the booklet AUSTUDY Guide `93: A Guide to Student Finance.
Part 5 of the Act provides for the review of decisions:
at first instance, by a more senior within the Department;
if the student is still dissatisfied, by the Student Assistance Tribunal; and
if the student is still dissatisfied, by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court.
ABSTUDY scheme

The ABSTUDY scheme does not have a statutory basis. The authority for the scheme stems from a Cabinet decision and the annual approval by the Minister of guidelines. The guidelines set out the procedures and policy of the scheme. More information about ABSTUDY is contained in:
the 1993 ABSTUDY Policy Guidelines Manual; and
the booklet ABSTUDY 1993: Money to Study.
ABSTUDY decisions are reviewable:
at first instance, by a more senior officer than the officer who made the decision;
if the person is still dissatisfied by the decision, by the Minister.

It is proposed that legislation be made for the ABSTUDY scheme during 1995. It is proposed to amend the Act in the Autumn Sittings in 1994 to authorise regulations to be made for ABSTUDY. ABSTUDY decisions would then be reviewable in exactly the same way as AUSTUDY decisions.
AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement

The AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement came into effect on 1 January 1993. The provisions relating to the Supplement are contained in Part 4A of the Act. The Supplement is a loan provided to students through the private sector under agreement with the Commonwealth Government. More information about the Supplement is contained in:
the Report on the Operation of the Act 1992 (a concise outline of the Supplement is given at p.2);and
the Supplement 1993 Information Booklet: More Money to Study.
Decisions in relation to the Supplement are reviewable:
if the student qualified on the basis of his or her (actual or hypothetical) entitlement to AUSTUDY—in the same way as other AUSTUDY decisions; and
if the student qualified on the basis of his or her entitlement (actual or hypothetical) to ABSTUDY—in the same way as other ABSTUDY decisions.
Ministerial discretions

Senator Loosely also asked for details of discretions which may be exercised by the Minister. In relation to the AUSTUDY scheme, the Minister is given the following discretions under the Student Assistance Act:
to appoint prescribed officers for the purposes of the Act (section 4);
to make a determination as to the courses of study in respect of which benefits are payable (section 7);
to enter into an agreement with a financial corporation for the payment by the corporation of financial supplement to students (subsection 12D(1));

to appoint and terminate the appointment of members of the Student Assistance Review Tribunal (sections 15 and 17) and to appoint a member of the Tribunal who is not a Convenor to act as a Convenor (section 19);
to determine that late payment interest is not to be payable in relation to particular periods (subsection 41(1)). Note that this discretion is also given to prescribed officers;

to make a determination as to the guidelines to be complied with by the Minister or other persons in the exercise of powers under Part 6 of the Act (which relates to the recovery of overpayments) (section 44); and

to delegate all or any of the Minister's powers under section 41 (to determine that late payment interest is not payable) or subsection 43(2) (to write off debts) to the Secretary or a Senior Executive Service officer (section 53).
The Minister is not given any discretions under the AUSTUDY Regulations.

In relation to the ABSTUDY scheme, in a general sense the whole scheme (apart from matters relating to the recovery of overpayments) is subject to the Minister's discretion. The Minister may at any time make changes to ABSTUDY policy to remove anomalies or accommodate new circumstances. More specifically, under the Policy Guidelines, the Minister has the discretion to review decisions .

Part 6 of the Student Assistance Act relates to the recovery of overpayments for ABSTUDY in addition to AUSTUDY. Accordingly, the discretions given to the Minister in relation to Part 6 outlined above are also relevant to the ABSTUDY Scheme. These powers are,briefly:
to make a determination as to the guidelines for .he recovery of overpayments; and
to delegate the Minister's powers under section 41 to the Secretary or an SES officer.

I trust that this information is of assistance. If you would like to arrange a meeting to discuss this matter further, please contact Ms Ruth Doobov, Assistant Secretary, Student Assistance Support Branch, on ph. 276 8217.
Yours sincerely
Ross Free

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation on the Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1993 and six related superannuation bills as referred to the committee by the third report of the Selection of Bills Committee be extended to on or before the last sitting day in October 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice I have just given.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee has a long-standing reference to inquire into legislation to implement the recommendations of its first report entitled Safeguarding Super. In essence the package of superannuation bills before the Senate embodies the much needed reform to the prudential control and supervision of superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: In accordance with its terms of reference and in anticipation of the introduction of these bills in the Senate, the committee has already conducted hearings in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, taking evidence from 60 witnesses. The committee has found the legislation to be both far reaching and complex. It is with this point in mind that a detailed and well argued report will need to be prepared and placed before the Senate. Also the committee is working closely with the ISC.Accordingly, I seek the agreement of honourable senators for the report on these superannuation bills to be tabled on or before the last day of sitting in October.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that a protest action is currently taking place in the Coolangubra State Forest against the logging of this important old-growth forest;
(b)applauds this and a similar protest action that will take place on the weekend of 2 and 3 October 1993 at the Hawke Block in the Karri forests in south-west Western Australia; and
(c)condemns:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Tasmanian Government's plans for major new logging roads and clearfelling in the south-west and Great Western Tiers areas of Tasmania, which have been recommended to be listed as World Heritage areas by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, the Australian Heritage Commission and the State Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage, and

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the law relating to export market development grants.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this bill amends the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 to implement the amendment announced by the government on 24 June 1992 to exclude from eligibility claimants with criminal convictions under the corporations law or in respect of serious fraud, and certain claimants under schemes of arrangement. The bill provides also for firms to claim half yearly in the early stages of overseas marketing, and makes a number of `technical' amendments which protect the scheme's integrity and administrative efficiency.

The payment of grants to persons with criminal convictions under the corporations law or in respect of serious fraud is currently possible under the scheme. It is considered that the integrity of the scheme is at risk where it allows convicted persons access to public funds. The bill does not prevent persons with minor convictions from obtaining grants, only those who have been convicted of more serious offences under the corporations law, or in respect of fraud. For example, a company director who failed to lodge a company return by the appointed time, is not excluded from the scheme. Whilst a criminal offence, this conviction, in isolation, does not assault the scheme;s integrity in any serious way, and this display of flexibility is seen as preserving the underlying open access nature of the scheme.

Further, it is considered that payment of grants to business operations with very low viability, and consequently low probability to any future benefit from export promotional expenditure, is not within the spirit of the scheme's intent. Although on occasions an insolvent claimant may eventually trade on to become a viable operation, this generally is not the case, and the legal and practical difficulties associated with assessing potential viability are considerable. Also, the scheme is essentially open access and does not attempt to determine this viability on the basis of value judgments.

Mr President, half yearly claims lodgement is seen as a very practical method of assisting exporters' cash flow in the early stages of overseas market development. The scheme has operated very successfully for nineteen years, with the only significant criticism being the delay between incurring expenditure by the exporter, and the payment of the grant. This bill provides for earlier payment of grants based on the provision to lodge half yearly claims in respect of exporters' first three full grant years.

A great strength of the scheme is the freedom it affords exporters to make judgements as to the activities they wish to pursue, and the markets they wish to target. This premise, and the need for containment of administrative cost, means that some delay in payment is inevitable. Half yearly claims lodgement, however, provides the framework which could double the frequency of payments without altering the essential parameters of the scheme.

This bill implements also a number of `technical' amendments to the act. These amendments are essentially administrative and are required to clarify the established intention of the legislation, or assist with the tightening of ongoing risk management.
I commend this bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 1 December 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: A preliminary examination of all aspects of the validation of Care Aggregated Module (CAM) and Standard Aggregated Module (SAM) funding of nursing homes by the Commonwealth, in particular:

TAB.TAB: the timeliness of validations;

SPEECH.PARA: the consistency of decisions made by Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services validation teams;
miscalculations of negative loadings made by validation teams;
the retrospective application of reinterpretations and redefinitions of the financial principles;
the impact of validations on the continued financial viability of nursing homes; and
new proprietors being made financially liable for CAM and SAM funding spent prior to their purchase of a nursing home,
and to ascertain whether a further inquiry is warranted.

The motion before the Senate seeks to have an inquiry conducted by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs into the validation of the care aggregated module, CAM, and the standard aggregated module, SAM, funding.

PARA.TAB: The validation of nursing home expenditure by the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services appears to have considerable problems and has been criticised by all sectors of the nursing home industry. It is also currently the subject of an official inquiry by the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office.

The concerns that have been expressed by proprietors of nursing homes and their industry representatives about the conduct of validations are many and varied. Some of the more commonly expressed concerns include: the department validating nursing and personal care expenditure from before the commencement of the new CAM-SAM system in 1987; the purchasers of new nursing homes not being informed about negative loadings that are pending on nursing homes when they have inquired with the department; widely differing interpretations between departmental officers as to what constitutes nursing and personal care expenditure; the issuing of departmental circulars that amend the definition of nursing and personal care, and then applying these new interpretations retrospectively; significant miscalculations of negative loadings by validation teams; excessive tardiness by the department in validating nursing homes that are changing hands; excessively onerous requests by departmental officers for records and proof of expenditure from many years earlier, including when the home was under different ownership;the fact that undue discretion is given to individual validators in the validators handbook; totally unrealistic interpretations of the everyday duties of DONs, including whether it is a nursing duty or not to take linen from a linen cupboard down to a resident's room, or to take a resident's nightdress from the bed to the laundry, instances of which, I feel, really need to be looked at;the validation guidelines ignoring the fact that tax has already been paid on the money that is being recouped; and, possibly most disturbingly, the Australian Federal Police entering nursing homes for what would sometimes appear to be no apparent valid reason.

To give the Senate an idea of the department's tardiness in validating nursing and personal care expenditure, the new funding arrangements to which the validations supposedly apply commenced in 1987. The department now believes that it will be able to complete validating the first year's operation of the new funding arrangements by mid-1994. Certainly, I do not know of any serious business that would consider it appropriate to audit its books up to seven years after the money has been spent. But departmental officers will spend weeks, sometimes months, sifting through nursing home records, using nursing home resources at the same time, often to find a single, relatively minuscule record from up to six years previously.

It must be recognised that the federal government has estimated that it will realise some $96 million from these validations. As there are about 1,200 nursing homes being validated, this amounts to an average of $80,000 in negative loadings per home. At a time when nursing home margins have been significantly reduced as a result of an inflexible funding system and excessive bureaucratic interference and documentation, many proprietors are rightly worried that an inappropriately or unexpectedly harsh assessment by a validation team may send them to the wall.

There are claims that only one nursing home peak body and a small number of nursing homes are concerned about validations. I contend that the size of the savings estimates alone demands that these validations be conducted in a fair and professional manner. The Commonwealth Ombudsman has, I believe, received at least 13 individual complaints relating to validations. This is not an insignificant number of complaints about a single issue. However, it must be remembered that the results of any investigation by the ombudsman are not publicly available and in no way can such an investigation be reasonable considered to be an alternative to a public inquiry.

I want it to be known that the coalition does not for one minute condone the misapplication of government funding by nursing home proprietors. I am the first to recognise that some nursing homes have not spent moneys they have received from the Commonwealth in a way that is in line with the relevant funding principles. The coalition is not questioning the appropriateness of conducting validations of public funding of nursing homes. However, every nursing home proprietor must have an undeniable right to a timely validation that is prospectively applied in accordance with a consistently defined and interpreted set of guidelines by validation teams acting in a professional manner.

From speaking with the investigating officer from the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office, it is apparent that he wishes to question the department about a significant number of matters relating to nursing home validations. From speaking to both the voluntary and the private sectors of the nursing home industry, it is quite obvious that the concerns about the validation process are real and widespread. After reading a significant amount of correspondence between proprietors, their representatives and the department, it is obvious that this issue is in urgent need of a thorough and open public examination for the good of all parties involved.
I urge the Senate to support the motion to send the matter of nursing home validations to the standing committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION LIMITED SALE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited represents another important step in the Government's micro-economic reform program.

The Corporation was formed in 1970 to build and capitalise on the engineering expertise which had been acquired from all over the world during the construction of the Snowy Mountains Scheme. At the same time, the formation of SMEC reduced the need to use foreign consultants in Australia and provided a source of income through the opening of overseas markets for Australian consultants.

On 1 July 1989 the Corporation reached another important milestone when it was converted into a full public company. Since then, SMEC has conducted itself in the same manner as any other private sector company. This has included the benefits of full operational autonomy and also taking on the responsibility for debts and liabilities associated with its operations.

Throughout its distinguished history SMEC has `DONE US PROUD'. It is highly regarded overseas and has built up an enviable reputation for engineering consulting through completing some 1700 projects in 55 countries. It has now grown into a consulting organisation of international standing in civil, electrical and mechanical engineering.

But everything has its time and place and while it once may have been appropriate for the Australian Government to foster the development of engineering consulting skills through ownership of a consultancy company this is now no longer the case.

The rapid development of the Australian consulting engineering industry over the past 25 years and its internationally recognised capability has meant that there is now no reason to maintain SMEC in public ownership.

Although for the first 10 years of operations SMEC enjoyed financial success, in the early 1980's it was severely affected by the downturn in the international engineering consulting industry. After five years of losses SMEC returned to profit in 1987 but its performance was at best still only marginal.

In the year ending 30 June 1992, after significant restructuring and refocussing of its marketing efforts, it turned the corner and returned a pre-tax profit of more than $1 million before abnormals. Because of redundancies and other abnormals, SMEC's consolidated after tax result was a profit of $314,000. In the year ending 30 June 1993 SMEC's consolidated after tax result is expected to improve further to a healthy profit of more than $1 million. On behalf of the Government I wish to extend my congratulations to the Board, management and staff of SMEC for this excellent result.
A pre-sale scoping study undertaken for the Task Force on Asset Sales by Arthur Andersen indicates that SMEC's consultancy business is well placed to continue to prosper and return profits.
As with any service organisation, SMEC's resources are its skilled staff and the recent and future success of the organisation rests with those staff.

The Government has accordingly given first preference to staff to purchase the company. They made it what it is today, they built it up, they returned it to profit and the Government believes that SMEC's staff should be allowed to enjoy the fruits of its success.

It is the Government's intention to sell SMEC to Tinbury Limited, a company formed by SMEC staff specifically for the purpose of purchasing SMEC, provided that Tinbury pays a fair price and demonstrates it has the wherewithal to give SMEC a sustainable and viable future.
The Government is ensuring that a sales agreement with Tinbury addresses issues relevant to the staff of SMEC.
Specifically that:
Tinbury Limited will maintain the headquarters of SMEC in Cooma and not sell SMEC for a period of at least five years, and
all SMEC staff will have a further opportunity to purchase shares in Tinbury Limited before a sale is completed.

Because the staff and key managers of SMEC have a much greater knowledge of the company than the Commonwealth as shareholder, the Government is offering no warranties to Tinbury Limited post-sale except as to matters of corporate structure, ownership, title and the power to transfer them.

The Government as shareholder has no legal liability for SMEC's debts and this position is, of course, unchanged by the sale of the Government's shareholding. Other than in respect of proper payment of pre-sale Australian taxation, there is and will be no Government indemnity to SMEC of any kind post-sale.

However, in recognition of the possible contingent liability in respect of a 1990 incident at the Dartmouth Dam power station, which is noted in SMEC's Annual Report, the Government is providing a limited "Money Back Guarantee" to Tinbury. This means that in the unfortunate event that SMEC were to be forced into liquidation as a result of the Dartmouth litigation, Tinbury would get a refund of the money it had paid up-front to the Commonwealth from Tinbury's share capital or borrowings as part of the sale.

The Bill now before the Senate contains the legislative changes that need to be made to enable the sale of SMEC to be finalised while taking into account a range of possible sale outcomes. This is to cover the possibility that an agreement with Tinbury which is acceptable to the Government does not eventuate or a sale to Tinbury is not completed.
Much of the Bill is concerned with the removal of SMEC from the ambit of Commonwealth legislation so that post-sale SMEC will face the same treatment as any other engineering consulting organisation.

During the period of SMEC's financial downturn it accumulated taxation losses. These losses are of value to a potential purchaser because they could reduce tax paid to the Commonwealth on future SMEC profits. In order to reduce the initial cash cost of purchasing SMEC, should it be sold to staff the Bill contains a provision for the extinguishing of these losses. This means that future SMEC profits for the financial year in which the sale occurs onwards, will be fully taxable as if no past losses had been made. These taxation provisions will be proclaimed only if forming an essential part of the purchase price agreed in a sale contract.

Mr President. The Government's primary aim in the sale of its shares in SMEC is that employees continue to have secure and rewarding jobs and earn foreign exchange for Australia as SMEC increases its international success, particularly in the dynamic Asia Pacific region.

The Government is also committed to the protection up to point of sale of SMEC employees' entitlements which accrued during the period of Government ownership, especially in cases where these entitlements accrued as a result of Commonwealth legislation.

To this end the Bill provides for a number of "saving" provisions in respect of a variety of acts, such as the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act and the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. These provisions are similar to those in the Qantas Sale Act and will ensure that employees of SMEC do not lose the benefits that they will have accrued prior to sale.
Rights under the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act will continue to apply to those employees who commence leave within 12 months of a sale or are on leave at the time of sale.

Regulations will be separately introduced under the Superannuation Act 1976 to ensure that employees of SMEC who are currently members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme do not lose the superannuation benefits that they will have accrued under this scheme prior to the sale.

In general, other rights not conferred by Commonwealth legislation will not be affected by the sale as the Government is selling its shares in SMEC and the SMEC Award with its current conditions will continue post-sale.

As soon as possible after a sales agreement is finalised, a date for sale completion will be set on which SMEC is to be freed from all legislative constraints which apply generally to Commonwealth Business Enterprises.
The Bill also contains a provision exempting the transaction from state and territory taxes as well as other saving and transitional provisions relating to other Commonwealth Acts.

Mr President, this Bill puts in place a sound legislative framework to enable the sale of SMEC to be completed once an acceptable sales agreement has been struck, it will free SMEC from Commonwealth constraints other than those of a normal company and allow SMEC to take charge of its own growth and destiny.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have business of the Senate, disallowance motion, standing in the name of Senator Vanstone and relating to a declaration concerning the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, called on forthwith.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (a)recognises:

TAB.TAB: (i)that everyone is entitled to fundamental rights and freedoms without distinction such as based on race, sex, religion or nationality, and
(ii)that the child by reason of physical and mental immaturity needs special safeguards and care;

PARA.TAB: (b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)on 20 November 1989 the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child (Resolution 44/25),

(ii)on 7 November 1990 the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) advised the Senate that it would be surprising if, when Australia ratified the Convention, a reservation was not made acknowledging the pre-eminent role of the family so that in effect the Articles of the Convention would be interpreted in a way that safeguarded the primary and inalienable rights of parents,
(iii)when, on 17 December 1990, the Government ratified the Convention, it made no such reservation,

(iv)on 22 December 1992 the Attorney-General declared under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 that the Convention is an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purposes of that Act, and
(v)in the circumstances, there has been widespread concern in the community about the potential effect of the Convention on the family in Australia; and

PARA.TAB: (c)disallows the Declaration by the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is similar to a motion dealt with the day before yesterday in relation to a declaration made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) with respect to religious freedoms. As with that matter, this motion relates to a declaration made by the former Attorney-General under section 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, but on this occasion with respect to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The effect of the Attorney's declaration was to bring the rights and freedoms recognised in that UN convention within the definition of human rights for the purposes of that act, often referred to as the HREOC act, that is, the purposes and general functions of the commission with respect to human rights.

PARA.TAB: The very first point I want to make in relation to this matter is that the coalition is not opposed to the convention itself; the coalition has never been opposed to the convention itself. Should there be any doubt about that matter, I invite honourable senators to look at the speech in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) on 21 February 1991, not long after the ratification of that convention by Australia. In that speech it was made perfectly clear that the coalition, were it in government, would have ratified the convention. But—and I suppose there is often a but—it would have done so with reservations to particular articles of the convention so as to make Australia's interpretation of that convention crystal clear. The coalition saw that as being a very important step. It would have ratified the convention, but it would have done so with reservations to make the interpretation of particular articles of the convention crystal clear.

Therefore, in considering this motion, it is important to understand that the coalition is not in fact attacking the convention. What we are doing is questioning its incorporation into the HREOC act in light of the fact that Australia ratified the convention without any of the reservations we would have made had we been in government. They were reservations with respect to its interpretation. A second point that needs to be made is that, in raising this matter and seeking to have the Attorney's declaration disallowed, the coalition is not criticising the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

As to the background of this matter, the origins of the convention can be traced back to the declaration of Geneva on the rights of the child, which was adopted by the League of Nations back in 1924. That was in response to the needs of children after World War I. The declaration contained five principles. They were very general but, nonetheless, concise. For example, one of them was that children should be the first to receive relief in any emergency.

The United Nations adopted its own Declaration on the Rights of the Child in 1959, and that outlines 10 principles to guide parents, governments and voluntary organisations in their treatment of children. These principles include non-discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, sex, language, religion or political opinion; enjoyment of special treatment under the law; entitlement to a name and nationality at birth; enjoyment of social security benefits; provision of education; and protection against neglect, cruelty and exploitation.

In 1979, 20 years later, the United Nations Human Rights Committee commenced drafting a convention to deal with children's rights. The resulting Convention on the Rights of the Child was unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 20 November 1989—10 years on again. That is, some 30 years after the United Nations adopted a declaration with respect to the matter, it was able to unanimously adopt a convention. It came into force internationally upon receiving its 20th ratification on 2 September 1990.

Prior to Australia ratifying that convention, there was much concern about the potential effect of the convention on family life in this nation. There was at the time very particular concern as to whether it would undermine parental rights and responsibilities, particularly as they related to education, religion, association with others and privacy. The articles in the convention that are relevant to these issues—articles 12 to 16 inclusive and article 28—contain no express recognition of the primary rights and responsibilities of parents, and therefore appear to give absolute rights to the child. The Holy See, when it ratified the convention, made a reservation to the effect that it would interpret the articles of the convention in a way that would safeguard the primary and inalienable rights of parents.

It is interesting to note that in November 1990, prior to the ratification of the convention by Australia, the then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, made reference to the reservations to the convention which were made by the Holy See. He advised the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the Australian Government ratifies the convention, should it do so, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It would be surprising were that not the case . . .

Despite that statement, in December 1990—a little over a month later—the government ratified the convention without making any such reservations. The ratification took place at the time when there was a motion on the Notice Paper, moved by the honourable member for Kooyong, Andrew Peacock, calling on the government to give an undertaking that, in the event of the convention being ratified by Australia, reservations would be lodged to protect those inalienable rights of parents. But the government, in ratifying the treaty prior to that motion being debated, ensured that there was no discussion of the convention in the House of Representatives prior to its ratification. In other words, there was simply a fait accompli.

PARA.TAB: These concerns have bubbled up again as a consequence of the Attorney's incorporation of the convention into the HREOC act. Again prior to the ratification of the convention by Australia, Senator Evans responded to the concerns by simply dismissing them as `lunatic misapprehensions'. That did not do anything to set at rest the minds of those people who were concerned, and seems somewhat inconsistent with the remarks made by former Senator Tate.

There was one concession to those concerns in the lower house, in references by government representatives to the preamble and article 5 of the convention and to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, which sets out rules for the interpretation of international treaties. That preamble contains a general statement about the family, stating that, as the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and wellbeing of all its members, particularly children, it should be afforded the necessary protection and assistance so that it can fully assume its responsibilities within the community.

Article 5 of the convention states that parties to the convention shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or persons legally responsible for the child to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognised in the convention. However, those provisions fall short of providing the clear-cut interpretation of the convention that an express reservation as to the rights of parents, as has been done by the Holy See, would have provided. What appear to be the absolute rights of children, set out in articles 12 to 16 and 28, are arguably not sufficiently qualified by the vague reference to the family in the preamble; nor are they by article 5, which recognises the rights of parents to guide their children in the exercise of the rights recognised under the convention but does not, in its terms, qualify the rights themselves.

Lawyers specialising in international law in the Attorney-General's Department may be aware of, and have access to, the Vienna convention, but the average person in the street does not. The simple fact is that people in the community who will be looking at the convention and wanting to interpret it, such as social workers and perhaps law enforcement officers and parents, are likely never to have heard of the Vienna convention, much less have the skills required to interpret it and apply it to the Convention on the Rights of the Child as it should be.

As a result of the ratification, Australia is now bound at international law by the terms of this convention. The convention obliges Australia to respect and ensure the rights recognised in the convention and to do so without discrimination of any kind. In particular, article 4 requires that states `undertake all appropriate legislative, administrative, and other measures for the implementation of the rights recognised'. Of course, the rights of children are already legislated for in Australia. Unlike the United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief, the subject matter of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is the subject of quite wide ranging legislation in Australia.

In April 1989 a paper prepared by a working group on behalf of the Australian Council of Social Service indicated that existing government law and policies appeared generally consistent with the articles of the convention. It pointed out that, because there was no specification of what is meant by terms such as `social security', nor any detailing of other requirements, it was difficult to determine clearly the question of compliance in relation to some issues. In November 1989 Justice Elizabeth Evatt of the Law Reform Commission indicated that, in order to bring Australian laws into basic conformity with the convention, it might be necessary for legislative action to be taken in a wide range of areas, including family law, marriage, children's legal services, social security, and adoption.

Despite those observations, because of the generality and the failure to be specific, the report by the Australian Council of Social Service indicated that it was difficult to determine clearly the question of compliance. Despite the fact that Justice Evatt indicated that it might be necessary for legislative action to be taken in a wide range of areas—despite those observations—the ratification of the convention went ahead without the passage of enabling legislation either at the state or territory level, or at the Commonwealth level.

When Senator Durack put a question on 22 November 1989 as to whether or not the government had examined state child welfare laws in relation to many of the matters covered by the convention and, as a consequence of such an examination, made any judgment about their adequacy properly to protect the rights of Australian children, Senator Evans, the minister responsible for foreign affairs, said that the government had made a judgment that no Australian law was in contravention of the provisions of the convention. So we have ACOSS saying it is difficult to say; we have Justice Elizabeth Evatt saying some of the laws will have to be changed; and we have the minister responsible for foreign affairs saying the government did not think anything had to be done.

At the time of announcing the ratification of the convention, Senator Evans and the Attorney-General confidently said that state and territory laws already enabled Australia to meet all the obligations the convention would impose, with one exception, which was the subject of a reservation. That exception related to child and adult criminal offenders being in separate prisons. Nonetheless, those remarks obviously did not convince either the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Australian Council of Social Service.

In 1991, they engaged the Public Interest Advocacy Centre to conduct a six-months wide-ranging review into the implications of the convention for Australian law and practice relating to children. As I understand it, that review is yet to be finalised. It has been put on the backburner at the moment, reflecting the difficulties involved in actually interpreting the convention or in trying to apply it to see whether Australian law complies.

The government has therefore bound Australia to a convention while it is still unclear whether Australian laws comply with it, and it is unclear therefore what legislative changes are needed to enable Australia to comply with it at Commonwealth, state and territory levels. These issues, the coalition says, should have been resolved before ratification. No-one argues with the general objectives of the UN convention, that is, to prevent the exploitation of children and to ensure that their rights are recognised. The convention is directed towards preventing dreadful practices such as child prostitution and slavery and towards ensuring that there is proper representation of children in legal proceedings and a number of other very desirable objectives.

Nonetheless, given the lack of clarity of the terms of the convention and the acknowledged difficulties in interpreting it, given the government's failure to make an express reservation at the time of ratification that would have clarified the meaning of crucial articles of the convention, and given the widespread concern this has generated in the community, its wholesale incorporation into the HREOC act is undesirable. As with the UN religious declaration, the incorporation of the convention under the HREOC act also illustrates the unsatisfactory structure of the HREOC act, to which reference was made on 28 September.

The functions of the commission are set out in section 11 of that act. They include the examination of all relevant international instruments in order to ascertain whether there are any inconsistencies between any of them and any other international instruments already incorporated into the definition of a human rights act. Relevant international instruments are defined to be those declared under section 47. That is the type of declaration the Attorney has made that we are now seeking to have disallowed.

In so declaring an instrument under the act, it also brings the rights and freedoms recognised in the instrument within the other functions of the commission. Those functions include inquiring into any act or practice of the Commonwealth or its agencies which might be contrary to the rights or freedoms recognised in the instrument; promoting an understanding and acceptance of those rights within Australia; and reporting to the minister as to what laws should be made by the Commonwealth or what action should be taken by the Commonwealth in relation to those rights. Therefore, by declaring an instrument under the HREOC act, the commission is given the function of promoting rights and freedoms which, it is agreed by many, may, and on the coalition's analysis almost certainly do, conflict with rights in other instruments already under the act.

The anomaly is that the act creates a situation where the commission does not have the power to examine an international instrument to see whether it is inconsistent with an instrument already incorporated in the act unless the commission is put in the position of having to promote both instruments. Given the uncertainty that presently exists as to whether Australian laws are in compliance with the convention, the commission may therefore be obliged to promote rights and freedoms recognised in the convention which are, in fact, inconsistent with existing Australian laws. I cannot understand how anyone could not agree that that is a ludicrous situation to put the commission in.

Just as with the United Nations religious declaration, many submissions have been received by the coalition in relation to this convention, and many of those submissions have revealed a very serious lack of understanding among hundreds of members of the public about the impact of Australia ratifying UN conventions and a lack of understanding of the means by which they become part of our domestic law, the roles and powers of the commission itself and the effect of declaring international instruments under the HREOC act. The government, despite its protestations of being interested in human rights and despite some of the good work it has done, has simply failed to educate and inform the community about how the convention will impact on family life in Australia and is therefore responsible for causing quite deep and widespread concern throughout the community. The government should have taken on that role.

The ministerial declaration under the HREOC act therefore should be disallowed under this motion. But, just as I indicated several days ago in relation to the declaration with respect to religious freedoms, there are some things the government should now do that it should have done years ago. First, it should review the convention and ascertain whether Australian laws—Commonwealth, state and territory—are consistent with its provisions when correctly interpreted. Second, it should enact any legislation pursuant to that review and request the states or territories to do the same. Third, the Attorney should give careful consideration to whether, in light of the relevant legislation, any declaration under the HREOC act was necessary. If the prior steps are appropriately implemented, then we should be able to conclude whether or not the declaration the Attorney has made is necessary or otherwise.

In conclusion, what the coalition is asking the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to do is to join with us and disallow the Attorney's declaration and to set the Attorney on the path of reviewing the convention and ascertaining and reporting back to parliament as to the degree of compliance with the convention under Commonwealth, state and territory laws, the extent to which legislation can be enacted pursuant to that review, and how quickly that can be done. With that information at hand, then this chamber could decide whether it was appropriate to make the declaration under the HREOC act or not. Without that information at hand, without the government having done that job, it is simply unacceptable to allow the Attorney's declaration to put the Convention on the Rights of the Child under the HREOC act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and in opposition to the position taken by the Liberal and National parties in this place on this issue. What we are talking about is an international instrument which has as its primary objective the protection and the rights of children. It is an instrument which does not, in the way that it has been adopted by the government, take instant effect as domestic law in this country. It is an instrument which will, because of its application, provide the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with a role in protecting the rights of children—an educational role and a safeguarding role. It will not have any power to incarcerate a person because that person does not agree with the convention but it will have a role to ensure that the public are educated.

PARA.TAB: The other role of the convention will be to ensure that Commonwealth practices are in conformity with the convention. We do not talk about this convention as something that does not have any real, meaningful, direct relevance. We talk of it as having direct and important relevance, not just domestically within Australia but also internationally. I think the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Hall) in the House of Representatives made the point that in Australia in 1991 we had some 21,000 established cases of abuse of children. That figure itself reflects the fact that legislators in this country are not doing enough to protect children. That fact itself indicates the direct relevance of this convention, a role for HREOC and a responsibility on all legislatures, but particularly this one, to take a further interest in the rights of children.

Not only does it have that sort of role domestically but the convention is an important international instrument. It is important in that it targets the malpractices being perpetrated on children. Children are being sold; male and female children are being used for prostitution from the age of 12 or 13; children are being deliberately maimed; and so on. The world has set an international benchmark for the treatment of children, and it is important for Australia to be part of that. We were part of it in its formulation. It is important for us to continue to be part of it now.

To that effect, the Australian government has already taken measures to gauge the compliance of governments in this country with these benchmarks that even the opposition accepts. Both in this place and in the other place, there is an acknowledgment by opposition members that they do not oppose the instrument that we are talking about. To the extent that we as a government are operating, we have set seven major goals of an action plan against which we will check our obligations to this instrument. Those seven major goals are important and they are probably worth enunciating right now.

They are the reduction of infant and under five years of age mortality rates; the reduction of maternal mortality rates; the reduction of severe and moderate malnutrition of children under five years of age; universal access to safe drinking water; sanitary means of excreta disposal; reduction of the adult illiteracy rate, with emphasis on female literacy; and improved protection of children in especially difficult circumstances. They are all honourable goals, goals with which opposition members agree.

The trouble is that, once again, when it comes to actually putting their hands up on an issue of social importance, an issue of social reform, opposition members are being led from behind. Senator Hill, who has been leader in this place for a number of years, has once again abdicated his role of leadership. Dr Hewson, the leader in the other place, has also abdicated his role. They are allowing the wild backbench—the feral backbench—of the opposition to take over once again.
