They are abdicating responsibility in such a way that the public will very soon become aware that we have an opposition whose members not only are prepared not to make difficult decisions on policy on the economic front but will go to the next election, as they went to the last one, without a socially relevant policy; without a policy to cater for the social problems of this country; without a policy to cater for the needs of children, the needs of women, the needs of families and the needs of migrant groups—and this is another instance of it.

Opposition members come in here and go into the other place—and, I must admit, some of them who make these points are people with some intelligence—and try to weasel their way out of this instrument. They try to weasel their way out of support for an instrument which has overwhelming support in this country and has overwhelming support internationally. As I said yesterday, they do not come in here with any solid arguments, any rational arguments; they come in here with spurious rhetoric, with fabricated points of view, but none of them are relevant to the people of this nation or to people internationally.

They say that there needs to be a reservation to the instrument. The first line they advance is their claim that Senator Tate, when questioned about this matter some time ago in the Senate, gave an undertaking that there would be a reservation and that that reservation has not been made. The quote they use from Senator Tate is a deliberately misleading one and it does them no good to pursue it. They say that Senator Tate said in the parliament in respect of a reservation, `It would be surprising were that not the case', implying there was a full stop at that particular point. But Senator Tate went on to say a couple of important sentences. I will quote his remarks so as to give the full meaning of what he said. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be surprising were that not the case, given the fact that Australia inserted article 5, meaning that for the first time in the international community a document was open to ratification which recognised that pre-eminent role of the family, parents or legal guardians in giving guidance and direction to children in accordance with their evolving capacities.

That concern about the pre-eminent role of the family in giving guidance to children was responded to by Senator Tate. In the quote that was half repeated in this place and in the House of Representatives, he went on to say that concern `has been acknowledged by article 5'. Article 5 is an article that Australia had a major role in inserting in the instrument. It is there because Australia pursued it. That gives the lie to the point that they were making about a need for a reservation to protect the rights of families in terms of their guidance over children. Australia has already acted. It does them no good—and it does this institution no good—to come in here and half quote and deliberately misquote my former colleague Senator Tate. We have acted in the protection of the rights of families. That is there. It is there in article 5 of this instrument; it is there because of Australia's action.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members then say that the other point is that we need to take the same position as the Holy See in respect to this. They claim the Holy See made a reservation in respect to this instrument to protect the rights of the family over such matters as religion, education and so on. If one were actually to read the Holy See's so-called reservation, one would probably see it as a declaration interpreting the way the Holy See would read article 5 of this instrument.

The Holy See, I think quite fairly and quite rationally, can be seen to be taking that position, but let us have a look at article 5 in a general sense. Let us have a look at this instrument in a general sense. No other country around the world has made a reservation to this convention. No other country has made the sort of reservation that we are talking about. Other countries have not tried to weasel their way out of their commitments, their obligations both to our children in this country and children internationally. The countries include the United Kingdom, Canada and the United States. This is probably one of the most heavily ratified instruments internationally that the world has seen. But no, standing alone, in isolation, back in the backblocks somewhere are the National and Liberal parties in this place.

Come on, for God's sake, in the interests of the children of this country and of the world, can the honourable senators opposite just drop their ideological objection to some of these things and actually view them rationally—view them with some degree of decency and commonsense. It is no wonder the people of Australia have said to them that they have got no social policy, no social relevance. Time and time again, they are coming in here and showing it.

As I say, this is one of the most heavily ratified international conventions, and there is one declaration—not reservation—from the Holy See. Opposition senators come in here wanting to weasel their way out of an obligation imposed on government to act in the interest of children, an obligation imposed on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to publicise and to promote the interests of children. It is an obligation internationally to protect children from prostitution, from malnutrition, from illiteracy.

No, it is only the opposition side in this place which is standing alone against the rest of the world. When I say that the Opposition side is standing against the rest of the world, I should point out it is not just a case of over 147 countries having ratified the convention. Even in our own country we should look at what has been said by the National Child-Youth Law Council, the Australian Federation of Children, the Family Welfare Association, HREOC and, not surprisingly in this case, the Law Council of Australia. The Law Council of Australia is a body which I do not often find myself agreeing with, but honourable senators on the other side always do. But what has it said about this issue? It is worthwhile for honourable senators opposite to listen to what John Mansfield had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to what the people say, not what the lawyers say.

—What the people are saying all over the world, Senator, is that this is an important international instrument that needs to be ratified. Just a few years ago 49 leaders throughout the world got together and said it should be made a priority. People all over Australia with an interest in this issue are saying, `Don't put in a reservation'. The only people in this country, the only people internationally, who are saying, `No, we do not want to be part of this', are the troglodytes on the other side. It is no wonder that this Senate is getting the reputation of being the political Jurassic Park of Australia. It is because of the attitude expressed by people on the other side on issues such as this.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at a letter dated 1 September 1993 which was sent to the Attorney-General ((Mr Lavarch) by Mr John Mansfield, the Acting President of the Law Council. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Attorney-General,

PARA.TAB: You will be aware of the notice of motion—which I understand is to debated later today—

SPEECH.PARA: it was in the House of Representatives—

given by the Shadow Attorney-General, Mr Williams, calling for disallowance of a declaration by the Attorney-General that the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purposes of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act.

PARA.TAB: The Law Council is concerned that the motion, if adopted, may prevent the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission from fully carrying out its responsibilities under the Convention, or at least may limit the Commission's role in relation to the Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: To paraphrase the letter, the Law Council is concerned that the opposition motion, if adopted, would prevent the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission from carrying out a very important function. It continues:
The Law Council believes adoption of the motion would be embarrassing to Australia.

It does not bother honourable senators opposite, the Jurassic Park of this political institution, that this might be embarrassing to Australia and it might limit the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its responsibilities and functions in an area of priority and need. It continues:

Further, it would cut across and undermine much of what was achieved and agreed upon at the recent World Congress on Family Law and Children's Rights, held in Sydney, which the Law Council and LAWASIA sponsored.

PARA.TAB: The Congress called upon all governments which have not yet done so to give immediate and serious consideration to the ratification and implementation of the Convention. It also called on all governments to establish, develop and support at the national, regional and international levels effective, independent machinery to monitor compliance with the rights prescribed in the Convention, and to provide adequate resources to enable that machinery to operate.

For Australia to take the step contemplated in Mr Williams' motion would, the Law Council believes, be most unfortunate and would be likely to hold Australia up to ridicule in the international community.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not bother the Opposition; it does not bother the troglodytes on the other side; it does not bother those with no social commitment, no social policy. The letter continues:

We believe the Convention sets out the rights of children in a proper and commendable way, and we do not believe it holds any threat to the rights of parents to fulfil their obligations to their children, or any threat to the family, as alleged in the motion.
Let me just repeat that. It says:

We believe the Convention sets out the rights of children in a proper and commendable way, and we do not believe it holds any threat to the rights of parents to fulfil their obligations to their children, or any threat to the family, as alleged in the motion. Indeed, in several specific provisions, particular weight is given to the central role of parents in guiding and supporting children in the exercise and protection of those rights.

PARA.TAB: We understand that the Convention is supported by a wide range of organisations in Australia, including the Uniting Church Social Responsibility Committee, the Australian Early Childhood Association, the Youth Affairs Council, and others.

SPEECH.PARA: With best wishes,
John Mansfield
There it is. There is no problem with the rights of parents—as the Law Council should rightly say, given at least article 5 of this instrument.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, this is an important convention. It is one that this government is taking seriously to the extent that we have initiated already our response to our obligations under the convention. It has been necessary to consult with state and territory governments as well as relevant Commonwealth agencies in the preparation of our report. Letters seeking assistance and attaching a questionnaire were sent out at the start of 1992. The last response was received in June 1993, and a draft report was circulated in May to relevant Commonwealth departments and state and territory governments for comment. Not all have responded to this date, but we hope to lodge Australia's first report by the end of the year. In the context of the report, we are finding particular problems. Problems have been raised, for instance, by non-government organisations, on areas that in their view need to be changed, on laws with particular provisions to wards of state, care and control orders and so on. All are initiatives geared towards enhancing the rights of children.

I do not need to go on much longer, other than to make this very fundamental point: we have before us the opportunity to bowl over Australia's involvement in an international convention which has universal support across the world. At least 147 countries have ratified it. A few years ago 49 national leaders got together and proposed that governments should act on this instrument as a matter of priority. Of those 49 heads of government, governments such as those of the UK, Canada and New Zealand had ratified the treaty previously. If I have not got it wrong, that means that even Maggie Thatcher was one of those 49 leaders who in 1989 urged an early adoption of this particular instrument.

In Australia there is widespread support from the Law Council and from many organisations, including the Uniting Church Social Responsibility Committee and so on. There is only one force in Australian community life—and there is probably only one force in world affairs—that says, `No, let's not be part of it'; and it is the senators on the other side. If those senators continue with this course of action they will not only continue to have attached to themselves and this institution the title of the Jurassic Park of political thought in this country, but they will hold us up to ridicule, not just domestically but internationally.

We are not talking about an instrument which changes and has direct domestic law effect in this country. We are talking about an instrument which will be used by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for educational and promotional purposes, and will be a benchmark for the Commonwealth government to be assessed against. That is what we are talking about. We are talking about an instrument which universally in this country—apart from some of the shonky advice that they have got over there—acknowledges quite fairly, properly and adequately the rights of families when it comes to the protection of children.

The final point is that we are talking about an instrument with widespread international relevance, and not just domestic relevance. We are talking about situations of children. We are talking about weak members of our society who do need all the protection they can get. They need it against instances of child abuse—and, God, we have seen some quite horrific instances of that in this country recently. But they also need it internationally against abuse, against maiming, against being led into prostitution, against being sold and so on. It is a pretty important instrument. Our commitment to it in the scheme of things—

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with it?

—I am asked what that has to do with it. Our commitment to this instrument in the scheme of things is very important. It is totally irresponsible for those people over there to come in here and try to weasel their way out of it and try to weasel the parliament of Australia out of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the National Party and the Liberal Party have moved to disallow the ministerial declaration of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. We have done it for a number of reasons. Some of those reasons were put to the Senate in the debate on a similar declaration on religious freedoms. As I pointed out to the Senate then, people are concerned that their rights are being eroded by the handing over of the responsibilities of the Commonwealth and state governments to the United Nations, to some unelected court that represents a number of people. Senator Bolkus may not believe that those fears are responsible or that they should exist, but they are there. After a careful viewing of the declaration, arguments can be put forward that would sustain those arguments and the fact that those fears are real.

PARA.TAB: The motion relates to yet another declaration put forward by the former Attorney-General under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, to bring the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child under the purview of the act. The ministerial declaration was made on 22 December last year and published in the Commonwealth Government Gazette on 13 January 1993. I am not opposed in principle to the United Nations convention, and no-one could be, but the fact is that the principles that are enunciated by the act are already covered by law in Australia—by both state and Commonwealth law. We are responsible for administering that law in the parliaments of Australia. We seem to be handing our responsibilities to some United Nations convention.

I have reservations about incorporating the convention in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its present form. There has been a lot of community concern. We have had a number of letters and phone calls pointing out the problems in this declaration that are worrying people. I believe that those fears are real and valid. The convention, as it now stands, is vague and open to interpretation in several key provisions. It should not have been ratified until those provisions were clarified, with the rights and duties of parents expounded clearly and concisely beyond all possible future interpretation or misinterpretation.

The drafting of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child has a recent history of 10 years. Its origins can be tracked back to the 1920s with the League of Nations' adoption of the Declaration of Geneva, which contained five general principles, the most notable being that children should be the first to receive assistance in emergency situations. These nascent principles were developed further when the United Nations General Assembly adopted the Declaration of the Rights of the Child in 1959.

The Convention on the Rights of the Child was first proposed by the Polish government during the International Year of the Child in 1979. The United Nations took up the negotiations with religious organisations, charitable institutions and human rights groups to forge an international treaty guaranteeing children the right to an adequate level of care, shelter and education and protection from exploitation and abuse. The convention was finally adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1989 and was ratified in Australia on 17 December 1990.

Unlike the declaration, this convention is a legal instrument with which Australia is bound by international law to comply. These rights cannot at present be enforced by the courts. However, should the incorporation of the convention into the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act take place, children will be able to assert the rights recognised in the United Nations convention in courts of law. These children's rights become enforceable in the court. The associated complications that could result from this are sobering and could have far-reaching ramifications for Australian families.

The Convention on the Rights of the Child comprises 54 articles which address broad principles to promote and protect the fundamental rights of children. These principles include the right to life, name, nationality and culture; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; adequate standard of living; access to health services and education; protection from forced separation from parents; protection from abuse and neglect; protection from economic exploitation; and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse, capital punishment and deprivation of liberty.

Again I say that these rights already apply in Australia, and again I say that I am not opposed to the principles of the convention. The intention to prevent the exploitation and abuse of children and safeguard their basic rights is commendable. The provisions, particularly those contained within articles 32 to 37 dealing with children's rights to protection from physical and mental violence, economic exploitation, drug abuse, sexual exploitation and abuse, torture, capital punishment and deprivation of liberty, merit our utmost support.

However, the provisions laid out in articles 12 to 16 do concern me. They deal with the rights of children to express opinions; freedom of expression and information; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of association; and protection of privacy, honour and reputation. None of these provisions address the interlocking rights and duties of parents to advise and guide their children as they see fit. It can be summarised from these provisions that the children are endowed with absolute rights in regard to expressions of thought and opinion, access to information and association with whomever they choose, and these are completely independent of the parental mandate.

If this becomes law in Australia, who will interpret that? Again we do not know. It will not be the laws of this parliament. It will be some human rights commissioner or some court that sets itself up in Geneva. The people of Australia want these decisions to be made by the legislatures of Australia and this is why there is such concern about United Nations conventions usurping the rights of the parliaments of Australia. What starts out as a good idea at the time ends up with all sorts of unintended consequences. We have seen this in a number of areas in Australia, with children as young as 15 and 16 given the right, the money and the financial support to move away from their families, to go out on the streets. No-one disagrees with the principles that are expounded under the conventions, but the interpretation sometimes does not come up to the expectations.
The preamble in article 5 of the convention covers parental rights. The preamble states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the family, as the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well-being of all its members and particularly children, should be afforded the necessary protection and assistance . . . within the community.

Article 5 states that all states are to respect the rights of parents or other persons responsible for the child to give the child direction and guidance, consistent with his or her evolving capacities, in the exercise of the child's rights.

PARA.TAB: These rights should have been included with the rights of children in articles 12 to 16. If they were, I believe, we would not have the reservations that we are expressing at the moment. The family unit and children's rights co-exist with those of their parents, but this section of the convention does not acknowledge this fundamental family nexus. This has given rise to the fear shared by thousands of parents that their rights and duties in regard to their children's upbringing have been undermined, or could be undermined, with this further encroachment by the state into their family lives. Those fears, I believe, are genuine; and they are coming from thousands of people from whom we have received phone calls and letters.

The family is the basic unit of our society. In fact, that is one of the very strongest planks of the National Party. A solid family unit is the imperative base for a society to grow and prosper, and any move to diminish the rights of the family should be met with resistance. Families are under enough pressure at the moment from economic conditions and declining living standards, with one million unemployed: there are 700,000 children growing up in households where no-one has a job. Over the last 10 years there has been a steep increase in family break-ups, unemployment, youth homelessness and crime; and this has placed tremendous stress and strain on families.

Evoking a United Nations convention is not going to do one thing for those people that are going through so much stress at the moment. That is where we are coming from. What is this all about? There is so much pressure on the family today. So many children cannot get jobs. So many parents are stressed out because their children cannot get jobs and they see their years of economic sacrifice in putting their children through high school and college, and then through tertiary education, all going to nothing when the children go out there to try to achieve a job and find themselves bottled up in some sort of mickey mouse job program that does not lead anywhere or is of only six months duration.

That is what this government should be trying to fix up and adjust, if it really supports the family. This is just a cop-out, saying, `We really support the family and therefore we will support some United Nations convention'. The last thing that Australian families need is more pressure on them through the rights and responsibilities of parents being cast into doubt with the incorporation of vaguely worded United Nations conventions into domestic law.

Before ratifying the convention in 1990, the government should have included the essential reservations which would have left no doubt whatsoever about the rights and responsibilities of parents in the family unit. Then the government would have had our support. In the same way, the Holy See would not ratify the convention until the reservations affirming the rights of all parents were included. If the government had made those reservations, it would have allayed the fears of the Catholic church and a number of other mainstream churches and of people that hold their families up as their life and the main things in their life—and probably the only things in their life. But it has not done that; and then it comes to this parliament and says that we are not facing our responsibilities. We are not elected by 149 other countries or however many other countries Senator Bolkus cited. We are elected by the people of Australia, and our main responsibility is to them.

The reservation stated that the Holy See interprets the articles of the convention in a way that safeguards the primary and inalienable rights of parents, in particular insofar as these rights concern education, religion, association with others and privacy. Australia would follow that path had these reservations been moved by the government. They had been foreshadowed by former Senator Tate, who was then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and who stated, just prior to signing, that he anticipated that the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It never was acknowledged.

However, when the time came, the government failed to put forward any such reservations, obviously believing that the insertion of article 5 would be sufficient. But it did not satisfy Senator Tate. He is not here to defend those actions. I suppose he is glad that he is not, because he would have been totally embarrassed. Those reservations clearly have not been put forward. The level of community concern over the possible erosion of parental rights and family life attests to that failure.

I am opposed to the convention for another reason, which has not yet received any debate. As shadow minister for northern Australia and the external territories, I have grave fears about the real possibility of intrusion into the lives of communities such as those of Cocos Island, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which, under the act, has the power to inquire into acts or practices engaged in by or on behalf of the Commonwealth. It impacts differently on the lives of people in the islands and the territories. It has more power. It can actually involve itself in the everyday lives of those communities. So we have created two classes of people—one in Australia, including the people of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, where the act can be invoked only in relation to the Commonwealth or states, and the other in the territories, where it goes a lot further and can inquire into the lives of all the territorians.

This convention has the potential to be used against the residents of Cocos Island, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island, who are more vulnerable to the act than are Australian citizens. The possible ramifications of this have not been clearly thought through. If it had been possible to move an amendment, we would have done so, but that is not allowed in respect of the disallowance motion that has been moved in the Senate today.

I am not opposed to the underlying objectives of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Its intention to promote the basic rights and freedoms of children as well as to guarantee protection from abuse, exploitation and neglect cannot be faulted. But we cannot be asked to support poorly drafted documents and things that are not clear and are ambiguous, which could have a destabilising effect in their application and which might work against families. The convention should never have been ratified without the inclusion of the reservations emphasising the rights and responsibilities of parents. It should certainly not now be passed into law. For those reasons, I support Senator Vanstone's disallowance motion, as do all National and Liberal party senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that everybody supports the thrust of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, and properly so. Senator Boswell, in his usual magnificent contribution, made that point. It was also made right at the start of this debate in the parliament by the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Williams, who is the shadow Attorney-General, when he moved a motion of disallowance in the House of Representatives on 1 September 1993. He said in the course of his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: No-one should argue with the general objectives of the UN convention, namely, to prevent the exploitation of children and to ensure their rights are recognised. The convention is directed towards preventing such dreadful practices as child prostitution and slavery and towards ensuring adequate representation of children in legal proceedings and for other desirable objectives.
So there is no objection to the content of the convention, to the general thrust of what it is about. The objections are referred to in the next paragraph. It continues:

PARA.TAB: However, given the lack of clarity of the terms of the convention and the acknowledged difficulties in interpreting it, given the government's failure to make an express reservation at the time of ratification that would have clarified the meaning of crucial articles of the convention, and given the widespread concern that this has generated in the community, its wholesale incorporation into the HREOC Act is highly undesirable. As with the UN religious declaration, the incorporation of the convention under the HREOC Act also illustrates the unsatisfactory structure of the HREOC Act alluded to earlier this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, if this law is to become applicable in Australia so that it actually touches the citizens of Australia in a way that other laws that are made here do, it will have to become part of the domestic law. The legislation for that will then be subject to interpretation by the courts, and that is a thing courts do every day. That is the very idea of having courts. So to say the legislation is unclear is a reasonable point, but not a point that should lead to the acknowledged good that is contained in this convention being stopped from being bought into domestic law. I think there is a feeling amongst some of us that there is not a need to have laws to protect children and, if that is the approach taken, it is quite misconceived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already got them.

—Senator Calvert, a person who has great interest in this area, says that we have got those laws. That is the opinion he holds, and great respect should be given to that opinion; but great respect should equally be given to the opinion of other people who have had much to say in this area. May I quote, for example, the statement of Miss, Mrs or Ms Moira Rayner which appeared in the Age. I will just read the first two paragraphs of the article:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's child-protection services were in a mess and a national approach to children's rights was needed, the chairwoman of the board of governors of the National Children's Youth Law Centre, Ms Moira Rayner, said yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Ms Rayner, who is also Victoria's human rights and equal opportunity commissioner, said Australia never seemed to get it right on child protection. `We have scandals, we have deaths, we have a review and then a few years later it's all in a heap again,' she said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Mrs or Ms?
—It is Ms.
—Has she got children of her own?

—I do not know; it does not appear in the article. I would take it that as the chairwoman of the board of governors of the National Children's Youth Law Centre and as Victoria's Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, she is a woman of some substance, and this ought to be taken into account.
—What does your church say about it?

—What my church says about children and their protection is that they ought to be protected. In any event, the convention either stands or falls in its own terms. As people keep repeating, there is no objection to the convention except for the reservation, and except for the way it is to be carried out. There is much good fortune in this debate coming on now, because this is a very big issue at the moment in Victoria following the report of Mr Justice Fogarty. Mr Justice Fogarty has come in for considerable criticism, but may I say that he is a person who has had a most distinguished record in the law, both as a barrister and a member of Her Majesty's Counsel and then as a judge in the Family Court at first instance and as a judge on the appeal court of that body. He has revealed some most dreadful conditions that exist for the looking after of children in Victoria, and much criticism has been made of him in respect of that.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, it is interesting to see what people have to say. Mr Justice Fogarty has had great support from people such as Mr Mark Longmuir, executive officer of the Victorian Youth Affairs Council, who said that it would be irresponsible for the government to ignore or reject the report's finding and to go ahead with its savage and totally unjustified cuts. In this respect—and taking up the invitation from Senator Calvert about what my church might say—a spokesman for the Melbourne Catholic Social Services, Father Peter Norden, a man highly respected in my home state, said that the government, by pressing ahead with its cuts, would be abandoning the objectives of saving children's lives in favour of saving the dollar. The director of St Augustine's adolescent family services in Geelong, Brother Trevor Parton—also a member of my church, I remind Senator Calvert—said that the government's decision to cut its $780,000 funding by $400,000 would force it to close three or four residential care units for young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does your church say about this Convention on the Rights of the Child?

—The Pope signed it with a reservation. What I am saying to Senator Calvert is that our decision as a nation should be to sign this convention without the reservation, because the bulk of the good in this convention far outweighs any disadvantage that might arise from it.

PARA.TAB: What members of the opposition have done is to look at this convention and, having looked at it, they have found that they must support the general thrust of it. But then, as they do not want it to go through because, for whatever reason, they have got reservations about it, they have scanned it to find any sort of peg to hang a disallowance motion on. That is not a happy way of going about these things.

What we should do when looking at legislation is to look at the general thrust, at the good that it will bring about, at the overall objectives it pursues, and to pass it on that basis rather than trying to find an excuse for rejecting it. When those opposite look for an excuse to reject it, people might well draw the conclusion that they are not rejecting it for that particular excuse, because they have found a blemish in it, but because they do not like the overall objectives. That is the difficulty they find themselves in.

If they reject it for one reason, the appearance is that they have rejected it holus-bolus, which they have done. If they reject it holus-bolus, as they must on a motion such as this, then they are rejecting a convention, as Mr Williams, the honourable member for Tangney, said in the other place, which prevents the exploitation of children, which ensures that their rights are recognised, which is directed towards preventing such dreadful practices as child prostitution and slavery, and which ensures adequate representation of children in legal proceedings and for other desirable objectives—and at a time when there is much adverse criticism of the way we treat children in this society.

There is the discussion about the Fogarty report. There was discussion earlier about the juvenile justice legislation in Western Australia—which was passed by an Australian Labor Party government, that is conceded. There are concerns about the way children are treated in every state of this Commonwealth. Yet when there is some proposition brought forward in this House which, at the very least, goes against the culture that has produced that sort of abuse, it is rejected because of what could only be described as fairly technical reasons at best. After all, if this convention were finally put into domestic law, it would be interpreted by domestic courts. Even at this stage, when it goes into the HREOC legislation it is interpreted by the Federal Court, and there is an overall supervision of the way it is administered by the Federal Court and by the High Court of Australia.

The rejection of this convention is a rejection of the proposition that our courts are courts of high quality, courts able to administer properly the law in this nation in the best interests of this nation. The more one looks at it, the more one wonders why the opposition wants so strongly to reject this report, given its application to the situation in Australia. We should be supporting it because it sets world standards, and children around the world obviously need protection and help. If we reject this, we are saying that we have got no interest in what happens to children around the world. That is understandable if a very parochial view is taken. But what is not understandable is that this particular convention has great relevance to Australia at the moment, because of the concern about the way children are treated. In the light of that concern and in the light of the overwhelming evidence that children do need protection and do need rights, when we, as a federal government, have an opportunity to do something about that, what do we do? We move to have it rejected.

People on this side of the House will not be taking that approach. Knowing Senator Spindler and his great and well-established appetite for civil rights and for justice, I imagine, without knowing, that his party would be supporting this. I would hope the members of the Greens party would also do so, they having the same sort of approach as I would have hoped most Australians would have towards this.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I call Senator Watson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think this is the first time I have addressed the Senate with you in the chair as Acting Deputy President. I take this opportunity of congratulating you on this office, because you bring to this high office a degree of tolerance, fairness and impartiality. I wish you well.

PARA.TAB: I rise today to add my voice to those of my colleagues who have already spoken and of those who will follow me, including my Tasmanian colleague Senator Calvert, in support of the coalition's proposed disallowance with respect to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

Honourable senators might recall that earlier this year the former Attorney-General, the honourable member for Holt, Mr Duffy—a man of great distinction in the law and in this parliament—made a declaration to incorporate the convention within the ambit of subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The effect of this declaration was to bring the rights and freedoms recognised in the UN convention within the definition of human rights for the purpose of the act and the general functions of the commission with respect to human rights.

As my colleagues have made abundantly clear, and will continue to make clear, the coalition is not opposed to the convention itself. Unfortunately, because of the processes of this Senate, we are not able to pick out those elements that we do have some concern about. It is unfortunate that the only avenue available to members of this opposition who have concerns about particular sections and subsections is to reject the whole of the declaration itself.

This is indeed unfortunate, and can lead to the sorts of criticism that our colleague on the other side, Senator Cooney, has referred to. We are very much against child molestation, imprisonment, slavery and all those sorts of issues. But, as we have mentioned before, we have adequate processes and freedoms within this country that enable due process of these freedoms. What we are concerned about is that we are not extending the freedoms to Australians under this act. What frightens us is that we could be actually constrained. This is the problem.

It is important that we stress on the record that our current Liberal-National Party coalition has always supported the thrust of the convention, but—and I emphasise that—with reservations to particular articles in the convention, so that the terms and conditions and the rights contained therein would be made perfectly clear. This is where our concern is. There is a lot of ambiguity there and, as a result, confusion can arise. We do not want to make it more difficult. It is no reflection on the ability of the Australian courts in any way at all, but we believe it is unnecessary to add confusion.

We would like the issues to be clarified so that there is not an element of doubt or confusion as to what parents' rights are or what children's rights are. For example, the coalition is concerned that the rights of parents as well as the rights of children are clear and do not need further interpretation. This is a problem, because they are not clear; they are fuzzy. The issue has caused a flood of correspondence and representations to my office in the form of personal visits, petitions and letters. That is not surprising; but the number of constituents who have contacted me on this issue would run into the hundreds—and for Tasmania those are great numbers.

Therefore, as an elected representative of these people, I feel that it is my duty to outline to this chamber the sorts of concerns they are bringing to me almost on a daily basis. I think it is important that I use the opportunities afforded by this chamber to outline to the Senate some of the concerns of the people who come to me. I would like to feel that I am representing these people fairly, and so I give expression to their views.

Firstly, the ambiguity of the wording of the Convention on the Rights of the Child makes it difficult for parents to know where they stand in the raising of their own child. There are difficulties particularly with articles 12 to 16 inclusive and article 28 of the convention, because they contain no express recognition of the primary rights and responsibilities of parents but, at the same time—this is where the confusion arises—they give absolute rights to the children. That is why I used the word `fuzzy' somewhat earlier in my presentation.

When articles 12 to 16 are examined, unfortunately further queries do arise. It is not a question of going through it and nitpicking. This is going to be a tremendous vehicle for lawyers to run on, because of the doubts. They thrive where the law is not precise or clear, and particularly in circumstances where it is ambiguous, so we want to try to remove those ambiguities.

At the same time, it is unfortunate that we have no avenue for making these deletions or amendments and that we have to be seen to be rejecting the whole lot, even though the thrust of the convention is perfectly acceptable and, in many cases, it is absolutely necessary and fundamental. Many of my constituents feel that article 12 raises questions as to who should decide a child's fitness to form his or her own views on matters on conscience. Of course, it comes back to age—whether the child is a five-year-old, a 10-year-old or a 15-year-old. Does article 12 prepare the way to allow a teacher to implant and implement a view of thinking contrary to the parents' way of thinking? That is another problem. Are the parents prevented from voicing their concerns here?

Much debate can occur as to whether the interpretation is correct or not, but the very fact that this can be read into the convention declares that these matters do need clarification before they are allowed to become part of Australian law. I think it is incumbent on the Senate to make sure that our laws are precise, clear and free of fuzziness.

Another question is the very funding of court costs that could occur when a child, by his own wish, is removed from his parents' care. Naturally, this causes a lot of concern. I have had representations from parents who were terribly distressed in relation to a particular case only about three weeks ago in Launceston. Article 12 seems to indicate to the many parents who have written to me that the child's court costs will be covered by the courts, while the parents must fund their own costs. Despite the fact that we are expressing some opposition, I think the responsibility is on the minister to answer clearly the sorts of questions I am posing which have come from my very concerned constituents.

Much comment has also been made with regard to article 13 of the convention, which gives the child the right to freedom of expression and to seek information from any source he chooses. The question is therefore raised by the parents: is this a blanket denial of the right of parents to raise a child in a manner which is consistent with their religious obligations as parents? That is fundamental. I refer to religious education. The Jesuits always said, `Give me a child for the first seven years and you can have him for the rest of his life'.
The phrase `in the best interests of the child' also figures in the convention. In respect of this issue, one mother writes:

SPEECH.PARA: By making these articles into legally binding agreements it immediately means that each word and phrase is open to legal scrutiny and interpretation which may result in the letter of the law being upheld at the expense of the intended spirit. The term, "the best interest of the child" immediately falls into that category . . . As a parent my intention is always to act in the best interests of my children, but my opinion concerning that differs greatly, at times, even from other members of my own family, who also love my children and desire the best.
This mother continues by stating:
How then, can the State become the one to decide what is in the best interests of my children (and indeed, should they?)

As noted by the Holy See when it ratified the convention, reservation was made to the effect that it would interpret the convention in a way that safeguards the primary and inalienable rights of parents. I ask the minister whether his government will direct the courts in terms of its interpretation of acceptance of this convention and whether it will take the same approach as the Holy See. If so, some of the reservations and concerns of people such as the mother who wrote to me, I believe, should be satisfied in another way.

PARA.TAB: So what is the intent? What is the purpose? I do not think that the minister can really back away by saying that he cannot direct the courts. It is true that he does not, but in his second reading speech, in the deliberations here today, in the speeches of people who will follow, an indication is needed because, when the courts look at these matters, they look at the second reading speeches to see what is the government's intent and purpose.

The right that has concerned my citizens the most, I suppose, is this reservation of the Holy See—the inalienable rights of the parents themselves. Within this UN convention, while there is an attempt to preserve the rights of children, the legislation is unevenly weighted against the parents in favour of the state.

The letters raise the query: are our current laws so inadequate in protecting and caring for our children? Is the quality of Australian parenting so poor that this parliament has to legislate to protect our children from their parents? We are not in India, where they discard baby girls. We are in a sophisticated democracy, with lots of rights guaranteed under our court system and by our constitution.

The only references to the family and to the rights of parents by this government in the discussion leading to the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child were to the preamble, to article 5 of the convention and to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, which sets out rules for the interpretation of international treaties. Unfortunately, this preamble gives a very fuzzy outline about the family. However, it is deficient in giving a clear and unambiguous interpretation of the convention, in that there is no implicit reservation or question about the rights of the parents. What appear to be the absolute rights of children set out in articles 12 to 16 and article 28 are arguably not sufficiently qualified by the vague reference to the family in the preamble, nor are they provided for by article 5.

I think it is unfortunate that we did not have Australian representatives on the body drafting the convention, because I am sure that the participation of our legal profession would have directed attention to the deficiencies by virtue of the vagueness of the language. Where are the rights of parents to guide their children in the exercise of the rights recognised under this article of the convention? Of course, it does not in its terms qualify the rights themselves. I therefore would like to refer to comments made by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General in the other place, the distinguished Mr Williams QC, when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the lack of clarity of the terms of the convention and the acknowledged difficulties in interpreting it, given the government's failure to make an express reservation at the time of ratification that would have clarified the meaning of crucial articles of the convention, and given the widespread concern that this has generated in the community, its wholesale incorporation into the HREOC act is highly undesirable.
I believe it is not too late for the government to make such a reservation, a reservation that the Holy See saw as necessary.

PARA.TAB: I ask the government to take these issues on board and address the questions about the uncertainties I have raised so that I can go back to the hundreds of constituents who have written to me concerned about their rights and concerned about the future parenting of their children. I look forward hopefully to the fact that the government may see fit, in the light of the debate that has taken place, to place such a reservation there. It is not too late, but I think we do need some comfort and support from the government to allay the fears that have been raised by me and by my colleagues in this debate. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is discussing a motion standing in the name of Senator Vanstone relating to the disallowance of a declaration concerning the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. This declaration would enable the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to promote the understanding and acceptance of the convention to inquire into, and report to the minister on, possible breaches of the convention. It is worth noting, even at this stage, that it has no power to take any other action.

PARA.TAB: I noted Senator Cooney's generous comments in which he suggested that we should give some respect to the views that lie behind the moving of this motion of disallowance. I find it a little difficult to be quite as charitable. The ignorance, the distortion of readily available facts, or, at worst, the cynical pandering to extremist fundamentalists who I believe are using the coalition for their own ends is to my mind rather difficult to understand.

The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child does not automatically form part of Australian domestic law. This would require positive legislative action by the federal parliament or by the various state parliaments, and subsequent changes to the administrative practices of federal, state and local governments and their departments and agencies.

In signing the convention on 22 August 1990 and ratifying it on 17 December 1990, Australia undertook a solemn obligation, together with other countries, to make necessary changes to its domestic law, policies and practices to bring these into line with the principles of the convention. There is no way individual sovereign countries can be compelled to take such action except through the persuasive pressure of world opinion. One of the ways to bring this world opinion to bear is to require regular reports on the progress they are making and thus to monitor the degree to which signatory countries are meeting their obligations under the convention. The Australian government undertook to provide such reports to the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child. The first report is in the process of being compiled and is already eight months overdue.

This draft report, containing contributions from all Australian governments, shows very modest advances in Australia's progress in the terms of the convention; nor does it mention backward steps, such as the Western Australian juvenile justice legislation, the Victorian indeterminate sentencing legislation and the Victorian Crimes (Amendment) Act, or the failure to provide adequate access by children to their mothers in Victorian prisons. As well, there is the general reluctance to accept that children have a right to separate legal representation in court proceedings affecting them, for instance in the Family Court. It is time Australian governments took positive steps to meet their obligations to Australian children. This declaration which is now the subject of a disallowance motion is an important step in that direction.

The declaration by the Commonwealth minister on 22 December 1992 that the convention is an `international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purposes of the Act'—that is, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Act—does not incorporate it into Australian law in a substantive way. It does, however, give the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission the same responsibilities for promoting the understanding and acceptance of the convention and for inquiring into and reporting on possible breaches as the commission currently has in relation to a number of other fundamental human rights instruments, such as the United Nations conventions on civil and political rights and on economic, social and cultural rights and the conventions on racial discrimination and sex discrimination.

One of the main reasons advanced for this quite unbelievable attempt to disallow the declaration is that it is an attack on the family and on the rights of parents. In fact, the convention strongly affirms the importance of the family. The preamble to the convention recognises that the family is `the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well-being of all its members and particularly children'. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the child, for the full and harmonious development of his or her personality, should grow up in a family environment . . .
Article 5 requires that parties to the convention:
shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents . . . to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance . . .

Much has been made of the suggestion Senator Tate, the then Minister for Justice, made in 1990 that ratification of the convention should be reserved—in other words, made subject—to the pre-eminent role of the family. It is difficult to see why this should be necessary when the fundamental role of the family is acknowledged in the convention as outlined above. It is useful to quote in full article 5 of the convention which stipulates:

States Parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family or community as provided for by local custom, legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child, to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognised in the present Convention.

I would have thought that was a very clear statement in the body of the convention of the rights and responsibilities of parents and the intimate relationship between parents and children which this convention seeks to safeguard. It is worth noting that this article was inserted in the convention at the initiative of the Australian delegation and no doubt at Senator Tate's instigation. In that connection, it is worth noting that if coalition speakers had continued the quotation from Senator Tate's speech they would have found a reference to the fact that the Australian delegation had inserted article 5 in the convention, and therefore that the reservation he had in mind was clearly not necessary.

PARA.TAB: In substantive terms, the family obviously provides the best protection for children, but there must be a very important proviso. In fact, it may have been a consideration when inserting this provision into the body of the convention and not reserving it that, while most children are protected and nurtured within a family environment, there is a substantial and tragic minority who need to be protected from their own parents and guardians and a government cannot diminish its capacity to provide this protection.
On 17 June this year, the Age reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: At least 20,000 Australian children were subjected to physical, emotional or sexual abuse or neglect in 1990-91 . . .

This was according to a national report on child abuse and neglect. The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare report found that most offences were committed by parents or guardians, except in the case of sexual abuse, where 89 per cent were attributed to friends and neighbours. The report showed that 49,721 cases of child abuse and neglect were reported to and investigated by state and territory departments in 1990-91. Of these, 18,273 children were involved in substantiated cases and a further 2,545 were assessed as being at risk, putting the abuse rate at five cases per 1,000 children aged up to 16.

PARA.TAB: This is a shameful and tragic state of affairs, and I believe that it is equally shameful for someone to suggest that we should slow down the process of monitoring how our various governments are trying to cope with the situation.
There is more such material on record. With respect to health and health services, the convention states:

SPEECH.PARA: The child has a right to the highest standard of health and medical care attainable. States shall place special emphasis on the provision of primary and preventative health care, public health education and the reduction of infant mortality.

The most basic indicators of child health place Australia l8th out of a possible 33 industrialised countries. The under-five mortality rate of 10 in 100 for the general population has to be compared with the really shameful and tragic fact that this figure doubles for rural Aboriginal children. The poor state of health of Australia's indigenous children relates to a disproportionate amount of poverty and homelessness amongst this group of children. Aboriginal child poverty is so severe that it prompted Dr Graham McIntosh to say that the findings of his research in South Australia resembled `a situation more commonly found in reports about poverty stricken Ethiopia than affluent Australia'. Professor of social work Jan Carter points out that `Aboriginal child poverty has been omitted from the government's strategy of child poverty'.

PARA.TAB: Statistics on immunisation rates in general, and in the Aboriginal community in particular, have also been criticised. So has the lack of preventative health services for children, guidance for parents on planned parenting, and the provision of primary health care information for children. Clearly, the government would do well to look at article 24 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which relates to the key characteristics of adequate health care, in conjunction with the independent report on our compliance, `Where rights are wronged', by the National Children's Bureau of Australia in March 1993, and to plan for better services in the future. I reiterate—it cannot be said too often—that the declaration by the minister was, and I trust will be after the vote today in this Senate, a significant step in monitoring the performance of our government to achieve the objectives of the convention. Any attempt to slow it down should be something about which those people trying to do it should consult their consciences.

I turn to housing. In his national inquiry into child homelessness, Commissioner Brian Burdekin revealed that youth homelessness was widespread. He suggested that it was caused in large part by family poverty, physical, emotional and sexual abuse, and the lack of adequate preventative programs for youth in crisis. His report estimated that there were at least 20,000 to 25,000 and perhaps as many as 70,000 homeless children and young people across the country, including at least 8,500 aged from 12 to 15. The fact that many children are forced to prostitute themselves for survival and that the incidence of sexual and physical violence against them is very high is, it need hardly be said, in obvious breach of the convention.
I turn to the topic of sexual exploitation. The convention states:

SPEECH.PARA: The state shall protect children from sexual exploitation and abuse, including prostitution and involvement in pornography.

Substantiated cases of sexual abuse in Australia, except ACT and Tasmania, in the year 1989-90 were for girls 3,100 and for boys 900. There was also a marked increase in the number of substantiated cases of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of girls aged 12 to 16 years, compared with other age groups. A greater emphasis on the convention, and a greater drive towards meeting our obligations under the convention, would serve Australia well.

PARA.TAB: I turn to juvenile justice. The convention states that a child in conflict with the law has the right to treatment which promotes the child's sense of dignity and worth, takes the child's age into account, and aims at his or her reintegration into society. The child is entitled to basic guarantees as well as legal or other assistance for his or her defence. I have already mentioned the Victorian and Western Australian government actions which have increased judicial control over children in what I believe to be the most inappropriate of ways. I further mention that the indeterminate sentences legislation in Victoria covers people of 17 years of age.

Article 12 of the convention relates to the right of the child to legal representation. As far as I am aware, no legislation that is now enacted by Australian parliaments places an obligation on police to ensure that detained children have access to independent legal advice or representation. There are many other matters in the legal system that we should advert to, but time does not permit.

I refer briefly to refugees. The detention of children seeking asylum in immigration processing centres for periods of up to three years is clearly in contravention of basic principles of human rights and justice, and of the element of the convention which guards against arbitrary detention.

The point needs to be made again that the declaration by the minister achieves nothing beyond enabling the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to monitor progress and to report on breaches against the convention to the minister. It also would give it the power to educate the community and to publicise the instances of obvious neglect of hundreds of thousands of Australian children which I have adverted to today.

I believe that we need to look very carefully—and that the coalition should look very carefully—at the action it proposes. It would not give the commission that capacity and would slow down that process. I believe the coalition, in concert with all representatives in this parliament, should be actively pursuing the government to resource the initiatives and to resource the process by which we will eventually comply with the objective of the convention, rather than bringing this despicable motion of disallowance which would remove one of the avenues of exerting pressure on this federal government and on state governments to take action to improve the life chances of Australian children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the amount of water I have consumed while I have been sitting here waiting and listening to Senator Spindler, my speech will probably be reasonably short. Senator Spindler has been talking about the effect, or the non-effect, of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. He said that it has no effect in Australia except to enforce the power to educate the community. I think the government has done a pretty fair job in that area. It does not need another convention to force it into educating the community in what is right and what is wrong with our children. If the convention has no effect, why did we sign it? Why have we gone to all this trouble? Why have we been standing here this morning and talking for 2 1/2 or three hours if it has no effect?

PARA.TAB: Of course it has an effect. In my own state of Tasmania I have already seen the effect of these United Nations conventions that we have signed. The convention gives the Commonwealth the chance to override states' powers. The reason why so many people are concerned about this convention is that there is a possibility that it will take away the rights of parents. That has been mentioned by my colleagues and by people in the community. Unfortunately, because this convention has come forward in the way it has and because we cannot amend it, we have no alternative but to move for a disallowance of the convention and the power given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to enforce it.

In this day and age in Australia, ordinary parents like me and my colleague Senator Herron, who is the father of 10 children, are concerned about their rights concerning their families. Under Labor governments for the last 10 years, we have seen the powers of the family being eroded by unemployment and by other people in the community telling us what to do, taking away our rights as parents, trying to tell us how we should bring up our children and those sorts of things. Now we are getting to the stage where we have international courts, high courts, federal courts and conventions all telling us what we should and should not do with our children. The only court that really counts, as far as children and child abuse are concerned, is the criminal court. It is fully occupied with taking action against all the sorts of things Senator Spindler raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is where your actions are leading us.

—I have no argument with that. The honourable senator and Senator Bolkus have been telling us today about the 20,000-odd children in our community who have been abused. On this side of politics, we know all that. We are very sympathetic towards them, but the criminal courts in each state are doing a very good job in trying to cope with that.
—The courts are your only answer.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is getting a bit hard to talk with his yapping in my left ear all the time. I would like to be able to concentrate on what I am trying to say.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Senator Calvert, would you address your comments to me and, Senator Spindler, would you please refrain from interjecting. You know that it is not orderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sat in my place without saying a word while Senator Spindler was speaking but he rudely interrupted me. Obviously, he is very sensitive about this matter.

PARA.TAB: Families have been coming to me. Senator Watson summed it all up. He has had hundreds of letters. So have I and so has just about everybody else. People fear that their rights as parents are being taken away. The reservations of the Holy See were quoted. Today it has been said on my left that Senator Tate was misquoted. I will read what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I anticipate that when the Australian Government ratifies the convention, should it do so, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It would be surprising were that not the case . . .

He went on, and it was said that we misquoted him. The fact is that I spoke to Senator Tate privately about it afterwards and he did have reservations. There is no question about that. We had reservations before the last election and we said so. We said that, if we got into government, we would put those reservations in the convention and then we would go ahead and ratify it. On 21 February 1991, Mr Peacock, the honourable member for Kooyong in the other place, made it quite clear when he said this:

There is no doubt that the aims of the convention are quite laudable. Had we been in government we would have ratified the convention, but we would have ratified it with reservations to particular articles of fundamental importance to the interpretation of that convention.
That has been our clear understanding all the way through. This was reiterated by our present shadow Attorney-General, Mr Williams QC, on 1 September this year when he said:
At the outset, I wish to make it clear that the coalition is not opposed to the convention itself. This has always been the case.

Those two quotes, and what has been said today by my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Vanstone, have made it quite clear that we genuinely support this convention. But our position in relation to reservations has always been apparent right from the start.

PARA.TAB: The convention is a further development of the declaration of Geneva relating to the rights of the child, which was adopted as long ago as 1924 as a response to the problems being suffered by children after World War I. These problems have not stopped; they have continued right through to this very day. In 1959 the United Nations adopted its own declaration of the rights of the child which related to 10 principles to guide parents, governments and others in the treatment of their children. So this is nothing new. As Senator Boswell said, in 1979 the United Nations Human Rights Committee commenced drafting the current convention relating to children's rights. We all know that that convention was unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 20 November 1989, and came into force internationally on 2 September 1990.

Naturally, some components of the convention relating to behaviour patterns would be almost unanimously supported by the general community. In particular, such matters as child prostitution and child slavery are referred to in the convention. My colleague from the Australian Democrats has concerns about this. I know that the government has been concerned about this. Members of the government have travelled to Asia. The Minister for Justice, Mr Kerr, went to Asia recently to look at the problems regarding Australians, in particular, sexually abusing child prostitutes in Thailand. The government has been taking steps to do all this.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, if this convention has no power, why the hell are we signing it? Why are we leaving ourselves open to the possibility of its being used and having the unintended consequences that we have seen in other conventions? The Catholic Church—the Holy See—and some members of the Presbyterian Church in my own state have all had concerns about this and they have relayed them to me and to other members of the parliament. They are not doing it because they do not believe in the rights of the child; they are not doing it because they do not believe in parliament having the power to impose sensible laws on the population; they are doing it because they are genuinely concerned about the possibility that some rights unintentionally may be taken away from the parents.

People have said to me recently that they do not want their rights as parents to be interfered with, or to be told by the United Nations how to bring up their children. It is getting harder and harder, with the social pressures, unemployment and the like, to be a good parent and to run a family these days. But I think the record of the family unit in Australia has been second to none in the world. The two basic things that most people in this country hold dear are the freedom of religion and the freedom to be a good parent. In the last two days we have had before us two conventions which try to tell Australians how they should conduct their religion and how they should bring up their children. That is what people are objecting to: being told by the United Nations—in this case, through this government—what they should be doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the children who die at the hands of their parents?

—If this particular convention were going to stop one person from dying at the hands of his own parents, I would not be standing here talking about it this morning. There are enough laws about that and enough publicity in the community at the moment. Everybody in the country is well aware of the disgraceful things that have been happening in recent times. The situation is brought about mainly by the pressures put upon these parents by the economic situation that this government has caused in this country in the last 10 years. That is the reason.

PARA.TAB: We are stuck with this convention. We have got no alternative on our side of politics, because of our concerns, but to vote to disallow the regulations. We are not against the principle of the whole thing, it is just the way in practice that this convention may be interpreted. I do not believe that if we disallow this convention it is the end of the world. For the life of me I cannot understand why the government did not insert reservations, just as the Holy See did. We would have been supporting it. If the government were so concerned about the rights of the child why would it not take the advice of some of its own members, in particular former Senator Tate?

TALK.START.PARA: —His Excellency.
—Yes, His Excellency, former Senator Tate. I thank Senator Colston. In summing up there are three critical areas which I believe need to be addressed by this government.
—Would this make you a better parent?

—I doubt very much whether it would do what Senator Panizza suggests. As I see it, the three critical areas are, firstly, that there is an overlap between the convention and some existing Australian statutes which has not been resolved. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre, which was engaged by the government in 1991 to review the convention and its implications for Australian law, has yet to finalise its report. That is how difficult the matter is—after nearly three years it has still not come up with what the effect will be.

PARA.TAB: The next major issue is that there is no express recognition of the rights and responsibilities of parents in certain crucial articles of the convention. This should have been the subject of a reservation by the government. We believe that the best action for the government would be to review the convention immediately and ensure that Australian laws are consistent with its provisions and are capable of being correctly interpreted. It should also ensure that there is no need for the convention to be given a wide range of Australian law or to work against the wide range of Australian law which already exists. I look forward to hearing the contribution from my fellow senator from Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that Senator Calvert expected my appearance but I accept his good wishes anyway. I speak in opposition to the motion to disallow the government's initiative to incorporate the UN declaration on the child into the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. It is important that we remove some of the fog and misinformation that surround this debate and start by looking at exactly what this initiative does.

PARA.TAB: Australia ratified the convention in 1990, after it was adopted unanimously by the United Nations in 1989. This is not a new convention; we have been a signatory to it since 1990. What has occurred is that in January of this year the government sought to incorporate that convention into the charter of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, to give effect to that convention. That is important because it provides for a more detailed statement of the rights of a child beyond those contained in the international covenant, but most importantly it provides government support to give effect to monitoring the rights of the child recognised in that convention.

What we have heard from the Liberal Party today is that it supports the rhetoric, it supports the convention, but if the government moves to do anything about that rhetoric to actually give it some force and some teeth, it will oppose it. Liberal Party members do not mind mouthing the rhetoric, but they are opposed to enforcing the principles that underline the declaration. If they were opposed to the convention, the time to oppose it was in 1990, but they were full of good words then. Today they are full of good words about the intent, but they have difficulties with the detail.

What they have difficulties with is our actually ensuring that the rights of children provided for in the convention are given effect to. That is what this does; it allows the human rights commission to give effect to those rights which we were all happy to accept and to monitor the government's performance in giving effect to those rights. It does not tell the parents what to do or how to bring up their children. It monitors the government's performance in honouring its obligations to the UN convention which we all agreed was worthwhile and deserving of signature in 1990. So that is what this debate is about.

Unfortunately, I do not think opposition members really have their hearts in this; some of them do because they come from a principle of opposition to the UN, some sort of xenophobia about anything outside Australia.
