But I think the more small-l liberal members of the opposition have a great deal of difficulty with the opposition's position on this. When you look at the speeches of Senator Vanstone and Daryl Williams QC, as with the debate on the declaration of religion, their hearts are not in this because really it is a very conservative, very reactionary step to oppose what the government has done on this occasion.

As I say, they support the rhetoric but the best they can do in opposing this is talk about the lack of clarity, express some reservations, talk about some community concerns and some lack of understanding about the UN conventions and their role in Australia. That is all very fine but they never actually get to the heart of it. They say they support the UN declaration on the child, but when we want to do something about it they look for pseudo-legalistic arguments to try to prevent us actually giving some teeth and some effect to that convention.

People like Senator Watson have put a genuinely held view about concerns about the rights of parents. I accept that there has been some community concern about the effect of that declaration but that concern is totally misplaced; it is totally based on the misinformation and fog that has surrounded this issue. It is one of the most highly supported declarations throughout the world. Even the Holy See has seen fit to ratify the convention so this is not something Australians ought to be concerned about. There is no negative effect on the rights of parents.

In support of that, in reply to some of the arguments that have been put it is important for people to understand what article 5 of the convention states. That is an article amended in part by an Australian initiative to overcome some of the concerns people had. Article 5 of the convention states:

SPEECH.PARA: States Parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family or community as provided for by local custom, legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child, to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognised in the present Convention.

That is a clear recognition of the role of parents. The convention does not tell parents how to raise their children; it tells governments how to fulfil their responsibilities to children in our society.

PARA.TAB: When looking at the opposition arguments in this matter, they fail to raise any widespread or authoritative community support for their position. We have all had letters from members of the community concerned about this issue, but the way to deal with that is to explain to them properly the impact of the convention and how this will impact on Australian society, not to act as a conduit for their fear and misunderstanding. Some leadership is required, and I will come to that issue again later. But what are the people in Australian society with an interest in this issue saying? I think the first thing I will do is briefly quote the Law Council of Australia.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity today to talk in the public interest debate on a very significant report that has recently been compiled by commercial and private interests in my electorate, the Northern Territory. This report refers specifically the economic impact of Ranger, Australia's largest uranium mine, and is entitled, The contribution of the Ranger uranium mine to the Northern Territory and Australian economies. The report is a 71-page study that was prepared for the mining company Energy Resources of Australia Ltd by the Canberra based consultants ACIL. This report describes the good neighbour role of Ranger, a controversial but commercially significant mine in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: The report estimates the economic contribution of this Northern Territory mine over its first 11 years, as well as the flow-on benefits to Aboriginal people. In today's money terms, the mine has contributed the equivalent of $5.3 billion to the national economy. It has paid $86 million in royalties to the Northern Territory government and has accounted for seven per cent of the Northern Territory's economic activity.

I am particularly aware of the very great contribution that has arisen through the consequential activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which has a very important environmental monitoring role, and has in effect come about because of the life of this mine. Significant also is the role of the tourism that has been generated because of the very important presence of the uranium mine and the associated activities that have been connected both with the mine activity and tourism activity through the infrastructure in the adjoining township of Jabiru.

Very important for both the Aboriginal people of Arnhem Land and the new residents of the township of Jabiru are the associated health and education facilities that have been injected into this important region. Much has been said about the potential of uranium mining in this country, but I would like to concentrate today on Aboriginal people and the benefits flowing to them via the royalties and the rentals from Ranger.

I refer specifically to the report. There are some very significant points in the introduction, including the estimated magnitude of Ranger's contributions to GDP and government revenue. There is also a chart that refers to the main components of the Ranger project's economic contribution to June 1992, which is highlighted in 1991-92 money terms.

The chart on page 12 of the report highlights the total of ERA revenue and expenses from 1981-82 to 1991-92. That chart deals with the revenue in historical value terms and also the value in current money terms. It compares the revenue, the production expenses, the various expenses of the mine, the dividends paid and the value-added components.

The charts that are set out in detail on pages 53 to 56 highlight in particular the various benefits that flow through what is called the Northern Territory input-output table, across all the significant industries: meat, cattle, fishing, hunting, manufacturing, wholesale, construction, transport, communications, finance, machinery and equipment, residential construction, health and education, entertainment, and many others.

In referring to Aboriginal people, I would like to highlight that in 1978 an agreement was negotiated between the Commonwealth government and the Northern Land Council to allow mining on the Ranger project area. The agreement covered the payment of rent and royalties, environmental controls, Aboriginal employment and training, liaison between mining and Aboriginal interests, and education of mining employees about Aboriginal culture. Since then, Aboriginal groups have received in royalties the equivalent of $288 million in today's money terms. According to the report, Ranger payments represent `a very significant proportion of the incomes received by the traditional landowners of Ranger, the Northern Land Council and the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory as a whole'.

To refer again to the report, on pages 57 to 59 there are important schedules and tables setting out the income, the expenditure and employment in three of the four Northern Territory Aboriginal land councils—the Northern Land Council, the Central Land Council and the Tiwi Land Council—which have all benefited very significantly and directly from the activities of the Ranger mine. With millions of dollars passing through the Aboriginal benefits trust account on behalf of Aboriginal people, it is important that the ABTA have the full confidence and trust of Aboriginal people. Yet, unfortunately, this is not the case. A number of senior and credible Aboriginal leaders in the Northern Territory have come to me recently with concerns about the administration and the operation of the Aboriginal benefits trust account.

Based on their information and the evidence that I have uncovered during Senate estimates hearings, my concerns were conveyed earlier this year to the Aboriginal affairs minister, Mr Tickner. He has since ordered an investigation by the Auditor-General into the ABTA and into the land council administration. I understand that the outcome should be known later this year and will be tabled in this parliament.

I would now like to turn to one of the Aboriginal success stories in the Northern Territory, particularly related to the Ranger project. The Gagudju Association, set up in 1979 on behalf of traditional owners of the Ranger project area, has the role of administering agreement and royalty moneys from mining at Ranger. It is up to the 330 members of that association to decide how the money is spent. According to the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Association has a balanced expenditure policy which includes disbursement of moneys for the immediate benefit of individuals or communities in the Association and investments in a range of economic activities.
Elsewhere the report states:
Investments of Ranger royalty and rental funds made by the Gagudju Association in particular will safeguard the welfare of local landowners for years beyond the mine's life.

So far, the Gagudju Association investments have included the establishment of a children's trust to safeguard children's share of payments received, as only adults can be members of the Gagudju Association, and tourist ventures such as Gagudju Cooinda Lodge and the Gagudju Crocodile Hotel. I am sure that many honourable senators and many other people in the Australian community are well aware of these important and first-class facilities now operating in close proximity to the Ranger mine.

PARA.TAB: There are other business ventures, such as a mobile food store, the Border Store in the East Alligator River area, mechanical and civil engineering workshops, a construction business, a buffalo farm, and real estate purchases in Darwin. Given the long-term nature of these investment decisions, it is not surprising that individual members of the Gagudju Association receive only a modest annual income payment of between $1,000 and $2,000 a year.

I would like to commend Gagudju on providing members with potential long-term opportunities for employment, particularly in the tourist industry, as well as a measure of economic independence rarely found in remote Aboriginal communities. Ranger's contribution to all Australians cannot be underestimated. Importantly, that significant contribution to Australia, whether it is through taxation, through mining activity directly or indirectly or through infrastructure support, is all highlighted in the report that is here today.

It is certainly a matter of regret that Labor's three-mine uranium policy acts today as a heavy hand of control over the development of this important uranium industry. This report highlights the benefits that flow, whether through direct job employment, through the community in so many ways or to Aboriginal communities directly, but that are currently being thwarted.

In a question in this House earlier this week, I highlighted the hypocrisy of the Labor government in its current policies with regard to uranium and the uranium industry. Very importantly, this government has lifted the sanctions on South Africa. That means that Australia will now be in open competition, as it should be, for all commodities, including mining products and including the trade in uranium. It means that South Africa now enters an open forum in this important area.

Yet, at the same time, the Labor Party has decided to keep the lid on uranium in Australia, thereby denying very important opportunities to so many areas. The government's hypocrisy in the way in which it has dealt with the South African issue and yet has a very different, discriminatory policy against Aboriginal people in Australia, who would be significant beneficiaries of an open policy on uranium mining, stands out for everyone to see.

I look forward to the day when new uranium mining is allowed to open in this country so that Australians can benefit further from this important industry. The report that I have highlighted, which deals with the contribution of the Ranger uranium mine to the Northern Territory and Australian economies, is significant. I seek leave of the Senate to table this report.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the report entitled Report of Investigations into Complaints arising from Demonstrations held at Aidex, November 1991, issued by the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I welcome the Ombudsman's report of these investigations as a careful, thorough and constructive assessment. I seek leave to table the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arms exhibition, which touted Australia as a weapons dealer and armaments manufacturer to this region and to the world at large, attracted some 1,200 demonstrators from peace, disarmament, church, political and union groups. Some 400 officers were deployed during the demonstrations. Honourable senators may recall that I and some other Democrat senators spent as much time as parliamentary duties would allow at the AIDEX demonstrations and that I reported then to the Senate my observation that police were using excessive force.

PARA.TAB: I vividly recall one occasion when some teenagers lined up behind me saying, `They will not hit us if you are standing in front of us'. The Commonwealth ombudsman, Philippa Smith, describes `the painful and potentially injurious holds' members of the Australian Federal Police employed, even on compliant protesters, including wrist locks, angle of the jaw pressure, hair pulling, ear pulling, kneeing and so on. She describes it in dispassionate language, which is nonetheless chilling. It is confirmation of my own observation that in many instances police officers went beyond their proper professional role and adopted the attitude of combatants in a battle, often exacerbated by lack of planning and supervision and a clear chain of command, as well as inadequate training and inadequate arrest procedures and lack of identification.

In a response which goes a long way towards the code of conduct I called for at the time, the ombudsman says in a letter to me that the AFP has received her report constructively and that discussions are under way to take action to improve these aspects. The ombudsmen also acknowledges that in many cases police officers were provoked by some protesters and that some 40 officers sustained injuries in the subsequent scuffles. The point remains that police officers must have the capacity to respond in a professional manner, and that people exercising their democratic right of political protest should not be intimidated or injured.
In all, 169 people lodged complaints against police behaviour. There were 410 separate allegations, and I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Of these, 78 have been found to be unsubstantiated, 157 to be incapable of determination, 6 have been found to be substantiated and 1 reconciled. Discretion has been exercised under section 24 of the Complaints Act not to investigate 84 complaints involving 168 allegations, mostly because the complainant could not be contacted or a person more directly involved in the incident had complained. Six people have withdrawn their complaints. Action has still to be completed in 8 cases.

The large number of unresolved complaints is due, in large measure, to the high standard of proof—namely, beyond reasonable doubt—now employed in the assessment of complaints against police. Given the importance of maintaining community confidence in the integrity of our police force, the civil balance of probability standard would seem more appropriate, and I understand that this is now under consideration.

PARA.TAB: The large number of complaints directed through my office—that is, 114—points to one other large area of concern highlighted in the ombudsman's report, namely the investigation of complaints against police by the AFP's own internal investigation unit and the reluctance of potential complainants to make complaints against Caesar and have them investigated by Caesar. In real terms, channelling the complaints really only made sure that the complaints went to the right address and also made it possible for me to receive progress reports from the ombudsman's office. It is, however, important to appreciate that the motivation for people to channel their complaints through my office was the desire to avoid harassment by police who may have become aware of the identity of the complainants. Indeed, I have received reports of two occasions where local protesters were subsequently accosted by police but significantly, they did not wish to pursue the matter for fear of further harassment.

The other motivation was the wish to ensure, as far as possible, that proper investigation is undertaken—something that I could not influence, of course, to any great degree. Again, the community's perception is important. Ombudsman Philippa Smith devotes a substantial part of her report to this aspect. She details the lack of objectivity of some investigatory reports which were disregarding and distorting evidence and slanting it in favour of police colleagues. She also adverts to the delays caused by the lack of investigatory staff, the lack of the management control system for the investigating process and last, but not least, the lack of staff in her own office.

I have already mentioned that the burden of proof for complaints is likely to receive early attention. It is pleasing to note also that a joint ombudsman-AFP working party will examine the training and case management procedures of the internal investigation unit. It remains for me to urge strongly that the ombudsman must have the capacity to act on her own initiative in cases of complaints against police, as the ombudsman has in all other areas. This applies in particular to the investigation of complaints which the ombudsman might wish to pursue when a parallel complaint has been lodged by another person. At the moment this choice is not open to the ombudsman.

The other necessary and urgent action is to increase the staff resources of the office to ensure that as much of the investigation as possible is carried out by the ombudsman's office. These measures are essential if the community is to maintain—or, in many cases, regain—respect and confidence in our police forces and in the safeguards of our democratic system to ensure that the democratic right to political protest is not eroded.

May I say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is refreshing in this instance to see that an agency such as the ombudsman's office is not content simply to provide a report, but has become actively engaged in follow-up work to ensure that some of the deficiencies that have been identified are in fact addressed. In large measure this satisfies my own requirement, which I suggested at the time, of a code of conduct for such occasions. In conclusion, I wish to state that the thoroughness and objectivity of this report, and the constructive improvement already under way as a result, have done a lot to bolster my own confidence in the safeguards of our democratic system, and have given me new motivation to build on this and to improve current arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly to Senator Spindler's comments. If he had said that he was appalled by the behaviour of some of these demonstrators who used violence in order to pursue a political objective, and appalled by their treatment of police who were simply seeking to do their job, then much of what he said in the remainder of his speech about how the ombudsman's office might be further strengthened and so forth would have been a useful contribution to debate. To leave simply Senator Spindler's words on the record would result in an unbalanced and unfair impression in relation to the very difficult circumstances with which the police here in Canberra were faced in this demonstration.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler said that individuals were exercising their democratic right of political protest. We have no objection to an exercise of the democratic right of political protest. In fact, we all stand firm in our belief that it is essential to preserving our democracy. But in this country the democratic right of political protest does not include the level of violence that was demonstrated by these demonstrators—violence that resulted, as the ombudsman admitted, in some 40 police officers receiving broken bones, bites, grazes and strains.

One can go on with other reports. I was not present at the demonstration, but these are reports of other people who, with Senator Spindler, were personally present. Apart from the broken bones, stabs, grazes, chemical burns and bruises, there were reports in the Canberra Times of police officers being sprayed with urine and faeces, and of roads being blockaded with buses, cars and metal to try to prevent police intervention. Not surprisingly, there were reports of police being verbally and physically abused. There were also reports of protesters placing booby traps in pine trees along Northbourne Avenue; of police finding pieces of wood with nails embedded in them buried at the protest site to take out police bikes; of mature trees cut down to obstruct police; and of protesters throwing missiles at police, including avocados studded with nails, syringes and barbed wire.

This is appalling and unacceptable behaviour in any form of political protest in this country in any circumstances. At the start of his speech, Senator Spindler should have risen in this place and unambiguously condemned it, then he could have gone on and talked about the police needing to learn from this unsatisfactory state of affairs. Maybe that would have been, with respect, a more useful contribution. That behaviour should be condemned.

It is a matter of regret, I think, that the ombudsman obviously determined that it was out of her charter to provide the balance in her report. She acknowledged that some 40 police officers received broken bones, bites, grazes and strains, but continued:

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is not part of my task in this overview to pass any judgment on the actions of the demonstrators, or any other civilians.

That may be how she has interpreted her task; I am not here to take issue with that at the moment. What I am taking issue with is, when we analyse her report and her advice to police on how they might act in similar circumstances if, regrettably, they again occur in this country, we should nevertheless take into account the very severe and almost unique provocation that they received in this instance.

PARA.TAB: Police in this country simply are not experienced in handling riotous behaviour. Political demonstrations in this country by our standard of values are peaceful; they are there to achieve a particular objective. They are not conducted in a violent way and that is what the police are not used to.

It is interesting that this protest followed shortly upon a violent protest in Melbourne at the visit of President Bush of the United States. I understand many of the protesters who tried to influence political events in Melbourne by violent means were in fact the same protesters who moved to Canberra for that purpose. That is a worrying development in this country.

I thought it was interesting to note the comments of some of the police officers after the Victorian protest. The Victorian acting chief commissioner, John Frame, said he was proud of his people and said, `Quite frankly, I'm absolutely sickened by the violence displayed towards the police'. Why did not Senator Spindler say he was sickened by the violence displayed towards the police rather than what he did say today, that he regarded the conduct of the police as chilling. I want to say that I understand what Mr Frame was saying in relation to the Victorian circumstance, and I can understand how the senior officers of the Federal Police in the ACT would have been equally appalled by the conduct of these protesters towards police officers here.

Mr Frame went on to say, `We don't use riot squads in this state'—he was talking about the Victorian experience—`and I hope there will never be a need for our police to act as riot squads in this country'. One way to ensure that does not occur is to have people get up in this place and condemn such violent protests as totally illegitimate within our political system. I hope next time Senator Spindler gets up he does exactly that. Mr Frame continued, `I'm not prepared to have our young members made punching bags'. I think that is a more than reasonable expectation of any senior police officer in relation to his men.

I understand that the violence in these two demonstrations was organised. I accept there were a lot of protesters within the 1,200 estimated to be there who were not violent. They were doing what I would stand up and support—protesting against political action that they disagreed with. It is a pity that a minority, apparently organised, it is said, by the international socialist movement, decided to bring violence as a means of achieving political outcomes into the Australian political framework. It is that minority that I am standing here to condemn today.

I hope that all senators and, in future, Senator Spindler, will be prepared to join with me in condemning that violence. When we pass judgment on how the police responded to that violence, we should recognise not only the uniqueness of the circumstances which they were facing, which were therefore unexpected, but also what an appalling set of circumstances they had to face.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Hill's remarks. I did say in my statement that the police officers were provoked, but I did not expand on it. I do not really need his challenge to condemn violent behaviour by demonstrators. I believe it is highly regrettable that that occurred. What is at issue is how our police forces deal with such behaviour. It is very clear—and it would be supported by anyone, including me—that police officers should use as much force as is necessary to contain such behaviour.

PARA.TAB: The issue here is that some police officers—not all police officers, just as it is not all demonstrators—have been violent. In fact, it was only a very small minority, as Senator Hill has said. The issue is that police have used excessive force to contain that behaviour, due to lack of planning, lack of training, inexperienced personnel or lack of a proper chain of command. It is important that these matters are pointed out so that we have an improvement in these arrangements in future.

The topic on which I rise today follows on from a matter I raised about three weeks ago during the adjournment debate. I accused Mr Garswood and Mr Beazley of doing an overt, if not covert, deal to ensure that Mr Beazley was returned. Having examined the flow of the preferences quite accurately since I made that speech, I find it is quite clear that Mr Garswood's preferences did play a very significant role in ensuring that Mr Beazley was returned to take up his present role as the Minister for Education, Employment and Training.

I would like to apprise the Senate of a bit more information that has come to light. Mr Garswood and Mr Beazley have both denied that there was any sort of deal. One would not expect Mr Garswood or Mr Beazley to come out and say, `Yes, Senator Campbell was dead right. We did shake hands and make a deal'. So that is not surprising. I thought it would be good for the Senate to see that Luke Garswood did indeed direct his preferences quite clearly to Mr Beazley. I have the how-to-vote card. It took quite a search to find it but I was able to locate one. I have sought the minister's approval to incorporate the how-to-vote card in Hansard, if it is technically possible. There is a picture of Mr Garswood on the card, so to incorporate it may not be technically possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made some inquiries and I think there are some technical difficulties. Perhaps the honourable senator would be kind enough to table the document instead of incorporating it. It is difficult to produce a facsimile of it in Hansard when it includes a photograph and so on.

—I seek the leave of the chamber because there is another reason why I would like it incorporated. PARA.TAB: I have, as a good citizen, referred this matter to the Electoral Commission to ensure that Mr Garswood complies with the law or, indeed, the penalty which would go along with it. I certainly hope compulsorily collected guild fees and National Union of Students affiliation fees are not used to help pay Mr Garswood's fine, which I am sure he, as a law-abiding citizen, would comply with. I would ask the minister for approval to

SPEECH.PARA: incorporate this material as far as is technically possible, because I think it is quite important. If Mr Garswood's youthful face needs to be deleted from the how-to-vote card, I am not going to complain about that; the rest of it is simple black-and-white typesetting.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could leave a blank space in which you could sketch it in!

—That is right. Having spent some time in talking to Luke Garswood—or in our yelling at each other at the rally—I am sure Mr Garswood would be happy to have the facts set straight for the Australian people. I seek leave to have the how-to-vote card incorporated in Hansard.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROAD TRANSPORT REFORM (VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as you well know, the road transport industry is in many respects the lifeblood of this nation. That is especially clear to those of us who come from the less populous states, such as the Northern Territory from where the minister comes, which are large in area but small in population. It is clear to those who come from Western Australia, like my good friend Senator Panizza, who frequently speaks on road transport issues and who I understand is following me in this debate.

PARA.TAB: We understand the importance of having a road transport regime in terms of regulation which works, which is responsive to the methods of the industry and, importantly, which is responsive to the needs of the consumers of that industry. Of course, the consumers of road transport industry services are the businesses, be they large or small, which are at the end of the transport routes. It is important from the point of view of this nation's wellbeing that we reduce as much as possible our road transport costs.

It is also generally accepted, particularly by the industry itself, that there is some necessity for uniformity in road transport regulations. I know that some of the proposed uniformities have been a matter of much contention across the floor of this chamber. Senator Collins will recall as well as I do the arguments we had in 1990 and 1991 in relation to the road transport charges and the proposed fees that were set out in that. The Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Bill does not really touch on the charges, but sets out to make it possible to create a uniform set of road regulations which have been agreed to by the states. The intention is that those uniform regulations would be adopted in modules in relation to particular areas.

Those of us in the coalition have looked at the matter very carefully. In our party room there was careful consideration of this because of the concerns of a number of states. For example, Western Australia is not endorsing the heads of agreement which have been put together and are the basis of the bill which is brought before the chamber today.

I note that the Minister for Transport in Western Australia, the Hon. Eric Charlton, wrote on 31 August to the National Road Transport Commission advising that Western Australia's position was not `derived from any desire to undermine the national reform process or obligations arising from the heads of government agreements'. He did point out, however, that Western Australia's position was different because `the geography and demography of this state are sufficiently different to warrant, on occasion, different transport solutions from the rest of the country'. I think that is a viewpoint that is reflected by many of the other states. I know that in South Australia there was concern about implementation of all of the proposals and, similarly, in Tasmania and New South Wales.

What I am saying is that this proposal will be agreed to by the opposition but we note that there is still far from unanimity amongst the states, and these are matters that will have to be worked through. We cannot have a situation arise where uniformity becomes all important and the needs and interests of the states are subjugated to that. For example, in Queensland we have a system of volumetric loading—as you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, being a Liberal Party senator from Queensland. Volumetric loading is important, particularly in the livestock industry. The ability to load one or two decks of cattle on the truck and get the truck away is very useful. It makes the transport industry much more efficient and it reduces the transport cost to the consumers of the services, namely, the beef cattle industry.

At the moment we need to keep transport costs down in the beef cattle industry because the prices themselves are low. It would be a nonsensical position if uniformity in road regulations meant that Queensland could not keep volumetric loading, because the roads, the conditions and the needs of the industries all suit volumetric loading. A lot of work has been done on that and it has worked very well.

I know that in Queensland at the moment the government is reviewing some of the consequences of volumetric loading. You would be interested to know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that as a consequence of taking away the gross vehicle mass restrictions through volumetric loading, the tare weight of some of the stock crates has gone up immensely. So there are now vehicles and trailers that have a very large tare weight. It is my understanding from the road transport forum that one of the things the state government is looking at is restricting the tare weight, but not the gross weight, of those stock crates. We are finding that some stock crates are built basically around a very large RSJ—a reinforced steel joist—and as a consequence are very hard to destroy. However, they are putting immense weight on the roads.That was not the intention of volumetric loading. Obviously, this is something that will be addressed in the future.

I know this is going to cause a little bit of concern and angst in the industry because many people have invested in these stock crates; and they are a substantial investment. Four or five years ago when I was involved in the manufacture of stock crates, we were selling a stock crate for something like $60,000. Obviously, the cost is higher these days. But if the tare weight of those stock crates can be reduced, obviously my position, the position of the National Party and the position of the industry would be that there would have to be a transitional period. What we are saying is that we do not want uniformity to swamp the advances that are being made in some states and we do not want uniformity to be an excuse to make the industry less responsive.

I know that New South Wales is also grappling with the issue of volumetric loading. I know that agreement has not been reached yet in New South Wales. But, if New South Wales decides to adopt this measure, it may take it on a different basis from Queensland. That is because the geography of New South Wales is different. Its main transport routes are much hillier than those of Queensland. There are particular difficulties in terms of the loading of vehicles which have to be addressed.

In Queensland we sometimes think that our roads are not particularly satisfactory, and many of them are not. However, having taken a trip recently along the Newell Highway, I know that there are many other roads in this country that are not as good as we would hope, and particular safety issues arise as a result of that. Again, safety issues have to be taken into consideration when regulations are being put into place, and that is why I believe that much more needs to be done in terms of getting uniform road regulations. The peak body of the road transport industry, the road transport forum, has been very supportive of uniform regulations and there are very good reasons why they should be implemented.

A transport operator in Queensland, having equipment that is lawful in Queensland, may have difficulties when he goes over the border into another state. Nobody in the industry sees any benefit in regulations restricting the right or the ability of operators to ply their trade in more than one state. That is something we have to look at, particularly as in many industries now there is a lot of interstate movement of road freight. In the livestock industry there has been a lot of interstate movement of road freight in the last 12 months because cattle have been taken from Queensland to areas as far away as the Murrumbidgee to be put on agistment. So these are not theoretical issues but very real issues which go to the right of people in the road transport industry to earn a decent living.

I want to go through some of the bits and pieces of the legislation. In division 2, clauses 15, 16 and 17 relate to emergency powers, application orders and exemptions. The first two are subject to termination by the ministerial council whereas the latter is not. This will remain under the control of state ministers, I understand. I note that Senator Collins is nodding and I thank him for that. That is the way it should be. The road transport forum does not quite agree with this because it sees it as compromising the integrity of the system. But I think that even the road transport industry has to accept the fact that particular circumstances will arise from time to time and will have to be catered for and they may vary from state to state.

Ultimately, the development of a national approach has to involve making judgments that are determined by the national interest. We have a difficult situation because the interests of individual states have to be balanced against the interests of the nation as a whole. The states have a lot of work to do. We all hope that a productive exchange will arise from this and that we will find productive and innovative solutions. I think the minister would agree that innovation will solve many of the problems. Rather than thinking in standard and established ways, maybe we need to look at different methods, in the same way as the road transport industry itself has looked at different methods of getting around problems, such as different combinations of rig and so on, to ensure that the vehicles that operate on particular routes are the ones best suited for the job, ones that give higher efficiency and ultimately better benefits to the consumers.

In agreeing to the passage of this bill, the National and Liberal parties recognise the concerns of the individual states and of some transport operators. We recognise that regional circumstances and requirements must be taken into consideration and must not be ridden roughshod over. However, the politics of the national interest and ultimately the interest of the road transport industry have led us to agree to this bill. But we believe that we have an obligation to the industry, as we have always supported the industry in the past, to express its concerns and viewpoints in the course of this debate. I have nothing more to say other than that we hope there will be continued cooperation between the states, the federal government and the road transport industry and that the consequence of this legislation will be of benefit to all concerned—the consumers and the operators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not scheduled to speak in this debate. I know that my colleague Senator Panizza wants to contribute. However, as he is not in the chamber at the moment, I will speak briefly to the broad question of funding for road transport and other matters that are the subject of the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Bill 1993. As my colleague Senator O'Chee has mentioned, there is a desire right throughout Australia to seek some uniformity, but not uniformity at the expense of particular matters that are specific to individual states. That desire for uniformity is in the national interest and is part of the economic reform which this government talks a lot about; it has not done much about it but it certainly talks a lot about it. The Liberal and National parties support the general thrust of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: We are, of course, concerned that there is never quite enough money for road transport generally, which is the lifeblood of Australia's economic system. Road transport enables our exports to get from the farm and from the factory to the wharf for shipping overseas. Of course, the Labor government has again cut back road funding in this budget. So along with many other things for which this government can be condemned—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, yes!

—The minister agrees. He will appreciate the condemnation that all Australians are directing towards his government as a result of the budget. Included in that condemnation—although not being accorded the same profile, as obviously the Democrats and the Greens have no interest in roads or exports—is the quite disastrous cutback in funding for roads. I support what my colleague Senator O'Chee had to say about the coalition's attitude to this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that I speak for Senator Panizza, in his absence, in saying that I know that he, too, would support this legislation. I do thank Senator O'Chee and Senator Ian Macdonald for their contributions to the debate. What Senator O'Chee has said is perfectly correct. The industry does support this legislation and, frankly, it is entitled to get it. The reason I say that is that there are two aspects of the national approach: one to do with charges and one to do with regulations. Particularly in terms of the short-term benefits to the industry itself in getting a sensible regime of uniform regulations across Australia, I think those benefits will be far more quickly realised in the regulation area than in the charging area because the new charges are not proposed to commence until 1995.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say to Senator O'Chee that I was able to speak to all the state transport ministers last week. I met personally with most of them. Unfortunately, I could not fit Tasmania in but I did speak to the Tasmanian minister by telephone. All those state ministers reaffirmed the support of their governments for the national approach. However, the point Senator O'Chee made is correct in terms of the regional differences that do exist in this approach. He correctly pointed to that section of the legislation that provides for them with the application order process.

I am pleased to say that the differences, such as they are—and they are minor—are regional differences, not partisan differences. There is a very high level of genuine cooperation on the ministerial council on this issue. That cooperation completely crosses party lines, and that will continue. Senator O'Chee has asked for reassurance on that point and I give it to him. There is a very high level of cooperation but we do recognise the regional differences. The application orders are, of necessity, considered to be an exception rather than the rule. Everyone agrees with that as well.

In the case of the states that have not immediately endorsed the peg bill as it is known, again the attitude of the government is very strongly positive. In the case of some of the states—for example, New South Wales—that abstained from voting, the position simply is that the state ministers, mostly for the benefit of their cabinet colleagues, want to have a look at the flavour of the regulations before they make any recommendations to their respective cabinets about the introduction of the complementary legislation next year that hangs off this umbrella legislation that we are processing through the Senate today. I am pleased to say that can be achieved, because although the module approach has been adopted, the majority of those regulations will be completed—as the ministers know—before the end of this year, and state ministers will be able to have a good look at them.

The other issue that Senator O'Chee raised is that the uniformity approach should not inhibit innovative or technologically new solutions. It is an important point and I can assure Senator O'Chee and indeed the industry and everyone else that that will not happen. In fact, the reverse will be the case. As I am sure Senator O'Chee would appreciate, the entire thrust of this exercise is to enhance the efficiency of this industry. There are no partisan considerations in this. No-one is setting out to ambush anybody in this process. All ministers are joined in a common desire to see the ministerial council continue to improve, so far as it can at a political level, the opportunities for the transport industry. It truly is the lifeblood of this country.

Any innovative measures or new technological developments that come in—they are occurring all the time and I personally get representations on many of them from road transport operators—will be carefully considered by the ministerial council. Where there is a considered view that the overall impact on regulations of those changes will be positive rather than negative, I have got no doubt that either the regulation should be changed or the application order should be granted in that case. I guess it is a frustrating thing for people in public life in Australia that do want to see positive change for Australia and see some of these inefficiencies removed that that area of political problems generally known as states rights often intervenes.

I conclude by reiterating that there is no question of states rights involved in this case. Legitimate concerns about regional differences throughout Australia have been expressed by state ministers and there is a positive attitude by the whole ministerial council to cooperate with those concerns. I have got no doubt that, where state ministers can make out their case—we have a fairly informal approach to these things when we meet—and it is a persuasive case that it would be sensible for the industry and for the national benefit for these exceptions to be made, then the ministerial council will agree that those changes should be made.

May I say, as the transport minister, how pleased I am to see this legislation getting the support in the parliament that it has had from coalition. I have no doubt that the transport industry will be pleased indeed when the national regulations are in place and a sensible national regime, with regional differences incorporated, is in place across Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In light of the government's current obsession with Christmas, will the minister inform the Senate how a low tax paying family will be better off this Christmas, given that most Christmas presents—in particular, toys for the kids—the cost of driving to family gatherings, any accrued annual leave to pay for the holidays, beer, wine and soft drinks and even the nibblies and bonbons for the festive table will be dearer for the normally joyous celebration, yet the generous compensation of $2.89 for this government Christmas cheer will not be received until well towards the following Christmas?

—In my office before we came to question time, I asked, `Do you think we will be lucky enough to have anyone ask me a question that will give me a chance to talk about taxes in the lead-up to Christmas?'. The response was no. Let me tell the chamber of the choice that faces workers in the tax situation in the lead-up to Christmas.

PARA.TAB: As we know, a very high proportion of Australians take annual leave around Christmas and they get paid in advance. The amount of tax that will be deducted from their salary will be determined by this Senate. The extent to which the benefit of that tax cut will flow through to the four weeks pay that ordinary Australian men and women get when they go on their Christmas holidays will be substantially determined by whether or not this Senate continues to obstruct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister is not answering the question that he was asked. He was asked, `Aren't Christmas presents going to go up? Isn't the cost of driving going to go up? Isn't annual accrued leave paid for holidays going to go up? Aren't beer, wine and spirits going to go up? Are all these going to go up as a result of the further impost the government has put on ordinary Australians in this last budget?' Why does he not answer that question rather than go off on the frolic that he is on?

—I will speak to the point of order. If Senator Hill wrote that question for Senator Short, he should have got him to read it properly, because that is not the question he asked me. He asked, `How are these people going to be better off at Christmas?', and I am trying to tell him, Mr President.
—Order! The question was about tax increases. At the moment, the minister is dealing with that subject.

—That is right. I know those opposite are very embarrassed about these figures that I am about to give because they have probably worked it out themselves. They are trying to work out how to avoid the situation where ordinary Australian men and women are going to have pay more tax every week from 15 November onwards if the Senate does not pass this package by 21 October. So people will lose the tax cut and the economic stimulus that will flow from the expenditure. Average workers will lose $50 or $60 in their pre-Christmas annual leave payments because of the increased rate of tax that will apply if this Senate fails to pass the budget.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that Senator Short said which is true is that there is a stark choice. Australian working men and women face a stark choice regarding the tax situation that they will face in the lead-up to Christmas. Will they get $50 or $60 extra in their leave payment when they go off on leave for Christmas or not? It is for them to judge. It is in the hands of this Senate. If the Senate passes the package, they will get it; if the Senate does not pass the package, they will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister totally failed to answer that question and tried to answer a different one. Is he aware that Australian taxpayers will lose their promised tax cut only if the government decides to deny them that tax cut? It is on the government's head, no-one else's. Also, is it a fact that the so-called tax cut benefit that the government is talking about giving Australians for Christmas will be about $300 million? By that time, if its tax measures go through, the government will have ripped almost $500 million out of people's purchasing power?

—I am delighted to have the opportunity to follow up with the second point I wanted to make. The way Senator Short expressed his question makes the second point, that is in stark contrast, absolutely clear. The opposition is not proposing a no-cost alternative. If it were in control of measures, we would not be in the situation where all these goodies would flow at no cost. I am not talking about its silly GST proposal; I am talking about funding.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is also talking about a lower deficit. It would fund tax cuts by slashing outlays. Every bit of available evidence shows that the biggest benefit to average Australians and Australians in need flows from the way that governments spend their money.

The opposition knows that the big losers would be the poor and middle income families who are dependent upon health and education services provided by government—the very services that those opposite would slash. This would significantly undermine the living conditions of ordinary Australian families. That is where the crunch would come. That is what those opposite are significantly trying to cover up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to consistent reports of increasing exports of high value added goods to China. Is the minister in a position to inform the Senate of the progress that Australian companies are making in breaking into the market for elaborately transformed manufactures in China? Is he further able to advise the Senate what the government is doing to assist such companies? How is government policy contributing to the progress, and what are the constituent elements of that policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a very good day to ask this question, because I notice that there are reports that CITIC, the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, may be contemplating listing itself on the Australian Stock Exchange. The figures for Australia-China trade from the financial year 1991-92 to the financial year 1992-93 show an increase of 56 per cent in trade to China from Australia, lifting the value of our exports to $2.3 billion.

PARA.TAB: China is now our fastest growing trade market in the world. During the same period of the last year elaborately transformed manufactures—the category that the Australian Statistician sets aside for the most complex and sophisticated manufactured exports out of Australia—more than doubled from $131 million last year to $300 million this year. That is an increase of 128 per cent.

Both elaborately transformed manufactures and simply transformed manufactures are now growing at twice the rate of the total exports to China. It ought to be noted, despite that very high increase, that the core trading export items out of Australia are coal, iron ore and agricultural products. In China, Australia is now getting a reputation as being a country which is a good source of manufactured goods, a sophisticated supplier of quality services and a high technology country which is able to supply quality technology competitive with that of Japan, the United States, Korea and Europe. We are seen as being able to compete effectively in quality with the innovations that the market wants, deliver on time and to price. It is a reputation for customised manufacturing and services and it is one that we should all want to promote as a broader image of the Australian manufacturing base.

Earlier this month, I had the privilege to lead the largest ever delegation of Australian business people in an offshore trade mission. One hundred and twenty-three Australian business people, representing 85 Australian companies, accompanied me on a nine day visit to China.

We opened with a seminar hosted by me and the Chinese trade minister, Madam Wu Yi, in Beijing. I then led delegations and conducted business seminars on behalf of Australia in Shanghai, Hangzhou and Quanzhou. The heroes of this delegation were the members of the Australian business

ANSWER.PARA: community who accompanied me. Many of the Australian business people on this mission conducted themselves in a fully professional way with a genuine interest in and understanding of the Chinese market. They gained a reputation for this country as one in which we are straightforward and honest dealers in business, selling quality products.

PARA.TAB: Let me mention quickly some of the Australian companies that concluded contracts during this visit: Ericsson Australia, Olex Cables, Alcatel Australia, Telstra, the ABC and Burns Philp. There was a whole range of other companies as well, culminating with a group of them agreeing on a letter of intent for a power station and freight and warehousing facility contract worth, in Australian dollars, $400 million. It was a very successful mission. There are three lessons now that the Australian companies should heed and enact. The three lessons are: follow up, follow up and follow up. This is a market that will pay great dividends for Australia. We have got our foot clearly in the door. We can now expand our presence there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the budget decision to increase excise duty on fuel oil by 3c a litre now and another 2c a litre over time, which amounts to an 86 per cent increase in taxation of fuel used by coastal shipping and some mining operations which do not have access to natural gas. Why did the Treasurer not consult his colleagues the Minister for Resources and the Minister for Transport and Communications—whom he is consulting now—before arbitrarily and foolishly deciding to impose taxation on fuel oil, which will bear heavily and unfairly on those industries and seriously affect our export performance?

—I consulted with my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications to confirm that he has in fact already dealt with this question at a previous question time. I have nothing to add to his excellent answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer about whether the Treasurer had in fact consulted with his colleagues before the decision. I also want to ask the minister why, before this arbitrary tax on fuel was decided on, no-one in the government realised that it would increase the tax burden on Nabalco, which operates the Gove alumina and bauxite plant in the Northern Territory—I did not hear Senator Collins say one thing about Nabalco—by 96 per cent over one year. Why will Nabalco be asked to pay $25 million more for power generation over the next 12 months while no other bauxite operation has paid or will pay any tax of this kind? I did not hear Senator Collins say anything about that.
—It is essentially a separate question but if the minister wants to answer it he can.

—It is not a supplementary question. It is not, of course, very relevant to my particular portfolio, given the extent to which he addressed it to whether Bob Collins replied to it last time. I assume the reason Senator Collins did not reply to it last time was that he was not asked. I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Given the Victorian government's decision to renege on the unanimous decision of the July 1993 Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, particularly the decision on health warnings on tobacco products, will the minister inform the Senate of the consequences of the Victorian government's actions? What will the national government do to ensure that this important reform is not jeopardised?

—Senator Carr and a number of others have for some time been concerned generally about the issue of cigarettes and what we ought to be doing to curb their use in the community. He would be aware, as many in the chamber would be, that in April of 1992 all of the state health ministers and the Commonwealth health minister agreed to a very tough position on the labelling of cigarette packets. I think they might have got a little over-hyped on that occasion. Only two states, South Australia and Western Australia, and one territory, the ACT, ever acted on it.

PARA.TAB: When it came time for the ministers to meet again last July I was criticised by some in the anti-smoking lobby for daring to move a resolution which, while weakening that of last year, still took to us to equal with Canada, which has the toughest position in the world. I did that because it was necessary—as, I am sure, all senators would agree—to get a national position. Certainly, the national government and every state wanted it. So, after a long discussion, we came to the agreement that has now been abrogated by Victoria. That meeting was chaired by the Victorian health minister, who spoke in support of the resolution. I do not blame Marie Tehan; she has been overruled by her Premier.

During that debate, Peter Foss, the health minister in Western Australia, was most critical of me for daring to break down the decision. He wanted us to stick to the original, as did Wayne Berry in the ACT and Martyn Evans in South Australia. But, in order to get a national position, we compromised. Everyone was in heated agreement. We were all patting ourselves on the back. We had to reassure each other that we would stick to the deal. If you had to back who was going to rat on that sort of a deal, I reckon you would absolutely have to put the house on the old Jeff, on Premier Kennett. There he was, openly ratting again. When I took the opportunity to phone him yesterday, I said to him, `Premier, could we talk about this?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Mate'.

—After I said `mate', I said, `Could we talk about this and negotiate it through?' He said, `No, there is no point in discussions with the Victorian government on this. We will stick to our guns'. Having listened to the arguments he has put up in the last couple of days, I think all senators would have to agree that, if we were to simply walk away from the responsibility that we took in that July decision, then not only the Commonwealth but every state would have reason to complain.

PARA.TAB: We are not talking about some trivial issue. There is no question—no-one can debate it—that smoking kills. It makes Australians sick every day. It makes them die every day. We have a responsibility to do something about it. The Commonwealth will use its powers to do it. If the Victorian government is so weak that it cannot perform in accordance with the agreement that it made with the rest of this nation, we will have to make it. Next week I will be going to cabinet with a proposal to do exactly that.

We will use all of the Commonwealth's powers, including the corporations power. We will make sure that Victoria complies with what the rest of Australian governments want and what a huge majority of Australians want. If we cannot be strong enough on this issue, I really think there is a problem. I would hope that this is not seen as a partisan issue. It had the support of Liberal ministers around Australia; it still does. It is not to be seen as a contest between the Commonwealth and the Victorians; it is to be seen as a contest between light and dark. I would hope very much that Senator Herron and many others on that side of the parliament get up and defend what they know to be right—bag Kennett; this time he is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr, President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the government considering the issues related to the parliamentary disclosure of gifts in relation to this matter in regard to the tobacco industry?

—I do not think I am responsible for that. In relation to donations to political parties, certainly the Commonwealth laws are such that it is pretty hard to hide them. Those who tried to hide them in the last election will, I think, come falling down very shortly.

—Can the Minister for Defence and Minister representing the Prime Minister confirm recent media reports which support the view that there has been an increasing level of human rights abuse in Indonesia, including an incident this week in which Indonesian security forces shot dead a number of protesters on the island of Madura? In light of the Prime Minister's recent comments in the United States, can the minister advise whether the Prime Minister intends to raise the subject of human rights directly with Indonesian authorities as a priority when the Prime Minister visits Indonesia later this month? What was the outcome of discussions between the minister and the Indonesian defence minister over the issue of human rights when the Indonesian defence minister visited Australia a few weeks ago?

—The Australian government continues to monitor closely reports of human rights violations in Indonesia. In response to the question on Madura, Indonesian authorities have confirmed reports that security forces shot at a crowd of around 500 local residents protesting against the construction of the Nipah dam on the island of Madura in East Java, killing three people and wounding four others.

PARA.TAB: The Indonesian coordinating minister for political and security affairs has said that the matter will be investigated and appropriate action taken. I understand that several people, including the security officers involved, have been taken in for questioning. The Australian government views this incident with concern and regret; however it would be inappropriate to make a further comment while the investigation by Indonesian authorities is under way.

We continue to engage the Indonesian government in a dialogue on a range of human rights issues. The government regularly raises these issues at the highest levels of Indonesian government. The Prime Minister's recent comments in the United States represent no change to the integral role of human rights in our foreign policy.

The Prime Minister discussed Australia's concerns on East Timor with President Suharto and Foreign Minister Alatas during his visit to Jakarta last year. There has been no announcement so far of any possible visit to Jakarta by the Prime Minister in the near future; however, the Prime Minister made it very clear in Washington that the government will not compromise on the questions of democracy, our commitment to human rights and our respect for human values.

The government has consistently and forcefully raised with the Indonesian government its concern over human rights in Indonesia and it will continue to do so. Human rights issues were raised during the recent visit of the Indonesian defence minister. Senator Gareth Evans discussed these issues, including allegations of abuses by Indonesian armed forces, during his meeting with the defence minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. What is the importance of overseas experience and training to the development of Australia's leading young musicians? What is the federal government doing to enable young Australian musicians of excellence to obtain such experience?

—I would ask the Senate to imagine what the circumstance would be if this situation had occurred recently: a young Australian woman goes to Austria and breaks a world record, goes to Paris and breaks another world record, then goes to Berlin and breaks another world record.
—Paul Keating would have been at the airport to meet her.

—There would be great publicity. It would be a very high profile event and there would be serious recognition. I suppose Senator Kemp would have lowered the level of that discussion as well, because he has an infinite capacity to lower the level of all debates he touches. The fact of the matter is simply this: in recent times a young Australian woman has been the first woman conductor of opera in Salzburg, in Paris and in Berlin. This is an outstanding achievement of which Australians are not aware.

PARA.TAB: The young woman's name is Simone Young. I had the opportunity to meet her recently when she was conducting an opera in Berlin, which she did remarkably well. This is in fact an outstanding example of the sorts of unheralded achievements which Australians are making. Ms Young was the Young Australian of the Year in 1987 when she was working with the Australian Opera. She is an outstanding conductor.

The important point is not merely to recognise the significance of her achievement, substantial as it is, but to realise that it would not have been possible for her and other outstanding young Australian musicians were it not for the sort of assistance that is provided, for example, by the Australia Council's international study grants. They have not only made some of the overseas study and activity which Simone Young has done possible; they have also offered invaluable experience to people such as Richard Tognetti, the leader of the Australian Chamber Orchestra whose work many people in this chamber have, I know, enjoyed over the years.

This year the Performing Arts Board has approved a whole new series of grants to young percussionists, violinists and people not only in the classical music area but also in the area of jazz and other musical genres. It is important that we remain, as a government and as a nation, committed to fostering Australia's best young artistic talent, giving our young artists the opportunity to maximise their knowledge, their skills and their career prospects.

These opportunities exist at home and we are doing a substantial amount—for example, by the extra assistance to the Australian Youth Orchestra—to help young Australian musicians develop this talent in Australia. But we do have to accept that, notwithstanding how much more we have been able to lift the level of arts training in Australia, particularly in music, it is still necessary—we are a country of only 17 million—if musicians are to rise to the international peak of their profession, for them to gain a spread of knowledge, educational experience and exposure which cannot be gained through study in any one institution in any one country.

While I join with all those senators who would wish to congratulate Simone Young on her achievements, I think we would also wish to say that the initiatives over the last seven years by the former Music Board, and now the Performing Arts Board of the Australia Council which has assisted 149 young artists and musicians to further their studies overseas, have been a substantial contribution to the development of the talent of a lot of young Australians not only in a way that gives pleasure to a lot of other Australians but also in a way that has given a substantial boost to a very important industry that employs a lot of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask this question against the background that Jennie George told the government this week to stop pussyfooting around and to implement the pre-election commitments which were made. What is the status of the heads of agreement document between the Minister for Industrial Relations and the ACTU's negotiating committee dated 1 September 1993? Are the proposals agreed to in the `in-principle' document binding on the government?

—The positive element of the question which Senator Crane raises is that it does focus attention on the very broad area of agreement that exists about what should be done in the reforms which the government is seeking to propose in industrial relations, and puts in context the somewhat more narrow area of disagreement. I welcome the fact that he has recognised that there are more elements in the industrial relations reform equation than merely that which is the flavour of the month and the focus of attention with the recent concentration on the area of disagreement as it relates to enterprise bargaining.

PARA.TAB: The government continues to have negotiations with a number of groups, including the ACTU, which is very important in the area of industrial relations, about the nature of the legislative package which will be introduced. Those discussions are continuing and no decision will be made by the government about the final nature of the legislation which will be introduced or the timetable of that introduction until those negotiations are concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the minister has basically avoided the question, could I try another tack.
—You cannot try another tack. It is supposed to be a supplementary question!
—It is a supplementary question, and I will do it. You just be quiet.
—No. Sit down.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, please cease interjecting.

—Will the minister explain which proposals in the agreement are not binding, with particular reference to minimum standard provisions? Further, will the minimum standard provisions be existing awards?

—To the extent that I have anything to add to my previous answer, the Minister for Industrial Relations advises me that he has reached agreement on all major issues, except the extension of workplace bargaining into the non-unionised sector—and that is a matter about which discussions are continuing. So whether the document that Senator Crane has is the final version of the document is a matter between the minister and those people with whom he has been in negotiation.

PARA.TAB: It is correct that there is a substantial area of agreement about the reform; I welcome the opportunity to emphasise that substantial area of agreement. But discussions will continue about that one area where there is not agreement. The government does not intend to allow the artificial legislative deadlines which people are trying to raise to rush us into interfering with the quality of the package, and the detail of what is in it will be released when we conclude it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. The minister will be aware that the WA state government has ceased construction of a replacement Bunbury regional hospital in favour of a proposal to contract services from a new private hospital built on state land. Does the minister think it is appropriate that residents in WA's second largest city should be denied access to a public hospital? Further, does the minister consider that the privatisation of public hospitals leads to any significant benefits for the local community?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for his question. Senator Chris Evans has shown considerable interest in this question of the Bunbury hospital and went with me to Bunbury a couple of weeks ago when we visited the public hospital, the private hospital and attended a massive meeting of Bunbury citizens.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note, in spite of Senator Panizza's earlier interjection, that the local Liberal member of state parliament has finally been dragged kicking and screaming to the barrier to come out opposing it. He is opposing it because wherever these kinds of proposals are produced there is an inevitable community reaction, because every community regards as its right—as well it should—the public hospital facilities to which it has always had access.

In the city of Bunbury a sum of $4 million has already been spent by the Western Australian government in getting a new public hospital ready. That has now been dumped for a new proposal. The proposal has been called a co-location. It is not, of course, a co-location; that would involve both a public and a private hospital in the one spot. On this occasion all the facilities will be owned privately. The government will be leasing some of those facilities in terms not yet known to the government or the private operator, let alone the people of Bunbury. It is no great shock, therefore, that people would be worried and deeply concerned about their health care for the future.

In the past few days I have written to Minister Foss with some suggestions in accordance with a meeting I had with him on how this might best be solved. There is no guarantee that money will be saved. If honourable senators opposite believe that this will be in some way a great saving on the public purse, there is not even a guarantee of that. What we are seeing here is the replacement of the public sector by the private sector. There is no question that in the next decade the public sector will need to hire or lease services from the private sector.

In the last election campaign the government had as one of its planks in the health area a promise to do precisely that, and that will continue. That is a promise that, as Senator Ian Macdonald knows—that leader of the open-mouthed and empty-headed—we will keep. We are working towards it now, and in fact I met with the Australian Catholic Hospitals Association this very morning. But there is a very considerable problem when one stops using the private sector as a supplement to the public sector and replaces it. Once replaced, one wonders how one ever gets it back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody believes anything you say.

—In a credibility contest I suggest that the first thing people would have difficulty with would be finding out who Senator Ian Macdonald is. I reckon after the week he has had, this would be the time to take a rest, take three deep breaths and leave the rest of us to it.

PARA.TAB: I hope that there is still an opportunity for the Western Australian government to reconsider this matter. Minister Foss indicated to me that he himself acknowledged that there were serious problems with this proposal. I can say that we will support the principle of co-location. I have suggested to Minister Foss a number of ways that that can take place and that the Commonwealth would be more than happy to cooperate. What we will not allow, what we will not ever sit back and support, is the use of the term co-location when, in fact, it is plain old privatisation; it is the plundering, the rape and the pillage of the public sector. That is something we will not sit by for.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The heads of agreement document between the Minister for Industrial Relations and the ACTU's negotiating committee discusses the fait accompli of transferring sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act `in their industrial relations application' to the Industrial Relations Act. Can the Minister define the expression `in their industrial relations application'? What would be the remaining application of sections 45D and E after such a transfer? Is the agreement between the minister and the ACTU now government policy and, if not, can the minister state what the government's policy is in relation to boycott provisions in sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act?

—The final version of the legislation will become clear when the legislation is introduced into the parliament, and that is some way away. There are important issues involved in the matter raised by Senator Minchin. It is true that the government is examining possible changes to federal industrial relations law to improve the federal system's operation. In the course of that we are certainly looking at compliance measures. It is also true that the government regards civil actions in the ordinary courts as an inappropriate way of seeking to resolve industrial disputes. It is also true that the ILO committee of experts has reinforced this point, including by criticisms of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act.
