PARA.TAB: An option is that there should not be immediate access to the courts through sections 45D and E or to the common law where industrial action occurs in an industrial dispute. Under this option, pre-litigation conciliation by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission would be required before sections 45D or E action could occur. I understand that the `hit them with a big stick brigade' opposite does not like the fact that we might comply with reasonable international obligations about which they were enthusiastic, when those same people were critical of legislation relating to trade unions; they trumpeted it with some enthusiasm. This is called selective indignation.

It is true that we are proposing to make changes to sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. That is not a stunning revelation. That has been clear in the whole thrust of the legislative reform package that the minister has been discussing, but the final form of it will be made clear when it is introduced into the Senate as part of the legislative package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why is the government, which seems to be of the unions, by the unions and for the unions, ignoring the concerns of thousands of Australian businesses about proposals to diminish substantially the protection employers presently have against unjustifiable union boycotts?

—When the law is introduced and the scaremongers get a chance to see what the reality is, we believe that people will recognise that not only is it a package of legislation that properly discharges our international obligations, but also it is one that is fair and reasonably balanced between the reasonable requirements of the parties to the industrial relations contracts, and that that legislation will be fair and will deserve and receive the support of the parliament.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. My question relates to the fact that tomorrow, the contract to supply services to the town of Woomera and the US-Australian Nurrungar base will be taken over by Australian Defence Industries, the Defence Support Centre Woomera, and Rockwell, from a private company called SERCo. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that up to 75 SERCo staff will lose their jobs and homes, affecting up to 300 family members in a town of 1,300, and that continuing workers will lose up to $12,000 of their modest disposable incomes. Does he condone the actions of his department which has not only stripped workers of jobs, homes and income, but also has provided no counselling and support services to counter the health problems and family break-ups which are now occurring? Will the minister initiate a high level independent inquiry into the contract handover and an investigation of alternative employment sources for the people of Woomera?

—What is occurring at Woomera is not an isolated incident. The Department of Defence embarked on the commercial support program as a result of not only the force structure review but the report done by Mr Wrigley. Essentially, we have discovered that we must put up certain activities for competition in order to reduce costs. In some cases, in-house bids have won; in other cases, private bids have won; and in this case, one private bid has replaced another private bid. The reason for doing this is not only to get the various military bases closer to the community and to move personnel from the blunt end to the sharp end, but also to save money to reinvest in the rest of the defence portfolio. There were 28 tier 1 activities identified, 27 of which are now completed. Savings of well beyond $40 million a year will be achieved.

PARA.TAB: I take some contest with Senator Woodley's comment that no counselling has been provided. Some has been provided, not only from the Defence point of view but also from local community organisations. Some of those employees will be eligible for redeployment within the Public Service and others will be able to apply to ADI to continue to work in those particular facilities.

I do not intend to launch an investigation into this particular contract unless Senator Woodley can bring to me questions of probity. In two other contracts some questions were raised. We had them fully investigated and dealt with to satisfy ourselves that full probity applied.

I find the attitude of the Democrats a little strange. Before the last election they wanted to cut $2 billion out of the defence budget, but in every case where some micro change is made, either to close a base—such as it Huon in Tasmania—or to change a contract anywhere, they oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that. He said, `Treat the people fairly'.

—The implication of his question was that we should not have instituted a commercial support program because some people may potentially lose their jobs. Whilst that is regrettable, it is an inevitable part of the commercial support program. Therefore, I do not think it warrants what Senator Woodley termed a high level inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I will make some inquiries to make sure that Senator Woodley's views are known in terms of whether sufficient counselling is done. If I find that the information I have been given to the effect that sufficient counselling has been done does not have a correct basis, I will try to pursue the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services advise the Senate, with respect to the Labor Party's John Curtin House Ltd lease with the Commonwealth, firstly, whether the Commonwealth's interest was acquired pursuant to section 40 of the Lands Acquisition Act? If not, how otherwise was it acquired? Secondly, if it was so acquired, did the minister at the time personally authorise the acquisition of the interest? If not, who authorised the acquisition? Finally, if the authorisation was done by someone other than the minister, was there a delegation pursuant to section 139 of the Lands Acquisition Act and, if so, what were the terms, date and any other such terms of the authorisation?
—You're a scumbag.
—Order!
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Bolkus has withdrawn an unparliamentary remark, but it was not the first one made today. Ministers have been accused of lying and I ask people to cease.

—One cannot be surprised that feelings run high about this matter. Attempts have been made consistently, persistently and without a skerrick of foundation to smear the reputation of decent Australians discharging their Public Service duties in various agencies of the Australian government.

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I asked a very specific set of questions. I simply want the minister to tell me whether the acquisition of the interest was made under the Lands Acquisition Act.

—Mr President, every senator in this chamber knows, that that was not a point of order from Senator Bishop; it was a debating point. Senator Bishop would be better served to go back to undermining Dr Hewson full time.
—Order! There are too many points of order. I do not think that was a point of order, but I had great difficulty hearing because of the interjections, and I ask that interjections cease.
—Senator Faulkner will cease interjecting.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is the third time you have named Senator Faulkner this afternoon. How many more times will you name Senator Faulkner before you ask him to leave this chamber?

—On the point of order, Mr President: `name' is a technical term. You have warned Senator Faulkner, quite appropriately, a few times—about the same number of times that you have warned Senator Ian Macdonald.
—I was about to make that comment.

—Although Senator Bishop would love to have the opportunity to answer this question instead of ask it, she has to get over a big hurdle: she has to win an election and then she has to get on the frontbench. There are two significant problems why she cannot determine—
—Order! Answer the question, Senator McMullan.

—I am enjoying the opportunity to do so. This is a matter that has been exhaustively investigated and discussed in the Senate and Senate estimates committee last year and this year. Outrageous allegations were made against decent officers of the Australian Valuation Office—honest people whose integrity has not in any way been impugned other than by some outrageous attempt to say that, because somebody went to the Labor Club, his or her professional integrity is obviously significantly undermined. What an outrageous allegation about that individual—even if the bit of information is true, which I do not know and which I do not intend to seek to find out. There have been allegations about the—

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have made a ruling in this place before that the minister may choose to answer or not answer the question. If he chooses to answer the question, it has to be relevant to the question asked. I ask you to either admit that he does not have an answer and will have to go away and find it, or require him to give me a simple yes or no as to whether it was required under the Lands Acquisition Act.
—Order! It is not for me to say whether the minister should answer yes or no. I ask him to be relevant.
—Say it outside and cop a writ.
—On a point of order: is it in order for a minister of the crown to threaten other senators the way that Senator Bolkus keeps doing?
—We are now having points of order used out of—
—Mr President, there is a point of order before the chair.
—Order! I ask the minister to be relevant.

—My point is that we are constantly seeing the opposition using divisive points of order to disrupt questions and answers. It is an harassing tactic. It disrupts question time and it should be discontinued.

—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to cease interjecting. I must say to Senator Macdonald, who raised the point of order, that it is not in order to accuse a minister of lying, as you did earlier today in question time.
—I have to say that notwithstanding—
—On a point of order—
—I call Senator McMullan.
—He ignores me.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Ian Macdonald has added to his crime by making an imputation against you. He has to withdraw that. I did not ask him to withdraw the other comments, but he has to withdraw that one.
—I ignored earlier comments so that we would not reach a situation like this. I think it was a clear imputation on the chair. I ask that it be withdrawn.

—Mr President, I was talking to Senator Bolkus and indicating that I thought you had ignored me when I stood to make a point of order. If you insist that I withdraw, I will withdraw. But I made the comment to Senator Bolkus because when I stood I did not seem to get the call.
—Order! I accept the explanation given by Senator Ian Macdonald.

—I appreciate the opportunity of being able to put some of these things on the record, because it has been a little frustrating not being able to respond to a series of allegations that have been made against staff of my department, particularly by the shadow minister and some others in the estimates hearings. It is disgraceful and unreasonable that they should do so. There are a whole series of—
—Can't you say yes or no?

—I am being relevant; it directly relates to the contract to which Senator Bishop has referred. If she does not like the fact that I am in order to use this question to respond to outrageous allegations, I am sorry; she should not have asked the question. But if those opposite are brilliant tacticians, they have to realise that when they ask questions, I can, within the standing orders, make responses which they do not like. But I am going to go on and make the responses.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have ruled that if the minister chooses to answer, he must be relevant to the question asked. I asked whether he utilised a particular act of parliament. He is straying from the question. I simply want a yes or a no or an admission that nobody has briefed him yet.
—Order! I thought the minister was being relevant.

—I am being entirely relevant. It may be somewhat uncomfortable, but it is entirely relevant. All the relevant documents with regard to this matter—piles of them—were tabled by Senator Bolkus and me last year. People have been scouring them for years trying to find a scandal. This is just another attempt at it. I have no intention of adding to it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Attorney-General's Department advises that the acquisition was made pursuant to the Lands Acquisition Act, I ask the minister to further advise the Senate, in addition to the questions I asked, whether he laid the agreement on the table of both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days of its agreement, as is required by the act; whether the minister contended that the interest acquired in the Labor Party building was available in the market within the meaning of the act; and, if so, on what basis that decision was made that the property was in the market within the meaning of the act.
—I would not know that level of detail about something that happened while I was the minister, let alone about something that happened while I was not.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Defence, relates to Australia's Defence Force personnel in Cambodia. Can the minister inform the Senate of the timetable for the withdrawal of these troops from Cambodia? Further, would the Minister be able to outline what plans have been made for welcoming these personnel home?

—The withdrawal plan for Australian Defence Force personnel in Cambodia is now in place. As honourable senators will know, the UNTAC mandate formally ended on 24 September. As a consequence, Lieutenant General Sanderson has already left Cambodia. He will return to Australia on 6 October.

PARA.TAB: Three hundred and forty ADF personnel will leave Utapao in Thailand on 7 October by UN charter 747 and will arrive in Sydney on 8 October. The remainder of the Australian contingent of about 140 personnel, including the force communications unit, military police and headquarters staff, will return to Sydney on 15 November 1993.

All members of the Australian Defence Force who served with UNTAC deserve praise for their efforts. They served with distinction and consistently demonstrated the highest standards of professionalism. During the CDF's recent visit to Cambodia, he received a wide range of unsolicited praise for the Australian contribution, which demonstrates that Australian efforts are recognised internationally.

In this regard, I must make special mention of the efforts of Lieutenant-General Sanderson. As Force Commander of UNTAC, his task was not an easy one. Despite the numerous difficulties and pressures he faced, he consistently demonstrated sound judgment, leadership and compassion. I am sure that Lieutenant-General Sanderson would be more than happy, after his discussions with me, to discuss the mission in Cambodia with opposition spokesmen and with the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

A welcome-home parade for members of the Australian contingent will be held in Sydney on 9 October. The parade will form at Martin Place and march along George Street past the Sydney Town Hall. I know that I speak for all senators in congratulating members of the Australian Defence Force for a job well done. They brought great credit to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Yesterday when answering a question from Dr Hewson and referring to his grand vision for a Keating fiefdom, the Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Naturally in the course of that all the symbols of our national identity will change with it.

I ask the minister: is it the government's or the Prime Minister's intention to replace our six official national symbols—the flag, the kangaroo and the emu from the coat of arms, our green and gold colours, the golden wattle, Advance Australia Fair and the opal—or is this just the Prime Minister's personal view? Where is the government's mandate for such actions? Can the minister inform the Senate what the replacement symbols of our nation will be?

TALK.START.PARA: —In honour of the Liberal Party, we are going to replace them with a dodo.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was asking the minister a serious question and I expect a serious answer.
—Well Senator Calvert, you did not get one.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to the government's Mabo legislation which will grant native title to traditional land holders who have maintained their continuous connection with the land. As the minister would be aware, there are many dwellers in Aboriginal communities who have resided there for generations, such as occurs on Queensland deed of grant and trust communities, but who are not traditional owners. What action will the government take to ensure that the present rights of the many inhabitants of these communities, who are not traditional owners, will be maintained, and that they will continue to have the same rights in the communities as the traditional owners?
—The existing rights of Aboriginal people who reside on land where they are not the traditional owners will be protected. That will be clear when the legislation is introduced into the parliament.

—Can the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs tell the Senate what the government is doing to locate and remove people who are in Australia illegally, and whether there have been any recent changes in the number of people overstaying their visas?

—I thank Senator Murphy for his question. The government takes this issue very seriously because of two major priorities that we have in this portfolio area. Firstly, we ensure that queue jumpers do not have any advantage over those who apply to come to Australia properly. Secondly, we attempt to protect the employment opportunities of Australians.

PARA.TAB: In this context I am pleased to be able to report that in the last 12 months there has been a substantial increase in the number of illegal entrants leaving Australia after being located by my department. At the same time there has been a significant decline in the number of people overstaying their visas. With respect to the latter group, at the end of last year some 82,000 people were estimated to be in Australia illegally, having overstayed their visas. However, by the end of June this year, that figure had dropped by nearly three per cent to about 79,800.

More importantly, when we consider that the number of people entering Australia legally has continued to increase over recent years—in the last financial year it increased by 15 per cent to some 1.9 million—the percentage of illegal overstayers as a proportion of the legal, non-permanent entrants into this country declined by some 20 per cent over the last 12 months. This fall has occurred in all visa categories, the most significant drop being in the student visa category.

In respect to the former group, the number leaving Australia after being located by my department, the figures are directly linked to the government's increasing success in locating and removing people who are living and working here illegally. Compliance results have been improving now for some three years. In the 12 months to June 1993, immigration staff located some 14,800 illegal entrants, compared with 11,600 in the previous year. This is an increase of 27 per cent over locations in the 1991-92 financial year. Because of that, there was an increase in the number of enforced departures. Some 9,180 were forced to leave in that financial year compared with 7,100 in 1992-93, which is a 30 per cent increase in supervised departures.

There is evidence of greater compliance success. The government is keen to build on that in the interests of protecting those in Australia who have the right to employment and also to protect the immigration program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I had a phone call from a 73-year-old constituent who received a letter from the Department of Social Security last week stating that her pension had been reduced from $276 to $94 a fortnight. She has a modest portfolio of managed investments that have risen in value during the last 12 months but are significantly below their original purchase price. There are thousands of pensioners in similar predicaments. I ask: is $94 a fortnight an adequate standard of living? Must my constituent now sell her managed investments at a substantial loss? Is this policy part of the government's social policy agenda?

—Obviously, I do not know the person and I do not know the individual case concerned. It is quite clear that $94 is not a sufficient payment to subsist on, let alone exist on. I would not at any point suggest that it was. Social Security would be reducing the pension to that kind of amount only if it were the case that substantial other income was being received. There is a published formula for how that is done. It is not a secret. On the basis of that formula, no doubt, the calculation has been made.

PARA.TAB: If there is any breach of those published rules—which, after all, are simply administering acts passed by this parliament, including the Senate—then, if Senator Patterson draws it to my attention, I will be very happy to draw it to the attention of the minister. But I will be surprised if that is in fact the case. What I think will be the case is that acts which this parliament has passed—including the Senate—are simply being implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister telling me that her pension is being assessed on income?

—I can only repeat: I do not know the results of the individual case. It is very difficult to comment on these things until one sees them. I never do. I always like to see it all. If Senator Patterson gives me the details of this individual case, I will give her a detailed answer next week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the government's attention been drawn to the fact that the most recent figures from the PRC show that in that country the sex ratio of children at birth is 118 boys to 100 girls? Would the government agree that this is largely brought about because of the target driven one child per family policy in China together with a predilection for a male offspring and the use of modern techniques for sex selection and abortion? Will the government give an absolute guarantee to the parliament that none of the ultrasound machines used in this process are those which Australia sent to China through the DIFF program?

—I am aware of reports that the sex ratio at birth in China is 118 boys to 100 girls. The obvious implication is that baby girls in some areas of China are still subject to being disposed of at birth.
—Do you mean killed?
—Yes.
—Why don't you say it?

—I thank Senator Kemp very much for his insistence on plain language. This is a serious issue; I did not want to divert into normal parliamentary byplay. However, to stick to the subject, I understand that the foreign minister has taken up this issue with the Chinese foreign minister recently. As to the commitment on DIFF funded ultrasound machines, I will have to check to see whether such a guarantee can be given. If I may, I will take that and the other elements of the honourable senator's question on notice.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill asked me on Monday, 27 September 1993 whether any money allocated in conjunction with the Sydney Olympic Games is likely to be directed to country areas. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has advised me that she is determined to ensure that the benefits of the Olympic games are shared by all Australians. Speaking to the Confederation of Australian Sport before the decision was announced, Mrs Kelly said:

ANSWER.PARA: I want to assure you that, if we get the Olympic Games, they will be for all Australia, not just Sydney or the Olympic sports.
I will ensure that the federal government's Olympic related programs cover all sports and all states.

The government is well aware of the difficulties young athletes in remote areas face, particularly with regard to gaining high quality competition, coaching and access to facilities. Many people in remote areas have already benefited from the government's coaching and facility programs. However, there is no doubt that more needs to be done. Hopefully, winning the Olympic games will prove a catalyst for more action.

PARA.TAB: The minister has already written to state ministers suggesting that they consider joining in a national approach to preparation for the Olympic games. I reiterate a comment I made yesterday: the government hopes that in seven years time we will see more than just a swag of medals; we hope we will see a fitter and healthier society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Lees asked a question relating to the federal government's response to the Senate inquiry into physical and sports education. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has provided the following information in answer to the question. The Crowley committee report on physical and sports education made a number of very important conclusions and recommendations concerning the state of physical education in Australian schools. The federal government is acting on many of those recommendations. Although, as I understand it, the government has not yet responded formally to the recommendations, the minister hopes to be able to do so in the very near future.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees would probably be aware that many of the recommendations, unfortunately, fall into the jurisdiction of state departments of education. Nevertheless, the federal government has taken a number of steps to attempt to rectify the deficiencies identified in the report. One of the major areas for input identified in the report was via the national curriculum. Action taken immediately after the release of the Crowley committee report resulted in a number of improvements to the curriculum and carried the potential for a new national standard of physical education.

Unfortunately, this sensible and vital initiative was thwarted by the short-sighted actions of conservative state ministers. The minister has advised me that she is pursuing a number of other avenues to improve physical education in schools. They include, amongst others, joint approaches with the minister for schools, Ross Free, and the state education ministers; moves to educate the community about the state of physical education in our schools; and action to implement many of the recommendations relating to retraining of teachers.

Naturally, the Commonwealth, through the Australian Sports Commission, will also maintain and improve its commitment to programs like Aussie Sport, which help develop skills and promote participation. However, education departments must realise that these Commonwealth programs supplement physical education—they do not replace them.

Winning the Olympics has provided the nation with a great opportunity to fix physical education. All state governments are keen to share the benefits of the games. They must also realise that the action they take now in physical education influences the success of the games in the year 2000. As Mrs Kelly has already pointed out, the champions of 2000 are the schoolchildren of today.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September 1993, Senator Ferguson asked, with reference to the 1993-94 budget measure to introduce, as he called it, a one per cent tax on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, whether a farm, a hospital or a mining company would be allowed a business expense deduction for the tax for income tax purposes. In a supplementary question he asked whether the net gain to the government would be far less than the $10 million shown in the budget papers and if, in that context, the government intended to raise the tax even further.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that Senator Ferguson is referring to the administrative fee which is to recover the cost of administering the diesel fuel rebate scheme from the beneficiaries of the scheme. The amounts of levy paid will be deductible for income tax purposes to the extent that they relate to diesel fuel used for producing assessable income.

In so far as Senator Ferguson's question relates to hospitals, hospitals, except those operated for profit, are exempt from income tax and, therefore, would not be able to utilise an income tax deduction. I am advised that mining companies will only be able to use the resultant income tax deduction to the extent that they would otherwise have a taxable income. The government is of the view that the budget estimate of the savings from the measure is appropriate and has no plans to increase the fee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time on Tuesday, 28 September 1993 Senator MacGibbon asked me how many complaints relating to sexual harassment I have received in total and how many I have received since the announcement of the HMAS Swan incident. I can provide the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: In the period that I have been Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, I have received three complaints relating to sexual harassment. Of these, one was received after the incidents on HMAS Swan became public. One of the complaints related to a recent incident of alleged harassment—that is, in 1993. The other complaints related to incidents prior to this year, one some 11 years ago. Of the three complaints received by me, one related to an incident in the army, one in the navy and one at the Defence Force Academy. Two further complaints brought to my notice had already been notified to the previous minister. In both of those cases, the investigations have concluded and disciplinary action is proceeding or has been taken. For privacy reasons I do not intend to provide any further detail on any of these cases.

I emphasise that these are the numbers of complaints received by me. I have had preliminary work done by headquarters ADF regarding figures of sexual harassment incidents reported to the services and to the Defence Force Academy and have now asked that those figures be very carefully checked for accuracy and comprehensiveness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling on this day relating to the proposed increase in fuel excise.

SPEECH.PARA: In his answer to my question today Senator McMullan was, in effect, taking the role of Pontius Pilate. Having had a whisper in his ear from Senator Collins during the question, it was obvious that Senator McMullan did not want to address the substantive part of the question which referred to the budget decision to increase excise duty on oil by 3c a litre now and another 2c over time, which amounts to an 86 per cent increase in taxation of fuel used by coastal shipping and some mining operations. Further, in the supplementary question, I referred to the operation of Nabalco at Gove in the Northern Territory where the impositions will result in a 96 per cent increase over one year—in the order of $25 million.

PARA.TAB: As I said, Senator McMullan chose not to answer in any way the substantive questions that were addressed. This, in effect, is disgraceful, given the considerations that have been before the government on this matter for some time. Senator McMullan implied that Senator Collins had already addressed this issue. So I had a look at the Hansard for 6 and 7 September when Senators Parer and Ferguson raised this matter very directly with Senator Collins in questions in this place. On 6 September, Senator Parer asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . how does he—
Minister Collins—

expect the Australian shipping industry to contribute to boosting Australia's competitive position when his government's budget mark 2 has increased fuel taxes by $358,387 annually for an average vessel, which far out-weighs the $270,000 per vessel reduction in annual operating costs from shipping reforms.
On that occasion, Senator Collins replied:
. . . I can advise Senator Parer that the government has the matter of the fuel oil excise under consideration at the moment.
So it was under consideration as at 6 September. Senator Ferguson followed up this matter on 7 September and referred to Senator Parer's earlier question. Senator Ferguson asked:

Does this mean the government is planning to further amend its already discredited budget of betrayal to lessen the devastating effect that the increase in fuel excise will have on our shipping, road and rail transport industries?
On 7 September Senator Collins replied:

There is nothing I wish to add to what I said about this yesterday, except to point out that it is not the shipping industry's fuel oil excise. Fuel oil is also extensively used for the generation of power in isolated communities, particularly in mining establishments. One of the most notable that I am aware of, which is in my backyard, is the Nabalco operation at Gove, which uses fuel oil for that purpose. So it is not simply the shipping industry that uses fuel.

So three weeks ago Senator Collins said it was under consideration and the next day he acknowledged that Nabalco, in his own backyard, in his own electorate, in his own very special consideration, was being looked at. Yet, today he whispered in Senator McMullan's ear and, like Pontius Pilate, Senator McMullan said nothing, got away with it, admitted to nothing that has happened in the way of government in the last three weeks and did not address the issues that really do stand out. What representations has Senator Collins made in cabinet, and elsewhere, if he really does represent the Northern Territory that he so proudly claims to represent?

PARA.TAB: The really important questions that have to be addressed in this issue that Senator McMullan failed to address in answer to my question today are: how could a Treasurer have made such a gross error, unfairly discriminating against one firm in an important export industry—$25 million for one company by one decision? To what extent does this compound the problem of sovereign risk for international investors in Australia? This is an extremely serious problem. No international investor in the mining sector can now look to this government without knowing that with a slash of a Treasurer's pen, new taxes will be put on in the order of $25 million. What confidence does that give in this particular area?

I was attracted to a statement by Nabalco that the new budget impost cannot help but emphasise the heightened sovereign risk of investing in mining and minerals processing in Australia. That is significant. It cannot be passed on, in an instance like this, to international consumers. Nabalco pays two-thirds of all excise on inland consumption of this nature. What are the long-term prospects for future investment, future earnings and job security in a place like Nabalco? Certainly we cannot continue to rely on the ERA just as we have in the past. Senator McMullan failed to address these issues substantively today. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate long in response to what is essentially a publicity stunt by Senator Tambling, but I thought we ought to at least qualify the publicity stunt. I am not saying that he is not entitled to do this. The Senate has been used as a publicity stunt since Federation and I imagine that it will continue to happen. I am not trying to be too high and mighty about it. We have all done it and he is entitled to do it too. But Senator Tambling knows now—if he did not know before, he was informed by me in answer to the question—the detail of the answer which Senator Collins had given and which indicated the state of the government's consideration of this matter, and there is not anything to add.
—Three weeks ago.

—Three weeks may be a long time in Senator Tambling's life; it is not actually long in the life of the process of dealing with important matters of public policy. We would not mind a guarantee that those opposite would pass some tax bills in the next three weeks.
—Give them to us.
—Those opposite have them all.
—When you are doing this to us.

—I understand that those opposite are saying that they want not to pass them. That is exactly the underlying rationale that Malcolm Fraser so correctly pinpointed was grossly irresponsible—and those opposite have just articulated it and I am very pleased; I have been waiting for someone to do it.

PARA.TAB: I would just make a couple of other points before concluding. One of the things about which great play was made, I think in the supplementary question, was the extent to which my original answer did not cover everything because Senator Collins did not refer to Nabalco in his first answer—although now, of course, it is apparent he did. So let us just put that in context.

TALK.START.PARA: —He acknowledged that it was there but he did not actually say anything about Nabalco.
—It is simply a display of Senator Tambling's ignorance about this matter. He should have consulted the Hansard before he came in to be boringly repetitious.

PARA.TAB: The only other point I want to make is that we do get a constant stream of people—and it would be very unusual if we did not—coming in concerned about the impact of tax increases on their particular business. In all the time I have been in public life, no-one has ever come to me to say, `Thank you very much for the significant improvement, for the reduction in taxes'—the fact that the corporate tax rate has gone down from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, for example, which has a significant effect on every company running a profitable business in Australia. None of them like to factor that into their equation. When they ask themselves, `Is the overall package of tax changes that has taken place fair and reasonable to me?', none of them choose to respond to that. I just want to put that qualification on the record.

But Senator Tambling is entitled to get up and make his point. Even though he knew there would be nothing new to add, it might get him a column inch in a paper in the Northern Territory. If that is the case, it might not be a wonderful contribution to the level of public debate in Australia but it is not a unique thing which he has done, and he is entitled to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to support the comments made by my colleague Senator Tambling in response to the answer given by Senator McMullan. I think it is unfortunate that we did not get a response because in raising this matter—far from performing a stunt, far from play acting—my colleague Senator Tambling expressed concern about the impact of a 50 per cent increase in excise, rising to 90 per cent, and the impact that it will have on the mining industry and on coastal shipping.

PARA.TAB: The question had particular relevance to one company in the Northern Territory, Nabalco—a company the Asian headquarters of which this government pleaded to have transferred to Australia, and a company that is owned by the AMP. So AMP policyholders around Australia will be affected by this decision, but there was no consultation. It was a targeted increase. It will have a tremendous impact on the profitability of this particular country.

But, surprisingly, it is running against the thrust of what this government is arguing at present. It is pleading with Australian industry to get out there and to add value. This will hit this industry which is adding value. It is a major export earner in Australia, and yet this government is hitting it with an increase in tax which will rise by $25 million to $50 million from a previous threshold of $25 million.

This increase also will have special implications for Tasmania. My colleague from Tasmania Senator Sherry is already aware of the difficulties that that state will face. It will have consequences for industries such as Timco, Savage River Mines, Pasminco and Comalco. Why will it mean special problems for Tasmania? Firstly, there is the state's dependence on coastal shipping. The increase in fuel oil will have a tremendous impact on costs over there. Diesel fuel increases will add something like $3 to the cost of a basket of groceries in our particular state.

Far from that, the long-term implications will be very severe. The government has not thought out the loss of employment and the loss of investment that will result from this increase. My colleague Senator Tambling indicated the problems of sovereign risk. This increase will further erode overseas investor perceptions about the stability of investing in Australia. It will heighten what is known as sovereign risk for people who are investing in this country, particularly in the mineral processing and mining industry.

The increase will have a tremendous effect on Nabalco. It will erode a lot of the competitive advantages that that company had over its competitors in Australia. Aluminium processing is not particularly profitable because of the world recession and this will further reduce the return to the investors, including CSR and the AMP. The government should realise that the present return on investment is quite minimal; it is just over one per cent. This increase is a further target on this industry which will further erode that minuscule return. Apart from that, it is the largest inland user of fuel oil. How will we encourage industries to move out of the coastal belt, to go inland and to develop this country if we are going to target them with premeditated increases such as this one?

We all know that aluminium is one of Australia's largest and most successful export commodities. Here is targeting of a particular company resulting in its reduced profitability. What effect will that have on future investment? The partners have shown a remarkable confidence in this company by investing in it—putting more money into it. This will certainly jeopardise the money to be put into this company in the future. The problem is that the elasticity of demand for fuel oil is low. The government's decision is short-sighted. It places further future investment in jeopardy. I ask honourable senators to consider the impact, not only on future investment, but also on Australia's balance of payments, because that will be eroded. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to industrial relations reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: I have reached agreement with Senator McMullan to table a document entitled Industrial Relations Legislative Reform and I now seek leave to table that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was quite obvious from the answer given by Senator McMullan that he was not aware of the contents of this document. That does not excuse him for the answer that he gave because he should have been aware of it in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton. My question was very simple and straightforward. It referred to the heads of agreement between the ACTU and the government. Although it was dated 1 September this year, it referred to what now appears to be an agreement that was put in place prior to the last election. It certainly has been referred to as such by Ms Jennie George and by Mr George Campbell in recent days. In fact, this week, Jennie George said that the government should stop pussyfooting around.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise two points in relation to this document. The first is minimum standard provisions and the emphasis that ILO conventions will be used. It is quite obvious from this document that that is not correct. It totally misleads the Australian parliament. There has been little or no negotiation with the employer side of the equation in terms of the direction that industrial relations in this country should take over the next decade; it has all been one-sided. The last sentence in point 3 of this document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with the Accord, awards will provide the safety net of wages and conditions; bargaining above that safety net would occur through the negotiation of certified agreements (or overawards).

I want to emphasise the phrase `or overawards'. That means that the industrial relations clock in Australia is being turned back in terms of enterprise agreements and Australia getting a more competitive, flexible industrial system. It is also clear proof that the ACTU is running the government's agenda on industrial relations; hence my comments on what has occurred over the last two or three days.

PARA.TAB: I urge the government to take into consideration the viewpoints of others in the community, whether they belong to a union or not and whether they are employers or employees. Right now this debate is totally one-sided.

The other point I want to refer to in this document—no doubt we will come back to it time and again, as will Mr Brereton as he is called to appear before his masters at the ACTU from time to time—relates to the proposals that deal with secondary boycotts, common law and civil action. I want to highlight the proposition that, following the transfer of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act, there must be a period of 72 hours before an employer who is being held to ransom or boycotted can seek to get a certificate from the Industrial Relations Commission in order to take some action. That is spelt out very clearly in point 30. That is purely and simply a legal licence to damage—something that has never been in Australian law before. It is disgraceful that this government should even be contemplating going down that track. In 1984 and 1987 it tried to remove sections 45D and 45E.
In summing up, a document put out by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says it all:

SPEECH.PARA: Unions will be provided with a licence to cripple employers by secondary boycotts in a similar manner to the licence which would have been conferred in the ill-fated Industrial Relations Bill 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Crane to take note of the answer given by Senator McMullan in question time today. Today Senator Minchin used a very devastating phrase, which I think bears repeating in this chamber. He said, `We have a government by the unions, for the unions'. That is precisely what the document that Senator Crane tabled today is all about. It demonstrates once and for all the nature of the government that runs this country—and who is, in fact, running that government.

PARA.TAB: This is an appalling document. It is appalling for a number of reasons: firstly, because it was concocted in secret between the Minister for Industrial Relations, Laurie Brereton, and the ACTU; and, secondly, because of the nature of the agreements which have been reached. These agreements are far-reaching and will substantially change the nature of labour market relations in this country and buttress further the power and privilege of the ACTU and the mega-unions which this government has helped create in recent years.

To add to what my colleague Senator Crane said, it is interesting to consider the far-reaching nature of this document which has been revealed to the Senate today. A new industrial relations court is to be established. The old AIRC will be abolished and a new industrial relations court will be established. It also raises, in an intriguing way, the fact that the government is backing away, as a result of what it sees as a ruling from the ILO, from the 10,000 member rule for unions. I suggest to Senator Bell that that leaves him in a particularly awkward circumstance. Senator Bell and his colleagues stood up in this parliament barely 12 months ago—maybe a bit longer—and argued strongly for the support of the ACTU Labor government proposal for the creation of mega-unions. Senator Bell dumped on the old policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't.

—Senator Bell's party dumped on its old policy and it voted with and supported the government's 10,000 member mega-union rule. Of course, now the government is backing away from that. So where does that leave the Australian Democrats policy? I put it to Senator Bell that it is a very good lesson for him and his colleagues now that the government is discussing these issues with the trade unions. It will leave the Democrats like a shag on a rock, like they have been left as a result of this particular in principle agreement between the ACTU and Minister Brereton.

PARA.TAB: As my colleague Senator Crane has said, the document indicates that there will be major changes in relation to the secondary boycott issues; there will be major changes in relation to the legislative arrangements for ILO conventions. As a nationalist in this chamber, I am very opposed to the involvement of international law in domestic disputes in this country. I would have thought that, as there has been a bit of the old republican push on the other side, those opposite would also be a bit opposed to the involvement of international law in the legal system of our country.

Every time we pick up a Labor document these days, we find the ILO or the UN being involved in Australian domestic circumstances. That is a very bad trend in this country. Of course, in order to conduct civilised relations between nations, we need international law and we need it to be observed. But it is far better in a democracy that, when we are concerned about relations between people in our own country, we rely on our own legal processes and our own laws. One of the most disturbing features of this so-called republican push is the desire of the Labor Party to further entangle us in international and UN conventions, and this document once again proves that point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to comment on the fairly predictable contributions which have been made, particularly those of Senator Crane. I want to deal with a couple of themes that were developed. I do not want to deal so much with the contents of the document that Senator Crane tabled, which is apparently dated 1 September—and I have seen the document. But I want to deal with the allegations of lack of consultation and concoctions in secret.

PARA.TAB: I find it a bit galling that Senator Crane alleges that there was little or no consultation with employers. Firstly, I make the point that there has been ongoing consultation with employers by the current minister and the previous minister, Senator Cook, who was a very good minister, although I know Senator Crane will contest that. They had a well developed, personal and ongoing combative relationship.

It is a bit rich when the opposition comes in here claiming that we lack consultation. When did the opposition consult with the trade union movement about the contents of Fightback? I remind the Senate and the people of Australia that the opposition has not withdrawn its industrial relations policy in Fightback. It has withdrawn the GST because it believes that that was critical in its defeat. The opposition should also have a look at its industrial relations policy, because that was pretty critical in its defeat as well. It is a bit rich for opposition members to be saying that we do not consult—we do—when they do not consult themselves. If members of the opposition want to push that principle, it should apply just as much to them as it does to us.

Senator Crane—this brought a wry smile to my lips—accused the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), of calling his masters in the ACTU. I have had a number of conversations and meetings with the minister on a range of matters over the last six months. Every time I pick up a newspaper there is generally criticism of him from a full range of the industrial movement. He has been criticised on a number of occasions by a number of unions. How can Senator Crane possibly claim that the unions are his master when they are criticising him for his alleged lack of action in a number of areas? Again, it is a total inconsistency in Senator Crane's assertion.

I noted the other day that one of the employer organisations—I think it was the Chamber of Manufactures; I could be wrong—praised Minister Brereton for standing up to the ACTU. Whether that praise was justified or not, an employer organisation praised the minister. In fact, it requested the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to continue to support Minister Brereton in his approach in resisting some of the claims of the trade unions, which Senator Crane alleges are his masters.

The truth of the matter is this: Minister Brereton is in a very difficult position. He is undertaking a very difficult set of negotiations with both employers and trade unions. Minister Brereton should be praised by the Senate—he is certainly going to be praised by me—for the unstinting efforts he has made over the last six months to engage in the maximum consultation.

He has been to Tasmania a couple of times. Quite often, the industrial movement in Tasmania is not given due consideration in these matters. He has been all over the country consulting with people. I do not believe that the criticisms that Senator Crane levelled can be justified in any way.

The only other point that I will comment on very briefly is Senator Kemp's point about the minimum size of unions and adopting ILO conventions. We are consistent. There is a ruling through the ILO that our current legislation and policy is not consistent with ILO conventions. We will be respecting that, just as we will be introducing, I hope, legislation to respect ILO conventions in a number of other areas which establish very important minimum sets of wages and conditions. So we are consistent.
We are a nationalist party. But we are also internationalist in our outlook. We believe that there is an important place for UN treaties in the world. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly before Senator Kemp leaves the chamber to correct a fallacy which he raised in referring to me. If Senator Kemp refers to the voting record, he will find that what he claimed about my voting record is completely wrong.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table report No. 65 of the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee entitled Collective investments: other people's money, together with a summary of the report.

That the Senate take note of the document and statement.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 6 of 1993-94—an audit commentary on aspects of Commonwealth-state agreements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important report that should engage the Senate with a great deal of consideration in the next few months. The Auditor-General has highlighted in audit report No. 6 of 1993-94 a whole range of aspects relating to Commonwealth-state agreements. I note in the forward to the report this comment:

The commentary is not based on any particular audit, rather it draws on the collective experiences of the ANAO in auditing such agreements over recent years and comments made on specific issues by State Auditors-General and central Commonwealth agencies.
I want to concentrate on three of the nine key points made by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the ANAO has encountered circumstances where its powers to conduct efficiency audits under the Audit Act 1901 are ineffectual. Secondly, a broader range of sanctions is required to more effectively deal with instances of non-compliance with the terms of agreements. Thirdly, progress on the development of performance indicators and targets is less than satisfactory.

Whilst I have highlighted those three points, I am not saying that the other six points that are identified as key issues by the Auditor-General do not deserve equal attention by other senators. In looking at the various points that the Auditor-General raised, I think it is important, when talking about Commonwealth and state relations, to focus on effectiveness. This is highlighted by those three particular points.

The report is very comprehensive. It takes us through the various histories of a range of issues and the appropriateness of arrangements between the Commonwealth and various state governments. It also comments in detail on the various audits that are currently being conducted by the ANAO and on some arrangements that are internal. I note the comment that is made on page 19, point 2.58. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Internal audit coverage, both at Commonwealth and State levels, has been observed in many cases to be inadequate or even non-existent.
That is a pretty damning comment to which I think each and every Commonwealth department and agency must give particular attention.

PARA.TAB: My emphasis comes from the interest I have in my portfolio area of housing. I note that in the concluding remarks on page 26 at paragraph 3.11, Mr Taylor, the Auditor-General, commented:

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect that is frequently overlooked by departments and agencies is the need for clear identification, measurement and reporting of Commonwealth obligations or exposure under the agreement. In the case of housing, for example, data currently available to the department is insufficient to determine both the true levels of subsidies provided under the various housing assistance schemes and the overall exposure of the Commonwealth under its obligations to meet any shortfalls in the operation of those schemes. When reviewing performance indicators and information requirements, agencies should examine whether further improvements in these areas are possible.

Again that is a damning indictment. After a decade of administration by a Labor Government in Australia, we have reached the point where the very crux and key issue of housing, which is fundamental to many people in Australia, has received such a damning report. I would have thought that the emphasis of any minister for housing—particularly as the Deputy Prime Minister takes responsibility for this important portfolio himself—would be such that we would see less of the sort of trenchant criticism that is now being expressed by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: This report was tabled today. Recently the Auditor-General gave a different view in Audit Report No. 1 1993-94. I refer in particular to volume 6 which addressed the issues of the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services portfolio. In that report again the Auditor-General's comments in the area of housing and planning were very scary—I think that is the appropriate way to describe it—and drew attention to a range of issues and agreements between the Commonwealth government and the state governments that needed to be addressed in the performance of the Commonwealth-state agreement.

I took the opportunity to raise these issues in Senate Estimates Committee C on Friday 3 September this year. I raised the matter and put different points. In particular, I draw the Senate's attention to the comments of the Secretary of the department in responding to some of my questions. On that occasion, Mr Cole, the secretary of the department, said:

SPEECH.PARA: He—
meaning the Auditor-General—

was looking at the record over a number of years and essentially found that the conditionality that is imposed on Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement moneys to the states has not been correctly supervised; that reports from the states which were not lodged on the due dates were not pursued as assiduously as they ought to have been; that when they came in a form that was not precisely the form that the Commonwealth had asked for there was not a lot of follow-up action; that some of the phrases in the conditionality were open to more than one interpretation; that no negotiated interpretation had been arrived at and promulgated to the states; and that no unilateral attempt at better defining that conditionality had been made by the Commonwealth either.
He further states:

The ANAO formed the opinion that the department has tended in the past to undermanage the CSHA, that there remains scope for further enhancement to the agreement and the manner in which it is administered, and that until recently there was little focus on the performance monitoring and accountability.

The issues that the Auditor-General, and now the secretary of the department, have acknowledged bring us back to the point of asking `Where is housing in Australia, and what rules, regulations and arrangements between the Commonwealth department have been put in place?'

PARA.TAB: I was also concerned to find, at the estimates hearings on 3 September, that when we walked the department through a number of the issues that had been raised with them by the Auditor-General, the department had not responded with any degree of urgency. In fact, whilst it had been aware that many of these issues had been on the agenda and had been looked at for some time, it had not addressed them properly. For example, in one of the questions I raised, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Have there been any proposals to change the resources in this area to meet with the requirements and the recommendations of the auditor's report?
The response from a Mr Johnston, a departmental officer was:

There have been discussions within the division about reallocation of staffing to address these particular concerns. At the same time, negotiations are under way with the states, through the working parties that I mentioned, to develop the mechanisms to improve the timing of receipt of this information.
Further on Mr Johnston acknowledged this, when he said:

There is also the question of information flow from the states, and there have certainly been many occasions when the department has vigorously pursued the states for information and it has still taken considerable time to receive that information. As the Auditor-General notes, there have been other occasions where we have not been diligent in pursuing the information.

That is a direct acknowledgment by a Commonwealth departmental official at a senior level that the issues relating to housing have not received the degree of priority and acknowledgment that should be in place. In the Auditor-General's general portfolio report, Audit Report No. 1, and now in the specific report, An audit commentary on aspects of Commonwealth-State agreements, the issue is again drawn to our attention.

PARA.TAB: There is a need for particular emphasis and priority to be placed on this issue by the government. We must not get to the stage where we arrive at Senate estimates early next year, or perhaps at this time next year, when I stand and ask these same questions of either the minister or the officials and receive the same priority. The funding allocation, the billions of dollars of Commonwealth money that is injected into housing, is an important issue to people in Australia needing housing—particularly those requiring welfare and Aboriginal housing. It is equally important to the construction industry and to the employment prospects throughout Australia. If the government is going to walk away and not acknowledge any of the issues that are put under its nose by an Auditor-General on matters as important as these, then we are in desperate and dire straits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Tambling, I would like to point out just how timely this report is. Perhaps my perspective is, however, a little different. I am concerned about the issues that have been raised in this report and I think we should begin from the presumption that most Commonwealth programs are well managed and that the funds are allocated in accordance with the terms of agreements entered into by states. Of course, they are carefully monitored and there is very strong public accountability for the Commonwealth's use of those funds.

PARA.TAB: The problem, however, goes much deeper than just the Commonwealth of Australia and this government. It relates to the other part of the partnership, which is, of course, the states. What this report relies upon and draws attention to is the need for clearly defined roles and responsibilities of the respective parties, the inclusion of incentives to identify and harness administrative efficiencies, the introduction and ongoing refinement of program planning, performance indicators and performance targets and the ability of an escalating range of sanctions to address non-compliance with the terms of agreements and the establishment of appropriate accountability mechanisms.

It is exactly that question of non-compliance that I am concerned about. Like Senator Tambling, I raised these matters before an estimates committee. I am particularly concerned about the question of substitution where we have a number of conservative governments across this country undertaking savage budgetary cuts which are decimating national programs.

In my own state of Victoria, massive budget cuts are being undertaken, particularly in the area of education. This is an area of concern that the Commonwealth government shares, not just the Auditor-General. Back in May the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) wrote to the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hayward, asking about this very issue of substitution. It took until September for a reply to be given by the Victorian Minister, Minister Hayward, on the issue of whether or not the moneys that had been allocated to Victoria for educational purposes were being spent in accordance with the agreements entered into.

It is important to note that $310 million is provided by the Commonwealth to Victoria for a range of recurrent, capital and targeted programs. These fundings are designed to supplement state funding, not to replace state funding, which is the point that many conservative politicians have failed to realise. They have the notion that somehow or other budget cuts are something they impose on Labor constituencies.

We are seeing that again and again in Victoria, particularly in the area of education. In the north-west region of Melbourne some 51 per cent of the schools are disadvantaged, but one finds that the major cuts and closures to schools programs are occurring in those regions. One has to ask: how can the Commonwealth stand by and allow that to happen? That is exactly the question that I asked officials before the estimates committee. What is happening to Commonwealth money in Victoria? The minister replied that the Commonwealth officials were somewhat reluctant to give that information. I trust that we will be able to establish clearly what has happened.

The Auditor-General also asks about this matter. The report states that in practice, the Australian National Audit Office has noted a reluctance on the part of Commonwealth agencies to invoke the various sanction powers that are available when non-compliance has been detected. What is the problem with that? Essentially it gives the impression that the Commonwealth is not prepared to follow through with implementation agreements; it gives the impression that the Commonwealth is prepared to turn a blind eye to non-compliance.

I ask the question again: what is the accountability? The Auditor-General asks that same question. There has to be a mechanism whereby public money is directed to specified purposes. Section 96 of the constitution lays down quite clearly what the Commonwealth is able to do; that is, to make grants on such terms and conditions as the parliament sees fit for specified purposes. In my view, direct grants to the states should become more common.

In terms of education is there any concern in Victoria, apart from the obvious fact that over 200 schools are about to close? Is there any concern that this might have an impact on the $310 million that is allocated for various national equity programs? Of course there is. It is not just a political concern raised by the fact that one is seeing schools close, railway lines cut as well as cuts to state housing which have a direct bearing on national programs and various other measures undertaken by state governments.

Let us look at the question of national equity programs. In July the Directorate of School Education in Victoria distributed a discussion paper on the way in which national equity program funds should be distributed. This is a paper, I might add, that the Commonwealth officials did not seem to be able to get hold of, but which is available to those who have some familiarity with the industry in Victoria. This paper spells out the way in which money should be allocated across the schools system in Victoria.

This has to be viewed in the context of a state government program that says there should be increasing attention for school funding to the local area. On the one hand, we have a national program attempting to distribute moneys at a state level; on the other hand, we have a state program distributing moneys at a local level. Of course, this is where the problem arises. The Auditor-General points out that the real problem is being able to get into the state systems because of the various secrecy provisions and protocols of Commonwealth-State relations. This means that at either end we cannot identify where the money is going from Commonwealth sources.

It is not just the Auditor-General or Labor politicians who have expressed concern; it is also the Victorian Government's own bureaucrats. We have, for instance, the response to the discussion paper by Russell Collier, General Manager of the North West Metropolitan Region in Melbourne. That region is the largest in the education system in Victoria and has within it 143 disadvantaged schools.

In commenting on the guidelines that have been circulated on the way in which national equity funds should be spent, Mr Collier says that he is particularly concerned about the way in which there would be identified target indicators. He queries whether national equity fund programs for schools will be in addition to school grants or whether they will just be wrapped up with all of them. The question of accountability arises again. Mr Collier also asks:

SPEECH.PARA: Which of the elements will have a school targeted focus? . . . Further, which processes are intended to be used if the interchange of funds were to be adopted? The Region—
that is, the North West Metropolitan Region—
would be most concerned if funds from the Literacy and Numeracy and Disadvantaged Schools elements were arbitrarily allocated to the Country Education element.

Senior officials are expressing their concerns saying that there are real worries about the way in which there will be reporting and accountability of national moneys. I share with Senator Tambling a grave concern, but I do so from a completely different point of view.

PARA.TAB: The financial arrangements for reporting need to be tightened up. There needs to be much closer scrutiny of the way in which the states spend money. When Minister Hayward, for instance, does reply to the Commonwealth, he should give those assurances and not just glibly dismiss them by saying, `Of course there are to be no cuts to the Commonwealth's funding'. What we are concerned about is the question of whether or not state funds will be cut and whether or not there will be substitution; that is, Commonwealth moneys being used to make up for state cuts. This is where we are having some real difficulties getting to the nub of the matter.

Currently, the states report annually through the Australian national report on schools in Australia under the guidance of the Australian Education Council, which is composed of state and federal ministers. This is particularly important in the case of Victoria because of the concerns I have expressed here today. New guidelines will be required. The states will be required to sign new agreements in terms of access, participation and attainment with regard to education. They also will be required to provide evidence that disadvantaged schools and disadvantaged students are actually getting the extra help that is provided by the Commonwealth. This is a matter of deep concern where we are finding some 200 schools closing in the state of Victoria.

In my view, we have a need for the Commonwealth to ensure that those programs are followed through and that the new agreements that the Commonwealth is seeking are honoured. An unfortunate situation has arisen. The Auditor-General has identified real problems which I believe should be addressed by the national government.

In the case of education, I believe that the minister is already moving in that direction. However, it is important for Commonwealth officers to appreciate, as is highlighted in the audit report, that its responsibility is to the national government and not necessarily primarily to state officials. When I talk to officials in various government offices I sometimes get the impression that their responsibility is to each other. They have more in common with the bureaucracy at various levels than they do with the political directions set by this parliament. I would urge this parliament to take particular note of the report. I hope that the government takes these matters up very quickly.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1991 the committee requested the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to provide terms of reference for an inquiry examining Australia's relationship with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the IMF, highlighting those aspects of Australia's relationship with the World Bank and the fund which would be in Australia's long-term economic and trade interests.

PARA.TAB: The reference was advertised in national and capital city newspapers in November 1991 and the trade subcommittee of the joint committee, chaired at that time by Mr John Langmore MP, conducted public hearings in Canberra during May, August and September 1992. A further public hearing, chaired by the Hon. John Kerin MP, was held in Canberra in July 1993. In total, 76 submissions and 101 exhibits were received during the course of the inquiry.

For countries like Australia, membership of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund offers both the potential to influence their policies and the opportunity to export Australian goods and services to developing countries under their programs. Regrettably, to date Australia has not always been able to capitalise on the opportunities offered by that membership.

In its 1989 report entitled, Third World debt: an Australian view, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade examined the impact of multilateral development bank adjustment programs on the poor in developing countries. The committee recognised that the primary responsibility for action lies with recipient country governments because the impact of multilateral development bank loans on poverty depends on the policies of recipient governments. However, the World Bank and the IMF have the ability to encourage those recipient governments to increase the priority accorded to poverty reduction through their country assistance strategies and their loan conditions.

Since that report of the committee was published in 1989, the World Bank has accepted that the need to address sectoral issues is a necessary adjunct to its policy of growth through structural adjustment. While acknowledging that the bank is attempting to deal with these issues, many witnesses and other commentators considered that the change in actual policies has been inadequate and have called on Australia to play a more active role in influencing both bank and IMF policies.

Particular areas of concern addressed by witnesses to the inquiry were: the failure of the bank and fund to lead a process of major debt reduction for severely indebted countries; the social problems created by the current focus of both the bank and fund on structural adjustment loans; the failure of the bank and fund to address cross-sectoral issues such as unemployment, inequity, poverty, population, growth, land redistribution and environmental issues in developing countries; the failure of the bank to learn from its mistakes through program evaluation; and, finally, the dominance of the fund and bank by industrialised countries with a particular narrow and naively theoretical philosophy of unconstrained markets, regardless of the extent of market failure.

The committee believes that membership of the World Bank and the IMF has a five-fold benefit to Australia. It provides the opportunity to participate as an active member of the international economic and financial system and to influence the policies of the MDBs to ensure that effective and equitable development policies are implemented.

Membership also provides opportunities, on the regional level, for Australia to encourage bank and fund involvement in South East Asia and the South Pacific, thereby enhancing our regional bilateral development programs. Australia is also able to participate in the development debate in our region through the World Bank's research into the economies of the South Pacific.

Involvement in bank financed business opportunities can help Australian firms in becoming established in serving export markets in developing countries, including the Asian region. From a trade perspective, therefore, the primary benefit to be gained from Australia's membership lies in the opportunity to participate in the procurement of goods and services, particularly in areas where Australia has comparative advantage.
