In relative terms Australian service providers perform better than our manufacturers. There are a number of reasons for this, not least of which is Australia's technical excellence in the fields demanded by the bank and the approach taken by service providers when tendering for bank projects. Evidence presented to the committee indicates that this is not the case for manufacturers and that considerable work remains to be done to improve the knowledge of Australian firms about the procurement process. Greater advantage should also be taken of opportunities offered through co-financing arrangements between the Australian government and the World Bank.

The lack of publicly available information about World Bank and IMF activities and consultation over issues affecting Australia was a recurring theme throughout evidence taken during the course of this inquiry. The executive directors of Australia's constituencies in the bank and in the IMF hold positions of influence because they are conduits between the Australian government, other members of our constituency and the executive boards. While limited consultation exists between the Treasury, non-government organisations and interested departments, evidence presented to the committee indicates that this is quite inadequate.

The committee is of the view that neither the cabinet nor the parliament are adequately apprised of issues affecting Australia and, as a consequence, believes that much wider consultation is required. Therefore, the committee recommends the establishment of an advisory council on international development whose role would be to monitor bank and fund activities and to brief relevant non-government organisations, departments and the parliament.

Recently, the World Bank announced the proposed establishment of a public information centre to provide information on project procurement opportunities, appraisal and evaluation reports, environmental assessments, country economic and sector reports and policy papers. Unfortunately, the IMF is not as forthcoming with information about its activities, particularly in relation to issues affecting Australia.

Therefore, the committee believes that the Treasurer should incorporate details of the fund's article IV consultations and the voting patterns taken by Australia on decisions made with the executive boards of both the bank and fund within his annual report to the parliament on the operations of the bank and the IMF.

Concern was expressed to the committee about the substantial increase in the proportion of Australia's aid program which is now taken up by our contributions to the MDBs and the fact that further real aid cuts without substantial reductions in those made to the multilateral development banks would lead to further distortions. This concern is particularly valid, given the increased demand for bank and IMF resources to assist Eastern Europe, the former states of the Soviet Union and Vietnam.

Since 1984-85 the multilateral development banks have been protected from 15 per cent real cuts faced by the aid program as a whole. In contrast to the rest of the program, World Bank contributions have increased by 31 per cent in real terms. The committee believes that multilateral aid should be a separate component of the aid budget and that a special mechanism should be established for dealing with MDB contributions so that payment does not take pockets of money out of the bilateral aid budget.

Finally, the committee is still concerned about the monopoly held by Treasury on positions of executive director to the multilateral development banks. This practice was criticised by this committee in its 1989 report entitled, A review of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and Australia's overseas aid program. In that report, the committee recommended that Australia's executive director and alternate director positions be filled on the basis of expertise in development and development finance issues.

In evidence to the current inquiry, the Secretary to the Treasury said that it has now become standard practice for vacancies in these positions to be advertised outside the department. The committee commends Treasury for following this course when filling the recent vacancy for the position of Executive Director to the IMF. However, concern still exists that the selection process is still weighted in favour of officers with experience more relevant to Treasury's internal requirements on occasion. Therefore, the committee reiterates its earlier recommendation that the expertise in development and development finance issues be an essential criterion for selection.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the members of the committee in both the 36th and 37th parliaments for all the time and effort spent on this inquiry, in particular the chairmen, Mr Langmore and Mr Kerin. I know that Mr Sinclair and Senator Beahan had a particular interest, as did Senator Harradine. The committee members extend their appreciation to the members of the secretariat: Marina Ellis, for her work in the organisation of the public and private hearings; and Cheryl Samuels, the secretary of the subcommittee. They performed in an outstanding fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade throughout the period of the hearings that led to the report entitled, Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The issues dealt with in the report are, as Senator Loosley has indicated, very complex. But I commend the report as a useful document for those who would like some insight into what is for most the mysterious world of multilateral development aid.

PARA.TAB: I want to draw attention to only three aspects of the report. The report goes much wider than that and covers a lot of things I would like to comment on but will not have time to. Firstly, I would like to address the concern that our involvement with multilateral development banks is at the expense of our bilateral aid program. The concern is sharpened by the belief of many—and I share the view—that bilateral aid is more effective in terms of Australia's control over programs—their relevance, effectiveness and sustainability—and in meeting our strategic, political, social and humanitarian objectives.

There is also concern that in times of understandable fiscal restraint, contributions to multilateral development banks have risen in real terms. For example, since 1984-85 contributions to the World Bank have increased by 31 per cent. What this effectively means is a real-term reduction in bilateral aid.

Concern is also expressed at Treasury's insistence on the bracketing of multilateral and bilateral outlays. What this means effectively is that it is always difficult to ascertain just how the aid budget is being disbursed. Treasury's argument in support of this bracketing is, I believe, shallow. Like so much of what it does, Treasury seems to be more concerned with obfuscation than with enlightenment.

The committee recommends at recommendation 5, therefore, that multilateral and bilateral aid should be separate components of the aid budget, that there should be transparency and that there should be a special mechanism to ensure that payments to multilateral development banks do not draw funds away from the bilateral aid budget.

The second aspect I would like to draw attention to—Senator Loosley has already adverted to it—is the question of structural adjustment loans and concerns about their impact on poverty. There has been widespread concern, particularly through the 1980s, about the impact of structural adjustment loans. They are loans to developing countries to assist in coping with debt, but loans which are given on conditions that the recipient countries adopt monetary, fiscal and exchange rate policies designed to rectify their external indebtedness. There is concern that the conditions that have been set have had unacceptably harsh effects on the poor.

While it is conceded that the major cause of poverty in the countries concerned is the global and national economic situation, there is real concern, and some evidence to support that concern, that the adjustment policies that are forced on these countries have themselves been contributors to the poverty and hardship. An example of how this might occur is that the deflationary effects of bank and fund policies have often increased unemployment and decreased real wages.

Rises in food prices have added to the problem of falling incomes. Food prices have frequently risen faster than other prices because subsidies have been discontinued, because of devaluation of currencies and because of deregulation of markets, all of which have been imposed as conditions of aid programs under the structural adjustment mechanism.

It is worth noting here—and the Democrats and the Greens, who have become the new protectionists of the house, should note this—that the policies of developed countries can impact adversely on underdeveloped or developing countries. For example, the high level of agricultural protection in Europe, the USA and Japan has two impacts. Firstly, it means that the price of food is higher than it should be. The impact of this falls most heavily on low or fixed income earners so that, for example, in Japan rice costs seven times more to the Japanese than it would if they accepted imports because of the subsidies that are added to it. Of course, the impact of that is on the poorer sections of the community, not on the wealthy.
The second impact is the subsidisation of production of commodities which the developing world is well placed to produce. Page 73 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Price suppression on the international market inflicts ever lower standards of living on the developing world.

The report notes that the bank has become more aware of the impact of its adjustment policies and is acting to alleviate their impact on the poor. But it notes also that the same cannot be said about the IMF. Recommendations 17 and 18 at page 81 urge the government to use its influence to increase the emphasis on poverty alleviation in structural adjustment policies.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, I would like to look at the question of procurement and the degree to which Australian companies are sharing in the benefits which flow from our role as a reliable contributor to the bank and the fund, benefits such as the procurement of contracts for the provision of goods and services. It is only fair that Australia, as a reliable, consistent and, I might add, prompt contributor to the bank and the fund—this makes it unusual, I might say, among the supporters of those institutions—should enjoy a fair share of procurement. It applies not only to multilateral development banks but also to United Nations agencies—not that we looked at those in this report. It is also important because such participation can help Australian firms gain a foothold in potential export markets, particularly in the Asian region. They gain that foothold through getting contracts through multilateral agencies, establishing themselves in the countries concerned and later exporting to those countries.

The committee found it difficult to obtain an accurate picture of how well Australia does in gaining contracts. Statistics from the bank and other sources simply are not good enough. A number of studies have been done. Some of them throw some light on the question, but very few of them give any substantive evidence of just how we are going. Recommendations 7 and 8 at page 39 draw attention to the need for more resources to be devoted to the collection of procurement data and to the general gathering of statistics.

Some generalisations can be made, however. The first is that Australian service providers perform better than our manufacturers and there are some good reasons for that. The second is that a big proportion of Australian procurements are in the provision of raw materials. I guess there should be no surprise about that given the volume of raw materials that are exported from this country—over 30 per cent of our export activity. The third is that manufacturers do not appear to be doing as well, given the fact of course that manufacturing is a growing area here and now represents something like 29 per cent of our exports.

As Australia's production mix changes and manufacturing assumes an increasingly important role, it will be equally important to ensure that manufacturers gain a share of these contracts. There is some evidence to suggest that Australian manufacturing companies are not up to speed in this area. There is, for example, a high level of non-compliance with tender requirements for bank projects reflecting, it seems, an ignorance on the part of manufacturers tendering for these projects of the processes they have to go through. There is a general hesitancy on the part of Australian companies to bid for contracts. That hesitancy seems to be backed by a lack of understanding of the bank processes, a lack of intelligence on what is going on within the bank and the need for the formation of consortia to allow small companies to participate in the tender process.

Recommendations 9 to 20 of the report go to trying to find some solutions to these problems. They place considerable emphasis on the need for education and information for our manufacturing companies. They place considerable responsibility on Austrade and AIDAB as facilitators in this educative process. The report also recommended that Austrade and AIDAB investigate mechanisms such as business consultative groups to encourage the formation of consortia to bid for bank projects. Of course that is important, not only for the export trade but also because business can be a very good supporter of the need for higher levels of aid, which has a moral underpinning as well as an economic one.

I was very pleased to note during the hearings that one of the witnesses—I have forgotten whether the witness was from the Metal Trades Industry Association or the Chamber of Manufactures—said that growth in the aid budget was in the interests of Australian business. This is how economic motivation can blend with the moral imperative of increasing our aid budget and, I think, result in a more humane approach to the whole question of aid by this country. I commend the report to honourable senators. It is a very detailed and technical, but very useful insight into what is, as I have said, a very mysterious and difficult area to understand.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the Department of Finance minute on the committee's report No. 325—The Midford Paramount case and related matters. I seek leave to move a motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not a member of the committee that presented a very detailed report called The Midford Paramount case and related matters. It was presented in the parliament in December 1992. It was a very detailed document that was scathing in its criticism of the Australian Customs Service and other departments.

PARA.TAB: The minute that I have just tabled from the Department of Finance has been prepared on the basis of responses received from the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Department of Finance and the Attorney-General's Department. General comments are made in an appendix by the Attorney-General's Department, Australian Customs Service and the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Briefly, by way of background, although I am presenting the minute, I was not a member of the committee. My colleague Senator Bishop was a member of the committee. She has had a very strong involvement with this issue, so I will defer to her.

The committee made 134 major recommendations. The report itself, as I indicated earlier, was a damning indictment of the Australian Customs Service and others. A number of charges were made by the Australian Customs Service. In the process of making those charges, which were unproven, innocent businesses and innocent people were destroyed. Their businesses were destroyed and they themselves suffered personally.

The concern, as brought out in estimates committee hearings by Senator Bishop—and I am sure she will pursue this with great vigour—was that of those 134 recommendations one was critical. If one believes in equity, fairness, probity and propriety in respect of government, one of those recommendations was very important. That recommendation was that the defendants in the Midford case be compensated for their unrecovered material and legal costs. As Senator Bishop found in the estimates committee in discussions with the Department of Finance, which leads an interdepartmental committee, that matter has not been resolved. It is now the end of September 1993. The committee's report was released in December 1992. We have responses to all recommendations except Nos 1, 3, 64, 76 and 77 which, as pointed out in the Finance minute, are policy matters.

It is an absolute disgrace. It is unconscionable that, after nine months, the government has not responded, for whatever reason, to recommendation No. 1 of the public accounts committee that these people receive compensation. The government has responded to the other matters but, even then, I would have to say that the slowness—nine months—to respond to a report of incredible detail put out by the public accounts committee is an indictment of not only the Public Service, but also this Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Parer with the most enormous sense of sadness at the way the bureaucracy is reacting to this report. The report on the Midford Paramount affair was dealt with in a bipartisan way by the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We brought down a unanimous report saying that grave injustice had been done to these individuals. Yet, we find still within the bureaucracies concerned intransigence—a refusal to say that they were wrong.

PARA.TAB: My concern is this: this IDC mechanism has been allowed to drag on for so long that one could be forgiven for thinking that the bureaucracy has taken the view that the people concerned will be dead, bankrupt or both before it is forced to make a decision. I say `dead' not in a light way. There was evidence in the Midford hearings of one man who was put under so much pressure that he did, in fact, die. There is more evidence of a man who was once a bold, strong, strapping man at the beginning of the inquiry who is now constantly hospitalised; he is about half his former size and is a wreck.

There is evidence of another man whose business was so destroyed that he wrote to us—indeed he has spoken to me in the last 48 hours—saying that, unless something is done to solve this impasse with this IDC committee, he will be bankrupt; he will have to close his business in the next five or six weeks. If the bureaucracy thinks it can beat the parliament and beat the public accounts committee by obfuscating, by taking evidence and continuing to refer, as it does, to a firm of accountants in a way that simply protracts the whole affair and holds it up, we will have people who are both dead and bankrupt—and the deaths and bankruptcies will weigh on the minds of those public servants who are responsible.

In the estimates committee hearing the other day the mood of both government and opposition senators was unanimous. The message to Finance was: `Get this matter resolved and get this compensation paid'. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has written to this IDC and told it: `Do not retry this matter. Do not retry the facts and judge culpability. That has been done by a committee of the parliament'. He said, `Just work out how much is to be paid'. As Senator Parer said, it is now nine months since that report came down. It is several weeks since we had that estimates committee hearing and still we have intransigence. I repeat that, if people either die or are forced into bankruptcy and ruination because of the deliberate obfuscation of the bureaucracy, a curse will remain upon their heads.

Justice is what the committee wanted to see done in this matter—justice for people who were wronged and who had the might of the bureaucracy against them. They fought back and, despite the fact that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet tried to prevent evidence being given to the court which proved that the action against Midford and others was wrongful, the court had the wisdom to say that the evidence was to be made available. The evidence was, indeed, cabinet minutes. It was through raising the matter in parliament and getting former Senator Tate to authorise the release of those documents that, finally, the whole picture was there for people to see.

But what we are seeing now is something that I can only describe as a wicked practice. The bureaucracy seems to have taken the attitude that, if it is forced to pay compensation, somehow this will be a precedent, that somehow it will be seen in a light that it does not want to be seen in. Well, tough!

It was wrongful action that has destroyed the lives, reputations and livelihoods of ordinary Australians who came to this parliament for help. Through the committee we found them that help; we brought down a report; and the Prime Minister has told the Department of Finance and its IDC to say how much is to be paid. I say in this parliament today that that amount of money should be up and coming and paid forthwith. There should be no more delays, no more obfuscation. If it is not, it is tantamount to the bureaucracy acting in contempt of the parliament. I think those matters will have to be pursued; they are very serious.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think this is the first time I have seen you in the chair, congratulations; it is good to see you up there. I present the second report of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee considering the powers, functions and operation of the Loan Council has to some extent been frustrated in that it has sought certain witnesses, some of whom are members of parliament and some are not, and some witnesses have chosen not to appear before the committee. In relation to those who are members of parliament, we have pursued an investigation as to how we may be able to get them before the committee. On the advice of the Clerk of the Senate, we are seeking in this report that the Senate pass a motion requesting the relevant houses in which these members of parliament sit to ask the relevant members of parliament to appear before our committee.

PARA.TAB: The reason for choosing this course of action is that the powers of one of the houses of parliament in this country with respect to the powers of another house of parliament in this country are ill-defined when it comes to bringing witnesses before another house of parliament. Those powers are clearly defined with respect to the Senate calling members of the House of Representatives or vice versa, but not with respect to, say, the Senate calling a member of a state house. Therefore, it seemed appropriate that, in the first instance, the request for these people to appear before a Senate committee be made in that form—as a request from the Senate to the relevant house that those members appear.

It may be argued that we are seeking witnesses who will give evidence that may not greatly extend the evidence that has already been received. But I would point out that the Loan Council administers the borrowings of money in this country to the extent of tens of billions of dollars. We know that a number of the states have gone outside agreed limits—most recently in the case of Victoria, but not only in the case of Victoria. We know also from the evidence we have received so far that the way in which that Loan Council has been administered, the way in which determinations of amounts are made and the way in which decisions in relation to those amounts are made is secretive and certainly not open to the scrutiny that it should be.

We have already had members of state parliaments come before us. We have had the former Premier of New South Wales and we have had the current Treasurer of Victoria. The evidence they have given indicates that we do need evidence from other members of state parliaments, treasurers and premiers to give a rounded picture of the operation of the Loan Council, because the recommendations which our committee will be able to make with respect to the better operation of the Loan Council will be very much in the broader interests of this country.

I think every member of the committee would agree that the operation of the Loan Council in the past has been totally unsatisfactory and very much in need of reform. Some reforms have occurred. I think the committee would take the view that further reforms are desirable and, in framing those further reforms, the evidence of other members of state parliaments would be desirable.

I commend the report to the Senate. I understand that at least one, possibly two, other members of the committee will want to make a few remarks; they have submitted a dissenting report. After they have spoken I

SPEECH.PARA: will be seeking leave to move a motion which will lie on the table until next week in relation to that matter of the request from this Senate to the relevant state houses of parliament for those witnesses to appear before our committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am currently deputy chair of the committee dealing with the Australian Loan Council and Senator Coulter from the Australian Democrats is the chair. Yes, I wish to make some comments about the second report of the committee, and Senator Carr and I have attached a dissenting report. Firstly, I think we should note that this is obviously not the first report of this committee. The first report was handed down some two weeks before 13 March. It was interesting that—
—Why didn't the other member on your side sign it?

—Senator Bishop is interjecting. Her continual lateness in her attendance at this committee was of particular note and particularly disruptive to the proceedings of the committee. Rather than interject, I suggest she goes away and has a good look at her own record of appalling attendance when she has been so preoccupied with attempting to undermine the honourable member in the other place, Dr Hewson, in trying to take over as leader. I think she should concentrate more on the duties she is paid for rather than attempting to remove her own leader.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, we are very concerned that this report is a continuation of what has clearly been a partisan political agenda set by the opposition members of the committee as well as, but I suspect for different reasons—well, I will assert for different reasons—the former Leader of the Australian Democrats and chair of the committee, Senator Coulter.

It is rather ironic that the states requested that we have a states house, the Senate, and we now have what is purportedly the states house, the Senate, attempting to pressure and coerce those state houses to require both current and former premiers and ministers to attend Senate committee hearings. It is a little ironic, and I think it represents yet another catalogue of a grab for power by the Senate far beyond that which was envisaged by the writers of the constitution—and I will not go into the particular situation that we face with the budget. We have a total grab for power by the Senate in this case.

It will be interesting to see whether, in fact, state Liberal governments are happy at the process that is being proposed in this report. I suspect they will not be. I suspect we will see a divergence of opinion between the various state Liberal governments in this country. I suspect they will not be very happy at the Senate attempting to lord it over the state parliaments, which is what is being proposed.

There are good reasons for ending the state of farce that has existed with this committee. Firstly, there is the enormous cost to date of the operation of this committee. The second reason why this committee should finish its work—and I think it is a very important reason—is that the current Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and government have already carried out reforms of the Loan Council. There has already been extensive reform of the operation of the Loan Council. Why are we continuing to waste public money inquiring into the way in which the Loan Council used to operate when, in fact, it has been extensively reformed, and evidence has been given that those reforms are of considerable value?

We have reached the point where clear and ample evidence—quite sufficient evidence—has been put before the committee to reach a satisfactory conclusion about the various aspects of the Loan Council. It is a little ironic and a bit perverse that, two weeks before the last election, when we had not even heard from a third of the witnesses, we were handing down interim reports, criticising the Treasurer of this country, Mr Dawkins. We had heard such little evidence yet we were making recommendations two weeks before the election. Now, when we have heard so much evidence, we need more. There is a basic contradiction which is brought about by the fact that this committee is pursuing a political agenda, not a genuine inquiry—and I will have an opportunity to speak on the motion next week. That is not the purpose for which the committee was established. It is not the purpose of this Senate to pursue political partisan agendas when we should be examining, and have examined in sufficient detail, the operation of the Loan Council.

We have not had a chance to publicly debate in the Senate the procedures that we went through prior to the 13 March election. We had a state of high farce. Meetings were being held in airport terminals. A member of the committee who was ill in hospital was interviewed in his pyjamas. We had telephone votes—and we could not identify who was at the other end of the telephone. It is no wonder that the reputation of this committee, and indeed, of the Senate, was severely damaged by the shenanigans that went on and the sham that occurred, led by opposition members, prior to the election.

I had hoped that, after the election—and the convincing re-election of this government—and the events in the two- or three-week period prior to the election, the situation would change. For a time I did believe that the committee was pursuing a reasonable position and was concluding its deliberations and its evidence. I am afraid my hopes have been dashed by the determination of both the Liberal and Democrat members to continue to pursue a partisan political agenda. What are they attempting to do? They are attempting to pressure and coerce—whether or not we call it a request—the state parliaments to require the attendance of none other than the premier of New South Wales. They are requiring the attendance of the current Treasurer and the former Treasurer of Tasmania, Mr Rundle and Mr Gray respectively. Mr Gray was responsible for sending Tasmania bankrupt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring him in here!

—We are not about usurping state rights. I will be very happy to hear from former Premier Gray. There is a principle at stake here, that is, the right of the Senate to pressure or otherwise coerce state parliaments. If we get to the stage where these people are successfully pressured and coerced to appear before the Senate committee, I will certainly be interested to hear from former Premier and Treasurer Gray. There is also an attempt to coerce former Premier Kirner, former Treasurer Sheehan and former Minister White from Victoria; former Treasurer and Premier John Bannon from South Australia; and the current Treasurer of the country, John Dawkins, to appear before the committee.
—He's hiding behind the skirts of the PM.

—I can give Senator Bishop an answer and I am tempted to give it to her in terms as blunt as those which were used by the Prime Minister, but I will not do that on this occasion. We certainly do not believe that the Treasurer of this country will appear before this committee. The committee has served its purpose. It is time this farce was brought to an end. It is time that we stopped wasting money and it is time that we got on with the business of this Senate, which is to pass legislation.

—We have to get a few things straight on the record. The first thing is this: Mr Dawkins, the Treasurer of the nation, misled the Australian people by failing to include in the budget prospectus—the single most important set of finance statements published in any given year—the fact that he knew that the Victorian government had breached the guidelines of the Loan Council by converting short term debt into medium term debt. He knew it. We established the date on which he knew it, the place where, and how he came to know it. He deliberately failed to include those facts in the budget documents.

PARA.TAB: I thought it would be perfectly reasonable for the Senate to want to ask Mr Dawkins why he did not include those facts in the budget statement. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said to the Treasurer, `Hide behind my skirts. You are not going to appear'—not the independent Treasurer, our Mr Dawkins, except when he tries to tell the Senate that it has to deal with unconstitutional bills. Mr Dawkins was hiding behind the skirts of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, like a boy. This Senate is saying that that is not good enough. He has evidence that should be heard so that we can determine why it was that Mr Dawkins misled the Australian people.

The second thing we have been investigating is the way in which the Loan Council can best operate for the future, particularly taking into account the reforms or the changes that are being implemented. The one thing that is coming through loud and clear is that there does seem to be a little clique of people in the bureaucracy and they keep the mysteries of the Loan Council to themselves, when there should be far greater accountability and knowledge of how it works so that its function can be useful.

To be honest, I thought that the evidence given by former Premier Nick Greiner was the most useful evidence we have heard to date. He explained in lucid, simple, easy to understand terms how he felt the Loan Council should operate, that we should effectively have a federal balance sheet so that we know precisely what is going on in the federal and state arena and so that we can make a sensible judgment about the way in which the needs of states and the Commonwealth can be served in terms of a loan agreement. So the committee has that dual function which I have just outlined.

The examination of how the Loan Council can best operate in the future is continuing. We are still hearing useful evidence. It will be worth while if we do nothing else but get rid of the mystique so that ordinary folk can understand the machinations of this little cell of people who share the information between themselves. We had the example of a former head of Treasury in Victoria writing to the head of Treasury in the federal arena and virtually telling him to go jump in the lake when he asked for information that related to how the Loan Council would operate. If we do nothing else but open it right up so that people understand the use and function of the Loan Council, this committee will have served that part of its purpose.

We will not be able to get to the bottom of whether or not there was collusion between people in the Victorian government and the federal government to prevent this information getting into the public arena because Mrs Kirner had an election to face—in other words, whether the proper processes of government were being subverted to a political process—unless we hear from the likes of Mr Dawkins, Mr Sheehan in particular, Mrs Kirner and Mr White. Mr Bannon could have a useful contribution to make all of his own. We might find out all sorts of things—like the things which were found out about the State Bank of South Australia.

The really serious point that does need to be addressed and the reason why the Senate is taking this serious step relates to the action of the Victorian Labor Party caucus. It had a little caucus meeting and it said to Mr Sheehan and Mrs Kirner and Mr White, `You will not appear before that committee because we, the Labor Party caucus'—the faceless men—`say you will not appear and give evidence'. It was not of their own volition but in a secret, closed meeting. I call the Labor Party caucus faceless men because they are generally not known to the Australian public. They are people who sit and determine that a former premier, a former treasurer and a former minister may not answer the call to give evidence.

What sort of a free country is this when a caucus can tell people they cannot appear before a committee? It is one thing for a Prime Minister to try to shield his inept Treasurer from making a fool of himself—or he thinks he will make a fool of himself—but it is quite another thing for the caucus to usurp the function of determining what information will go onto the public record and what will not. That is why this perfectly proper request is being dealt with today in the Senate. It is a question that will no doubt be resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the minority report, and to point out some of the inadequacies in the majority report, of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council which is before the Senate at the moment. I was interested to hear the remarks made by Senator Bishop. Perhaps those, more than any other, highlight just how inadequate this report is. As Senator Bishop indicated today, she has already made up her mind. She is very clear on what she believes has happened; she is absolutely certain about what is going on. Is it not a surprise that she found Nick Greiner's evidence the most useful of all, further reinforcing my belief that she has clearly made up her mind?

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop is concerned about the Labor caucus. Again, that goes to the nub of the problem. She is very concerned that she is not in government, whereas nationally we are. She talks about the faceless people in Victoria. One of the reasons they are `faceless', or are not known nationally—despite the fact that they have been elected and despite the fact that they represent the people of Victoria in their constituencies—is that, unlike Senator Bishop, they do not spend hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money flipping around the country telling everybody about their interests in replacing Dr Hewson. The real faceless people are members of the campaign committee behind Senator Bishop in her attempts to replace Dr Hewson.

Quite clearly, this Senate committee's agenda was spelt out very early in the piece—just before the last federal election. We only have to turn to the report put out just before the last federal election and look at clause 2.72, where the agenda is abundantly clear. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence so far has not revealed that the Treasurer acted to protect the Labor Government in Victoria against the advice of Treasury.

I emphasise the words `so far'. It is quite clear that in March the intention was to find the evidence. Since that time it has dredged Port Phillip Bay, running backwards and forwards and dragging around the bottom of the bay, and it has not been able to find the evidence that it said `so far' it was not able to reveal in March. It will not be able to find it if it continues this farce. Clause 2.72 of the original report continues:

However, it remains an open question as to whether Treasury's advice was tailored to the understanding that the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, would not have compromised the Kirner Government in an election year, if at all.

The intention of this committee is quite obvious. It is not to conduct a proper and legitimate inquiry; it is to engage in a political witch-hunt and a campaign of slur. It is engaged in a campaign to try to snare Treasurer Dawkins with some claim that it has created in its own mind as to what occurred in 1992.

PARA.TAB: It is totally inappropriate to continue with this farcical witch-hunt because a great deal of time has passed and a great deal of change has occurred. In late September yet another attempt is being made to drag out the work of this committee. The whole import of this proposal is to drag before the committee of this Senate members of other parliaments and to drag out the whole proceedings. One would have to question the motives behind that. What is the point? We have already gained quite extraordinary amounts of pertinent and relevant information. The committee has been conducting business for 11 months. It has held nine major public hearings. It has heard evidence from 46 expert witnesses from right across the spectrum of government in this country. It has already presented an interim report, where the majority of members have already stated their conclusions. They have already made up their minds. So what is the point of proceeding with this farce?

We all know that Victoria is the opposition's target, despite the breaches that have occurred in New South Wales—for instance, the Sydney Harbour tunnel scheme. A number of other states, as Senator Coulter indicated, have breached the guidelines in a whole series of ways. The Opposition's target is Victoria. Its campaign is designed to attack its political opponents in Victoria. The device it is adopting is rather crude and, I might suggest, will rebound on it. I will come to that in a minute.

There has already been a general election in Victoria. We have already seen a change of government in that state. We have already seen changed circumstances in the way in which the government of that state is administering its relations with the Loan Council. Since that time we have seen, sadly, a further deterioration in the economic indicators in that state. We have already seen much greater borrowings in that state—an increase of $2.2 billion. We have seen an increase in unemployment. We have seen an increase in the level of debt. We have seen all these things. It is quite clear that the Opposition will not be able to hide that from the people of Victoria for too much longer. We have also seen that the secretaries of both the Victorian government Treasury and the Commonwealth government Treasury have changed in that time. The Loan Council operations themselves have changed dramatically.

What is at the core of this issue is the debate about interpretation and terminology. We have seen plenty of evidence to suggest that there is a club operating at the Loan Council. There are questions of confidentiality and there are devices by which all governments come to arrangements to secure loan borrowings. There is no attempt in the Loan Council for anybody to sit down and say, `This is approved for a good purpose or a bad purpose'. When we questioned the present Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Stockdale, he indicated that he would resent quite strongly the notion that the Commonwealth government should at any point give any approval to funding borrowings and should have any role in the determination of what those borrowings are for.

We have seen quite important improvements already occurring in the way in which Loan Council operations are undertaken. We have had plenty of evidence to suggest just how effective those changes are. We are really talking about a witch-hunt. We are not talking about good administration of government and we are not talking about sound financial management. We are talking about a political witch-hunt; we are talking about trying to tar and feather people; and we are talking about dragging people before a committee of this chamber. Essentially, we are talking about trying to undermine the normal relationships between houses of parliament in this federation. It is important to bear that in mind.

There is no precedent for the action that is being proposed here—none at all. There is a general principle that has operated throughout the federation that houses of parliament have comity. There is this notion that we cannot mistreat members of parliament from another jurisdiction. We have this notion of privilege. The opposition is seeking to have privileges removed from the Labor members in Victoria. Woe betide the opposition because one day there will be another Labor government in Victoria. What will it say to the proposition of a Labor government there, using this precedent, calling Liberal members of the Senate before a state house in Victoria? That is clearly the precedent that the opposition is setting. It is clearly attempting to establish arrangements whereby members of this Senate can be called before state houses of parliament to assist with their inquiries, to use your good old copper's narks sort of language. That is precisely what this game is about.

The opposition does not seem to appreciate just how serious a precedent it is setting. In effect, it is talking about revenge and the notion that we won an election which it thought it had in the bag. It has to try to use the powers of this parliament and the Senate in such a way as to attempt to undermine that government and basically make up for the fact that it lost an election.

In my view, this report basically puts forward proposals which are unprecedented, incredibly dangerous and which in the end will not result in the good government of this country but establish a system of retribution, which will continue. There will be no time in which people can suggest that that will not occur because, quite clearly, there will be Labor majorities in state houses and they will reply in kind. And would not the opposition expect that?

One cannot honestly say that this committee has operated in any other way than in a partisan way. Why should not people be wary about being dragged before a committee which is operating in such a partisan way? Why should not people be concerned about being dragged before a jury that has already made up its mind? The opposition has demonstrated again today that that is clearly its intent. It has no intention of following a legitimate inquiry. The final report of this committee can now be written. There is no need to seek a further extension to this terrible farce.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Carr totally misrepresented the question of my travel expenses, which I put out and I published. I am the only member of parliament whose details of travel expenses are known to the public. The so-called expenses of ministers which have been published leave out the cost of ordinary air travel.

PARA.TAB: Senator Carr said that I had spent hundreds of thousands of dollars, but he was wrong. The figures for a 12-month period, including the election, were $64,000 for air fares, $26,000 for cars and $3,000 on the charter allowance. I ask whether or not members of the Labor Party, who seem to show such great interest in this matter, would like to publish the details of their travel expenses.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! Senator Bishop, you wanted only to correct things, and you have done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief comments about this report, particularly in view of the quite outrageous statements of Senator Sherry and Senator Carr about the procedures. Let us get certain matters clear. The first point that underpins the whole of this report is that this request of the Senate follows the proper processes clearly laid down by established procedures and mores of this parliament and our parliamentary system. Senator Sherry and Senator Carr seem to be saying that certain people in this country are above the normal processes and scrutiny of the parliament. I absolutely and totally reject that proposition, as would any thinking Australian.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry made some absolutely extraordinary statements. He claimed that the reputation of the Senate was damaged by the actions of the coalition in a couple of meetings held in the weeks preceding the election. I have never seen anyone to whom it so ill behoves to make such a statement. Senator Sherry came in here and talked about people usurping states rights, usurping this and usurping that. I hope that I am not breaching confidentialities, but I think it is generally known—it has appeared in the press—that Senator Sherry used quite improper processes to usurp the chair of the committee in the two or three weeks prior to the last election. He tried to manipulate a result from that committee in the most outrageous way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone else did that. They actually did a better job than I did.

—It was Senator Sherry and his colleagues—the whole bunch. I have never—and am sure Senator Coulter will nod acquiescence—seen such an act of political thuggery in my whole life. If one did not know that it was par for the course for some government members and senators, one would have thought it unbelievable for Senator Sherry to come in here today and postulate on matters in the way that he did.
—We are well trained before we come in here.

—I take that interjection. The characters on the other side of the chamber have grown up in a whole milieu of thuggery, coercion and pressure. I am glad to see that it has been acknowledged on the public record.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I seek a ruling on whether the word `thuggery' is considered to be parliamentary language.
—In the circumstances, I think the word `thuggery' should not be used. I ask Senator Short to withdraw that word.

—Yes. I used the term `political thuggery' the first time and I should have used it the second time. That was what I was referring to. Mr Acting Deputy President, I hope you would agree that `political thuggery' is not an unparliamentary term.
—There was no objection to its use the first time anyway. Senator Short has withdrawn the word `thuggery'.
—Yes; I substitute `political thuggery', though. I think it was Senator Sherry who said that we were trying to pressure and coerce all these people to come and appear. That is simply not correct.
—That is what Robin Gray said. Your own person; your own Liberal member in Tasmania.

—Premier Fahey and Mr Gray were invited to appear before the committee in the same way as a whole range of other witnesses, including those mentioned in this report. I understand that both of those gentlemen were prepared to come and give evidence before the committee. Mr Gray was slotted in at a set time of the hearing we had in Melbourne a few weeks ago, but due to sudden and unexpected cabinet pressures in Tasmania, he had to cancel that engagement. I understand that there has never been any suggestion on Mr Gray's part, or for that matter on Premier Fahey's part, not to come.

PARA.TAB: We are all aware that former Premier Greiner came without any coercion or any pressure. He came because he knew that the committee had important terms of reference and an important role to play. He came along very willingly, as did the now Victorian Treasurer, Mr Stockdale. The real problem is with those witnesses who are former ministers, particularly, but not exclusively, of the former Labor government in Victoria, and who were party to loan arrangements or borrowing arrangements which breached, in a massive way—to the tune of $1.3 billion—the guidelines of the Australian Loan Council and therefore caused very considerable problems for the confidence and the integrity of Australia's financial system.

The problem arises because of former Premier Joan Kirner; former Treasurer, Tony Sheehan; and a former senior minister, the Hon. David White; and the reason they are not coming varies. Mr Sheehan is not coming because, as I think Senator Bishop said, the caucus of the Labor Party in Victoria told him, `Thou shalt not appear'. But Tony Sheehan had indicated that he would appear. My advice is that he would like to appear, but he has been hobbled by the caucus in Victoria saying, `You're not to appear'. I think that caucus decision also relates to Mrs Kirner and David White.

Senator Carr, in his vitriolic outburst in this matter, and Senator Sherry are asking: should we, as a Senate, as a house of parliament with responsibility to pursue the issues that are the terms of reference of this committee, allow ourselves to have the task that the Senate has given this committee truncated and made impossible of proper carriage and examination because of the dictates or the resolutions of some caucus or group here, there or wherever around the country? That is what the issue is about. This issue now concerns whether we are serious about maintaining the authority of the Senate and its ability to pursue matters that it has a responsibility to pursue on behalf of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a witch-hunt.

—Senator Carr says that it is a witch-hunt. The simple facts deny that totally. We are not just asking former Labor premiers or ministers to come before the Senate; we are asking a range of state politicians and others who could provide a very useful input to the committee's deliberations. They are members of both sides of politics. That is one of the reasons why we would like Premier Fahey and Mr Gray to appear. If we did not ask those people, those opposite would say, `You are just asking Labor politicians'. That is simply not true, as the report shows.

PARA.TAB: This issue is about the Senate being able to maintain its authority and carry out the responsibilities that it has been accorded. What is very interesting is why the government is so sensitive about this issue. Why is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) so sensitive and arrogant in his refusal to allow the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to make up his own mind? The Prime Minister has said, `Treasurer, you are not allowed to appear before this committee or have anything to do with it under any circumstances'. Why is he so arrogant, obdurate and sensitive?
Equally, why is Treasurer Dawkins exactly of the same mould? What have Prime Minister Keating, Treasurer Dawkins, former Premier Kirner and former state Treasurer Sheehan in particular got to hide?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—If they do not have anything to hide, there is no earthly reason why they should not appear before this committee. This report asks them to do that. The coalition members of this committee and the chairman, Senator Coulter, are concerned with producing a report which does justice to, and reflects the role of, the Senate and the responsibility that the Senate has placed in this committee to carry out the task that it was allotted.

PARA.TAB: I welcome this report in one way. I am very sad about it in another way, because it is a report that should never have been written. It should not have had to be produced. The only reason it has been produced is that certain politicians—all of those who have refused point blank are Labor politicians—have refused to appear before the committee.

None of this would have happened if we had had a full and open exchange on the matter and a willingness by those people who are intimately involved in the workings of the Loan Council to see a better functioning of our financial system in Australia. It is their failure to appear that has produced this report, which otherwise would have been quite unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Short and I would like to make a personal explanation. The area of misrepresentation is the allegation that I used political thuggery to become the chairman of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council. That is simply not correct.

PARA.TAB: At the third meeting of the committee at the Ansett lounge in Sydney—we have met in so many Ansett lounges, it is a bit hard to remember them all now—Senator Coulter, who was the chairman of the committee, ruled that the report that we had already adopted could be reversed, that in fact the majority report that we had already adopted could become the minority report and we could overturn a previous decision of the committee. He ruled in that way as the chairman. Senator Faulkner then moved dissent to the chairman's ruling.

All of us in this place should be familiar with the ruling that, when a motion of dissent is moved, the chairman must automatically hand over the committee to the deputy chairman. I am not going to go into the other events, some of which I have mentioned today. So Senator Coulter quite rightly handed the chair over to me as deputy chairman while that dissent motion was being heard. That is how I came to hold the position of chairman of that committee on that occasion.

There was no manipulation or political thuggery, as Senator Short has alleged. I just happened to know my standing orders on that occasion. That is the context in which I became chairman for about half an hour while that committee debated the dissent motion in Senator Coulter's absence. Frankly, I would be surprised if Senator Coulter alleged that, by some sort of coercion or political thuggery, I became chairman of the committee for approximately half an hour. They are the circumstances, and they are quite innocent.

As I recall, it was a pretty heated debate. We all got a bit angry. I recall that we left the lounge. Former Prime Minister Bob Hawke was in the lounge. He was quite struck by the vehemence of the debate on all sides. We had all had a pretty whacking afternoon at each other. That is the context in which I became the acting chairman of the committee for half an hour. It was simply a case of conforming with the standing orders of this place and of the committee. That is as it should properly have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented. I do not want to take too much more time on this. As Senator Sherry said, it is hard to remember which airport we met in and so on. It was quite an extraordinary situation.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO.2) 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill makes amendments to a number of Acts within the Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services Portfolio. The amendments are largely of a minor procedural nature and are aimed at rectifying a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 2 of the bill amends Part II of the Disability Services Act 1986 and, although of a minor nature, will improve the professional administration of the Disability Services Program. It will do so in two ways. Firstly, the amendment to section 14J of the Disability Services Act 1986 will make it clear that a statement which the Minister is permitted to make under the section, regarding funded organisations' breaches of prescribed standards under the Act, will not become the subject of a defamation action nor will any person who fairly reports or summarises the statement be liable for defamation. This amendment restates the common law. The provisions should save litigation costs.

Secondly, where an organisation's assets are to be transferred to another person, transferees will be asked under section 16 of the Disability Services Act 1986, as a condition of approval, to sign agreements acknowledging the extent of any Commonwealth equity in the transferred land, buildings and equipment. This will place transferees in the same situation as the original grantee with respect to the protection of Commonwealth equity.

Part 3 of the bill amends the Health Insurance Act 1973. The amendments in this Part correct anomalies arising from the passage of the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991. In general these amendments are of a minor technical and administrative nature and do not have any substantive effect.

Clause 23DK extends the duty of responsibility for the keeping of relevant records to Approved Pathology Authorities who were the employers of an approved pathology practitioner at the time the service was rendered and the approved pathology practitioner is no longer employed by the approved pathology authority. It is impractical to require the approved pathology practitioner to continue to carry the responsibility for the retention of records, created at a time when he or she was in the employ of the approved pathology authority, after that employment has ceased.

Clause 23DNAA extends the exclusion of public authorities to include `joint ventures' between public authorities and private persons or corporations. Public authorities are funded through other arrangements. Without this amendment these `joint ventures' would be entitled to claim (additional) Medicare benefits as a private provider of pathology services. This is inconsistent with the intent of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

Clause 23DNC provides for a review of determinations made in respect to the allocation of specimen collection licences in special circumstances. Under the existing provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973 determinations made under this section are not subject to review and may remain in force at the discretion of the licensee. This amendment is to implement measures to ensure that determinations made for the granting of specimen collection licences in special circumstances remains for as long as those `special circumstances' continue to exist.

Part 4 of the bill makes three amendments to the Hearing Services Act 1991. The first of these is to extend the definition of "eligible persons" to include holders of a "Dependent Treatment Entitlement Card". This will ensure that widows of veterans are adequately covered under this Act. The second and third amendments provides for the official symbol of Australian Hearing Services to be included within the protected symbol provisions of the Act and so prevent unauthorised use of the Authority's symbol.

Part 5 of the bill amends the National Health Act 1953. The amendment provides that a pharmacist who wishes to relocate a pharmacy must obtain approval in respect of the new premises, and that the Commonwealth cannot pay for pharmaceutical benefits which have been supplied from unapproved premises.

These provisions have been in the NHA for many years; however, prior to the passage of the pharmacy restructuring legislation in December 1990 they were not rigorously enforced, particularly in the case of comparatively short distance relocations. In any case, approval of relocations was virtually automatic provided that the requirements of State law were met. As a result, it is suspected that a number of pharmacists have relocated their businesses without obtaining the necessary approval.

Since the advent of the pharmacy restructuring, it has become necessary to enforce these provisions. The pharmacy restructuring guidelines provide for different rules to apply depending on the distance of a relocation, and also the distance to the nearest pharmacy is a consideration in granting an approval of a pharmacist or the payment of an essential pharmacy allowance.

Some eight cases where a pharmacist had relocated without approval came to light during 1991/92. In these cases act of grace payments and/or waivers of recovery were approved by the Minister for Finance.

The Health Insurance Commission now wishes to conduct a survey to establish with certainty the location of each approved pharmacist's premises. To ensure compliance with the survey by approved pharmacists, it wishes to assure them that they will not be penalised for unapproved relocations which occurred prior to the commencement of the pharmacy restructuring legislation.
The Department of Finance considers it inappropriate to continue to use the act of grace and waiver powers to deal with what could be a large number of unapproved relocations.

Thus to prevent an injustice in either seeking to recover moneys or to put a pharmacist out of business we are seeking to amend the NHA to deem as approved at their new premises those approved pharmacists who relocated without obtaining approval, prior to 18 December 1990 (the date of effect of legislation establishing the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority).

Part 7 of the bill repeals subsection 25(2) and section 38 of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986. These unproclaimed provisions relate to the regulation of government nursing homes under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. With the transfer of responsibility for the regulation of nursing homes to the National Health Act 1953, the provisions are no longer needed.

Part 8 of the bill introduces a number of changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. Clauses 29(h), 30, 31 and 32 will amend the Principal Act to facilitate the introduction of complementary State and Territory legislation that will support the regulatory framework set up under the Commonwealth's therapeutic goods legislation.

Amendments to the objects of the Therapeutic Goods Act have been included to clarify the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories in establishing a uniform national system of controls over therapeutic goods.

Uniform regulation over the quality, efficacy and safety of therapeutic goods manufactured for supply and use in Australia cannot be achieved without the establishment of corresponding State and Territory laws that will adopt the Commonwealth's regulatory requirements in respect of appropriate standards, including manufacturing and advertising standards, for therapeutic goods. The States and Territories have agreed to set up complementary legislation to complement the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. It is anticipated that state complementary legislation will be in place by as early as 1994. When this occurs, the amendments to the Principal Act dealing with complementary legislation will be activated by proclamation.

On 25 January 1993 Australia acceded to the Convention for the Mutual Recognition of Inspections in respect of the manufacture of pharmaceutical products. This convention allows for the mutual exchange of information on the manufacturing standards of manufacturers in the eighteen signatory nations. This will allow regulatory authorities in those countries to establish the acceptability of manufacturing standards and procedures used in the manufacture of imported pharmaceutical products without the need for overseas inspections to be undertaken by the importing country. Under this scheme export of Australian manufactured pharmaceutical products will be greatly enhanced. The inclusion of clauses 29(i), 37(b), 38(b), 47 and 50(d) will give effect to the convention.

Changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act are necessary to clarify the application of the Act to goods such as first aid kits and other packs containing mixed products. Such kits fall within the definitions of `therapeutic goods' and `therapeutic use' already existing in the Act.

These amendments make provision for the inclusion in the Register of kits, as a single entity, where the individual therapeutic goods contained in each kit have already been registered or listed in the Register. Provision is also made to enable a number of kits to be grouped together, as a `gazetted kits group', so that each kit may share a common listing number and sponsors of groups of kits need only pay one set of annual charges for maintaining listings of grouped kits in the Register.

The proposals have been discussed with companies supplying kits and the industry associations and have their agreement. Entry of kits on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods is necessary to enable complete traceability of therapeutic goods which are supplied either separately or in the kits.

Other amendments included in Part 8 of this bill seek to clarify the meaning and operation of the Therapeutic Goods Act and to address problems that have surfaced since the Act came into operation two and a half years ago.

The powers of the Secretary to declare goods exempt from the operation of the Act when labelled in a particular way is to be changed to close a potential loophole. Many goods may not qualify as therapeutic goods but for the way they are presented for supply. Therefore the Secretary may declare goods to be therapeutic goods where their presentation suggests any therapeutic use. At present sponsors could label their goods in a certain manner to avoid regulation, yet subsequently advertise or present their products as therapeutic goods. The amendment will preclude this from happening.

The definition of an `authorised person' is to be amended to make appropriately experienced members of the Australian Federal Police authorised persons for the purposes of Part 6 of the Principal Act. This will simplify administrative procedures when such officers are called upon to assist the Therapeutic Goods Administration with its investigations into breaches of the Principal Act.

The definition of manufacturing premises is to be amended to remove the restriction that such premises are to be confined to buildings on sites. This will allow manufacturing activities to be undertaken in places other than buildings, including mobile vans used for collecting blood plasma. Such places usually present no increased hazard to the products being manufactured, and should be permitted.

An amendment is required to enable an application fee to be charged for every application to add a new product into the Register, even though the new product comes within a gazetted therapeutic goods group. At present, sponsors of goods that fall within the description of a gazetted therapeutic goods group only pay one application fee to include all such products in the Register over a period of time. Agreement has been reached with industry on how the fee will apply and the levels of fee to apply.

An amendment is required to introduce a penalty for a sponsor who fails to provide information or who provides false or misleading information. This amendment addresses problems experienced by the Therapeutic Goods Administration in getting sponsors to provide information about the quality, safety or efficacy of therapeutic goods where there may be a concern over a product that has already been included in the Register.

At present the Act provides that in the event of entry and search of premises, evidence of the commission of offences may only be held for sixty days before commencement of prosecution. Experience in the first two and a half years of operation of the Act is showing this timeframe to be too restrictive to allow for analysis or testing of goods, compiling of briefs, and laying of charges. This amendment will permit the Therapeutic Goods Administration to make application to a magistrate for an extension to this sixty day period.
A related amendment will extend the 12 month period in which prosecutions for certain offences may be brought under the Act to two years.

Amendments to section 66 of the Principal Act will clarify the position that goods included in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods under the transitional arrangements, following the commencement of the Principal Act, may not necessarily have been evaluated or assessed. The transitional arrangements provided for a period of grace during which eligible sponsors of therapeutic goods could continue to supply unregistered and unlisted goods without committing an offence, whilst their goods were being included in the Register by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. Goods included in the Register as a result of transitional arrangements may nevertheless still be evaluated or assessed at a later date, to establish whether or not such goods should remain in the Register.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: I take pleasure in introducing the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1993 to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act 1989 (the Principal Act) imposes annual charges on the registration and listing of therapeutic goods, and on the licensing of manufacturers of therapeutic goods.

This bill makes amendments to the Principal Act that complement simultaneous changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 that are introduced in Part 8 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993.

Part 8 of that amendment bill introduces a number of changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 to facilitate the introduction of complementary State and Territory legislation that will support the regulatory framework set up under the Commonwealth's therapeutic goods legislation. Details of these changes are contained in the Second Reading speech for that bill, and the associated Explanatory Memorandum.
The amendments to the Principal Act that I am now introducing address the remaining administrative implications of these changes.

The Principal Act will be amended to enable the Commonwealth to collect annual charges for maintaining registrations and listings of therapeutic goods, and for maintaining manufacturing licences, where such registrations, listings and licences have been effected on behalf of the States and Territories under complementary therapeutic goods legislation. Charges to be collected by the Commonwealth for the performance of functions on behalf of the States or Territories will be commensurate with the level of charges currently collected for the same activities performed in relation to therapeutic goods that are regulated under the Commonwealth's jurisdiction.

These amendments are subject to the establishment of corresponding State and Territory laws that will adopt the Commonwealth's regulatory requirements. It is anticipated that the first State and Territory complementary legislation will be in place by as early as 1994.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK (QUOTAS) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to extend the operation of the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 for a further three years until the end of 28 December 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 provides the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) with the powers to establish quota schemes on the export of meat and live sheep from Australia in particular circumstances.

In the case of meat, the Act empowers the Corporation to operate quota schemes where restrictions are imposed, or likely to be imposed, on Australian exports by importing countries or by the Australian Government. Honourable Senators will be aware that the Corporation currently operates quota schemes for beef, mutton and goatmeat to the United States and for beef, sheepmeat and buffalo meat to the European Community in response to restrictions imposed by those markets.
Quota on meat must be allocated free of charge.
In each of the last three years, Australia has reluctantly agreed to restrain exports of meat to the United States to avoid imposition of quotas under the US Meat Import Law (MIL).

The imposition of so-called Voluntary Restraint Agreements not only disrupts our trade to the United States, which is a major market for beef worth in excess of $1.1 billion, but also creates uncertainty and impacts on the stability of Australia's domestic and other export markets. The MIL continues to be a trade irritant between Australia and the United States, and the Australian Government is seeking to achieve the elimination of the MIL as part of a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round.

Similarly, the EC imposes quotas on the import of beef and sheepmeat. Although the access level of Australian meat into the EC is relatively small (17,500 tonnes of sheepmeat, 6,032 tonnes of beef and 2,250 tonnes of buffalo meat), the Community represents an important market for high valued product, worth almost $146 million in 1991-92.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 also empowers the Corporation to operate quota systems on live sheep and lambs where the Corporation considers it in the best interests of the industry to do so. Quota on live sheep and lambs may be allocated free of charge or by auction, sale by tender or private sale.

The Corporation has not used the powers conferred on it in relation to live sheep, but once the live sheep trade is resumed to Saudi Arabia, these powers will give the Corporation the option, if necessary, to control the supply of live sheep for export to the Saudi Arabian market as part of a mutually satisfactory arrangement under which the trade could operate.

Australia voluntarily suspended the live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia in 1991 following a series of rejections supposedly for quarantine reasons. The trade was suspended with the full support of the industry to prevent damage to the international standing of the Australian livesheep industry as a supplier of quality livestock in the Middle East and to ensure that the Government's animal welfare obligations were met.

To ensure all quota arrangements are equitable, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 requires the details of proposed quota allocation and management schemes to be set out in the AMLC's Corporate Plan, which must have Ministerial approval. These details must also be available to all exporters.

There is also a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in respect of AMLC decisions regarding the period of validity of quotas and variations to quotas granted. The AMLC is also required to publish details of all quotas allocated in its Annual Report.
Passage of this bill will not effect Government expenditure and will have no staffing implications for the Commonwealth.
I commend the bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
