TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the story in the Australian of 22 September 1993, `Liberals to oppose HECS rise', and
(ii)that the story reports Mr Chris Pyne, the Liberal Member for Sturt, saying that the tax `will mainly hit young people trying to establish their careers'; and

PARA.TAB: (b)welcomes this expression of new-found support by the Liberal Party for Australia's tertiary students.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion in order to draw attention to this year's anti-education budget. It is a punitive and brain draining budget which increases fees and loans for students and inflicts financial and psychological penalties on them.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats are the lone voice for education and students in the Australian Parliament. Our record on education issues is second to none. We do not enjoy being in this splendid isolation, especially at a time in our nation's history when the community must be given incentives to develop its skills. The Democrats' commitment to an education system which is equitable and accessible by all, is unshakeable.

It was with some degree of interest and, indeed, scepticism that I read the comments of Mr Pyne, the Liberal member for Sturt, in the Australian. He urged the Democrats `to show some backbone and vote with the Liberals' in order to `block the changes to HECS'. The article in the Australian on 22 September stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party was likely to block the Budget amendments to the HECS in the Senate, the federal Liberal MP Chris Pyne said this week. Pyne said he was confident the party would decide to oppose changes to HECS, which would see graduates taking their second undergraduate degree charged double HECS. This followed discussions with his Liberal colleagues in both the Lower and Upper Houses.

PARA.TAB: Pyne said: "The ALP has unveiled an unexpected burden that will mainly hit young people trying to establish their careers. Each year tertiary students sign a payment options form. They have the choice of paying tuition fees up front or having them deducted from their earnings once they reach a certain level.

SPEECH.PARA: The article continued:

PARA.TAB: "The students who take the later option sign a one-sided agreement with a party that can change conditions at whim.
Pyne said while the Liberals did not hold the balance of power in the Senate, he believed the Democrats would be forced to vote with them on ideological grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: The article stated further:

PARA.TAB: "The Democrats have always been very pro students but they have been very quiet about these changes, " . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That situation really has to be addressed. For the information of honourable senators and Mr Pyne, I believe the only way to deal with that accusation is to catalogue the so-called silence, starting with this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: On 10 August, which was before the budget—and a long time before 22 September when Mr Pyne was finally heard to raise his voice—I issued a press release entitled, `Budget horrors for students: Democrats leading role in national protest'. Essentially that press release stated our case.

At the University of Tasmania's Launceston campus I undertook, on behalf of the Democrats, to ensure that we voted against the proposed changes to HECS in the budget. This was part of a national day of action conducted in cooperation with the National Union of Students. I warned then what this budget signalled. I think that was the initial salvo in this particular issue.

On 12 August my colleague Senator Meg Lees from South Australia continued that warning by saying, `Welcome, Generation HECS. The budget heralds HECS hikes and funding cuts'. She described today's students as being `the debt generation'. She addressed students at the University of Adelaide. Mr Pyne was invited to that very function at which Senator Meg Lees spoke. He did not attend and did not make any announcement to either support or challenge Senator Lees at that time. I wonder where he was on that day. The new-found enthusiasm for these matters was not expressed by any Liberal Party member in any shape or form either then or until 22 September.

On 15 August I launched a petition suggesting that students could send a message to government. This was well publicised and well distributed. It was a petition in which students were invited to express their opposition to further increases to the higher education contribution scheme and to oppose any drop in the threshold at which students begin to repay their HECS loan. On budget day, 17 August, I gave a notice of motion in this chamber. Part of that notice of motion, which I am sure honourable senators will recall, read:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a)condemns any moves by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme . . .

On 19 August we saw the first of the flood of petitions which have come to light on this matter and which have been presented in this chamber almost every single sitting day since that budget day. Each of those petitions averages a couple of hundred signatures and I recall that one contained some 800 signatures. We have got to the stage where the aggregate is thousands of signatures. I dare say that flood of petitions will not readily dwindle, because I have seen another stack of them in my office just today.

PARA.TAB: On 28 August, still a long time before 22 September when we first heard from Mr Pyne, there was another press release from me which was well publicised. I recall speaking on radio across Australia on this matter. We announced our intention to continue to negotiate with regard to the education budget. The first sentence of that press release reads:

SPEECH.PARA: `The Australian Democrats will vote against HECS increases and the sinister erosion of student financial assistance', said Senator Robert Bell . . .
`We are committed to voting against these regressive measures in this punitive and brain-draining budget'.

On that same day I issued another press release, which was also well reported, again suggesting that the whole business was punitive. In particular, it drew attention to the measure which has been described lately by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, as well as by the National Union of Students, as being a move against the best principles of education theory, even. It is the proposition that those students who take longer than an extra semester to complete their degree should be penalised by being required to pay 50 per cent more HECS. On 28 August I listed that as one of the prime concerns which we would continue to campaign against and vote against when the bills finally reach this chamber.

PARA.TAB: On 1 September I issued another press release asking the government to justify the budget increases to HECS repayments rates and levels and suggesting that students would be hit with a double whammy because they would have to pay double HECS rates for their second degrees. I criticised the government then for not sufficiently defining what a second degree was, or explaining how that program would be administered.

On that day I asked a question without notice of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in this place, Senator Robert Ray. The essence of that question was to find out how many students would be affected. I referred to proposed budget changes and I asked the minister how many students would be affected by this double whammy when both increases applied. I also asked what the definition of a second degree was and how it would be administered.

Senator Ray answered that approximately 11,000 students would have been liable to pay the double HECS in respect of a second undergraduate degree if it had applied in 1992. It was estimated that if the 50 per cent increase in HECS payable by students who took longer to complete their degrees had been applied in 1991, 12,000 students would have been liable in that way. I think that was significant. I pursued that matter and found out the details. This was 1 September and we still had not heard a squeak from Mr Pyne, who had yet to discover the issue.

On 23 September the Hobart Mercury reported that the university leaders, as they were described in this particular article, which was the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, had criticised as unfair and illogical the measures which I have just been describing. They at least acknowledged that the Australian Democrats were involved in opposing this measure.

Just recently, on 27 September, there were another 125 people on the list of petitions that I previously mentioned. Also on that day I am sure honourable senators will recall my question to Senator Robert Ray representing the minister about the disproportionate effect which the penalty for slow progress will have on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. I also asked about the increases in HECS charges and how that would disproportionately affect women, who are five times less likely than men to have repaid their HECS loan before the age of 30. I asked those questions as part of an overall strategy to reveal the government's general lack of understanding of how this will penalise students, and perhaps even the lack of a factual basis upon which these proposals have been made.

I followed that up with a press release on 28 September headed, `Democrats reveal government ignorance'. I was not impressed by the fact that the government was not aware of the studies which had been done at Sydney University with regard to this and the fact that 82 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are likely to be affected by the silly proposition that if one takes more than one semester longer than the minimum time to complete a degree, one will be slugged with 50 per cent extra HECS. I think I have amply demonstrated the ignorance of the government in that area.

That brings us to this day. So much for the contention that the Democrats have been silent on this. I know that my colleague Senator Woodley has been vociferous in his opposition in Queensland and that Senator Lees, in South Australia, has been equally determined to reveal how inequitable these proposals are. I have tried to do it on behalf

SPEECH.PARA: of our party and, I think, with some degree of success, I have revealed the problems associated with these proposals.

PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne is right to discuss the matter with his Liberal colleagues. He says he has done it in both upper and lower houses. He is right to do it because the record shows their previous stubborn unwillingness to support the sorts of actions which he is now recommending. Those actions have been attempted by the Australian Democrats in the past.

I have here a table demonstrating our record in this area. It shows that in 1982 the Democrats voted against the introduction by the Liberal-National government of fees for second and higher degrees. That is when our opposition and the initiatives of the Liberal government in this area started. In 1986 the higher education administration charge was applied by the ALP government. Did Mr Pyne's colleagues make a squeak about that? Of course not. The Democrats did, and our record continued. Rather than take up the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table which considers each of the higher education moves in this area.
Leave granted.

PARA.TAB: This record reveals that the whole episode we are talking about now is nothing more than a blatant publicity stunt on behalf of this new Liberal MP. He is attempting to attract the youth and student vote that the coalition sadly and desperately lacks. The students have been betrayed by these budget proposals of the government. The students must repay their HECS debt faster and sooner, and they face further financial penalties if they fail to complete courses within a minimum time. They are being rushed through the system as fast as possible in much the same way as products off a conveyor belt. The penalty for not rushing through as fast as possible is to increase the HECS repayments by 50 per cent.

Increases in the rates of HECS repayment—from the previous rates of two per cent, three per cent and four per cent, to three per cent, four per cent and five per cent—and the parallel lowering of the threshold at which students begin to repay their HECS debt from $27,748 to $26,402 are nothing but sinister moneymaking measures at a time when graduate starting salaries are at a 16-year low. This means that more people will be hit by that threshold.

Students will have to consider carefully whether it is worth being slugged with a double HECS debt. Students who fail to complete their courses within a minimum time face a 50 per cent increase in their HECS repayments for each additional unit that they undertake. This budget views education as a mere moneymaking commodity. It has no concern about the impact of these financial and psychological disincentives on traditionally disadvantaged groups.

As I have already mentioned, women are five times less likely than men to repay their HECS debts by the age of 30. Yet this government has introduced a measure which discriminates against women, especially mature age women who may have interrupted periods of study due to domestic or employment commitments. Women are measurably discriminated against by this proposition.

I hope that Mr Pyne's initiative brings about a situation where the opposition starts to think about this, perhaps even hears the cries of students and actually does something. I will paraphrase Mr Pyne, who said something about somebody having to put their money where their mouth is and suggested that the opposition should be doing that. What a mouth it is. It opens only in mock protest against budget measures. Students will be saddled with a debt for life.

When it really counts, I predict that the government and the coalition will prove once again how bipartisan education policy is. The coalition would do well to listen to those who have convinced Mr Pyne that it is important to bring up this issue. As to his suggestions about the way to resolve this, I think it would be wise to look at the track record. Those who have most consistently opposed it, the Democrats, have been repeatedly confirmed as the only political party committed to a fair and accessible education system for all Australians. We are giving the Liberals and the government a chance to prove otherwise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the chamber for long, but I was given the honour of representing Mr Beazley in this chamber after the last election, so I should at least put a government view. The late Billy Hughes once said the following: `See a move, block it; see a sore, rub it'. Senator Bell has followed his advice today.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the greatest `I told you so' motions that I have seen moved in this chamber. It is disappointing in one sense. While it might be a bit of theatre to poke fun at the Liberal Party over its dilemma of a maverick member going off in one direction without the benefit of counselling from his leadership, on the other hand the Democrats get only two opportunities in the spring session to move a general business matter. I think the sort of psychic salary that Senator Bell has achieved out of this issue today is not in proportion to the value he could have achieved on other issues, although I do concede that he has used this issue in a somewhat disguised way to reopen the HECS debate generally.

The issue came up primarily as a result of an article in the Australian by Fiona Carruthers reporting the views of a Mr Pyne, the member for Sturt in South Australia. Mr Pyne had a burst of opportunistic excess in discussing these issues somewhere and, not knowing the history of HECS and where the Democrats stood on it, he decided to put the blowtorch to the Democrats. The fact is that he has misunderstood where the Democrats have stood on HECS from start to finish: they have opposed it. They have been consistent, and they have been wrong from start to finish. The same tired old arguments are being trotted out here today.

If HECS had to be repaid yearly irrespective of income, there would be a lot of merit to what Senator Bell has said. He always says that academic salaries and things are not going up as fast as expected. But, if they do not reach the cut-in point, they do not pay it. Whilst we have a responsibility for people doing second degrees and people who unfortunately fail and have to repeat part of their course, we have an equal responsibility for those in the community who are currently deprived of getting a tertiary education. This government's emphasis—I think the opposition is coming from a different path—has been to try to open up as many positions as possible for people to attend tertiary institutions.

But for those who have a money tree in their backyards like the Democrats, this does not present a problem—print more money, allocate more money but never give the government the means of raising the revenue, by cutting budgets to ribbons. That is not a practical approach but it is one that a minority party can sustain because it never has to balance its wish list with the real demands of governments and the allocation of resources.

I found Mr Pyne's statement interesting because Senator Bell has probably properly identified what is developing in the Liberal Party—a total policy hiatus. Following the last election, in which the Liberals thought they were going to the electorate with a very positive and firm policy, they woke up on Sunday 14 March to a terrible shock.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish I had not woken up on that morning.

—That is something we share; I wish that Senator Campbell had not woken up, either. But I do have some sympathy, because I know what defeat is like. Those opposite made a mistake to become embittered and they made a mistake initially to blame the electorate for their loss. When they looked at themselves, they made another basic decision. How could they have lost five elections in a row? If they had gone to the electorate with a positive platform, how dare the people not support them?

PARA.TAB: This naturally put pressure on the leadership of the Liberal Party and Dr John Hewson, in particular. Their answer was to dump all policy. I do not think Dr Hewson had any other strategic choice but to dump all policy. If he had indicated that he was going to hang on to it, his colleagues, especially some of the less altruistic ones sitting both in this chamber and in the other one, would have seen him removed fairly rapidly. Therefore, we are going to have a policy hiatus out of the Liberals for some time.

It is not to be recommended that a defeated opposition should try to produce an alternative policy a few weeks or even a few months after an election. It does require reflection; it does require that opposition to be working hard to provide an alternative policy. Certainly we can say the opposition has adopted that policy because I have seen no evidence to the contrary. What Mr Pyne was trying to do, I believe, was garner a few votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get rid of his `L' plates.

—I do not know about that; that may be unkind. He just thought, `There's not much policy on this. I will make an opportunist statement. I'll embarrass the Democrats'. Unfortunately, he did come to it just a little green, in political terms. If he had seen the history of the Democrats' stance on this he would probably have come to realise, as I have, that it is flawed, that it is wrong and that it has been consistent. His statements when measured against that record tend to be enormously hypocritical.

PARA.TAB: The one thing the opposition has found is a new political Camelot. What this says, in very quick summary, is, `Everyone should get tax cuts; there should be no alternative revenue measures to make up any shortfall therein; deficit reduction is a good thing but, sorry, we don't want to contribute in any way to it; and, finally, any gap can be bridged by a reduction in a bloated government expenditure and bureaucracy'. Honourable senators will note of course that those opposite never identify—now, today, and in the last few months—where they believe those cuts should occur because that can be political poison as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we?

—`Why should we?', says Senator Campbell. So that the opposition can have a rational, consistent approach and not just an oppositional approach that replicates what Mr Fischer advocated—constructive trench warfare in this chamber. If those opposite want to be a credible political force they will not get away with saying, `We always support tax cuts but we never support any consequential revenue measures'. They will never get away with the fact that they are supporters of a deficit reduction when they fail to identify any areas of expenditure cuts.

PARA.TAB: It is amazing in the macro sense that those in the Liberal Party recommend expenditure cuts but the first time action is taken, as I have had to do, to close a small military base or something else, they are all in there objecting saying, `You can't do that'. The micro approach triumphs time and time again.

In retrospect, we made a rather foolish promise that, if we lost government and had to go onto the opposition benches, in spite of our rigorous opposition to the alternative fiscal and tax regime that the coalition would impose, we would not block those measures in the Senate. We have been paid back in kind by the opposition trying to block everything that moves, leaving a potential extra deficit this year of $500 million and $1.7 billion in the second out year. That is predicated, of course, on the first proposition of wholesale sales tax increases going through. You can add enormously to that into the future.

Today Senator Bell has indicated a certain narrow level of hypocrisy in Liberal Party education policy. He could have gone on to say that this simply reflects the whole of the coalition at the moment where we see no policy, no rationality, and fiscal and revenue vandalism at its worst. The theory of those opposite is, `Let's deprive the government of as much revenue as possible. Let's force them into unpopular expenditure cuts'. Those in the opposition do not have to identify any of them; since the election they have not identified where they would cut expenditure and Senator Campbell says, `Why should we?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no use three years out; why should we?

—I am not inviting Senator Campbell to identify where he would cut if the coalition were in government. I am inviting him to suggest, if he believes this government should be cutting, where he wants to cut.
—Start with Gareth's building.

—He would start with Gareth's building when it is halfway built. That is a really constructive idea. There are a couple of other easy patsies around, why not nominate those? To make the sorts of deficit reductions that both sides probably think is sufficient, they cannot get past five per cent of the total with anything they bleat about today. Every one of those in opposition has forfeited the right to any respect on fiscal and tax matters. They have forfeited, as they always have—
—You forfeited your right when you lied your way to government.

—This is the explanation now. The Liberals lost the election because we lied our way into government! It was not the fact that they adopted a crypto-fascist industrial relations policy, was it? No! It was not the fact that they put an ideologue from the north shore in charge of the party. It was not that either. It was not because they adopted the GST policy; it was not because they tried to vandalise Medicare; and it was not because they had an $8 billion hole in their outlays area. None of those reasons. It was apparently because we fibbed to the electorate. Can Senator Beahan believe that?

PARA.TAB: This cannot be the same exploitative party that in 1977 offered tax cuts, set up a 008 number and said, `Ring and find out how much you can save' and six months later said, `Sorry fellas, we have just won an election, buzz off'. This cannot be the same party that so misled the electorate in 1966 as to our geo-strategic circumstances and the threat from the north. Can this be the party that tried to manipulate the Petrov affair in 1954?

There is no doubt that when it comes to manipulating and misleading the electorate those opposite were the old pros. They were the people who succeeded for years. I can always remember former Senator Chaney coming in here one day and saying to me and the rest of us here, `You're not like the Labor blokes of the old days. They were good, genuine blokes'. I said to him, `Yes, you used to love it. You used to love people who didn't understand opinion polls. You used to love people who couldn't run an advertising campaign. You used to love people who couldn't raise money, because you and your machine could roll straight over the top of them'.

Welcome to the majors, ladies and gentlemen opposite. It is no longer the case that we are going to be rolled over the top of by smarmy Liberal Party campaigners, nor are we going to let those opposite get away with the fact that they are going to be obstructionist in this chamber, and try to oppose every bit of legislation that the government puts up because they have absolutely no consistency and no alternative.

I say in summary that the government will not be voting for this particular motion because it is not factually correct when it `welcomes this expression of new-found support by the Liberal Party for Australia's tertiary students'. I have found no such thing yet in terms of a change in opposition policy. I think those opposite have said—I know Senator Teague will correct me—that the jury is out, and that they will consider it on its merits. Neither I nor those on my side can vote for a motion that is not strictly in accordance, not so much with the truth but with the reality as we see it. I know Senator Bell has enjoyed moving this motion, but he has broken the greatest political saying of all: vengeance is a dish best served cold. He has rushed this one a bit.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had two predictable speeches on education—one from the government from Senator Ray and one from the Democrats' Senator Bell. The debate has grown into some wide-ranging evaluation of the last election and why we all sit in the seats that we sit in now.

PARA.TAB: I wish to say with regard to Senator Bell's motion that it is consistent with the Democrats' position over many years now that, irrespective of the cost to taxpayers, the Democrats would give free education to tertiary students. The Democrats will never be in a position to do it, but they will persist with this consistent line in order to try to woo tertiary students to vote, not at six per cent for the Democrats but perhaps six and a half per cent for the Democrats. They would be led along by the nose that somehow or other the Democrats would be able to give free education to tertiary students—Austudy for all, no HECS, and all you have to do is pass year 12 and the Democrats would put you straight into university and give you an allowance to pay for it.

That has been the position of the Democrats. Therefore, they say to everyone else in the chamber who is responsible and who does have to answer to the taxpayer that we should try to win the affections of tertiary students in the way that they so irresponsibly have urged in that policy approach with regard to HECS, Austudy and tertiary students generally.

I say to my good friend Senator Bell that his speech today was predictable. It was consistent with the Democrats' irresponsible taxation policy for all Australians. It would cost billions of dollars more for the Australian taxpayers who are suffering in a recession, a rural recession, with a million unemployed. But the Democrats would add another $5 billion of tax to provide the irresponsible, open slather policies that we see reflected in Senator Bell's speech today.

We in this chamber will not be lured from what we regard as a responsible policy that has to add up for all Australians. I find greatly encouraging when visiting universities, as I do frequently, that a majority of students do not vote Democrat because responsibly they put their minds to what is affordable within Australia, to what is a fair thing with regard to their own personal contribution to their study, to what is a fair thing with regard to allowances under Austudy and how far that can be spread around Australia. Of course, if one superficially approaches any group and does not give them a chance to think responsibly, they will put their hands up for a benefit that may come particularly to them. If one looks only superficially at tertiary students, one could well come up with a policy to give Austudy to all, to abolish HECS for all and to have completely free education on the taxpayer.

When Senator Bell spoke with regard to my colleague the honourable member for Sturt, Mr Pyne, he did not project those Democrat policies on to my colleague, a Liberal member of the House of Representatives, but rather he commended him for listening carefully and being in dialogue with students. When I began my speech in the chamber I was surrounded by the two youngest members on the coalition benches. I refer to Senator Bill O'Chee, who I think is about 26, and my colleague Senator Ian Campbell, who I think is about 34. Senator O'Chee came here to this chamber in his twenties and Senator Campbell came here perhaps just after turning 30.

I know that both Senator O'Chee and Senator Campbell join with me in wishing to continue the dialogue with young Australians. I speak as another erstwhile young member of this chamber, having been here for 15-odd years. I think I came here when I was 33 and came to this place from the University of Adelaide where I was employed. We must have the sort of spirit so admirably displayed by Chris Pyne in being in dialogue with young Australians to ensure that, as politicians, we listen to young Australians. Certainly the Liberal and National parties want to hear the views of all tertiary students and all young Australians.

My colleague from South Australia, Chris Pyne, was elected for the first time in March this year to a seat that I know very well; I lived and worked in that area for many years. I commend the refreshing approach that he and all of us in the Liberal Party bring to the job of listening to students. Mr Pyne, who I think is now 26 and who was 25 when he was elected to parliament, happens to be the only member of parliament who has ever paid HECS, the higher education contribution scheme. It may well be that one or two others have paid it, but they have not disclosed that to me. Certainly Mr Pyne has paid HECS with regard to his last couple of years of enrolment in university.

Mr Pyne is the youngest member of the parliament and as a new Liberal member in the House of Representatives he has gone out of his way to make sure that he listens to all parts of his electorate, including tertiary students. He has a very important campus, the University of South Australia, very close to his electorate office and I am sure that there and in every other part of the electorate he has listened to people. I acknowledge that Senator Bell in no way imputed to Mr Pyne Democrat policy or any criticism for the carefulness with which he represents the tertiary students of his electorate and for having been in dialogue with them.

It is normal and natural that his individual views as the views of the youngest member in the coalition will be expressed to us when we meet in the party room. With regard to the higher education funding legislation, including the higher education contribution scheme, the Liberal and National parties have not yet determined their policy approach to the legislation—as to what precise form the amendments will take to improve the legislation.

In the dialogue that is now under way that is preceding that determination it is to be expected that a member such as my colleague Mr Pyne will express his own personal view. Indeed, his own personal view was quoted in the newspaper. He even rightly said, as quoted in the newspaper, that this matter has not been determined by his colleagues in the Liberal and National parties but that he was talking to them. He also did not purport to be the education spokesman for the Liberal and National parties. It is reasonable for an active and alert member of the House of Representatives to think through these matters and then to bring his conclusions to the discussion in the party room and this parliament, but certainly that can be done in some detail with regard to HECS. I also want to see that the government does not go beyond reasonable limits when it puts a new penalty on those who undertake second degrees. After 15 years of debate in this chamber on education matters, it is my view that it would be wrong if the government, even unintentionally, were to put an unfair burden on those Australians who undertook second degrees for which there was a legitimate, combined and good effect in the way in which those people with a double degree would in their chosen professions be able to serve all Australians.

For example, in Senator Bolkus's and Senator Cooney's field of law, it is quite normal these days for law undergraduates to take on a combined degree with arts or economics. For example, one of my good friends in South Australia young Rob Bailey—a very able South Australian—is doing an engineering-law degree. He has rightly perceived that the vocabulary of engineering and law can be put together to give a specialist approach that is very useful for both professions and for the community.

So we have these kinds of combined degrees: often a degree in medicine will be combined with a degree in physiology; often a degree in mathematics will be combined with a degree in science—and so it goes on. There are some usual double degrees and I would urge the government—even now I take the chance—that there be no prohibition, no further penalty, added to Australians undertaking such combined degrees.

I would further say that there ought not to be a double rate of HECS, even where the first degree was undertaken and completed and some years have elapsed before the second degree is begun. When that second degree is begun I believe that, if it is a part of a usual combined degree, it ought to attract a student contribution at the single rate of HECS, not at the double rate of HECS. In that way, where people take on a second degree as a second profession, as a complete new start, they do not gain from the taxpayer a benefit by doing it at the single rate of HECS; rather, they would incur the double rate of HECS, if this government, being the elected government, is determined to make such a proposition. So I would want to urge, as I understand my colleague Mr Pyne would, that there not be this penalty on usual combined degrees.

Another area is the government's proposal that HECS accumulate at 1 1/2 times the normal rate where a student has not made normal progress through a course. The government is proposing that if it takes six months more than normal, any additional study accumulate HECS at the 1 1/2 times rate. I would urge the government that it be at least a full year behind before that so-called penalty rate of 1 1/2 times is attracted. That is a matter for discussion; it is a personal view of mine which I put now in the chamber, as I have the opportunity. As a third matter in relation to HECS, I believe that it ought not to be retrospective in any significant or substantial way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your policy? Are you going to vote for it?

—The new arrangements with regard to HECS ought not to embarrass people who have genuinely begun a course, knowing what the parameters are, but who then find that they cannot conclude that course because the rules have been so significantly changed halfway along. I think that that principle of non-retrospectivity ought to be one that we take into account in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to be as substantial and fair dinkum as I can be. I see Senator Woodley and Senator Bell nodding. I also put these personal views. We are all senators in dialogue with students. We want to see good outcomes for education in Australia—certainly we in the Liberal and National parties do. Let me put a personal view in the same way as Mr Pyne has put a personal view—and it is still to be determined in the party and parliamentary debate as to what the precise situation will be at the end.

I raise another matter which I know the National Union of Students has already discussed with the minister, Mr Beazley. It has not been at all happy about that discussion; it has not been welcoming of the responses that the minister gave. Mr Acting Deputy President, as a medical practitioner you would well know that a medical student usually takes on four subjects in first year, and we will say that each subject is a quarter of the year's workload. If a medical student fails one of those subjects—passing three but failing one—most medical schools will not allow that student to go into second year until he or she picks up the quarter of the year missed out on. In that event, it would appear that they are going to take 12 months to catch up. Mr Beazley infers from this that that student would be one year behind as a result of failing one quarter of a year.

I put it—and the National Union of Students and students generally put it—that the student's rate of progress should be docked only a quarter of a year and not a full year. The student is doing a part-time second year, presumably with access to some part-time work if the student can find it. Therefore, I believe that this is a directly practical matter that ought to be acknowledged by the government and, in particular, by my good friend the minister, Mr Beazley: do not dock the students a year when they are only behind by a quarter of a year; let them catch that up and do not use this legislation to count it against them.

These are the matters which spring to our discussion when we are trying to have dialogue with the students of Australia and the government has made announcements for HECS reform in this way. It is in this sense that we are rightly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Geez, you're a bore, Baden.
—I really do ask Senator Bolkus, when he goes to the cabinet table, to take just those four suggestions, to make sure that the cabinet ensures that the legislation does not offend in these ways.

PARA.TAB: I would go on only to say further that, when the budget was put down, with its announcements about HECS, two days later the leader of the coalition, Dr Hewson, gave a very clear response to the budget in which he said that there were four particularly offensive elements of the budget that Mr Dawkins had announced and that the Liberal and National parties would resolutely oppose them. There were other matters which we regarded as objectionable but which we would leave until we had referred them for Senate committee inquiry and other matters which we would leave until we saw the precise legislation.

Let me remind the Senate that it was these four most offensive matters to which we announced our immediate opposition: the increase in the petrol tax, the increase in the wine tax, the increase in sales tax and the retrospective increase in tax on accumulated leave—it was both an increase and retrospective. We hope still to win support in this chamber for our position on all four measures. We have already had an effect upon one or two other matters. We have objected to the fringe benefits tax effect on the accommodation industry in this country—and the government is backtracking like mad on that matter. We objected to the new increased tax that has been put on credit unions by the Labor government. There was also the measure with regard to optometrical benefits under Medicare—which the government has completely backed down on, given the statements that we and the community at large have made.

We will give careful consideration to legislation that is outside the four most offensive elements of this budget and, when we come to the debate, we will of course announce what our position is. Why is it that we have opposed these four particular matters with such severity, with such total opposition right from the start? It is because the government lied to the electorate with regard to these matters, fooling the Australian public to vote for the Labor Party in the last election—and then it comes in with this reprehensible budget announcing such lies.

I join with all of my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties in making sure that this government will always understand that it must come to budgets with the program and with the policies it took to the election. It cannot get away with winning an election on one set of grounds and then trying to put into place, through budgets and other legislation, a program on other grounds. Where there are lies, we will oppose them; where there are broken promises, we will oppose them. That is why I, with all my colleagues, still hope that we can gain a majority—and one is forming and looks to be solid—with regard to the reprehensible increase in petrol tax, wine tax, sales tax and the tax on accumulated leave.

I conclude by referring to my friend and Senate colleague Senator Ray when he took this as a good opportunity to talk about what he saw as a—did honourable senators hear the word?—vacuum. He is trying to be derogatory of the Liberal and National parties' policy position. There is no vacuum in the Liberal and National parties. We have policies in place developed over years which have been moderated by our dropping of the goods and services tax and our seeing that the word `Fightback' is now a historical description of our policies.
Debate (on motion by Senator Schacht) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)24 September 1993 marked the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian Senate by a woman, Dame Dorothy Tangney,
(ii)29 September 1993 marked the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian House of Representatives by a woman, Dame Enid Lyons, and
(iii)since federation, 59 women have been members of both houses of the Australian Federal Parliament and that 30 of those 59 are currently in office; and

PARA.TAB: (b)congratulates Ms Ann Millar on her book Trust the Women which commemorates the 50th anniversary of the advent of women to the Australian Federal Parliament, and proves the accuracy of the book's 1916 quote from Vida Goldstein, `The all importance of having women in Parliament is being demonstrated every day'.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we are, and how many more words have we contributed to this parliament since the first speeches of those two notable Australian women? I thought I would take the opportunity in speaking to this motion to refer to an excellent paper prepared for submission by the Australian National Group to the Parity Working Group of the Interparliamentary Union, which met here recently, entitled Towards a plan of action to correct present imbalances in the participation of men and women in political life. This was published in August this year. I think it helps to set the scene in Australia in 1993 to look at this matter from an historical perspective. Women won the right to vote relatively early in this country but prevailing social values meant that the first women were not elected to the federal parliament until 1943.

PARA.TAB: Political scientist Dr Marian Sawer has pointed out that although Australia was a pioneer of women's suffrage, it had the greatest time lag of any country in the world between the eligibility of women to stand for the national legislature and their actual arrival in it. While women currently comprise only 8.8 per cent of parliamentarians in the House of Representatives, their higher representation in the Senate, where we are 17 out of 76, lifts this overall figure to 13 per cent for the Australian federal parliament. If we take state and federal parliaments together, the representation of women has risen over the years and is now a whopping 14.5 per cent, compared with zero in 1921 and 10.1 per cent in 1987!

With 14.5 per cent of the total seats in Australian parliaments, women in Australia have a higher degree of representation than do women in many other countries. But if one compares us with our Scandinavian friends one will see that our present record is overshadowed because in countries such as Norway and Finland 40 per cent of their members are female.

A lot of reasons are put forward as to why we ought to have more women in parliament and why we do not have enough women in parliament. There are five basic arguments that are usually put forward in support of the need for women's increased representation, not just in politics but also in positions of political leadership. The first argument is based on democracy and egalitarianism—the fact that women constitute half the population and they should be represented proportionately and the recognition that women's rights to full citizenship must be reflected in their effective participation in the various levels of political life. People rightly say that there cannot be true democracy where women are excluded from positions of power.

The second argument that is often put forward for why we need increased participation of women relates to legitimacy. The argument is that women's underrepresentation can be dangerous for democratic systems where the validity of all-male decision making is under question. There is an increasing awareness that the outcome of such decision making is not the same for men and for women.

The third argument which is usually put forward is that of difference of interests. Men and women have different interests. Political participation involves articulating, providing and defending these different points of view or these different interests. I think it is a very reasonable proposition to say that women know better about their own needs and interests in the same way as men are probably more aware of their own. For example, women have been better aware of the need for access to things such as family planning. They have been very aware of what they require as the bottom line in the provision of things such as child care. Studies have shown that where there are a lot of women parliamentarians in a parliament, such as in Finland, they have initiated legislation which benefits women and other disadvantaged groups more frequently than have men.

The fourth argument is that the increased representation of women actually broadens the political agenda because women bring to the parliament issues such as child care. We are enlarging the public sphere of life just in being able to bring these issues into the chambers.

TALK.START.PARA: —But men worry about that too.

—Of course they do. Dr Marian Sawer, whom I cited earlier, has shown how the increase in women representatives from two per cent to 13 per cent in parliament over the last two decades has resulted in a redefinition of politics in this country with the inclusion of issues such as abortion, domestic violence, sexual harassment, rape, single parenthood, women's health and suburban isolation as normal parts of public debate in this place.

PARA.TAB: The fifth argument is really obvious—the efficient use of human resources. If women, as they do, comprise half of the world's pool of potential talent and ability, why not use it? Why not use it efficiently for the benefit of this nation?

Sometimes people add another argument along the lines that the increased participation of women can actually lead to a reform or an improvement of politics. Very frequently research records an increasing level of cynicism, particularly about the confrontationist tactics and style characterised by male politicians in this country. Opinion poll research has suggested that women politicians are viewed differently. For example, a 1991 ANOP survey of a Queensland electorate showed that 64 per cent of those surveyed believed men enter politics out of personal ambition and desire for money and that only 11 per cent believed that women have the same motive. Thirteen per cent of those surveyed believed that men were motivated by altruism and concern for community welfare and 54 per cent believed this of women.

A lot of reasons are advanced for why we have this gender imbalance. It is really pleasing to see that we, in all the political parties, are looking much more seriously at this issue. I could point to the record of the Australian Democrats. We have had three female leaders and, throughout our history, we have had roughly a fifty-fifty level of representation of men and women in our parliamentary party. I think, though, it is very important that we, as a society, recognise that we need to address and redress the gender imbalance.

I recently read a very interesting article in a newspaper which pointed to the role that the proportional representation voting system has played in Scandinavia, where there are more female parliamentarians. The article noted that, where there was a contest for a single member electorate, men fought really hard and the numbers were organised more successfully for the men because they thought this was the do or die effort; this was the only prize. But wherever there was a list for people to choose from, very often in the preselection process and in the compilation of that list, people looked for a gender balance or they said, `Yes, it's okay for a woman to be on this list'. Then the voters very often looked for the female candidate to vote for.

If one looks at the representation in the House of Representatives, which reflects single member electorates, and the representation in the Senate, which reflects the proportional representation voting system, one sees that a very real and tangible link can be made. The voting system—in this case it is proportional representation—has been responsible for the election of more women, not just in Australia, but throughout the world.

Explanations for the underrepresentation of women have included political socialisation, a lack of interest, an unwillingness of women to put themselves forward as candidates and, in some countries, lesser educational opportunities. Very often women cite the confrontationist style in the atmosphere of male dominated parliaments and the unsympathetic treatment of women by the media as real disincentives. They do not want to be involved in something which they see essentially as either dirty or confrontationist. But we all know that it does not have to be like that. We would not stay here if it were.

Another relevant point relates to the massive size of this continent. We travel to this place for about 26 weeks of the year. That is a very difficult thing for many women who have chosen to have families. I am sure it is also difficult for fathers to leave their children for 26 weeks of the year. Nevertheless, I think that, while women choose—and are often forced—to be the major nurturers, it is very hard for them to free themselves from that role to also live out the necessities of that equally demanding role of being a full time member of parliament.

If we look at the history of women parliamentarians in Australia, we see that it is very interesting and quite inspiring. I would like to repeat some of the comments I made at the launch of Ann Millar's marvellous book entitled Trust the Women. I referred to women who have had an important place in the political history of this country, starting with Enid Lyons and Dorothy Tangney; Annabelle Rankin, who was the first woman to hold the office of whip—one of the delightful photographs in this book is that of Senator Margaret Reid and Senator Susan Knowles, each holding up a whip on their election as whip and deputy whip of the opposition—Margaret Guilfoyle, who was the first woman to have portfolio responsibilities for a government department; Susan Ryan, who was the first Labor woman to sit in cabinet; Joan Child, who was the first woman Speaker of the House of Representatives; Janine Haines, who was the first Australian Democrat in federal parliament and the first woman to lead an Australian political party; Carolyn Jakobsen, who was the first woman chair of caucus; and Kathy Sullivan, who has served in both houses of parliament and has been a parliamentarian for 20 of the 50 years that this book, Trust the Women, covers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is endurance!

—I'll say! As I said in the motion, in the 92 years since Federation, there have been 37 senators and 22 members, which is a total of 59 women. As I am fond of pointing out, I am only the fifth woman since Federation to be elected to represent the state of Queensland. Of the whole pool of women from which we can choose, I find it extraordinary that only five of us have managed to get through the system in this way. We have only one woman—Ros Kelly—in federal cabinet. We have only one woman—Senator Jocelyn Newman—in the shadow cabinet.
—What about our shadow ministry, though?

—Yes, there is impressive array along the front bench. There is no doubt about that, Senator Patterson. If one looks at the Senate's record of ministers, one sees that it is only marginally better than that of the House of Representatives. We have had one woman minister since Dame Enid Lyons left, which is a period of 36 years.

PARA.TAB: We need to focus on the future. There is a lot to celebrate. What we have achieved is worthy of note. It is not easy to get elected; we all know that. I have not found it easy in the Democrats to get elected to parliament. It took me 10 years as a candidate to be elected. For women in other parties I do not think it has been a particularly easy job either, but we have come a long way and there is a long way to go.

This book, Trust the Women, manages to celebrate our contribution and points out how far we have to go in the future. That is why I wanted to take time tonight to dwell on this subject. I think it is important that we can look back at those first speeches and recall that we were talking about 50 years. We can look at the issues we are talking about today. We can assess the roles we play and the contributions we are able to make as members of this chamber. We can be reflective of what those who have gone before us have had to work towards so that we could be in this position today. While I feel that we still have to assume our rightful place, our rightful numbers and our rightful importance, tonight is an opportunity, through this motion, to reflect on where we are and to congratulate Ann Millar on this marvellous book, Trust the Women.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to rise in this place to support this motion moved by Senator Kernot, which marks the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian Senate by a woman, Dame Dorothy Tangney and the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian House of Representatives by a woman, Dame Enid Lyons. The motion also notes that we have had only 59 women elected since then and it congratulates Ms Ann Millar on her book Trust the Women.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted to rise in support of this motion. One of the things that I liked very much about the book was to find the maiden speeches of Dorothy Tangney and Enid Lyons in the back of it. For those who have time to search the library or who have not misplaced their previous copies, it is very good to find those speeches in the back of the book.

I was particularly struck by the similarities and the points of difference in the comments of Dorothy Tangney and Enid Lyons all those years ago. Two points made by Dorothy Tangney stand in my mind. First, we must remember that her speeches were made in 1943 when Australia was still well engaged in the Second World War. In her remarks Dorothy Tangney said that she hoped Australia would recognise the importance of having a new view of itself and its place in the world—that is, its place in the Pacific—and the importance of working with the countries that are near neighbours. That was an acute observation by Dorothy Tangney all those years ago.

Further on in her speech Dorothy Tangney referred to the fact that the Australian people were finding #1.5 million for the war effort. She sincerely hoped that they would find #1.5 million for the peace effort, particularly when the war ended to assist people to get established in Australia with the change in industry and all the other things that went with it.

I also particularly enjoyed reading Enid Lyons's comments about new brooms sweeping things clean, while not wanting to refer to the House of Representatives as a cupboard. I am not sure whether such metaphors should be commented upon. I thought it was rather well set; I enjoyed the way she set it out. There is probably some awful apposition about the use of a broom to sweep clean the House of Representatives. I also liked her reference to heat in kitchens. As I remember it, that phrase belongs to some American politician. I think the place of women has always been in politics, if only in metaphor.

Clearly this book by Ann Millar highlights, as Senator Kernot said, the significant dearth of women in this place—dearth as to their number rather than their contribution. There are 59 women on the cover of the book and I like that line very much. It is Senator Kernot's line, but I will use it again, if I may.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not used it lately, so you can.

—I thank Senator Kernot. I make the point that we can have all the women who have ever been in parliament on the cover of one book. I hope that the next time we publish an updated version of Trust the Women the number of women will be far more than one cover's worth.

PARA.TAB: A month or so ago I was able to join state ministers at a meeting of Commonwealth-state ministers on the status of women, which was held in Wellington, New Zealand, to acknowledge the suffrage celebrations of the women's vote in New Zealand. I join in congratulating New Zealand on that achievement a hundred years ago. I had the pleasure of doing that more formally in the New Zealand High Commission just the other night.

In particular, the woman acknowledged for leading the campaign in New Zealand is Kate Shepphard. The day after the election she presented a white carnation to the parliamentarians who voted yes for women's suffrage. When we were in Wellington, Minister Jenny Shipley was fascinated to comment on the foresight and planning of women. Two years before this centenary celebration, some women, recognising the opportunity, bred a new camellia which they named the Kate Shepphard camellia. It is now planted the length and breadth of New Zealand. It is turning out to be a very successful program. The camellia is worth it in its own right and it is a very striking highlight of this year's celebration. Again, I acknowledge the wit, wisdom and inventiveness of women's minds.

Another thing I would love to share with this parliament is an account of one of the many celebrations in New Zealand this year. On this occasion women walked, jogged, rode, hiked, backpacked, mountain climbed and rock climbed to the top of seven mountains. From the top of those seven mountains they were able to speak to each other by a Telecom hook-up. The whole episode was filmed from a helicopter. The people of New Zealand were able to see these women covering the slopes and getting to the tops of mountains. As much as it demonstrates the physical prowess and capabilities of women, it is nice to think how high women can go—even to the tops of mountains, given half a chance.
I am also pleased to have been able to participate in New Zealand's centenary celebrations because next year is the centenary of suffrage in South Australia, my own state.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Loosley. It is a matter of great celebration. While we mark this year as a centenary of the women's vote in New Zealand, next year in South Australia we will mark a particularly significant first. Not only did the South Australian women get the right to vote, but they also got the right to stand for parliament.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, this was not the intention of the people moving the motion at the time. An amendment was moved as a tactic to try to defeat the bill for yet a third time on the grounds that it might get women the vote but certainly would not enable them to stand for parliament. But the people moving the amendment did not get the numbers right. So as a result of a grudging contribution, in 1894 women in South Australia not only had the right to vote but also the right to stand for parliament.

Very importantly, that voting right also covered Aboriginal women. There are some histories and records of Aboriginal women who were able to exercise their right to vote in South Australia. The history is still a bit cloudy as to whether Aboriginal women did have the right to vote in the 1902 bill. It is certain that very few were able to exercise it because they were not encouraged to vote or advised on the matter, or indeed even knew how to get on the electoral roll. We do know that post 1967, Aboriginal women and men were finally acknowledged as citizens in their own right in their own country. Since then, of course, Aboriginal women have been able to exercise their right to vote.

In some countries I have visited—for example, Mozambique—Australia's expertise in assisting people to get on to the electoral roll and to learn of their right to vote in a democracy has been one of the stunning successes enjoyed by this country and a service that we have been asked to provide to other countries. We are very pleased to assist. The people in Mozambique, who are preparing for their first democratic elections, have been assisted by our Electoral Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has done a magnificent job.

—Yes, it certainly has. Those countries have been interested to know about the Australian Electoral Commission's capacity to be able to go to remote places and to talk with people. For example, it has talked to Aboriginal people, whose first language is not English. Indeed, it has been at pains to reach people in Australia, particularly those in rural, remote and Aboriginal communities. It has served as a model that is now much sought after by countries such as Mozambique. It is one of the things that makes me very proud of this country. It is vitally important that the democratic right to vote is experienced by women in Australia.

PARA.TAB: For the record and the edification of some senators, I simply conclude my comments about South Australia by saying that, as late as 1959 in South Australia, a woman who was elected to parliament—Jessie Cooper—had her right to sit in parliament challenged in the Supreme Court by the Liberal man who was defeated in preselection. The case he brought against the Electoral Commission was to the effect that Jessie Cooper was a woman and not `a person' under the act. That occurred in 1959 in South Australia.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be pleased to know that the president of the time, Mr Playford, made it quite clear, by amending legislation, that women were persons, which is what the Supreme Court found. It is a case that is not without quite a lot of precedent in England. Indeed, the reason it was able to be argued that women were not `persons' flowed from a widely held view that women were not fit for public office. This was spelt out in all sorts of ways in court cases in England in the 19th century. Unfortunately, in some cases it has been repeated in courts in Australia.

One of the best examples I know is the campaign against women getting into universities in the late 19th century. Senior Victorian politicians and public figures argued strenuously in the late 19th century that if women went to universities their uteruses would shrivel! There ought to be a loud hoot of laughter. It is quite clear that gender transliteration of that kind of comment would never be said because women are not so silly—neither are most men these days. That is just one example of the absolute stupidity that women had to campaign against. It was not just a battle for their rights, but they also had to deal with a campaign of folly, of put down and of destruction—a clear denial of rights for women. Our grandmothers had to muster all the possible arguments to counter nonsense of that sort—at a time when they did not have access to property, to a university education or to the vote, in many cases.

The history of their fight in Australia is something about which we should be remarkably proud. Until this book was written, we knew very little about this history. I congratulate Ann Millar for writing this book. She has actually given us a volume that we can present to our sons and daughters, to our schools and to our communities so that that history is not forgotten, not written out of existence and not overlooked, but powerfully taught. It ought not be just a matter of women's rights, although that seems to me to be sufficient justification—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a matter of human rights.

—Yes, Senator Loosley, it is a matter of human rights. It is also a matter of a great achievement for democracy. Australia, with New Zealand, was teaching the rest of the world—as the title of the book and that wonderful banner suggest—that people can trust the women, however one wants to interpret that. I do not know how Hansard can show the difference between `trust the women' and `trust the women'. It looks the same on paper, but there are two meanings.

PARA.TAB: It is certainly interesting to note that in 1911 that banner painted by Dora Meeson was being paraded in England in, I think, the coronation suffrage parade. It was only two years after that, in 1913, that the cat and mouse acts were introduced into English law to deal with those outrageous creatures—women—who were being taken to gaol, going on starvation—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were on hunger strike and were being force fed.
—They were being force fed because they refused to eat. I am doing very well with the assistance of my colleagues!

PARA.TAB: The cat and mouse acts were introduced to enable the force feeding of those women who then recovered enough to come out of gaol, to demonstrate again, to be arrested, to go into gaol, to go on hunger strike, to be force fed and around they went again. Here were the women of England in 1913 being submitted to that kind of legislation. I wonder what we would be saying in this place if the government or another party tried to introduce that kind of legislation. Here was England going to such lengths to stop women achieving the rights that Australian and New Zealand women had achieved some 20 years earlier. I actually think it is a remarkable achievement for the antipodean countries of New Zealand and Australia. I am pleased to speak about this at every opportunity I get and I am, indeed, very proud of those achievements.

The book has many photographs and I am delighted that Senator Kernot referred to one. Contemporary photos being what they are, I say, `That is nice, there are my friends'. But the photo I particularly like is the one of Vida Goldstein looking absolutely splendid going off to be a candidate in the election in 1903. I am not sure that I could ever look like Vida Goldstein, but I refer anybody reading the book to that photo—there is a model for us all. What a feisty and spunky lady she was.
I think it is very important that we have this history for our sons and daughters to read. It is also an acknowledgment of the contribution women have made to building this country.

I reiterate what has been said here and in other places: quite clearly we do not have sufficient numbers of women in parliament—either in our federal parliament or in our state parliaments. Quite clearly we do not have enough women on the boards of management in this country, in senior management positions, as senior members of our universities or in senior positions in our public sector. One could not be satisfied with the representation of women in any of those positions.

It is important that we campaign to get fair and reasonable representation of women—at least 50 per cent as a goal—in all of those positions. It is not a question of just going for a quota; it is striving for fair recognition of the variety of talents and contributions that women can make. As I have said in other places, it is a profligate country that is prepared to waste the talent of 51 per cent of its people. It is a matter of justice, it is a matter of equity and it is also a matter of best practice. If one deliberately overlooked talent in trying to fill positions in management, then I think it would be a measure of inadequate management or poor hiring practices. We do not have enough women in those positions and we suffer because we do not utilise their talents.

In supporting this motion and congratulating Ann Millar on her book, I certainly believe that we have a wonderful marker in the continuing struggle for a fair representation of women here and in other forums. There is absolutely no doubt at all that the contribution made by women over the years in this place is no less and indeed very often much more than the contribution of other senators. Women can certainly make their contribution in this place—they have done so and they will continue to do so.

I believe it is a matter of equity and opportunity for this country that we ensure that the balance changes. That is something which is of great concern to the Labor Party and is being rigorously debated in all quarters of the party. I am very pleased to know that that debate is taking place.

It is not a question of whether there will be more women, but how more women will be preselected. I would like to think that the expectation now is that women do not have to fight to justify their capacity. What we have to do now is merely fight for the opportunity to have a go and to take a place in society. That is one of the great cries of this country. It is certainly time to make sure women have a piece of that action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words in support of Senator Kernot's motion. The motion notes that 24 September 1993 marks the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian Senate by a woman, and that 29 September marks the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian House of Representatives by a woman. The motion also congratulates Ann Millar on her publication Trust the Women.

PARA.TAB: Some honourable senators have just noticed that Ann Millar is hiding up there in the press gallery. I suppose she thinks she is a press person now that she has published something. Trust the Women was launched this week and commemorates the anniversary of the advent of women in the federal parliament.

I would like to join the Leader of the Democrats and my colleagues, who have spoken and will speak, in commending Ann Millar for her book. Some of my other colleagues, who will not be speaking, have commended Ann Millar personally. I congratulate her not only for writing the book which provides an informative written and pictorial record of women in federal parliament, but also for organising a wonderful exhibition in the public area of the House. Usually such exhibitions come and go very quickly, but this one has stood the test of time. When one looks at that exhibition one sees the extent Ann had to go to collect the material, quotations and photographs of people like Rose Scott, Vida Goldstein and Catherine Helen Spence. It would have been great to have actually had the opportunity to meet some of those people.

When Senator Crowley was talking about the feisty nature of some of those people, it reminded me very much of my grandmother's aunt who reared my grandmother. When I was a small child I knew that she lived at about the same time as Rose Scott, Vida Goldstein and Catherine Helen Spence. She chose not to marry and wanted to have a licence of a hotel. In order to do that she had to be married. So she got married and had the marriage annulled three days after she got the licence for the hotel.

I come from a long line of feisty women. I love the quote that is attributed to Rose Scott in the exhibition. She was asked why she did not get married and she said, `Life is too short to spend it in the service of one man'. I think that is a very good quotation. I take heart from the quote that Ann Millar found. I am sure Rose was not saying it in a negative way, but she had so much to do that she was going to get on with her life.

Those characters come out very clearly in the exhibition. They were the people who set the pace, who probably did not achieve everything they wanted to achieve in terms of being in the political life and being members of parliament, but they were the pacesetters and the trend makers for those of us who have come on after them. Ann has captured that in her book.

One of the most wonderful photographs in that book and in the exhibition is of Dorothy Tangney and Enid Lyons together walking in 1943. On the back there is an inscription which says in strine, `A cuppler drunks and may we remain pals for all time'. I think it showed the ability of those women to put aside their political differences, to have some humour and to see that they needed to work together to achieve some of the aims that they had set out to achieve when they came into parliament, now 50 years ago.

I am proud in a very small way that when I was at the opening of that exhibition I suddenly said to Ann in a moment of inspiration, `Ann, you can't lose, this exhibition has to go into a book', and I appreciate the fact that Ann Millar acknowledges that on page 9. She had just finished putting the last bits together—changing some little mounts and inscriptions—and was looking pretty exhausted, when I suggested that she might make a book, and I think it was the last thing she wanted to think about. But she has done it. It is a tremendous record. It will be used by many people, especially young people, in Australia because it has that lovely mix of text and picture which helps one to move through what some people might see as a dry topic. Because the book is beautifully put together in an interesting way, people are led through that history. I congratulate Ann on that.

I would like to address the quote from Vida Goldstein that `the all importance of having women in parliament is being demonstrated every day'. She made this comment in 1916 and it is just as pertinent today as it was then. I am sure that my parliamentary colleagues on both sides of this chamber would agree that women bring at times different but equally important perspectives to issues that we deal with in this parliament.

I think it would be true to say that women in this parliament have taken a great interest in many issues, especially social issues but not only social issues. One of the great privileges I had as a member of this parlia

SPEECH.PARA: ment was to attend a delegated legislation conference in London. There we were, not addressing social issues per se, but the issue of delegated legislation. Australia has led the Commonwealth in protecting individuals' rights. It is a committee which very few people outside political life know about. Senator Loosley and I have served on that committee together. It is a committee in which we can put individuals' rights above our political differences and work together, instead of confronting each other, to protect people's rights and to make sure that delegated legislation does not affect them in that way.

PARA.TAB: There were four women at this conference, two from the Labor side and two from the Liberal side. We also had with us our Deputy Clerk who is a female. We must not forget that we have women not only in parliament paving the way but also in important positions serving the Senate and the House of Representatives—people like Anne Lynch—paving the way for those women who will serve the people of Australia in those roles. Politicians come and go and we forget that sometimes. Comcar drivers stay longer than we do, so do the clerks and deputy clerks. Our time here is much more ephemeral. In someone like Anne Lynch we have a tremendous role model for women because she has a true commitment to the importance of this place. She has also dedicated a significant part of her life to ensuring that we scrutinise legislation and actually work as a proper house of review. It was tremendous that there were five women at that conference on delegated legislation, which people would not always see as being an issue that women would take up.

I am sure that my colleagues would also agree that in order to make our public institutions more representative and more democratic we need more women to become involved in the legislative process. While I do not wish to denigrate the achievements of women to date in political life, it is not good enough that only eight per cent of the members of the House of Representatives are women, and it is not good enough that only 21 per cent of senators are women when over 50 per cent of Australians are women.

However, I am firmly convinced that one of the reasons—I am not saying all the reasons—why women have traditionally been under-represented in Australian political life is that sometimes they undervalue their skills and talents and are reluctant to put themselves forward for public office. There are other issues of family responsibilities but that is one reason. Those of us who are here ought to do all we can to encourage other women to see that they are capable of doing this job and making a contribution. We need to educate and encourage other women to take up their cudgels, to put themselves forward for preselection and to join us in this place.

It is for this reason that I am happy with the measures that my party is taking to enhance the opportunity for the recruitment, training and promotion of women into politics. Recently, the Liberal Party has been taking a leading role in the push to encourage more women to stand for political office. Only last month, a national Liberal women's candidate forum was established to provide an opportunity for the Liberal Party to get more women to participate in the electoral process.

A major objective of the forum is to provide a way for Liberal women around Australia to speak on a wide range of topics advocating women's involvement in contemporary political issues. It will also provide an opportunity for the party to develop a focused campaign to encourage more women to stand for public office. The establishment of this forum is important because it represents the most significant drive for women as candidates in Australia's political history.

I would also like to commend the New South Wales Liberal Women's Council for embarking on a state wide campaign to encourage women to stand for parliament.
