The council has advertised for women of talent and commitment. By identifying, training and supporting potential women candidates, it will give women a greater chance of winning preselection. I really believe that this is a step in the right direction. One of the reasons why I am a member of this place is that a group of Liberal Party women decided that they would support me in my bid for preselection. In fact, it was not only because of their suggestion that I stand for preselection but also because of their interest and encouragement that I actually represent Victoria here in the Senate today.

I would also like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to the strong role women have taken in the formation and development of the Liberal Party itself. Many people are unaware that Australian women played a crucial role in the founding of the Liberal Party. In 1945 the Australian Women's National League was the largest single non-Labor political organisation with over 40,000 financial members, and that was a women's organisation. By voting to amalgamate with the new Liberal Party, these 40,000 women enabled a significant political force to be established.

It was partly because of this significant role that women played in the founding of the Liberal Party that their right to have a voice in party decisions was constitutionally protected. In Victoria it is protected to the point where we have equal numbers of men and women in our governing body. I was asked by the press to comment on Mr Carlton's little foray into this issue about whether we should have equal numbers of men and women by having two representatives from each electorate. I, with tongue in cheek, said, `That's one way to ensure that we don't get beyond 50 per cent', and, therefore, I did not approve of it.

The Liberal Party also has a proud record of women taking an active role in Australian politics. Many of the first women elected to Australian state parliaments have been from the Liberal and conservative parties. We all know that Dame Enid Lyons was the first woman elected to the federal parliament, but not as many people know that the first woman ever elected to a parliament in Australia was Mrs Edith Cowan. She was elected to the lower house of the Western Australian parliament in 1921 for the Nationalists.

Finally, I would like to say how disappointed I was at the recent meeting of women parliamentarians in Canberra to discover that the ratio of women in parliaments around the world has declined over the past five years. Although women make up more than 50 per cent of the world's population, as at June 1993 they occupied around 10 per cent of parliamentary positions. This is a drop from a high point of 14.6 per cent only five years ago.

I hope that in five years time we can report to this parliament that the number of women in Australian parliaments and in parliaments around the world has increased dramatically. I seek leave from my colleagues to table a record of the number of women in parliaments around the world as at June 1993, so that we can make that comparison in five years time.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to speak in this debate until Senator Kernot spoke to me. Her motion commemorates not only an important milestone for Australian women but also a very important milestone for all Australians interested in our political process and in the evolution of our democracy. It is entirely appropriate, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you should occupy the chair at this time, given that you, from memory, were the first woman elected from the state of New South Wales to the Australian Senate. That was a first-class political development.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot's proposition comprises two different parts: marking the milestone itself and congratulating Ms Ann Millar on her exhibition and book, both of which are first class. I attended the original exhibition last year. It has become an integral part of the Australian parliamentary scene, of Australian parliamentary life. One wonders at the impact on many tens of thousands of Australians who have had the opportunity to see that exhibition over the previous year. I hope that it becomes a permanent fixture of the parliament. It commemorates significant dates, events and personalities and demonstrates the evolution of our political process and the magnificent contributions that have been made by a small but growing number of Australian women.

There was one element of Senator Kernot's motion that I particularly wanted to take up. Of the 59 women who have served in the Australian federal parliament, some 30 are currently serving. That raises the question: why now? The answer is that women political candidates, generally speaking, are very well attuned to the needs of electorates, in particular, marginal electorates. They have tended to be politically more attractive to constituents and politically more responsive to the demands and aspirations of constituents. That has been as true of state politics as it has been of federal politics. There is no doubt in my mind now, not only from the experience of the Labor Party but also from the broader experience of all the political parties, that women candidates in marginal seats are great political assets.

Looking more broadly at the achievements of women in international politics, the Speaker of the House of Commons, Ms Betty Boothroyd, was elected on a bipartisan basis. The Japanese Diet has a woman Speaker, Ms Takako Doi, for the first time. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has referred to the President of Ireland, Mrs Robinson, as being in a great many respects the model for a future Australian head of state. If anyone has been following the hearings before the United States Congress house ways and means committee just this week on the American health system, they will know that Mrs Hillary Rodham Clinton has demonstrated beyond doubt that it will not be very long before the president of the United States is a woman. That threshold argument is now won in terms of the capacities of women to contribute in any number of spheres of public life.

I enjoyed Senator Patterson's contribution. She was absolutely right in saying that it is very important at times to put notions of partisanship to one side and focus upon issues. That has certainly been the case with the regulations and ordinances committee on which I had the privilege to serve as chair. I have no doubt that a lot of that capacity is reflected in our parliament by the presence of an increasing number of very able Australian women.

I was a little uneasy some years ago when the ALP introduced quotas for women's participation. I am no longer uneasy. There is no doubt in my mind that it has made our party's organisation and policy making far better. It encouraged a greater number of women to contest and win public office preselections, and go into public office at the different levels of Australian government.

Senator Kernot was right to speak to me. Not only is it important for women to celebrate this milestone, but also it is important for all Australians to celebrate and commemorate it. On my behalf and, I am sure, on behalf of everyone in the chamber and beyond I commend Senator Kernot for her motion and Ann Millar for a magnificent exhibition and book. We look forward to the evolution of the exhibition and future publications of the book and also to a steady improvement in the numbers of Australian women present in, making a contribution to and changing the face of our politics for the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support Senator Kernot's motion. It has been supported by everybody in the chamber who has spoken on it, and I am not surprised that that is the case. There is not the slightest doubt that 1943 was a significant year in this country. We were at war and that dominated what occurred. It was also a year when women's organisations throughout Australia realised that they had to make a supreme effort to capitalise on what had occurred at the beginning of the century.

PARA.TAB: Going back earlier than the beginning of the century, New Zealand is now celebrating 100 years of women's suffrage. Next year South Australia celebrates it, a state where, as Senator Crowley pointed out, women achieved not only the right to vote but also the right to sit in parliament. In 1902 the Commonwealth Franchise Act gave women the right to vote and to sit in the federal parliament.

Until 1943, some 41 long years ago, there had been a number of women candidates for the federal parliament over the years but no woman had been elected. Edith Cowan sat in the parliament of Western Australia in 1921 and May Holman was a member of the Western Australian parliament in 1925. But for 41 long years, women were not present in this parliament. It was not that they had not tried or that they had not been active.

We heard mention tonight in the debate of Vida Goldstein of Victoria, a woman who stood for parliament on five occasions between 1903 and 1917. She was a tireless worker, an effective speaker, a writer and editor. She published her own journals. She went to the United Kingdom with Dora Meeson to take part in the coronation suffragette procession on 17 June 1911 when the magnificent banner which bore the words, `Trust the women' was marched through the streets of England to encourage the British to give women the right to vote in that country, as had happened earlier in this country. It was not until 1918 that women in England over the age of 30 obtained the right to vote. It was not until 1928 that women over the age of 21 were given the right to vote.

One cannot discuss these times without thinking of Rose Scott and Louisa Lawson, women who were extremely active in New South Wales. I love the writing on the photograph of Rose Scott in 1902—`Rose Scott—enfranchised, 1902'. None of us sitting here tonight could imagine not being franchised. We were born with the right to vote. To have had to fight for it is something that we can only read about and imagine. The simple phrase on that photograph says so much about what these women had gone through to achieve what really ought to have been a right.

Rose Scott set up the women's political education league. She was instrumental in establishing the National Council of Women. She went on lecture tours. She was the secretary of the Dawn Club, that phrase coming from the book written by Louisa Lawson, who was also of those times.

As a South Australian, Catherine Helen Spence is somebody whom I particularly think about. She was part of the Women's Suffrage League and is said to have been the greatest woman of the 19th century. She certainly was a formidable woman. She was the first woman to stand for election in that she was a candidate for the 1887 convention. She was not successful but she was eligible to stand and she did stand. I claim that she would have been the first woman to have sought election in that way. She was a suffragist, a preacher, a journalist, a novelist, an educationalist, a strong woman and a model whom we can still look to today.

In 1943 there was a big effort, and it was successful. In that year there was a conference in Sydney of 91 women's organisations including the National Council of Women, the Australian Women's National League, the Council for Action for Equal Pay, the United Association of Women—the organisation that Jessie Street was so involved with—the League of Women Voters, the Women for Canberra Movement, women's service guilds, the Union of Australian Women, the Business and Professional Women's Club, the Women Graduates Association, Soroptimists, the Young Women's Christian Association and the Country Women's Association. The political parties were also there, as well as many others. Many issues were important to them, such as equal pay and child care, but I think their main aim was to do something about getting women elected to the parliament.

The election on 24 August 1943 was the turning point. There were 24 women candidates in that election and two were elected—not a very high percentage, but I think it tells us that the more women candidates there are, the more likely it is that some will be elected. If there are only a few, perhaps there is an expectation that women are not quite the thing. If there are a lot of women candidates, it is more likely that the electorate will respond and recognise that there ought to be women and then there will be women elected from that number.

There is no doubt that, as Marian Sawer said after the March election this year, the major political parties are still very reluctant to endorse women for winnable seats. I think the facts indicate that. It is also apparent that women have been elected more readily to the Senate than to the House of Representatives. It was with considerable dismay that only recently I heard one of the senior Labor members of this chamber indicate that he would like to do away with proportional representation for the election of the Senate and elect on some other basis. Presumably he is conscious of what that would mean in terms of the number of women who are here at present. I think there are very good reasons other than that as to why the Senate's electoral system should remain as it is. I think that he did not really care too much about that aspect when he made the suggestion that he did.

After 1943 it really was not a very rosy or rapid advance. Doris Blackburn joined Enid Lyons in the House of Representatives in 1946 and remained until 1949. Dame Enid was there until 1951. This might be irrelevant to this debate, but it is something that I feel conscious of today: a week ago today some Australian soldiers were killed in a motor vehicle accident in Malaysia. One of them was the great grandson of Dame Enid Lyons and son of a friend of mine, who was buried in Melbourne today. Although it is not quite relevant to the debate, somehow it seems somewhat poignant.

When Dame Enid left the House of Representatives it took 17 years until another woman was elected there. I think it is only in recent times that the significance of that has really come home to me. That woman was Kay Brownbill, from my own state—at that time—of South Australia. I knew her. She was there for only three years. To have gone as a woman on her own into the House of Representatives at that time must have been difficult. I would say that those of us here today for whom life has been considerably easier perhaps do not fully understand the contribution that she made in those three short years.

After Kay Brownbill left in 1969, it was another five years before there was a woman in the House of Representatives. That was Joan Child, and she served then for only a short time. In 1980 she returned to the House of Representatives with a number of women—not a big number, not one to get carried away by, but at least more than one. Since then there have been few—but a greater number than in the past—in the House of Representatives.

When I came into the Senate there were nine women. I certainly did not feel alone in coming into this chamber, and nor should I have. It has been much easier for those of us here in the 1980s and 1990s. We can only reflect on the contribution made by the women who came here in 1943 through until the 1980s and 1990s, but I still think it is the women who were here between the turn of the century and 1943 who made an incredible contribution. Knowing that they were getting knocked back at every turn, they kept fighting on because they knew they had to do so.

I had the honour of being asked to launch the book Trust the Women earlier this week. It is launched to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the election of women to this parliament. It is a splendid book which will be used by students of political history and those interested in women's role in the parliament for a very long time. We are indebted to Ann Millar for having put it together. Ann Millar put together the exhibition that is still to be seen in this parliament called Trust the Women, which is centred around the banner which I referred to, created by Dora Meeson and taken to England from Australia. One of the really good things from the bicentenary that is permanent is the fact that that banner was purchased by the bicentennial fund, returned to Australia, and is now in this parliament.

This book has magnificent pictures and is very readable. At the back are all the charts that show the details. They are impressive because of the sparseness of women representatives in earlier time. It has an excellent source section which gives the primary and secondary sources. Honourable senators will spend a long time going through all those sources familiarising themselves with the history. It has in it the maiden speech of Dame Enid Lyons, given 50 years ago today in the House of Representatives, and that of Senator Dorothy Tangney, the first woman to have spoken in the Senate, delivered in the Senate 50 years ago last Friday.

I could go on and talk about a lot of things relating to this 50th anniversary. I certainly could say a lot more about this magnificent book. I am pleased to support the motion moved by Senator Kernot in the Senate tonight, and I hope that in 50 years time we will need a book three or four times this size to account for the women who will be here after 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support this motion moved by Senator Kernot:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)24 September 1993 marked the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian Senate by a woman, Dame Dorothy Tangney,
(ii)29 September 1993 marked the 50th anniversary of the first speech in the Australian House of Representatives by a woman, Dame Enid Lyons, and
(iii)since federation, 59 women have been members of both houses of the Australian Federal Parliament and that 30 of the those 59 are currently in office; and

PARA.TAB: (b)congratulates Ms Ann Millar on her book Trust the Women which commemorates the 50th anniversary of the advent of women to the Australian Federal Parliament, and proves the accuracy of the book's 1916 quote from Vida Goldstein, `The all importance of having women in Parliament is being demonstrated every day'.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity to attend the launch of this book earlier this week and I add my congratulations to Ann Millar on the much overdue publication. In supporting this motion, I congratulate the current female members of parliament, who are making a wonderful contribution to the parliament. I think that at times the sacrifice that all members of parliament make in representing people in this place is very much more difficult for the women. Maybe that is why there are not more women in the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I would like to put the National Party on record as recognising the role of women in the political process, which I believe is second to none. The National Party does not at the moment have any female representatives in the federal parliament although I must say that former Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen was here in the last parliament. I believe she did an outstanding job, not only for Queensland but also for all people in parliament and for all people in Australia.

The federal director of our party, Cecille Ferguson, is not in parliament but she does a lot to help us stay here and a lot as far as the party is concerned, working for the people that we represent. I believe that she is the first woman to hold such a position in a political party in Australia. I believe it was the National Party also which had the first female federal president of a political party in Shirley McKerrow, some years ago. I regret that there are no female National Party members in either the House of Representatives or the Senate at the moment representing women in their own right. I say again that we all miss Flo in this place.

The National Party also had the first female general secretary of a state political party in New South Wales in Jenny Gardiner. She was appointed at the time I was the chairman of the party in New South Wales. The National Party's record of having women on our central council I believe also is second to none and I think the majority of representatives on our central council would agree that the women there play a major role in forming policy.

Of course, in the New South Wales state parliament we have Wendy Machin, who is a minister there, and in other states we also have female members. Jenny Gardiner, who was the general secretary in New South Wales, is now an MLC in the upper house of New South Wales. I do not really believe that the National Party is lagging behind although, as I said, it is sad to me that the we do not have any women representatives in the Senate at the moment. The National Party has stood some outstanding women candidates in recent election campaigns and their contributions to the party remain, despite the fact that they were not successful. One of those persons is Gaye White, who is in the parliament at the moment working for one of our newest senators.

The widow of the late Sir Earle Page is here today in the federal parliament as my guest as part of a group of women. She reminded me of a delightful saying of a well-known political female figure of her day: `I know I am a woman. I hope I am always a lady'. I think that exemplifies the point I would like to make that titles are irrelevant. Whether male or female, it is the contribution people make to this place that is the most important thing. I believe each has a role to play in making a better society.

On behalf of the males in this parliament I would like to pay tribute to the help and support we receive from our wives and partners outside this place. I am quite sure the women in this place would like to pay tribute also to their partners who support them in this place. Whether we are males or females, it is the support we get from our partners or spouses that gives us the energy and the drive to continue working for what we believe in. I think the old adage that behind every successful man is a very intelligent and supportive woman is not so appropriate today. It is more a case of `beside every successful man or woman is an intelligent and supportive partner', so I would like to pay tribute to our partners.

It is interesting to note that in today's Telegraph Mirror Senator Schacht, who I notice is at the table, is quoted as saying that banks are more likely to lend money for small business ventures to women because they are better managers and more likely than men to succeed. I would say that it has been more difficult for women to get to the top of the tree than it has been for men. I suppose I would have to say that the mover of this motion, Senator Kernot, has got to the top of the tree in her party on which I congratulate her. Also, sitting behind me is Senator Reid, who has got to the top of the tree as the opposition whip in this place. The contribution she makes in this place, I believe, is—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Bourne?

—Yes. I could go on for quite a while, could I not, I suppose. Senator Bourne is a whip as well for one of the minor parties in this place and obviously she has made a contribution. What I am trying to say, in supporting this motion, is that over 50 per cent of the population are females—I do not believe Senator Kernot was quite correct when she said that the figure is 50 per cent. Women have the ability to live longer than men and I do not know whether that means they are stronger or whether they are more resilient than men. I wonder whether in the future, when women play a much larger role in running the country or running businesses, the stresses and strains pertaining to that will mean there will be more of a balance between the longevity of males and females.

PARA.TAB: I admire the change that has been brought about by a changing society where men are now much more capable of looking after children at home and their wives of having a very big part not only in parliament but also in business and where they share the load of whichever spouse wants to take the role of moving ahead.

In finishing, I would like to congratulate and thank all of those women who are on the central councils, whether they be of my political party or other political parties, for the jobs that they do. Even though they might not be in this place and have the chance and opportunity of actually being right at the coalface, right at the front, they play as great a part as those who are in here.

Those who are lucky enough, fortunate enough and probably resilient enough to get into the parliament, have been written about in Trust the Women, Ann Millar's book. I have read parts of it and I must say that it is an outstanding book because it really sets in place the contribution that women have made in this place. I wonder whether a book could be written by one of my sex about the males that have been in this place and the advantage over females we might have had in past years to play a part. I once again congratulate the writer of the book.

I thank those women in this place for the contribution they make. I particularly would like to thank those in my political party who have given me and others the opportunity of being in here working for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take much of the time of the Senate because I see we are nearly out of time and I know there are other people wanting to speak on this motion, as there should be. I rise at this point particularly to point out to everyone who reads this Hansard and to everyone who is in the chamber at the moment that everyone at the table at the moment is female. We have Madam Acting Deputy President, we have the two clerks and we have all the Hansard reporters. There are not enough of us around them, I am afraid, but there are quite a few.
—How did you fix it?

—Senator Schacht says he can fix that, and I really do not know what he means, but I would hate to think. The book Trust the Women is one of the most readable books I have ever had the honour of reading. I congratulate Ann Millar, who I see up in the gallery, on doing a really excellent job on this.

PARA.TAB: I was at a conference recently and happened to have the book with me. I am afraid I did not pay much attention to the conference because I was reading this book. I was not just looking for photographs of myself, although I did find a couple. It is a very readable book. It is very worth while. I am definitely buying some copies for my family for Christmas, and I hope everyone else does.

There is one chapter in particular that I would like to mention called Some leaders are born women—the United Nations slogan for International Women's Day 1983. I would like to pay tribute to our first woman leader, Janine Haines, who once said to me that I was lucky in this place because she had been out the back of this chamber and discovered that there were two sets of toilets, one for men and one for women. In the old house there was one toilet for senators. She went in there once and was not welcome because it was the men's. There was no women's toilet outside the Senate chamber in the good old days.

She became our leader at a point when it was not as easy as it is today, and, I must say, today is not particularly easy. Senator Kernot does not get much sleep, and I know for a fact that she works herself far too hard and never sees her family. I think that is the case with most women in this place and, indeed, with most of us in this place, men and women. Our families never see enough of us. I must say I think it is more difficult for women with small children, in particular, because there is a particular bond there that is necessarily stretched very thin.

I would like to pay tribute to Janine Haines and to our other women leaders. As we know, we have had three: Janine Haines, Janet Powell and Cheryl Kernot, who is sitting in front of me at the moment; therefore I cannot say anything too nasty or she might turn around and hit me! I do not think she would. The book is excellent and I must recommend it to everyone.

I reiterate the point that Senator Reid raised earlier about the fact that it was a long time between when women got the vote, when women became eligible to stand and when they were first elected. Then it was another very long time before the next women were elected. At the moment we have more than half of all the women who have ever been in parliament in parliament right now. That is not a good thing to say about this parliament, except that we are improving. We can only hope that we improve even more.

I have been asked many times why the Democrats seem to have about 50 per cent women and 50 per cent men. I think the reason is that we are a very young party; we have only been around for 16 or 17 years. When we started we were chosen purely on merit. There was no background that made it better, in our minds, to have a man in parliament. There was no accepted wisdom that said that. I think that is why we now have 50 per cent men and 50 per cent women in parliament—state and federal. That is why we have had so many women leaders. I think that is something that the other parties really ought to have another look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rose at the same time as my good colleague Senator Bourne to make exactly the same observation as she did, as I very much wanted to congratulate all those—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Teague, I just add that the person staffing the broadcasting box is female, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just about to add, Madam Acting Deputy President, that we also have a woman staffing the broadcast box and the only attendant in the gallery is a woman. When I first made the observation there was actually a majority of women in the gallery. So for those who want to mark this occasion, you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are in the chair, the two Clerks are women, the Hansard reporters in the chamber at the moment are women, the operator in the broadcast box is a woman and the attendant in the gallery is a woman. In addition, the spouse of one of our senators is in the gallery and my spouse happens to be in town listening to this debate at home, riveted.

PARA.TAB: I really wanted to congratulate everyone who has contributed to this debate. We observe that it is not just on this occasion but on a number of occasions that we have seen women in the leading positions in the Senate. I conclude by congratulating Ann Millar, who is sitting in the press gallery, on her very good book.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to congratulate Ann Millar. I have had a long history of involvement in the production of books and magazines, and this book is quite outstanding in its presentation, apart from the content, which has been gone over by previous speakers. It is brilliantly produced, if I may say so, and I congratulate her. I congratulate Senator Kay Patterson whose idea it was that it should be produced. I would not have the temerity to speak up for the males because we are obviously outnumbered.
—You've had 90 years at it, so what are you talking about!

—I come from the profession of medicine in which there has been equality of opportunity for women in this country for over a century. But I make the point that I do not believe in quotas. I think that the women who have succeeded within political parties have been equal to or better than their male counterparts. I think they have to be to succeed to the extent that they have.

PARA.TAB: In my own state of Queensland we have at present a female leader of the Liberal Party, Mrs Joan Sheldon. When I was president of the party in Queensland I was preceded by Mrs Yvonne McComb. They are both outstanding people but they did it on their own merits. They did not get there through quotas. They got there because they had the ability to get there.

In the presence of my wife in the gallery and having seven daughters between us I have to be very careful in my wording. I am also outnumbered around my family table. Having said that, I think it is important for women to be brought up as equals, as my daughters have been.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you, being the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, would know that Senator John Devereux and I often felt that we were the token males on that committee but, since Senator Sandy Macdonald has joined us, we are evening the numbers up. We have worked on that committee in the last parliament and in this parliament as a team. I think that the great virtues that women bring to parliament are that they have a viewpoint and an empathy with the community that exceeds that of the male. We are complementary, one to the other, as we are on those committees.

I congratulate Ann Millar, once again. I congratulate the women who are present within the parliament for their contribution. I am sure that, as time evolves, because of the character and the ability of the people who are in parliament at the moment, both here and in the House of Representatives, each one of them is creating history in her own way, just as Senator Kernot is creating history in her own party by being the first Queensland leader of the Democrats. I am sure that the abilities that they all show will lead their successors in history to demonstrate the contribution that they undoubtedly will make to the future of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, on behalf of the Greens (WA), join in congratulating Ann Millar on her book Trust the Women and express how appreciative we are of the sensitive assembly of information in that book and the inspiring way it has been presented, as well as its content. Gender balance for the Greens (WA) is not something to be artificially structured, not even to be consciously striven for, but more looked at as an indication of health within our organisation. We believe that to have an imbalance, whether it be of gender or of any particular minority group not having power or a choice, needs to be addressed. Our community is changing. Women are emerging from structures that have held them back for years.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate to celebrate the numbers of women who have been achieving parliamentary representation for the community and to encourage more to come. However, we must not forget that simply to have numbers is not the purpose of that change. It is to make sure that the full balance of the voices of our community can be heard at a political level. As Senator Brownhill mentioned, that balance can be injected not simply by domination of a particular gender, but by looking at the contribution that women make, whether it is unseen or visible. I think there is an invisible or unacknowledged contribution and I am very grateful to Senator Brownhill for pointing that out. I was beginning to be afraid that the debate would degenerate just into congratulating ourselves on having women here.

I would end my comments by saying that it is really the feminisation of political structures, the ability of women in the community to negotiate and achieve consensus, decision making and participation that we need to bring into the political arena before we can congratulate ourselves on succeeding so far. I conclude by again adding my voice to those of other senators in commending this book and the motion moved here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I seek leave to incorporate by consent in Hansard two tabling statements of Senator John Watson in relation to superannuation reports which were presented and tabled during the recess. The first is the tabling statement of the sixth report on superannuation, Fees, charges and commissions; the second is on the seventh report, Super inquiry overview.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Tabling of the Sixth Report on Super-Fees, Charges and Commissions
The sixth report is the second last report on the committee's original 17 terms of reference. This report was prepared under the active and dedicated chairmanship of Senator Sherry.

Under Senator Sherry's leadership the committee met on 93 occasions during a two year long inquiry and it is a tribute to the work of the chair and also the members that on only about 2 or 3 occasions did the committee divide.

By any standard that is a remarkable achievement and is evidence of the potential that parliamentary committees have to break down party political differences which are often based on ideology as opposed to sound logic.

The report on fees, charges and commissions was indeed a difficult task, possibly the most complex issue which the committee has thus far addressed. To arrive at a final package of reforms the committee tabled an interim report, an issues paper which floated options for reform, and a report on its tripartite Super Consumer Seminar. The final package of reforms recommended by the committee has been given a high degree of scrutiny by both the committee and the community.

The report has been based on evidence before the committee from a range of interest groups but the committee relied heavily on the 50 or so individual case studies which are detailed in the report. The committee also relied on parallel reports handed down by the ALRC and the TPC and, on behalf of the committee, I congratulate both agencies on their work in this regard.
The committee was unanimous in the view that all is not well in the personal superannuation industry.

The industry is in drastic need of microeconomic reform to bring it to a position where it can offer high value but low cost products in keeping with the new superannuation environment. That environment is open, competitive and lean.

The Government will need to recognise this and bring the industry into line with developments in other financial sectors. Also, the Government will need to inject and instil a higher degree of confidence in the industry than is presently the case. The revamped and better resourced ISC should play the role of the catalyst in this structural change process.

If the change does not occur, the whole retirement incomes strategy will be at risk. The job of the Government will be to look at the Committee's report and implement its recommendations as soon as possible. . . otherwise the community will become increasingly more disgruntled about super policy.
The MLC Super Index is an interesting barometer of super confidence. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the most recent data.
I am pleased to report that the two major interest groups LIFA and the Australian Consumers Association have made positive public statements about the overall thrust of the report.
The report was well timed because in the weeks following its presentation, the Cabinet agreed on a package of reforms which is closely aligned to that of the Committee.

The Committee believes that it has struck the right balance in formulating a package of reforms which will empower consumers to allow them to make more informed decisions in purchasing super products. The key elements of the package are:

PARA.TAB: Agents should disclose any initial and on-going commissions before contracts are entered into.
Agents should disclose details of the contractual relationship they have with the life offices promoting each product on sale.

Consumers should receive summary documentation relating to each policy. This material will be written in plain English, presented according to a standard format and thereby allow product-by-product comparison.
When being advised by an agent, consumers should receive a written needs analysis which will be kept by the life office as verification of that advice.
The Prices Surveillance Authority should become a key player in monitoring the level of fees, charges and commissions and report to the Parliament annually on this matter.
The Committee fully supports the Government's decision to establish an external disputes resolution tribunal.
The Committee calls on the ISC, in conjunction with the industry and consumers, to develop a five year strategy to increase the level of consumer awareness about superannuation.

The Committee recommends that consumer counselling services be provided by the ISC in each of its capital city/regional offices. In this context I would inform the Senate of the ISC's undertaking to set up an office in each of the state capitals. I am deeply concerned that the ISC may be considering to break this promise and not proceed to establish an office in Hobart.
The Committee recommends that the industry establish its own agent registration system, together with a code of conduct to be approved by the ISC.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee awaits with interest the formal government response to this report and the other reports for which a response has not as yet been given. . . .namely, the third, fourth and fifth reports.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Seventh Report-Super Inquiry Overview

The Seventh report of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super Inquiry Overview will receive the plaudits of the Government because, unlike the previous six reports, it does not contain any recommendations.
It does however contain a considerable number of dictums on superannuation policy in general and the role of the committee in influencing that policy in particular.

The report should be compulsory reading for any new Senator about to embark on the `argy bargy' of committee life. It demonstrates that the procedures which govern Senate committees are living and breathing instruments which give Senate inquiries powers which other parliamentary and quasi-judicial bodies do not have.

It contains more than 60 pages describing and analysing the evolution of the Select Committee on Superannuation during its first two years of inquiry and the impact that the committee has had on policy formulation.

That impact was only made possible because the committee elected to break its mammoth task down into seven digestible pieces or reports. This report describes how that break down occurred. In doing so the report identifies those themes which emerged again and again throughout the inquiry. These themes included:

PARA.TAB: What should be the goals of a sound retirement incomes system?
To what extent should voluntarism and compulsion or a combination of both drive the system?
What should be the appropriate level of government intervention to protect consumers of super products?
What are the micro and macro economic implications of superannuation-related policy options?

SPEECH.PARA: The report shows that a successful committee inquiry needs a high degree of organisational and managerial input from all members and that is what occurred during this inquiry. It demonstrates that the committee relied on quality evidence to arrive at conclusions and to make recommendations to influence the shape of retirement incomes policy. So good was this evidence that the committee did not need to engage consultants to assist in the preparation of the report.

Instead the committee relied on the combined expertise of government departments, individuals and umbrella organisations representing the interests of superannuation funds, for example, ASFA—the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. In this context I would advise the Senate that the Executive Director of ASFA, Brian Scullin, has recently been appointed to a new position in the banking industry. Both the Committee and the superannuation industry will greatly miss his considerable expertise and leadership and I wish him well in his new venture.

The sweep of super policy is broad, its impact on individuals is profound and its potential to create confusion and uncertainty is great and it is for these reasons that the Senate has agreed to extend the life of the Select Committee on Superannuation. As the new chair of the committee I will endeavour to ensure that the committee maintains its active role in scrutinising the policy and operations of superannuation.
I thank the Senate for the opportunity of speaking in support of the committee's seventh report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to report No. 42 of the Standing Committee of Privileges into the treatment of James Gaffey by the Australian Securities Commission. In doing so, I will be making various comments in respect to, in particular, Mr Ron Trevethan, the Regional Commissioner, Victoria of the Australian Securities Commission, who is of course one of the important persons mentioned in the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The reason why I speak on this matter—and I am not a member of the committee—is that I have recently made personal inquiries into this matter which have led me to believe that to impose any additional penalty upon the two Australian Securities Commission officers involved would be unjust and, indeed, an improper application of the Senate's authority. For the benefit of the Senate, I would like to indicate the facts which lead me to this conclusion.

Mr Ron Trevethan is the Regional Commissioner, the responsible head of the ASC in Victoria. The commission is a significant entity in Victoria. It has over 200 employees, a considerable number of whom are professionally qualified. It is organised into sections within which supervisors perform the ASC's several monitoring and compliance responsibilities.

The central complainant in respect of the privileges committee inquiry, James Gaffey, was at the time a junior legal officer in one of those sections. Over some period he had developed a reputation for adverse behavioural problems with his office colleagues, and there was also concern over the professional quality of his work. Eventually these shortcomings came to a head with his shouting at and using intimidatory language and conduct towards his immediate supervisor, a Mrs Anne Dalton.

As a consequence, he was instructed to appear before Mr Trevethan for formal counselling as to what was appropriate behaviour. Mr Gaffey's attitude thereafter became increasingly defiant of any authority, so I am advised, and over the period of the following two months he successfully avoided appointments for the consultation.

Conscious of the adverse effect this was having upon discipline within the ASC, Mr Trevethan felt obliged to charge Mr Gaffey with a failure to fulfil his duty as an officer and asked the Victorian ASC's regional counsel, Ms Mardi Waters, to draw a charge to that effect. In turn, she sought advice from the Australian Government Solicitor's office, which office in fact drew up the charge citing six behavioural complaints, including the offending one which has led to the report of the privileges committee.

That offending charge drawn by the Government Solicitor's office was to the effect that, some five months before the unacceptable conduct incident and in violation of the Public Service Act, Mr Gaffey had given evidence in public to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, which was directly contrary to that which had been submitted by the ASC itself, and was thus seen as compromising the commission. The unintended contempt implication of that charge was appreciated almost immediately. Mr Trevethan was advised and, eight days after the charge was laid, he apologised and caused it to be withdrawn. The other five charges remained standing.

As a consequence of my investigations, I believe that Mr Trevethan's contempt was completely inadvertent; that the offending conduct was remedied by him personally immediately its effect was appreciated. The offence passed unnoticed through legal counsel and the Government Solicitor's office; indeed, it was initiated by the latter—that is, by the Government Solicitor's office.

Mr Trevethan's sole motivation in this matter was to maintain proper discipline in his office in the face of a determined abuse of such discipline. He also appreciated and acted at all times in accordance with the Public Service regulations, which are not framed with these circumstances in mind. The ASC has supported the initiatives proposed by the privileges committee and is developing within its own organisation an information program to achieve the objective outlined by the committee.

A couple of weeks ago I was very pleased to receive a letter from the chairman of the ASC, Mr Cameron, dated 8 September, advising of the Australian Securities Commission training seminar, entitled `Accountability to the houses of Parliament and parliamentary committees'. In the letter inviting me to attend the seminar and, indeed, to speak at it, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: To implement the recommendation of the Senate Committee of Privileges recommendation from the 42nd Report "Possible Adverse Treatment of a Witness before the Corporations and Securities Committee" the ASC will be conducting the above Training Seminar at its Regional Office in Melbourne on 1 November 1993. The programme is aimed at Senior Executive Service staff together with appropriate Senior Officers in the Victorian Regional Office and the Office of the Chairman at Melbourne.

I have greatly appreciated the assistance of the staff of the Senate Procedures Office in helping my own staff develop the proposed programme. I believe that the presentation of the Seminar would be greatly enhanced by the participation of a Senator in delivering the key element of the Seminar.

I was somewhat honoured to then be invited to attend the seminar. Unfortunately, I very much regret that I will not be able to because I will not be here. The important point I want to make is that the ASC has acted promptly and very well in response to the situation that was revealed and that it found itself in as a result of the work of the privileges committee.

PARA.TAB: The next point I would like to make in explaining to the Senate why I have come to the view that I have is that in a formal submission the chairman of the ASC expressed his belief that individual officers should not be cited for contempt because the lack of knowledge of the Senate's privilege was a failing on the part of the ASC itself—in other words, the whole commission—and, indeed, across the whole public sector. It is a matter of concern that in attempting to press the point that senior officers in public agencies should have a better understanding of parliamentary privilege, the committee has chosen to make an example of Mr Trevethan `to encourage the others'. That is what the privileges committee report said.

Having heard from some of those involved and understanding this chronicle of events, I have come to be strongly of the opinion that Mr Trevethan was and is innocent of any intent to hold this Senate in contempt—that his endeavours to administer his office in a wholly appropriate manner inadvertently led to his becoming involved in this way. Under advice, he thus committed an inadvertent breach which he immediately remedied and for which he publicly apologised. The officers under his administration legally have very significant powers of public investigation and conduct and he personally places great importance on the fact that they conduct themselves properly and do not exceed that power. Their behaviour in all respects ranks highly amongst Mr Trevethan's own priorities.

It is also relevant to note that one of our most senior professional bodies, in full possession of the facts of this matter, recently elected Mr Trevethan as its Victorian president. In all the circumstances, I believe that to add further to the personal suffering which I know Mr Trevethan has already endured would not constitute the pursuit of justice but would be a travesty of justice and not a correct application of the authority of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Short spoke about this report of the Senate Committee of Privileges. I have just spoken to the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, the secretary of the privileges committee. She is a most outstanding secretary, although a very hard task master.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Herron would agree with that. While this inquiry was taking place, the chair was ex-senator Patricia Giles. I am sure Senator Herron and the secretary would agree that she was quite outstanding as the chair of this committee.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is the manner in which it has been brought on. As the secretary has informed me, there has been an attempt to bring this matter on on several occasions and now it has been brought on without it being on the order of business—the red. That causes me some concern because, if we accept the recommendation of the committee, we find two people guilty of contempt of parliament, which is a very serious matter in my view.

We in this parliament become used to the circumstances here. We have exchanges across the floor, we make pronouncements and we become inured to the effect that those pronouncements might have on people outside this place. As Senator Short has said, Mr Trevethan has become quite disturbed by this matter. I wonder whether or not we should deal with these recommendations before the Senate in a different fashion. Just to have an outstanding committee produce some findings and then to endorse those findings without more discussion may not be as fair to the people against whom findings are made as it could be.

As I re-read this report I was quite impressed with the dissenting report, which I notice I signed myself and that is probably why I am so impressed with it. In spite of the most profound and moving arguments of others on the committee, I could not find sufficient evidence that Margot Waters, another senior official in the Australian Securities Commission, had committed contempt. I finished up saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Breach of parliamentary privilege or contempt of parliament is a grave matter and a decision about its commission should be made with considerable caution.
In my view the evidence in this matter is not sufficient to support a finding of contempt of Parliament against Ms Waters. Accordingly I find she did not commit a breach of parliamentary privilege.

I would like to convince this Senate to support the minority report. The mechanisms of the way this place works and the circumstances in which these matters come before the Senate make that nigh impossible. The concern that Senator Short expresses about the findings against Mr Trevethan about Margot Waters are similar to mine, except that he said that Mr Trevethan committed the contempt, but did so without intent. I think that would be the general feeling of the committee. Having searched the Hansard transcripts of evidence, my position is that there was just no evidence against her at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Against?

—Ms Margot Waters. Mr Trevethan says that he instructed Ms Waters to prepare the charges and to get some advice from the Australian Government Solicitor's office. After the charges were prepared, he had them served through the agency of Ms Waters. So although there is evidence against him, there is no evidence that Ms Waters laid the charges or joined in the decision to commence them. The evidence is very worrying from the point of view of having this particular charge of contempt of parliament found against her.

PARA.TAB: We are going through an exercise here as a parliament. This decision tonight will implicate us all. Senator Short was saying that he has concerns about Mr Trevethan. He has not had the opportunity to discuss his concerns or put them in a way that might convince this Senate. What is happening tonight in respect of Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters is that we, as a Senate, are finding them guilty of contempt, but we really do not have the facts in the way the committee did.
I think the privileges committee is quite magnificent. The people on it are of the greatest integrity and ability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not suggesting otherwise.

—I know, but on the other hand, we are the ones making the decision. With Senator Short's concern about one and my dissent about the other, it becomes quite a concern for this chamber. I think we too easily and too readily endorse a finding that may well be correct—given the research, the investigations and the great knowledge that the committee brought to this. It probably is right. Nevertheless, if there is doubt, can we, simply on the basis of a recommendation, make the findings we are about to make? As a parliament, we have to look at this process.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well for the committee to find them guilty of contempt. Fair enough. That binds the committee. But the Senate is the body that will find them guilty without them having the opportunity to address us, which is well nigh impossible, or having someone set out their case in some form. Enough senators might then get to the point where they say, `Thank you very much, privileges committee, for the magnificent work you have done, but on this occasion we think it is appropriate to make a finding that there was no contempt of parliament'.

What will happen now is that we will have a vote; this will go through. Senator Short has spoken about the high integrity of and the high regard held by his fellows for one person; I am saying that Ms Waters seems to be in much the same position. Yet the whole 76 of us in the Senate are about to say that those two people are guilty of the very grave offence of contempt of the Senate of the federal parliament of Australia. I think that is very drastic action for us to be taking here tonight. Although this motion is about to go through now, we will all have the responsibility for voting in favour of a finding that these two people committed a breach of parliamentary privilege and that they are in contempt of parliament, and they will wear that for the rest of their days.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly refer to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, which was tabled on 24 November 1992. I am sure that most honourable senators would have received representations in relation to the Family Law Act. It was regarded as an important matter to investigate.

PARA.TAB: I realise that the election has intervened. I wish to express my concern about the delay in the government's response to this report. I will not deal with it in much more detail except to read one letter that I have received. There were many recommendations in the report relating to access to children, the representation of children where there has been a suggestion of some sort of sexual abuse or where, in the opinion of the court, the circumstances warrant it, and other matters. I conclude my brief remarks by urging the government to give this a very high priority.

This letter—I will leave out the address and the name of the young person concerned; I am not drawing any conclusions as far as the parents are concerned—highlights the need for a child to be represented and to have a say. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Reid,

My name is I am a fourteen-year old student. My father who I do not see anymore abused me sexually, mentally and physically. He took my mother to court everytime I did not want to visit him. He would ask the court for access or custody. I would go to counselling sessions and felt as if I wasn't being listened to. He would always get access and my mother would be left in debt because of legal costs. Every time I went to my father's house he would abuse me. My mother asked the court if we could leave Melbourne because my father took out a Restraining Order. The judge agreed and we came to Canberra. That was back in 1986.

PARA.TAB: A few months ago my father went back to the court because of my refusal to go visit him. He asked for access\custody. A few thousand dollars later the court realised that I am now fourteen and asked me what I wanted. Now I don't see, talk, ring or write to my father. To this day my mother has spent about thirty thousand dollars and we are in debt by eight thousand dollars. The court has allowed this to go on for eight years. This should not have happened. I dislike what the court has put me through and I hope that the court will not do this to anyone else.

TAB.TAB: yours sincerely,

SPEECH.PARA: The letter is signed. It is urgent that the government respond to the recommendations of the committee that inquired into the aspects and interpretation of the Family Law Act. Situations such as this are real and need a different solution.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that my contribution, like the last contribution, will not be as uplifting as the earlier ones on the role of women in the Senate and the parliament. PARA.TAB: I welcome what is an interim response to the examination by the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities of the Close Corporations Act. It was introduced by Senator Robert Ray as the government's response. I do not think it is the government's response; it is an interim response and does not go as far as a full response ultimately will.

The government has taken up the major thrust of the recommendations contained in our report on the Close Corporations Act. The Close Corporations Act was passed through this parliament—as the term implies, it is an act—but ran into constitutional difficulties and was never proclaimed. Our committee was given the task of looking at it. We skirted around the country getting views on whether it was an appropriate vehicle for the needs of small business.

The Close Corporations Act tried to introduce a new form of incorporation for small businesses. It was designed to introduce a simple structure that was less onerous in reporting requirements but which still offered the advantages of limited liability. While there was support for the need for a simpler vehicle to provide incorporation for small businesses in the evidence presented to the committee when we went around the country, most witnesses gave only limited support to the Close Corporations Act itself or as the most appropriate type of vehicle.

Among the criticisms of the proposal was that the restrictions on its powers would render it unsuitable for small business and that limited liability could be lost relatively easily. Interestingly, we also found that the whole concept of limited liability did not provide a major incentive for small business; it is not a major concern.

Another criticism was that the structure and reporting requirements of the Close Corporations Act remain complex and that there is no simple process for converting a close corporation into a proprietary company. The committee instead recommended the introduction of a new corporate form called the private company. It proposed that this be enacted as a new chapter in the Corporations Law; that it be written in plain English to make it a little different from the rest of the Corporations Law, which is becoming more and more complex, onerous and difficult to follow; that its establishment be simple and cheap; that its reporting obligations be minimal; that its internal administration be simple and uncomplicated; that there be a simple process for dispute resolution between members of the private company; that the vehicle should offer the normal benefits of incorporation; that the transition to a more complex corporate structure should be simple in order to accommodate the growth of a business; and that the structure should be tax effective.

While the government's interim response does not adopt all these features, the discussion paper circulated by the Attorney-General on 15 July—the day after the letter to me that has been tabled as the interim response—includes a summary of them. The Attorney-General states that he is seeking:

SPEECH.PARA: a . . . simplified corporate form . . . to facilitate the needs of small businesses which have found the exempt proprietary company structure inadequate for their purposes or too cumbersome/costly to operate.

I simply thank the Attorney-General and the government for setting in place a process which I hope will lead to a sensible reform in this long overdue area of seeking an appropriate vehicle for small business to incorporate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 November 1989 the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It was not until 17 December 1990 that the government ratified the convention. On 22 December 1992 the Attorney-General made a declaration with respect to the convention in accordance with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986.

PARA.TAB: As previously stated by Senator Vanstone, the coalition has no opposition to the convention as such and what it stands for. However, notwithstanding the subsequent ratification and declaration by the Attorney-General, there has been a great deal of concern about this in the community. My office and, I believe, those of fellow senators have been inundated with correspondence on this very matter. Nearly three years after ratification, concerns are being widely expressed about the effect that this convention might have on Australia.

In general, the opinion voiced has been that this convention tends to undermine the authority of parents and those in whose legitimate authority children are placed. As well as that, there has been complaint that insufficient time has been given to the discussion of this convention before either ratification was made or the declaration was made by the Attorney-General.

I was interested to note in the debate we had yesterday on religious freedom that there were some 11 years between the adoption by the United Nations and ratification by this country. It would seem that two years is a very small period within which to discuss a most important subject as this. In any event I ask fellow senators who spoke on this matter to remember that part A of the motion moved by Senator Vanstone states:
That the Senate—
(a) recognises:

TAB.TAB: (i) that everyone is entitled to fundamental rights and freedoms without distinction such as based on race, sex, religion or nationality, and
(ii) that the child by reason of physical immaturity needs special safeguards and care;

SPEECH.PARA: So it is not a question of the coalition being hardnosed in relation to this convention. It is not a question of the coalition denying that such rights should be recognised or afforded to children. It is, in fact, nothing of the sort. It is simply the fact that there is some reservation about the declaration by the Attorney-General in relation to this matter and the subsequent effect that the declaration might have on Australia.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, let us look at the convention. The convention comprises 54 articles. I was not in this place when the ratification took place, but I believe there are some aspects of it which could give rise to some concern.

Articles 12 to 16 were singled out in correspondence that I have received as being the areas of main concern. The comments that I have received are that these articles deal with the freedom of children to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, freedom of association and that there should be no arbitrary interference with the privacy of children.

As such that is all very well. That deals with the rights of the child per se, but the criticism has been in relation to the lack of comment on the role of the parent. Now I understand that the Australian delegation was responsible for insertion of article 5, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: State Parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family or community as provided for by local custom, legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child, to provide, in a manner consistent, with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognised in the present Convention.

Of course the crucial words are that `the parent shall offer appropriate direction and guidance'. A good deal of correspondence that has been addressed to my office has expressed concern about this matter.

PARA.TAB: The fear is that although the declaration might be a starting point for practices adopted by the Commonwealth—as stated by Senator Bolkus—it could well extend into Commonwealth legislation. The fear is exactly what interpretation would be placed on article 5 as opposed to articles 12 to 16 and how it relates to domestic legislation.

As I understand the position in Europe, there is the Treaty of Rome whereby European countries acknowledge that they will be bound by such conventions and they will have consequential domestic legislation. I believe that writers on this subject have been of the opinion that Australia should be in the same boat. It would seem to me that the comments from the government are in the same vein.
An interesting point was made in an article written by Neville Turner in the January-February 1992 edition of the Law Institute Journal. He says:
This article has sought to identify issues that the N.C.B.A.—

SPEECH.PARA: that is the National Children's Bureau of Australia—

might well concern itself with in its role of implementing and monitoring the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child. But it is, I believe, readily apparent that the legal profession also has a major role to play in ensuring that it is translated into reality.

That is an article that goes into the matter in some depth. It betrays the thinking behind this and that is that lawyers have a role in translating this convention into reality. What it is about is not just the convention providing some sort of guidance for Commonwealth practice, but in translating it into day to day living for Australians.

PARA.TAB: The disallowance of this motion in no way detracts from Australia's international obligations on the matter. Australia, as I think Senator Watson said, is one the freest countries in the world. With 15 years legal experience, I can say that in areas of family law and in the jurisdiction of the children's courts, more than sufficient regard is had to the rights of the child. For instance, section 64(2) of the Family Law Act provides that in relation to access, custody, guardianship and matters touching on the welfare of a child `the court shall regard the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration'. Indeed, two striking examples in that act illustrate the point that I am making. Previously the wishes of the child in relation to custody and access were regarded when the child was age 14 or more. That has been done away with and the court assesses the child's wishes according to the maturity of the child.

Furthermore, separate representation is provided for a child in a variety of circumstances. From my experience in the Family Court, it is not uncommon for a child to have separate representation and legal aid can be provided for that to be done. In Western Australia there is ample provision for abused children or neglected children. In fact, under state legislation the relevant department takes out a care and protection order.

From what I have heard today in this chamber, it would seem that if we do not allow this declaration to stand, all sorts of calamity and chaos will befall children in this country and the whole question of human rights will be thrown into question. That is simply not the case. As I say, Australia has a very good record. When we look at other countries and say, `They have not applied a reservation to the ratification of this convention', we could well say that those countries had better follow us rather than that we follow them. When one looks at the rights of citizens over the age of 18—and the convention applies to people under the age of 18—one sees that there are very few countries in Asia, South America, and especially Africa, that could tell Australia anything about children's rights or human rights in general. I believe that this country is one of the leaders of the world in this area.

During my time practising in the law, I discovered in a very practical way the problems that face children who are the victims of abuse and neglect. I can relate to the Senate a case where I was representing one child, a female aged 15, who wanted to obtain bail on a charge that she faced, but she could not obtain it because she had nowhere to live. I set out to find her a place to stay so that she could be granted bail. I approached the relevant welfare department and made inquiries there, but I also contacted the relevant voluntary welfare agencies, such as Centacare, the Wesley Central Mission and another one run by the Uniting Church. It was not the government department that got back to me pretty quickly. It was the churches and the voluntary welfare agencies that got back with a secure place to stay for this young girl who was virtually living on the streets. Those are the practical problems we face.

All the debate that we can have on some convention will not help any child in that sort of position. It will not help an abused or neglected child. I have seen people in my office who have been underprivileged and who have been really down on their luck, and what those people need is economic security and employment. It is only in that way that they can provide for their children or fulfil any sort of duty as a parent. Those are the questions we should be looking at, not some airy-fairy convention and declaration that we think will change the world.

That leads me to the more practical element of what causes children to come into conflict with the law and end up on the streets? I would like to refer the Senate to a Couchman program on 9 May 1990. It was during the course of that program that a mother, Brenda Rowlands, related a story. It was Peter Couchman who put the question to her as to why she was there and what her concerns were. He asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What happened with you and your son?
She said:

Well, I'm most concerned about it because what happened with my son, happened four years ago, pre-Convention; the Convention had nothing to do with it. But my son, from about the age of 15, decided he didn't like school, he didn't like being told what to do as in doing homework or anything else, and he was advised of his rights by his teachers, so he came home at about 15 and a half and said, `Oh, when I'm 16, the law says I can leave home'. The law didn't specifically say he could leave home, but it said that I couldn't get him to come back, which amounted to the same thing.

Couchman said to Mrs Rowlands, `So he left'. She replied, `So at 16, he left'. Couchman went on to say, `Who did he live with? Who became his guardian?'. Mrs Rowlands replied, somewhat sadly, `Well, he left and slept in refuges and knocked around the streets a bit. I don't know what he did because he cut himself off from us, because that is what he wanted to do'.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, I can tell you that that story is not in isolation. I have represented hundreds and hundreds of children in the last 15 years in the Children's Court of Western Australia and that story is familiar.

What children need is a secure family background and a good education. With that start in life they will have some sort of future. This notion that a child aged 15 or 16 can simply do what this boy did in relation to his family life, strike out and end up on the streets, is absolutely fallacious. The whole question of the role of a parent needs to be looked at in society. We have to look at the duties and responsibilities of parents.

While I am on that subject I would venture to say that there are a good many people who become parents without understanding the responsibilities that attach to that. That is at the base of the problem of juvenile crime and the problems facing youth today. I can tell the Senate that the majority of children I represented came from a broken background or a situation where they were left to fend for themselves at an early age. It was uncommon, to say the least, to have a child on a charge who came from a secure and stable family environment or who had a good education.

We know that a person under the age of 18 has special protection from the law for a very good reason. That is because they need nurturing; they need protection; they need assistance; and they need an upbringing to prepare themselves for the future. But trying to translate these sort of rights into the law by saying, `This will be a panacea. It will sort things out. It will suddenly make a lot of children better overnight' is completely without foundation.
I would like to quote from an article in the August 1992 volume of the Australian Journal of Family Law by Otlowski and Tsamenyi, which referred to article 5:

SPEECH.PARA: This article clearly envisages that parents may make decisions on behalf of very young children, not mature enough to make decisions for themselves, and that in respect of older children, parents may provide guidance and direction in decision-making.

This society can only be on a downward trend when we allow children to tell their parents what to do, to have complete control over what their parents say and where parents can only make decisions on behalf of very young children. An adolescent aged 13, 14 and 15 is not equipped to go on to the streets and make decisions for himself or herself. It is for that very reason that we find them addicted to drugs and involved in child prostitution, because they do not have that care and sustenance of their parents.

PARA.TAB: When I look at the March 1993 report by the National Children's Bureau of Australia for the Children's Rights Coalition, I see a depiction on the cover which shows two parents looking face to face at a child, obviously theirs—
Debate interrupted.
