TALK.START.PARA: —The waterfront dispute, temporarily settled yesterday, came near to paralysing Australia's trade on a day when the balance of payments showed that we are still on the slippery slide to a banana republic. The naval deployment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 46 cargo ships carrying 20,000 containers cost over $2 million to shipping companies and exporters while the ships lay idle off the Australian coast. The meter certainly ticks over while ships rest at anchor.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, admitted in an answer to a question asked by me on Monday, the strike was `not in the least helpful to Australia's export industries'. It was a strike that will remind our trading partners that we still have some of the world's most unreliable ports. We are unreliable. We are not dependable. If foreign countries have a choice of sourcing their raw materials or manufactured goods elsewhere, they will do so. I would.

The strike arose after a threat by the maritime union of Australia that `years of industrial disruption' would follow if Australian stevedores took redundancy action against 313 surplus workers after a recent merging of stevedoring companies. Australian Stevedores was formed on 1 July from a merger of National Terminals Australia and Strang Patrick. The new company has determined that this number was surplus to its waterfront work force of 2,000 people. At last week's hearing, the unions warned of `an almighty dispute that would teach the employer a lesson' if enforced redundancy was implemented.

The Labor Party's conspiracy with the waterfront unions to keep true labour market reforms out of the expensive reform process over the last three years has come home to roost with this current strike. The crunch issue in the strike is redundancy—in other words, the job for life concept so dear to the standover dinosaurs of another age which still survive here. The union has stated flatly that it will not abide by any decision that insists on compulsory redundancies. It is this refusal to come to terms with the contemporary commercial realities, however unpalatable they may be, that has led to the current crisis.

No-one likes to be told that their job is no longer viable, but it is a commercial fact of life for almost everybody else. For decades the waterfront has been quarantined from the real world of commerce and has developed a reputation of dishonesty and inefficiency that will be a measure of industrial bloody-mindedness for some time. It was because of the total inefficiency of the waterfront that the government was forced to embark on the three-year waterfront reform program which was completed in October 1992.

Some 4,479 employees left the industry under extremely generous terms. The cost of the redundancy payments was $413 million, of which the Commonwealth contributed $165 million. The remainder of the cost to the industry was paid by shipping companies through a levy. A further $20 million was contributed for additional departures in response to an idle time list, to which shipping companies are refusing to contribute.

Since the end of the program, the government's priorities have been centred on studies by bodies such as the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Trade Practices Commission to determine whether the savings, claimed by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority to be in the order of $300 million, have been passed on.

The government's aim is to produce evidence that its reforms have produced savings both in ship turnaround times and in actual costs. Since end users have, with the exception of a few customers, denied that they have received cost benefits, the government has sought to lay the blame for this elsewhere. One of its targets, with some justification, has been port authorities. Port authority reform has now been placed on the agenda by Mr Keating. The government, of course, previously mocked the opposition for urging port authority reform on the grounds that the Commonwealth did not own the ports. Labor has unfortunately stopped short of the right policy position that privatisation is the preferred outcome.

Shipping lines have pointed out that turnaround times have improved markedly and that this represents a saving for them. They also claim, however, that shipping rates have been at bargain basement levels—in terms of on-water costs—for some time and that they have a margin lag to make up before they are able to pass on any savings to end users. So despite $400 million being spent to persuade 4,479 surplus wharfies to retire early and their $100,000 golden handshakes on top of their already generous retirement benefits, including cash in lieu of unused sick leave—a perk virtually unknown anywhere else in the work force—the problem of market force redundancy was squibbed.

It was squibbed because the problem of labour market structure, as it affects the waterfront, is security of tenure held by wharfies. There is no real labour flexibility, and this was not addressed. So only partial reform was achieved after so much money. There is no change of the culture on the waterfront. The one-off adjustment that the redundancy program produced has not brought the labour flexibility to the waterfront that is required for us to be an efficient and fully competitive trading nation and that is essential for our farmers and our exporters to do the job right.

It is worth noting that Australian ports are still 2 1/2 times more expensive than our New Zealand counterparts on average. Ordinary Australian consumers and exporters are paying more for their goods and getting less for their products as a result. This dispute has been temporarily settled with the help of the heavy hand of the ACTU, which cannot afford to have another bushfire burning just at the moment as it has its hands full arguing with the government over changes to enterprise bargaining.

The fact that the maritime unions were prepared to defy the Industrial Relations Commission and renege on agreements signed with constituent companies of the merged Australian stevedores confirms that the real issue was ignored during Labor's waterfront reform program. The suggestion by Senator Collins yesterday in response to my question that the opposition drew comfort from the disruption of the Australian waterfront is an unfortunate slur in that it has no basis of fact.

To suggest that opposition senators `were clearly praying for an extension and continuation of the dock strike' is a poor attempt to suggest that they would be content to see major damage done to Australian exports and to Australia's trade reputation—which is obviously the very thing that opposition senators most want to prevent. To suggest that they felt `obvious disappointment that the industrial disputation would not be enlarged and would not continue' is not only fanciful but insulting.

It is time that Senator Collins heeded the opposition's warnings and dealt with the real reform needs of the waterfront. He should, however, be under no misapprehension that the opposition wants anything other than an end to all strikes. It will not endorse capitulation to the unions' bullying but requires rather that genuine reform be undertaken before such crises and strikes can recur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the comments, as recorded in the media, of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) whilst overseas on the situation in East Timor. Mr Keating said in an interview that the debate on the invasion of Timor was over. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The time to have had that was in the middle of the 1970s. That opportunity has passed. I think to be arguing now against the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia would be absolutely fruitless.
Strikingly, these words followed Mr Keating's comments in Washington to the President of the United States, Mr Bill Clinton, regarding human rights generally in the Asian region, where he said:
More balance is required between the question of trade and human rights.

In diplomatic language this was taken as a signal to place the question of human rights second to that of trade negotiations. A very softly, softly approach to human rights in Asia was Mr Keating's prescription for the conduct of foreign policy in the Asia-Pacific region. With this attitude, Mr Keating would have been the worst advocate for Australia in its Olympic bid. It was precisely those Europeans who vigilantly protested against the Chinese violations of human rights, and the Tiananmen Square massacre in particular, who helped to turn the votes to Sydney's favour in the final count. The week before the vote on the Olympics, the United States Congress passed a resolution condemning China's human rights record and openly declared that for this reason China did not deserve to be awarded the Olympics in the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Further, it should be noted that the Asian nations supported the Chinese bid for the year 2000 Olympics only on the grounds of future trade benefits, totally disregarding China's record on human rights. We have to ask whether the Prime Minister has forgotten what type of regime China really is. Has he forgotten the basic fundament that China is a communist country? Has he no sense of history—the history of the blood and the torture that the communist regimes as a bloc inflicted upon the world? Proudly, the majority of European countries have not forgotten; they have learnt from history. The human rights and sovereignty questions of East Timor were totally ignored by the Prime Minister, and his comments regarding them are of serious concern so far as they signal to the Indonesian government that the human rights policies will go unchecked or mere tokenism will be in place.

The history of Timor clearly shows that, however small the island, its people, however few, are a people with a distinct national identity. The Portuguese first settled in Timor in 1520. The Spanish arrived in 1522. The Dutch took possession of the western portion of the island in 1613. The British took over from 1812 to 1815. The Dutch and the Portuguese fought for supremacy over the island's eastern half, and their respective interests were settled by treaties in 1860 and 1893.

Throughout the period of colonisation, the East Timorese retained a distinct nationality and culture. How is this land Indonesia's land any more than it is the land of the British, Spanish, Portuguese or Dutch? History shows us that many national groups have waited for centuries to recapture their sovereignty.

The Turkish ruled Greece for some 400 years. Afghanistan has seen more armies march through it than any other nation, and it has always retaken control of its own sovereignty. The national groups of central Asia and eastern and central Europe have also waited for decades, and in some cases centuries, for foreign occupiers to be forced to retreat. The Jewish people have waited 2,000 years to return to their homeland. In the case of East Timor, it may take years—it may take a century; it may take forever—to recapture its sovereignty and rights, but nothing will wipe away the truism that the East Timorese are not Indonesians and that their country does not belong to Indonesia.

More important, and more immediate an issue, is the question of human rights in East Timor today. This question has been dismissed by the Prime Minister. As it was reported, he rejected the Irish position of trying to re-open talks between Portugal and Indonesia to try to resolve the human rights problems in Timor. Mr Keating said that he did not know why Amnesty International was staging a silent protest to coincide with his visit.

Sadly, it would seem that Australia's newfound policy on human rights does not match Portugal's persistent attempt to defend the rights of the East Timorese. No-one should think that the Indonesian government does not exercise authoritarian control over the island of East Timor. At all levels of society it is running a shadow government. Unlike typical Western armies, the Indonesian army is deeply involved in social affairs. The staff structure corresponds broadly with the various tiers of the civilian administration and the police hierarchy, down to the village level, where there might be an NCO to monitor political and social developments and the work of the village headman.

On 12 November 1991 the human rights question was brought to the forefront of the world's attention with reports of the Dili massacre. The reports of the number of people killed ranged from the Indonesian claim of 50 to several hundred, according to foreign journalists. Such persecution was not unprecedented, but the advantage this event had was that it was filmed by foreign media and flashed around the world. It was the world that responded to condemn the Indonesian government for such an undue use of violence.

The Dili massacre was condemned by the UN. Now Australia is standing very much alone in its view of recognising the Indonesian annexation and with the tokenistic approach to human rights in East Timor. The world does otherwise. For example, relations with Jakarta and Washington were strained of late when the US Senate foreign relations committee voted to ban US arms sales to Indonesia until it had improved its human rights record in East Timor.

Under the committee's amendment, future arms sales to Indonesia will depend on six criteria. The first is whether civilians convicted in connection with the November 1991 East Timor incident have been treated in accordance with international standards of fairness. The second is whether the Indonesian government is taking steps to curb human rights violations by security forces, including bringing those responsible for the 1991 massacre to hand. The third is whether there has been a full public accounting of all the individuals declared missing after the massacre. The fourth is whether the international humanitarian and human rights organisations have been granted expanded access to East Timor. The fifth is whether the Indonesian government has started decreasing its military presence in East Timor. The sixth is whether Indonesia is cooperating with UN efforts to resolve disputes.

Following such pressure, the Indonesians have agreed to allow access by UN agencies and human rights groups to East Timor. The decision of the Indonesians was mediated by no less a personage than the UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, at a meeting between the foreign ministers of Portugal and Indonesia. In Jakarta a group of Swedish MPs has requested that the Indonesian government withdraw its troops from East Timor and has claimed that an arms embargo would be imposed on it until the status of the former Portuguese colony was determined.

It is now time for Australia to reassess its foreign policy regarding Timor, particularly in the light of the original justification by the Indonesian government, supported by the Australian government, that occupation was necessary to prevent a little Cuba developing. Perhaps in 1975, at the height of the Cold War, this had some reason. That was the year that the Vietnam War was lost. That was the year that US policy in Indochina collapsed and there was a fear that the red menace would continue its southwards march. Indonesia was seen as the bulwark against that threat. For such a wild act to be undertaken and supported by Australia at the time, it must have been believed that no chances could be taken with an independent East Timor. Now that the Cold War is over, when new alignments are being formed and peace is being given its best chance, such threats are no longer credible.

It is encouraging that the President of Indonesia, President Suharto, has recently acknowledged that East Timor was more trouble to Indonesia than it was worth. Perhaps this comment, however gratuitous it may be, is the first sign of a preparedness on the part of the Indonesians to accept the judgment of the international community.

There is one chapter in Australia's history which says that we owe it to the East Timorese for their contribution to the defence of Australia in World War II. They helped Australian soldiers in the defence of our country and for this East Timor was extensively damaged and tens of thousands of East Timorese were killed or died from starvation. I wonder how this history and present human rights violations in East Timor weigh on the Catholic conscience of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who was quoted in the media as saying, `We possess each an innate human dignity'.

Mr Keating claims that it is his Catholic conscience which prompts him to call for a republic and this equates with the defence of human dignity. I would have thought that a more serious and deeper analysis of his Catholic conscience would have led him to a stronger defence of human rights in countries such as East Timor. Now Australia stands alone in regard to the East Timor situation and what was justified by policy in the past is no longer as world history has ended and begun again. It is therefore crucial that Australia reassess its foreign policy towards East Timor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give the Western Australian perspective on the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Bill 1993. This Bill was part of a scheme designed to improve the safety and efficiency of road transport and to reduce the administrative costs associated with road transport operations in Australia. It seeks to achieve the objectives of the heads of government agreement on heavy and light vehicles. This agreement provided for complementary legislation to achieve a workable framework for the implementation of a national scheme of road transport regulation.

PARA.TAB: Those of us from Western Australia have no problems with the main thrust of that bill. We are certainly in favour of uniform standards on heavy and light vehicles. We are in favour of standard dimensions. We are in favour of standard mass limits, standard speeds, standard driver qualifications and standard vehicle inspection. The Western Australian minister at the ministerial council voted at various times against introducing the whole bill in Western Australia because of the standard charges on all vehicles around Australia, no matter how much or how little they work, where they work and whether they are on-road or off-road most of the time.

I point out to this chamber that it is not only the present Liberal government of Western Australia that has had this problem. Previous Labor governments—those disgraced governments of Burke and Dowding, and the Lawrence government—had exactly the same problem with it and that is why they would not buy it.

New South Wales will not buy standard charges either because it reckons the standard charges are too low and that would then affect that state's road funding. Western Australia says that the charges are too high, and there are no exemptions for those vehicles that are important, which do not spend much time on the road but which have to be licensed because of third party insurance liabilities. An example is farm vehicles—ones used for seed, super and water carting. They hardly ever go on a road but now and again have to cross a road, or go to a standpipe, or a fertiliser shed to load up, or something like that. They probably operate out of the farmers' sheds for only six weeks of the year.
Another category of vehicle which Western Australia has had a lot of trouble convincing its authorities about is the fire truck which also comes under national standard vehicle charging.

Another concern with Western Australia's big mining industry is the drilling rigs. The trucks have to be licensed because now and again they have to go for an inspection, and now and again they have to go back to their bases for servicing, and some of those bases can be thousands of kilometres away. Most of the year, drilling rigs are in very isolated areas. Mining leases in Western Australia are way out and the rigs very seldom see a road—if they do, they are very backward roads. I am talking about the Gibson Desert, the Great Sandy Desert and areas around Kalgoorlie, Wiluna, Meekatharra, the harsh Pilbara and even into the Kimberley. I am not talking about the south-west of Western Australia where there are big built up areas, but about those remote areas. They are the problems we have in Western Australia and I would like to put them on record.

This bill, which went through parliament today, covered only the ACT and, I believe, a certain part of New South Wales around the Wollongong area, and the Federal government expects state parliaments around Australia to pass complementary legislation. As usual, the big stick of this federal government—of which you are part, Mr President—is that if the states do not toe the line, they will come in for cuts on road funding, as was the case with the black spot program. If Western Australia were to get any funding for the black spot program it had to introduce the .05 breathalyser count which it opposed for many years. The previous state government, the Labor Party government, did bring it in so it was able to get the black spot program funding. Incidentally, it was far less per capita than any other state in Australia considering that Western Australia has more kilometres of roads per capita than anywhere else in Australia, and probably in the world. The situation will be exactly the same in this case.

Mr President, you might have heard the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, say in question time the other day that he had no time for any states that did not spend untied road funding on roads. I share his dislike for that because I have always been an opponent of untied road funds. I have never believed that tied road funds should continue where the funds are tied to particular kilometres of roads, whether they be in a shire, whether they belong to the federal arterial road system or whether they belong to the road system. I do not believe in that system, which was in place for many years.

I believe in the system that road funding allocated in the name of road funding should be tied to roads—full stop. Whatever is allocated to roads should go into roads. Shires should not spend the money somewhere else and then run back to the state or federal government and say, `We have no money for roads. We need more'. So I agree with Senator Collins on that point. But he has to be brought to account for making such a statement when the One Nation package made a quite massive contribution to roads to try to build up some of the road systems in Australia before the last election. Mr President, you probably remember that well.

Bearing in mind what Senator Collins said about not spending untied road funds on roads but road funds on roads, I have a letter here dated 9 July 1992 from the office of the Premier of Western Australia, who was Carmen Lawrence at the time, addressed to the Treasurer of Australia, Mr J. S. Dawkins MP complaining about $8 million of certain road funding. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear John
I refer to your letter of 2 June 1992—
That is the Treasurer's letter—
proposing that $8 million of road funding made available for Western Australia under the `One Nation' statement be reallocated to the Subiaco Oval redevelopment.

This is a government that believes that untied road funding should be spent on roads. The Treasurer wrote to the Premier of Western Australia on 2 June saying that the government had allocated $8 million—not Western Australia, Western Australia is still looking for the $8 million; it does not know where it went—to redevelop the Subiaco Oval. Once again, I believe that this had something to do with the election that was around the corner in 1993. The letter from Carmen Lawrence continues:

I cannot agree to this proposal, as Western Australia has very substantial needs for road funding which are not being met from existing resources. Western Australia's share of national and arterial road funding from the Commonwealth has declined substantially in the last few years,—
I have always said that in this chamber—
and I understand that only 9% of national roads funding in the `One Nation' statement was allocated to Western Australia, which does not even represent a per capita share of funding for this State.
I believe that the $8 million can be readily allocated to road projects in this State through consultation between the respective Commonwealth and State Transport Ministers.

So there is it. The Labor Premier of Western Australia at the time complained to the Treasurer about that missing $8 million. The next letter is dated 2 October 1992 from Pam Beggs, the former Minister for Transport in Western Australia, who was defeated in the last state election. I must say that Pam Beggs, although on the other side of politics, did try to do something for the roads of Western Australia. Her letter to Mr Brown, the Minister for Land Transport, states:
Dear Mr Brown
Your recent advice about the allocation of Land Transport funds gave a total of $161.2M to Western Australia in 1992/93.

The total One Nation road package to Western Australia is $55.4M of which $2.5M was allocated in 1991/92 and $44.90M is included in the advised allocation of $161.2M in 1992/93. A further $8M is yet to be allocated.
In June the Federal Treasurer, Hon J S Dawkins, MP, wrote to the Premier proposing the $8M be set aside for non-road projects which related to the redevelopment of the Subiaco Football Oval.
It has been documented a second time. The letter goes on:
In July the Premier replied to the Federal Treasurer disagreeing with this proposal and advising there is a greater need for the funds to be provided on roadworks.

She went on to describe that the $8 million would be better used between Wubin and Meekatharra in Western Australia. I totally agree with her sentiments that that is where the $8 million should have gone.

PARA.TAB: But here we have a federal government which allocated quite a tidy sum at the time because it had to catch up with road funding. As I have said many times in this chamber, in real terms, since 1982 when the Fraser government went out of government, road funding went down and down and the whole system in Australia broke down badly. In that One Nation package the federal government attempted to bring the road system back up to standard.

So after road funding being neglected all this time, this $8 million was made available, but Mr Dawkins, the federal Treasurer, who is under siege at the present moment—I do not know how much longer he will be around as a Treasurer; I do not believe he will resign; I think Mr Keating might push him sideways—directed that that $8 million be taken off road funding that was so badly needed, and reallocated to develop Subiaco Oval for political purposes. If that $8 million had been spent on Subiaco Oval, which I disagree with but I am a great follower of football—the Eagles, East Fremantle and that sort of thing—I could find a way to excuse it, but that $8 million has disappeared altogether and we, from Western Australia, want it back again.

There is a letter from the present Minister for Transport in Western Australia, Eric Charlton. I cannot find his letter, but I have found his press release. I must say that Eric Charlton and I have not really seen eye to eye too much over the last 10 or 15 years in politics, but he is doing a very good job as Minister for Transport in Western Australia. Eric Charlton belongs to the National Party. His press release says that he has written to the federal Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, seeking a re-allocation of that $8 million, because the $8 million that the Treasurer asked to go to Subiaco Oval has not even gone to Subiaco Oval and Eric Charlton is looking to get it redirected.

Wherever Senator Collins is this evening I think he should hang his head in shame for the statement he made that he has very little time for states that do not spend untied road funding on roads. If he wants to lift his head up, he should ask Mr Dawkins to find the $8 million that he reallocated to Subiaco Oval but which was never spent, and he should give it to the Western Australian government so that it can spend it on the roads that badly need it to keep up our export income from primary production, minerals and all that sort of thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the West Coast Eagles?
—They will be back again next year.
—Don't they play at Subiaco Oval?

—Not always. They play at the Western Australia Cricket Association ground now and again when they play night games. The point is that $8 million was allocated for roads. I ask Senator Collins, in his absence from this chamber, to please get it back for Western Australia.

—Earlier today in question time this chamber was treated to the greatest piece of evasion that this house has seen since the Khemlani letter affair nearly 20 years ago. I refer to the evasion we saw on the part of the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) and the infamous and notorious Labor Party lease, which the Commonwealth has entered into, which will deliver to the Labor Party $80 million over 15 years—$34 million more than the Department of Finance says is justifiable in commercial terms.

PARA.TAB: Let me start with an elementary proposition. When the government of the day is a Labor government and it takes a non-commercial lease of a building, which is not yet even built, for a non-commercial term of years, without any evidence at all of any attempt to negotiate a proper commercial arrangement—and takes this lease from its own party—the very least we could expect is that the punctilious observance of all relevant statutes, regulations and guidelines would be the case.

But, as we heard today, the minister is not even prepared to say who made any of the relevant decisions. He is unwilling to say what act of parliament the minister at the time claimed to be acting under. He has not even produced a scrap of paper showing how in all of Canberra this was the only building on these exorbitant terms available to the government.

Instead, in meaningless phrases, he distorts every question asked by attempting to treat them as slurs upon the Public Service. He well knows that this is not the purpose of my questions. Their purpose is to sweep away the tissue of evasions, distortions and obstructions and ultimately to get to the truth about this unprecedented deal—and `deal' is the right word. This Labor Party is notorious for its deals—a deal here and a deal there—and when it uses the people's money to do its deals, this house is not prepared to be treated with contempt.

The minister seems unwilling to face the very serious implications raised by the questions. It would be difficult to imagine a worse situation of conflict of interest. The situation appears graver day by day as it remains unexplained and festering.

The other very serious implication arises from the application of the fruits of this fantastic deal. Do members of this house, enjoying the largess of the contract, sit here with their places in jeopardy because of the operation of section 44 of the constitution?

These are matters which I certainly will continue to pursue, no matter how long it takes and no matter what obstructions I am confronted with, because I can think of no more important matter upon which the light of day needs to be shed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening in the Legislative Council in Western Australia—that august body of legislators in my home state—a relatively new member of that chamber, the Hon. Alannah MacTiernan, rose to her feet and decided to tip a bucket on me. I now rise to my feet—
—To tip a bucket back on her.
—Not to tip a bucket back on the honourable member of the Legislative Council, I would not dare stoop to that level, but to set a few matters straight and put them on the record here in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The Hon. Alannah MacTiernan referred in her speech this evening in the Legislative Council to a student rally demonstrating against the voluntary student unionism legislation, which occurred in Western Australia a couple of weeks ago. In fact, those who were listening to the Senate during the matters of public interest debate earlier today will remember that I referred to it there. It was a robust meeting with a few hundred students in attendance and a number of Liberal Party politicians, including me, some Labor Party politicians and even a new Green politician from the state upper house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not another one!

—Yes, they are reproducing. It was a robust meeting and it was somewhat of a surprise to me. Firstly, it is a surprise that in 1993 one can get a group of students to actually demonstrate in favour of being compelled to join an association. I was not given the opportunity to speak at the rally. We were denied that opportunity because not only do these people not agree with freedom of association, they do not agree with freedom of speech. They call a public rally and then allow all the speakers to put the one side of the case. They did not allow the minister who was representing the government's position to speak; they gagged him. They certainly did not allow me or any other speaker to speak.

PARA.TAB: Such actions surprised me. Student activism in Australia is a proud tradition, as it is in most Western democracies. Many of us will remember, even though I was very young at the time, the rallies at Kent state university and universities across the globe rallying and protesting against involvement in the Vietnam war and specifically against the compulsion of the draft. So it is very surprising to see a few years later, in 1993, dedicated, principled students arguing in favour of being compelled to join an association or a union. We on the Liberal side of politics do not believe in compulsory student unionism or compulsory industrial unionism. We do not ever seek to distinguish between the two because an individual should be born free in Australia and should be free to choose whether or not to join any association whatsoever.

The Hon. Alannah MacTiernan—who would probably describe herself as a Ms rather than a Miss or Mrs, and that is her right—decided to describe my behaviour at the rally. I will try to read out of the Hansard of the Western Australian Legislative Council to the extent that I can, because I have a terrible facsimile copy of it. She specifically accuses me of using physical threats to various female members of the student protest. She says that I continually threatened and harassed people who had obtained permission to conduct the rally on the steps of parliament house. She further says that I was continually trying to block them from having access to the microphone—access to the steps, she went on to say.
Then my friend Ross Lightfoot, a member of the upper house there, interjected—out of order, Mr President, I am sure. The Hon. Alannah MacTiernan went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that his highly offensive sexist statements to the women who were in attendance were recorded and will be the subject of further inquiry.
I shudder while waiting to see the outcome of their inquiries.

PARA.TAB: I bring this matter to the attention of the Senate because, firstly, I say to Alannah MacTiernan that to make those sorts of comments about my behaviour, with the protection of parliamentary privilege in the Legislative Council of Western Australia, is an act of cowardice. I remember earlier today in the Senate that Senator Robert Ray, the acting Leader of the Government here, challenged my good friend and colleague Senator Bishop.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Bolkus.

—No. Senator Robert Ray challenged her to `walk 30 yards to courage', he said. I thought it was quite a poetic turn; Senator Robert Ray is good at that. He did say that and I thought it was rather nice. Of course, it was Senator Bolkus who did challenge Senator Bishop to go outside and repeat what she had said. He clearly did not hear the question because I am sure Senator Bishop would be quite happy to repeat her question standing on top of a building or railway station as it had no legal indictment of anybody included in it.
—It did cause him to froth at the mouth, though.

—It certainly did, but that is not unusual for Senator Bolkus. In relation to what was said by the Hon. Alannah MacTiernan, member of the Legislative Council, I say to the Senate—and I can be challenged on this and will be—that I behaved quite normally and in a very fair and just manner at the rally to the extent that one can do so when surrounded by a few hundred people jostling and pushing you and generally yelling in your ear. I would ask her to go outside of the Legislative Council chamber, perhaps stand on the front steps of parliament house in Western Australia tomorrow—I will be travelling back to the west tomorrow morning, but I should be there around about noon—and I challenge her to say outside what she has said under the protection of parliamentary privilege in Western Australia. I consider her accusing me of using physical threats and other intimidatory tactics against female students as being not only quite defamatory of my integrity and standing in the community but also totally untrue.

PARA.TAB: I might say that on a number of occasions I had to ask the police who were present at this rally to come and protect some members of the university Liberal Club in Western Australia, because members of the protesting group were elbowing people in the mouth. As for statements as to my making threats to anyone, all I can say is that the only person I recollect making any sort of threat to was a bloke who stuck his elbow into the head of one of my young friends from the university Liberal Club. I actually went up to the bloke and said, `You do that again and I'll get this policeman over here to come and talk to you'. If that is a threat of anything, then so be it.

I was accused of making sexist statements to women at the meeting. One of them actually said that I had asked her for a date. I would like to put on the record once and for all what actually happened because it has been the subject of a couple of tiny articles in some august journals in Western Australia. One of the young ladies there was screaming at my friend and upper house colleague in Western Australia, the Hon. Ross Lightfoot, asking him his name. She was screaming, `What's your name, what's your name, what's your name?'. Ross Lightfoot refused to give her his name. Not many people in Western Australia do not know Ross Lightfoot on sight anyway, but Ross refused to give this girl his name. Ross Lightfoot said, `I don't need to give you my name'. This girl said, `My name is . . . '—whatever it was; I cannot remember now—`what's your name?'. She continued with this quite puerile line of questioning. I stepped in, in an attempt at humour and in an attempt to defuse the situation, and said, `Why do you want to know his name; are you going to ask him for a date?'. She misheard me in the ruckus and thought I had asked her for a date.

I assure the Senate that I have been happily married for about four years and have had a tremendous relationship with my wife, Brenda, for at least five years and have certainly not invited any girls out for a date in that period. If I were ever tempted to ask a girl out for a date, I can assure honourable senators that this particular girl would certainly not be the object of my inquiry. I am not attracted to girls who wear earrings in their nose and have orange hair.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit discriminatory.

—It is not, because I am not attracted to those girls. There were certainly no sexist comments. To put this in context—I will try not to delay the Senate, even though I am sure it is a fascinating story for all those listening—after that incident this girl got particularly upset, even though she had the story totally wrong and then insisted that I apologise to the rally. I took this as an opportunity because right up to the last hour leading up to this I had been arguing that it was probably a fair thing for the minister to put the government's case. They said, `No, we've organised this rally, we're putting our point of view and that's all we're going to do'. In fact, they told us that we should not have been there because they got the licence for the rally and we were not even allowed to be there. In other words, they were having a public rally but one could not be a member of the public and be there and one certainly could not put another view.

PARA.TAB: I had generally been standing there negotiating as much as possible with the members of the student groups to say it would probably be better for the fairness of the rally if the alternative view was put. I certainly wanted to put the federal Liberal Party's point of view on the funding issue—the threat by the federal government to take away up to $5 million from the state of Western Australia if this legislation went through the parliament. I wanted to put on record our views on that and the fact that we will oppose the legislation based on that threat to Western Australia. I was not allowed to speak.

But when I was invited to speak to apologise to this girl to whom I was supposed to have made sexist remarks, I thought that would be a good opportunity to grab the microphone. As the people in The Newcastle Song said, `Don't you ever let a chance go by'; I grabbed the microphone and said something to the effect that, `I apologise to all of you here'. Then the girl got upset and said, `You're not meant to be apologising to them; you're meant to be apologising to me'. So I turned to her and said, `I apologise to you as well because you have been brought here and the people who are organising this rally are not allowing you to hear the alternative side of the argument. I ask you all to allow the minister to be heard'. Having said that, they were forced to have a ballot as to whether the Minister for Industrial Relations, Graham Kierath, could actually speak. To the great credit of the student body and the protesters, they voted overwhelmingly in favour of allowing him to speak. He grabbed the microphone shortly after that and some freedom of speech oriented member of the student body decided to pull the plug on the microphone and that was just about the end of the rally. That was all good fun and games.

I conclude by saying that I think protests and rallies are all part of the democratic process. It is very important that we have a vigorous exchange of ideas and views at these meetings. At these rallies there is always danger of bodily contact and people jostling and so forth. As long as that is done in a good-natured way, no-one will come to any harm. Members of the radical Left and members of the NUS and so forth certainly did not behave in that way but I will not make the sorts of accusations against them that they have made against me because they achieve little in the overall debate.

I do say to Alannah MacTiernan, who has gone into the Legislative Council of Western Australia tonight and made these defamatory points about my behaviour on that day, that if she is so convinced of what she says she should go outside onto the front steps of Parliament House tomorrow noon or tomorrow afternoon and repeat what she said in front of witnesses. I look forward to the courts deciding whether or not what she says is defamatory, or even correct.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) If a taxpayer takes the $200 annual deduction available in regard to employee share schemes pursuant to section 26AAC(4A) is the said taxpayer often disadvantaged because the amount is taken off the cost base for capital gains tax purposes.
(2) Will this anomaly be corrected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) An employee who acquires shares at a discount under an employee share acquisition scheme pursuant to section 26AAC(4A) may exclude from assessable income an amount equal to ten per cent of the value of the shares, up to a maximum of $200 per year, pursuant to section 26AAC(4F). For capital gains tax purposes, the cost base of the shares is deemed to equal the market value of the shares at the time of acquisition, less the amount of any discount excluded from assessable income under section 26AAC.

(2) In the 1993-94 Budget, the Government announced that it will examine the operation of section 26AAC. The interaction between section 26AAC and capital gains tax provisions is one matter that will be considered in this context.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has hydrological research carried out by Melbourne Water in Victoria, and similar research in New South Wales and Western Australia, demonstrated that timber harvesting in eucalypt forests can reduce water production from those forests by as much as 50 per cent.
(2) Has the Victorian Government commissioned studies into the economic impact of timber harvesting in the Thomson catchment.

(3) Has an assessment been made of the study undertaken for the Victorian Government by Read, Sturgess and Associates into the economics of wood and water production in the Thomson catchment; if so, what is it.

(4) Does an unpublished study by Peter Gell and Robert Wilby into the hydrological impact of logging on Victoria's Errinundra Plateau indicate that the normal flow of Delegate River could be reduced to a trickle by the end of the century.
(5) What is the economic significance of the Delegate River for rural communities in New South Wales and Victoria.
(6) What is the significance of the Delegate River in maintaining environmental flows of the Snowy River.
(7) What are the implications of the effect of timber harvesting in eucalypt forests for the management of water resources and the allocation of water rights.
(8) What is the likely quantity of water resources used in the management of eucalypt forests for timber production.
(9) Should State forest agencies and the timber industry pay for water used in the management of eucalypt forests for timber production.
(10) What effect is the hardwood forestry industry having on the profitability of rural and urban water agencies.
(11) What is the impact of hardwood forestry operations on rural and urban water prices.
(12) What is the likely impact on water resources of logging in old growth forests compared with logging in regrowth forests.

(13) Will the Minister undertake to write to State forestry ministers to seek a strengthened commitment to the provisions of the National Forest Policy Statement relating to the conservation of old growth forests and wilderness areas, and the need for wood pricing and allocation to reflect the total economic cost of water consumption; if not, why not.
(14) Is Commonwealth approval of export woodchip licences in breach of Section 100 of the Constitution as it relates to actions by the Commonwealth which impact on water production; if not, why not.
(15) Will research into the economic impact of hardwood timber production on water production be commissioned; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The following answer addresses the honourable senator's question to the extent that the information is available to my portfolio. However, some parts of question concern matters which relate to the day to day management of forestry operations and the allocation and pricing of water resources which are the responsibility of State Governments and agencies. If the honourable senator requires additional information on matters which are a State responsibility, I suggest that it would be appropriate for him to approach the relevant State Ministers or agencies.

(1) Hydrological research in Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia has shown that immediately following serious fire (such as the 1939 fires in Victoria) or intensive timber harvesting there is usually a significant increase in water production for a few years. After this initial increase, the resulting regeneration begins to require substantially more water than the original older forests, reducing the water production. Where this occurs there is a gradual reversion to the original patterns of water use as the forest ages. The extent of these changes varies greatly with forest type, soil type, topography and climate. It has been shown that stand thinning usually reduces the rate of water use by the regenerated forest, increasing its water production closer to the original levels. By way of example, the 1939 fires in Victoria caused the complete elimination of very large areas of old growth forest which were replaced with regrowth forests, some of which were of a single species, Mountain Ash. During the late 1960s and early 1970s Melbourne Water observed a substantial decline in water yield from catchments in regrowth Mountain Ash forests.
(2) Yes.

(3) I understand that McLennan Magasanik Associates has made an assessment of the study "Evaluation of the Economic Values of Wood and Water for the Thomson Catchment" which was undertaken by Read, Sturgess and Associates for the Victorian Government. The assessment criticised aspects of the study's methodology (that timber and water prices were not valued on a consistent basis, that consideration of the social and regional employment consequences arising from a shift in timber milling operations was omitted and that additional sensitivity analyses involving changing the values of the economic variables simultaneously may have been appropriate). The assessment concluded "that considerable doubt attaches to changing the present (forest management) system, and it is by no means certain that a new rotation strategy would be an advance. Indeed there is a strong implication that the community in general would be worse off." I understand that a second report is to be prepared which uses different economic assumptions.

(4) There have been no long term or detailed studies on the hydrological impact of logging on the Errinundra Plateau. The unpublished study by Gell and Wilby attempts to extrapolate water use patterns from other forest environments into the Errinundra region, which serves as part of the catchment of the Delegate River. This provides a model that has not been tested. As much of the Errinundra Plateau is reserved from timber harvesting under conservation reserves, it would not appear that harvesting could have such a dramatic impact on stream flow as the question implies.

(5) The Delegate River is of local significance in New South Wales for stock watering and recreational fishing, and in Victoria, through its input to the Snowy River, it contributes to the water source for an irrigation area of some 500 hectares in the Orbost region. The Delegate River is the principal source of municipal water for the town of Delegate and a partial source, through its input to the Snowy River, to the town of Orbost.
(6) During periods of high redirection inland of Snowy River water, the Delegate River may provide a significant proportion of the downstream flow of the Snowy River into Victoria.

(7) Timber harvesting can have an effect on water production from eucalypt forest by both increasing and decreasing the rate of stream flow. It is difficult to make generalisations about the implications of timber harvesting for the management of water resources because water production depends on local factors such as the climate, soil type, terrain and the nature of the vegetation (ie, rooting depth, species, age and leaf area). However, it is possible to apply catchment modelling techniques to predict the effect of forestry operations on water yield. Where reduction in flow rates could prejudice water rights, research has shown that management of the regenerated forest can minimise the impacts.

(8) Water resources used in the management of eucalypt forests are derived from rainfall. It is not possible to quantify the extent to which such water resources are used in the management of eucalypt forests for timber production due to the wide variation with forest type and environmental factors (such as climate, soil type, terrain and species) and the lack of research in many types of forest. As only 17% of the total area of Australia's native forests is available and suitable for timber production, the total impact is not likely to be great. Where there is significant local impact, management regimes can be modified to compensate.

(9) Under the National Forest Policy Statement, the States have adopted a number of principles as the basis for pricing and allocation arrangements for wood from public native forests including that prices will be market based, at least cover the full cost of efficient management attributable to wood production, include a fair return on capital, and provide an adequate return to the community from the use of a public resource. The Government supports the application of processes that allow transparency in the costs associated with the management of forests for timber production and for other community service obligations. The issue of payment by forest management agencies or industry for water allocation or management is one for State and Territory Governments to consider in the context of water pricing, allocation and management policies and strategies.
(10) This question should be addressed to the relevant State rural and urban water agencies.
(11) This question should be addressed to the relevant State rural and urban water agencies.

(12) Depending on the forest type, intensive harvesting of both old growth and regrowth could both lead to short-term increases and longer-term decreases in water production, with the regeneration of the forest. Old growth forests generally exhibit a patchwork of various ages. Conventional forestry operations, involving harvesting of coupes on a mosaic pattern, would result in the replacement of old growth forest with a patchwork of regrowth forest of varying ages. Therefore regrowth forest may not use any more water than the original old growth forest.

(13) States and Territories which have signed the National Forest Policy Statement have, by their signing, committed themselves to the provisions of the Policy. The Commonwealth will work closely with the States and Territories in implementing the provisions of the National Forest Policy Statement. A joint subcommittee has been established drawn from members of the Standing Committees of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council and the Australian Forestry Council which is responsible for regular monitoring

ANSWER.PARA: and reporting to Governments on progress of the National Forest Policy Statement initiatives. Given the cooperative approach to implementing the Statement there is no need to write to the States as suggested.

PARA.TAB: (14) I refer the honourable senator to Senate Standing Order 73(1)(j), which provides that questions shall not ask for legal opinion.

(15) One of the main areas of current research by the Cooperative Research Centre for Catchment Hydrology is the development and evaluation of predictive tools for water production in natural, disturbed and managed forests. The research is being carried out in collaboration with Melbourne Water, the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources and the CSIRO Division of Water Resources. Other relevant research could be sponsored by the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation and the proposed Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation but decisions on the timing and conduct of commissioned research would be matters for the individual organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)What is the extent of bilateral aid by Australia to the Republic of Kiribati in 1991, 1992, 1993?
(2)Does the aid include a survey of the sewage disposal problems in the atoll of Tarawa south?
(3)What options are being considered to deal with sewage which is causing massive health problems and polluting the lagoon?
(4)If a water borne system is being considered, how will the sewage be disposed of and in what way will it be treated prior to disposal?
(5)What is the likely capital and recurrent costs, including the provision of a sea water flushing supply, for such a system?
(6)What environmental studies will be done to assess the possible effects of a water borne system with discharge to the ocean?

(7)Given that much of the diet of the people of the island consists of fish and many fish inhabit the edge of the reef, what will the effect of a sewage discharge on the fish and subsequent health of the people?
(8)Have other systems of sewage disposal been examined, such as composting. If not, why not?
(9)Is the Government aware that several Australian designed and manufactured composting toilet systems have already been sold overseas?

(10)Have any of these been considered and cost comparisons been made, bearing in mind that any water borne system in the atolls will also require a sea water supply system with its heavy costs of maintenance?

(11)Does the Government see that the encouragement of composting toilets will help a new industry with export potential and which, in turn, is prepared to help with technology transfers to Pacific neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Islands Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The aid program follows a financial year funding arrangement. Expenditure on bilateral aid to Kiribati for the last three financial years has been:

ANSWER.PARA: (2)The performance of three ocean outfalls was investigated in 1985 by Consulting Environmental Engineers of the NSW Region of the Department of Housing and Construction, and in June 1993 the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) conducted a field appraisal of the South Tarawa Sanitation Project being developed by the Government of Kiribati (GOK). The appraisal concluded that it would not be possible to provide assistance until a comprehensive multidisciplinary approach to encompass all health issues is developed in Kiribati and all inputs are co-ordinated under this approach to achieve an effective and sustainable improvement in health conditions.

PARA.TAB: (3) Tests show that the sewage disposal from the present sewerage system is not the most likely cause of the health problems on South Tarawa The present salt water flushing system empties into the sea through discharge outfalls via pumped reticulated sewerage mains. The zone of influence of the discharge on the bacteriological quality of the water at the reef edge extends less than 100 metres. Faecal coliform levels beyond 100m from the outfalls very seldom exceed 200 org/100 ml, the accepted safe standard established by the United States Environmental Protection Agency for recreation and bathing waters.

The problems of health and pollution, however, are due more to population pressures and persistence with traditional methods of waste disposal, rather than to technical deficiencies in the sanitation systems.
Options for dealing with the remaining sewage problems on South Tarawa will only be considered as part of a program which addresses the overall critical health situation.

(4) Extension of the present water borne system is one measure under consideration and options for treatment will be considered within that context. Sewage in the present system is not treated before discharge at the ocean outfalls and this has not caused significant problems (see response 3).

(5) The costs of upgrading and extending the present system have not been estimated at this stage since such work is only one aspect of a possible GOK integrated development program addressing the total health spectrum on South Tarawa This program is at a very early stage of consideration and does not yet have the full approval and support of the GOK.

(6) The present system has been tested and found to be operating within acceptable coliform levels. The bulk of pollutants and other causes of the critical health situation are considered to arise from population pressures in non-sewered areas and not from the sewerage system as such. Should the GOK request the development of a program of Australian assistance to address the full range of health issues on South Tarawa, environmental studies will be conducted as mandatory aspects of AIDAB project development.
(7) See response 6. AIDAB is not aware of data that allows an assessment of how and to what extent fish at the reef edge are polluted.

(8) Yes, but only in the broader context of the AIDAB appraisal (June 1993) which examined the full spectrum of health issues on South Tarawa; including water supply and sewerage systems, waste disposal in non-sewered areas, solid waste disposal, health education and population aspects. Alternative sewerage systems were considered within this general approach.
(9) Yes.

(10) Not as yet, since the Government through AIDAB has not had a formal request from the GOK to undertake a program of activities which would address the full spectrum of health and population issues on South Tarawa

(11) Yes. Should GOK request assistance with the full spectrum of health issues, AIDAB will ensure that the sewerage system utilised will be the most appropriate, bearing in mind the cultural, physical, budgetary and political constraints to implementation. Composting toilets will be examined as part of such a comprehensive solution. Australian suppliers for AIDAB projects are invited through the normal free and open tendering process. When new equipment is provided it is normal practice to also provide technical assistance to facilitate operation and maintenance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a condition of the class 3 licence granted to the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (AOTC) under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 that the licensee shall decide requests for reconsideration within 25 days.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 1 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: For each officer of the department who, within the last 12 months, has been outposted to Parliament House or whose services have been available in any, and in what, capacity to assist one or more Labor Caucus committees, or members thereof, in the preparation of reports and other like material.
(1) What was the name of the officer.
(2) What was the salary classification of the officer.
(3) To which caucus committee was the officer principally attached or to which committee was assistance provided.
(4) For what period (including uncompleted periods) did the officer provide any, and what, assistance to the caucus committee or its members.
(5) At whose request did the department make the officer available to the caucus committee and who approved the outposting or the provision of assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: No officer of my Department has been outposted to Parliament House to provide services or have otherwise provided services in any capacity to assist one or more Labor Caucus committees or their members in the preparation of reports and other like material.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are Australian troops who are serving with the Papua New Guinea Defence Forces carrying out their duties in Australian military uniform.
(2) What guidelines have been issued to cover the use of military force by Australian troops during their visits to Bougainville.
(3) What capacity is there for the communications infrastructure on Bougainville which Australian troops are assisting in restoring, to be used for military purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Visits to Bougainville by ADF personnel on loan or exchange with the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) and Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) have been conducted in accordance with Guidelines for the use

ANSWER.PARA: of Australian Loan Personnel in Politically Sensitive Situations agreed by the Australian and PNG Governments. Approval for these visits has been sought on a case by case basis at Ministerial level, following consultation with DFAT, PM&C and AIDAB, and has only been granted for visits to specified sites, assessed as being in a low to moderate threat area, to perform identified support tasks in line with the loan officers' agreed duties.

PARA.TAB: ADF personnel visiting Bougainville operate under the protection of the PNGDF Security Forces and do not carry weapons. In the event of an incident occurring or the threat level escalating during the course of the visit, ADF personnel are briefed to extract themselves as quickly and safely as possible. These guidelines have been followed by all parties and there has been no direct ADF involvement in PNGDF operations on Bougainville as a result.

(3) ADF personnel on loan to the RPNGC have visited Bougainville to assess the remaining communications infrastructure and identify the equipment needed to restore police and civil communications throughout Bougainville and with Port Moresby. These visits have helped to maintain progress with the restoration of services on Bougainville.

The repair of Bougainville's communications infrastructure is an integral element of PNG Government efforts to restore services and civil authority to North Solomons Province. The police have primary responsibility for law and order, and the resumption of normal police services has made it a critical requirement to restore communications to allow the police to effectively carry out their duties.
